best_comment: This class is great as an introduction to contemporary Africa. I took it to learn more about the continent and it sure was one great class. The conversations were so engaging, and the class was relatively like a seminar class and I felt included in all the conversations. Some of the  discussions were really eye–opening and I just can't emphasize how much my perspectives of the African content have been shaped. For those wondering about the workload, don't even think about it. It's really manageable. Just make sure you do your readings ahead of time and prepare a few points for discussions in class. The rest is a smooth ride back home!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

course_title: Introduction to African Languages and Cultures 001
best_comment: This is a great class to take if you're interested in learning more about African language and culture. The class is a little longer than necessary and dull at times but it's not too difficult and you end up forming a great community.
subject: African & African Amer Studies
course_title_2023: Introduction to African Languages and Cultures

course_title: Introduction to African Popular Culture LEC
best_comment: This is a great course. African students are likely to enjoy it and have very interesting and engaging conversations in class. It’s very manageable through the semester but that final assignment will sneak up on you…25–30 pages is no joke!
subject: African & African Amer Studies

best_comment: It's very informative and engaging if you are interested in African history or Architecture in any way

Definitely take this class! Out of all the classes I've taken at Harvard, this one definitely ranks towards the top. The content is extremely interesting, and you leave the class with a newfound appreciation for coalition building. Additionally, this class does a great job of using the struggles of other racial minorities/marginalized individuals to highlight why coalitions have been so powerful in American history. If you're looking for a great history/African American Studies class that examines prominent issues that have impacted Black people, then this is the class for you. Professor Eatmon is a terrific professor who genuinely cares about her students, and she's well–versed in the content. Must take class.
worse_comment: I would not recommend anyone take this course, as the classroom environment is hostile. Specific students are targeted in the course and are harassed for how they speak and for the contributions they make. It’s also listed as a discussion course, but Professor Eatmon simply cancels discussion.  This makes it uncomfortable to speak.The course provides no flexibility and Professor Eatmon makes it difficult for you to ask for an extension for assignments. She also tediously marks for attendance, including lateness. This matters more for your participation grade than what you actually include in the course.  She would rather students not come at all than come late or need to leave intermediately for medical for medical or other reasons. The classroom is not an open space. Feedback was met with pushback. I think we all hoped for acceptance and a place where discussion was allowed to occur. This was not the environment for that. Further, there is no flexibility in terms of lateness and extensions. This creates a burden for students who experience health conditions and family issues throughout the semester. As the course stands, several students were denied needed extensions for coursework for sickness, death, and other issues in their lives and their families. Class time was also used to stream full documentaries in the course. Because the Professor would not sleep or would otherwise not want to lecture, we would sit through documentary films unrelated to course material. There is little discussion of Jim Crow within the course even though it is described as a course about Jim Crow. We spent more time on present–day issues than history and  barely discussed Black history after Reconstruction.I would prefer to see a consistent policy on slurs in the classroom. Professor Eatmon full on said slurs against multiple groups in the class that were not Black.  Black students couldn't say the n–word but she would say multiple slurs.Further, the documentaries and high–school–level videos we watched were not applicable.  Professor Eatmon expects us to put her course above everything else in our lives, including our well–being and other coursework. Thus, she assigns hard to understand assignments and expects us to spend all our time on them.  To take this course, you have to commit to always being right on the dot for class  and agree with her in every class.
subject: African & African Amer Studies

best_comment: Take this course! Not only is Jesse a fantastic teacher and brilliant thinker, you will get to read so many amazing poems, novels, essays, and stories.
Great way to fulfill your language requirement. Loved this class. Make sure to review the material often.
subject: Swahili

best_comment: I highly recommend this course! This year, it was taught by Grace A. and she's great. Learned so much about a fascinating language, 10/10
subject: West African Pidgin

best_comment: Take Yoruba. It's not as daunting as you may think, and the class goes so much deeper than language itself but into the culture. You will learn more about where you fit into Yorubaland as a Diasporan.
subject: Yoruba

best_comment: 98a is a wonderful opportunity to think critically about anthropological research and even come up with your own research proposal –– really invest a lot of care into this class because, if you do it right, you can emerge from the class with a very solid research proposal for your senior thesis (although you don't have to come up with a thesis topic; it can be any research proposal). ilkim is also a wonderful TF who is so supportive and helps to cultivate such a wonderful classroom environment.
worse_comment: Put a decent amount of thought into the topic you choose to research the beginning of the year because you end up stuck with it
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year 001
best_comment: This is required, of course, but it is genuinely helpful! It's great to hear feedback from your peers on your writing and you become pretty familiar with each others' projects. It is stressful to produce 8 pages in two weeks as the course makes you do sometimes for the biweekly meetings (and let's be real we cram it last minute) but it is so helpful for progress on the thesis. You'll live! Pretty fair thesis tutorial compared to other departments.
subject: Anthropology
course_title_2023: Thesis Tutorial in Anthropology - Senior Year

best_comment: This was my favorite class! The professor is so passionate and knowledgeable about the topic. If you are interested in the internet, humor and online hacktivist superheroes, take this course! I learned so much about the history of the internet in general, online activism, and hackers. Also, if you are interested in discussing very important topics like Wikileaks, whistleblowers, internet security/privacy, and political protest in the 21st century, this is an essential course to take. The class is not only engaging and fun, but also very inspiring!

course_title: The Pyramids of Giza: Technology, Archaeology, History 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class if you are looking for something new. I took this class to push my slightly out of my comfort zone and really enjoyed the material. Some topics in the course can get slightly repetitive so I would recommend reading up on the topics and deciding if you are interesting before you sign up for this class. Also, the work definitely begins to pick up towards the end of the semester, especially with the final project so take this class seriously and it will be incredibly rewarding.

course_title: Human Diet: from Neanderthals to the future of food 001
best_comment: Although the material is very interesting, there is a lot of reading. The pop quizzes are super annoying so if you're taking the class for a letter grade I would recommend a reading group. I would also recommend reading smart. The pop quizzes aren't hard. When it comes to articles read the introduction, read the conclusion, and skim smart (something I regret not doing). In terms of books, you could break up the reading. I think the readings are very interesting but very hard to do especially if you have other reading–heavy classes. I saw "GEM" in other course evaluations and I would have to disagree. Readings are super important later in the class when it becomes more discussion focused or else class is awkward. The sections were super fun and hands on. Overall, if you're taking it for fun like I was, I would recommend to take it pass fail (my biggest regret). Also the first midterm is very memorization focused. I would also recommend you answer the questions as you go or find a group to answer them as you go because if not the study guide becomes quite unmanageable. The final is a little easier if you've gone to most or all the lectures and have done most or at least half of the readings. Despite its difficulty for me, I'm glad I took this class. You learn sooo much. This class is also moderately DAO accommodation friendly. I would recommend communicating your needs throughout the semester (although communication can be hard).  Also remember to ask for extensions early if you need them. Also do the extra credit throughout the semester. Don't miss class because you can't make up the pop quizzes unless you have a good reason such as a doctor's note. Also keep in mind some weeks it's less work while other weeks when you have assignments such as a project, the midterm, the final paper, and the final it's a LOT more work.
best_gem_comment: Kind of a gem? The readings were awful and long but the class itself was really interesting, and you could probably get away with not doing too many readings if you're smart about it. Assignments were easier than I thought they would be but that might be because I actually studied for it. It definitely got me thinking.

best_comment: I took ANTHRO 1450 as my first anthropology class, and I would highly recommend it. You learn more than you could have imagined about water and water infrastructure in Boston's waterworld, and going on the 3 field trips (Hobbs Brook, Chestnut Hill Waterworks, and Fresh Pond) is refreshing, exciting, and valuable in terms of furthering your learning). The interviews with the authors of the reading are also a really cool experience.The course staff is also excellent: Professor Caton is an effective lecturer and has a wealth of knowledge about the topic area. Majid is awesome TF, super accessible and provides helpful feedback . The class is also great for its inter disciplinary nature and the diversity of academic backgrounds of the participants in it.

this class is so, so, so good and SO fun (especially in devising and carrying out your own ethnography). annikki and chiara are both incredibly supportive –– they are both blessings in the classroom and do so much to cultivate an enriching class community i was always excited to see on thursday afternoon. you get so much out of this class just by engaging thoughtfully with course materials and the project, and it will make you a much better researcher by the end of it!
worse_comment: This class is so so boring. The out of class assignments are engaging but the in–class time is extremely dull.
subject: Anthropology

course_title: Ethnic Studies, Anthropology, and the Transpacific Ethnography of Asian America 001
best_comment: This is potentially one of the best, if not the best, discussion–based seminars I've had (and I've taken ten at the College). The time flew by in each 2 hr 45 min session. Joy is an excellent facilitator and the students in this class seemed to have done the reading and came to each class engaged. Each class had a good combination of activities (warm–up questions, background information and summary of the main arguments of the texts so everyone is on the same page, solo reflection / partner discussion, structured group discussion based on student–written discussion posts, student presentations on related texts) so things never felt dull. The readings are manageable and interesting. The only assignments are weekly Canvas posts and short writing assignments that build towards your final paper / project (which she is very flexible on).  Overall, one of the best classes I've taken. Given the general dearth of ethnic studies courses here, I am very glad I got the chance to take this while Prof. Garza was still here.

course_title: Neoliberalism: Empire, Extraction, and the Making of the Global Social Order 001
best_comment: Take this class–– it was one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard. It's pretty much all readings and then a twenty page paper at the end, so the workload throughout the semester is flexible: you will get as much as you put in, and if you do the readings carefully this class will actually change the way you think about the world. If you are scared of the paper at the end don't worry. You can write it on so many different topics it will 100% be a meaningful experience to think through something you care about; 20 pages is not as long as it seems.
worse_comment: Neoliberalism is so taken–for–granted and pervasive as an ideology that it can be near–impossible for the average person be lucid and objective about this matter without taking a course like this. For me, ANTHRO 1716 was truly eye–opening and constituted a turning point in my own thinking about the world and social sciences. The only downside is that the revelations can be kind of depressing at some times.

course_title: Neoliberalism: Empire, Extraction, and the Making of the Global Social Order 001
best_comment: Take this class–– it was one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard. best_comment: This class was really thought–provoking and I'm glad I took it! It really opened my eyes to how pressing climate change is to matters of health, and forced me to contend with my responsibility to respond as an aspiring physician. It can be a lot of reading but Annikki only asks that you post a low–stakes 1 paragraph discussion post before class and after class each week, so you can definitely take it easy on the weeks that other classes are all–consuming. The final project experience was actually really cool – there was a great distribution of research papers and creative projects, and everyone did such amazing things ranging from quantitative modeling of eco–syndemics to writing and illustrating a children's book!

course_title: Introduction to Social Medicine Methods and Practice 001
best_comment: If you are looking to take a class to explore a new topic, this is the one for you. Social medicine is a fascinating field that has something for everybody. This class ensures that you will explore social medicine for all that it is. The readings aren't too much and the classes are super interesting. I definitely recommend taking this course.

course_title: Introduction to Social Medicine Methods and Practice 001
best_comment: If you are looking to take a class to explore a new topic, this is the one for you. Social medicine is a fascinating field that has something for everybody. This class ensures that you will explore social medicine for all that it is. The readings aren't too much and the classes are super interesting. I definitely recommend taking this course.

course_title: Introduction to Social Medicine Methods and Practice 001
best_comment: If you are looking to take a class to explore a new topic, this is the one for you. Social medicine is a fascinating field that has something for everybody. This class ensures that you will explore social medicine for all that it is. The readings aren't too much and the classes are super interesting. I definitely recommend taking this course.

This course – in its current form – tries to do too much, resulting in a somewhat scattered and unfocused result. There are a lot of readings assigned each week (too many to cover in class), discussions are not super effective (the class tries to be more student–led but ends up lacking direction), and a lot of small assignments throughout the course (care journals, audio explorations) that are supposed to help you with your engaged project but end up feeling more like busywork. Although I really enjoyed my engaged project, it is a fairly self–directed and rarely discussed in class. The course itself is not challenging, but be prepared to dedicate at least a few hours to a service project over the semester. The instructors are caring and well–meaning and open to feedback – there might be some changes by next year!

course_title: California: Histories of the Future at the Technological Frontier 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class if you are at all interested in the topic. Professor Jabloner is also a fantastic lecturer.  The reading list is so awesome and the assignments are very manageable— they really allow you to be creative about what you take away from the class and how you shape your learning. The best part is that it's designed to be very interdisciplinary, so the other students in the class come from so many different disciplines and have so many different takes on the material. Take this class if you want to think creatively with other students who are also enthusiastic about the material!
worse_comment: Take this class if you're looking for an interesting seminar on California. Just be aware that you will spend a lot of time discussing the faults of capitalism.

best_comment: Be prepared to spend a lot of time in the lab, studying for the first half of the semester or so and then coding bones for the final.

The class isn't necessarily difficult, but there are a lot of readings each week, so it will take up a lot of time if you take longer with readings. But you cover a lot of information, which is great.

This is an excellent course that I would recommend with enthusiasm to any student.  I learned so much from this course in the well–chosen readings, and appreciated being in class with a mix of undergraduate and graduate student. Anna is a great, kind, thoughtful, knowledgeable instructor who made the experience great and I feel like I learned so much from this course. For future students, I would remain open to the experience and allow for your thinking to be challenged.

Really developed my project (not only in terms of framing, but the content of the project itself), and got to do this in a supportive environment. I also learned a lot about how to have conversations about my own work and others' work, and how to do it in ways that are fruitful and supportive.
subject: Anthropology

best_comment: You need to have a decent foundation in Python before taking the class.  Knowing how to use your terminal, shell scripting, and Git is helpful for the first couple weeks but I didn't and I ended up totally fine; it will seem like a lot at first but don't get discouraged and after a couple weeks you'll catch on and have learned so much.  Hands down one of the classes with material most applicable to jobs in swe and data science.  Highly recommend you will learn a ton and Fabian is really smart and super active on Ed to answer questions
worse_comment: This is a far too practical class. Only take it if you really need to learn about Python and how to use Git quickly (for a summer job or such). I would only recommend this class to Graduate students, not because it is hard, but because it is not useful to undergrads. Spend your time learning theory: this class spends too long on specific syntax that will change year over year. The quizzes are torture, the participation grading is competitive (as is grading overall), and the content is all over the place.
subject: Applied Computation

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: This advice goes particularly to students who are not CS/AM/STEM and have not had previous experience with coding. I came into this class as an Economics concentrator, without ever having taken CS50 (admittedly because I was scared of computers), and only a brief encounter with using python and pandas for a network analysis. I had a lot of experience with economic research in R, and the PhD student I worked for recommended CS109 as one of the most useful classes he had done in his doctoral degree (also hadn't learnt python before). I came in scared that I wouldn't have the background to succeed, but sticking with this class was THE BEST DECISION I made. If you don't have much experience with coding, use HW0 as an opportunity to learn. It's very comprehensive, if you find a friend who can also help you understand the concepts and you use the Data Science Bedrock materials Pavlos provides, you'll learn Python really quickly. By the end of the class, I felt extremely proficient in my coding abilities, could complete all the homeworks quickly and without any problems, and honestly am super grateful that I had the opportunity to practice so much coding in college. The material I learnt was also extremely helpful for other classes, such as Ec 1126, and it helped me develop hard skills which I later plan to use for research/jobs.I left this class now in Am/Ec and considering a secondary in CS because there are simply too many other courses I want to take. This was a great introduction to data science and I highly recommend anyone who wants more experience with handling data to take this course. If you're not super comfortable with coding, just make sure you are willing to put in the hours (particularly in the beginning) and you'll do fine.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. This class takes lots of time, not because the material is difficult but because of busywork.  Professors aren't interested in teaching, class is 100+ students, Ed crashes all the time, online quizes don't work, assignment grading has no actual feedback... many problems with this course. It's much better to watch external online videos and learn by doing. The amount of work/learning ratio is really really low for this course.
subject: Applied Computation
course_title_2023: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

course_title_2023: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

course_title: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project 001
best_comment: Not a big fan of the available projects, but overall the class was great
worse_comment: You get what you put into this class; it depends on who you choose to work with for capstone which can either make it a very positive or negative experience
subject: Applied Computation
course_title_2023: Computational Science and Engineering Capstone Project

course_title: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: Don't take this course concurrently with Math 1b if you don't have to. This is an applied math course. There will be math. You will have to apply it. Applying math to a coding/engineering problem generally requires *understanding* the math you are applying. Unless you're a rock star at math up through multivariable calculus and linear algebra, some of the math will seem a little hand–wavy, but you can still get a lot out of the course if you work to understand what's going on. For this course, prior math knowledge >>> prior coding knowledge.It's a great alternative to CS–50 for all my engineering friends looking to fulfill that CS requirement who don't want to participate in the experience that is CS–50.The pace of the course does pick up quite a bit so don't be fooled by the first couple of weeks (especially if you know how to code already). That being said, if you work to follow along and actually understand the lecture, lab, and review section, you will be able to copy–paste–edit large chunks of code on the problem sets without too much trouble.WORK WITH OTHER PEOPLE: go to the help rooms (Logan is very helpful as are the CAs), talk to people at your table and exchange phone numbers, make group chats and meet–up times around the midterm and final projects so that you are not alone, etc.No midterm or final exam is a HUGE plus. It fits the learning style and material of the course, and it saves your life during midterm and final season (especially if you're in STEM and have lots of lovely 3–hr exams).The teaching in this course is medium to good. Logan's lecturing is quite good. The entire teaching team is friendly and approachable and they will make time to help you if you're confused.Go to the review section if you can. It's directly applicable to the problem sets.
worse_comment: Take this for your AM requirement if you don't have a particular interest in CS! I learned a lot of the basics of CS and got exposure to the different things I would learn if I pursued CS more seriously without feeling overwhelmed!
best_gem_comment: This was a good class to begin to learn how to code with python. It also was not a lot of work as problem sets can be done in a group and most of the stuff on them comes from the lectures. Definitely a pset gem.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2023: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers

course_title_2023: Computing with Python for Scientists and Engineers

best_comment: Do yourself a favor and TAKE THIS COURSE. Do not take math21b. This class is literally the most low–stress class I’ve ever taken at Harvard. Shlomo is a great professor. He explains everything clearly and goes through the material at a great pace. Has a great sense of humor too. We also only learn about interesting stuff without delving into too many math concepts that we won’t ever come across again. The psets are very reasonable both in length and in content. Each pset consists of 3 parts: hand calculation, conceptual questions and proofs, and computation (matlab) questions. The proof questions are not too hard and he gives you hints. The computation questions also come with clear instructions and it’s generally very satisfying to see the application of the concepts we learned in class. And did I mention this class is 80% PSETS 20% MIDTERMS (and both midterms are open notes)? It’s such a great class to learn interesting concepts without having to stress too much about grades/tests. As long as you understand the concepts, the midterms are very straightforward. He gives you hints for the harder questions, and you won’t need anything outside of what is taught in class (no need to read the textbook, but if you want to, that’s great). Just make sure you pay attention to when Sholmo goes over the pset questions in class because he doesn’t publish pset solutions and there are no practice exams. Overall, I really loved this class, loved the mix of concepts and application, loved the structure. If you have to fulfill a linear algebra requirement, this is the best class you could ever ask for.
worse_comment: First half of the semester much more difficult than the second half. Final exam surprisingly hard.
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Complex and Fourier Analysis with Applications to Art, Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: Overall a good class if you're interested in understanding complex analysis and its applications. The lectures weren't super enlightening, but the readings and section notes were great and helped me a lot with the homework. I really enjoyed the material, which was presented with a focus on applications. The class culture was frustrating; it felt like most people didn't really want to be there, and that was definitely reflected in section and OH. But it's a fairly chill class overall and a great way to learn about complex analysis, which is very cool.
worse_comment: Be prepared to spent a ton of hours outside of class simply trying to understand material taught in class. The textbook is ok but in class teaching is unsatisfactory, with almost no explanation given for things
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2023: Complex and Fourier Analysis with Applications to Art, Science and Engineering

best_comment: I would recommend taking this course! You assign yourself your own grade (though you must be very honest with it). With that being said, how much you get out of this course is a function of how much time you put in. Out of the AM distribution courses, this has been my favorite class. There are 2 quizzes and they are exactly like the class worksheets/psets. So as long as you review and fully understand the worksheets and psets, you will be TOTALLY OKAY (there’s also a cheat sheet). The psets aren’t the hardest, just go to OH and work with a partner and you will be fine, the skill checks are super easy and make sure you are keeping up with course material (you can retake the skills checks and Sarah gives you example questions – so you are guaranteed a 100%). The final project was honestly a grind, but that’s because it was hard to reproduce a paper – make sure you choose a good group and good paper/project (and START EARLY – you have an 8 page individual paper). Overall i’d definitely recommend taking this class :) it was great :)if you put in your 100% you will definitely get a good grade. but if you don’t, then that’s up to you
worse_comment: The psets are annoying but can help with understanding. The skill checks are pointless but you need 80% correct. The lack of published notes/handout answers is so ridiculous when it comes to studying for the two tests.
best_gem_comment: Excellent course! While it is self graded, don't expect it to be a gem or an easy A. The course structure means you have to actually understand the concepts and be able to solve problems in order to maintain your self grading privilege. However, this is done in a way that isn't super stressful and ensures you learn at the same time, which is a balance not many courses manage to get right!
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods 001
best_comment: This course does a great job building up optimization from first principles. I felt like, from beginning to end, each class made a reasonable jump that pushed the course content forward while also building on foundations from previous classes. Because of this, I felt like I really understood the content by the end! I also thought that the workload was very well distributed across the semester. Quizzes and pset due dates alternate weeks, so each week feels like it has about the same amount of work. In general the workload was on par with a good pset class–– enough to do sufficient practice with the material but certainly still manageable. It was really nice that quizzes were distributed throughout the semester as this made each one feel much more manageable and less stressful than a big midterm and final. If you're interested at all in the topic, I definitely recommend this class! I came away feeling like I could genuinely set up and solve real–word problems with optimization, which feels like a super useful and applicable skill.It is important to think about the format of the class, which is somewhat flipped classroom. We had readings that we were expected to do before each class along with a brief reading check. We would then do problems as a group in class. Personally, I found it most useful to skim the readings and do enough to answer the reading check, then go to class and work through the problems (which were useful in going through the content), and then return to the reading after to actually take comprehensive notes. Finally, I just wanted to say how lovely Margo is! You could tell that she genuinely cares about the students. Throughout the class, she made a few adjustments to the schedule to better tune it to the group and make sure our workload was at a good level, something that I always really appreciate about a professor. I definitely enjoyed taking this class.
worse_comment: Getting behind in this class is fatal. It is imperative that you do pre–class assignments on time, attend office hours if possible, and participate every day in class. The vast majority of learning is done on your own and comes from thoroughly reading the pre–class assignments. Quizzes are straightforward and easy if you have a solid understanding of the concepts. Problem sets are difficult, and the extreme optimization project is the most difficult/worst part of the course. Utilize class time to ask questions because the office hours are limited and you will likely not be able to get a tutor at the ARC.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods

best_comment: It's hard, but the psets are really cool. I definitely learned a lot, and the material was very enjoyable. Some of the concepts will take a lot of time and concentration to understand, but I think that's reasonable. You definitely need to know how to code pretty well to solve the psets. Also, symbolic programming will be your friend (and it's really nifty, too).
worse_comment: I think the materials are useful but you don't need to take this curse to learn it. Lecturing is very bad.
subject: Applied Mathematics

course_title: Advanced Scientific Computing: Stochastic Methods for Data Analysis, Inference and Optimization 001
best_comment: Great material, great preparation for anyone doing science.
worse_comment: Try to avoid this course. The content is invaluable, but you're likely better off learning on your own. Probably the most poorly taught course I've ever taken, which is  a shame because this course is critical for research like mine. It's really frustrating for students that really want to learn to be taught so remarkably poorly.
subject: Applied Mathematics
course_title_2023: Advanced Scientific Computing: Stochastic Methods for Data Analysis, Inference and Optimization

best_comment: The class is great, and it is a great introduction to theoretical computational neuroscience. The homework’s are very long and time–consuming, and they can be challenging for many people. Resources for help is very good though, and going to office hours and asking TA’s can save you time. This is definitely not a class you would take for fun, because it’ll take many hours off of your week.
worse_comment: The problem sets are fairly difficult, as anyone will tell you. However, they are also very well written, and beyond a few tricks that you should probably figure out in OH, many of the problems are very inspiring to go through yourself.

course_title: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Information Processing and Learning 001
best_comment: An excellent class, and Yue is an excellent lecturer and a very helpful person to talk to about research. I strongly encourage you to take it (even if you're an undergrad!).

course_title: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I 001
best_comment: I really really enjoyed this class. I needed to take physics as a pre med req. and had zero experience, not even in high school. It was not a class that you need prior experience in even though it gets very in depth. There are a lot of assignments every week which do take a pretty decent amount of time, but the solo attempts for all of these assignments are graded on effort, and accuracy only after discussing/reviewing/correcting with group mates and TFs. Putting in effort and making sure to do accurate corrections will pretty much guarantee both an A AND a good understanding of the material, which I tend to think is rare at this school. I cannot emphasize enough how crucial it is to read the entire syllabus, especially the part about how grading works and the letter grade breakdown based on the scores you get in the class (learn how the virtual tokens work, what to do if you don't get a 2/3, etc.) BEFORE the class starts because it moves fast and the grading is super different from any other class I've heard about. Overall definitely take this if you need to actually learn physics thoroughly but also don't want to tank your GPA.
worse_comment: READ THIS HONEST REVIEW: This class is terrible. You will not learn anything. You will be inundated with busy work every week and realize in the end that you learned not a thing the entire semester. Eric will brag about how his flipped classroom model is ingenious and amazing because there are no exams. But you will leave this course realizing you wasted your time. Yes, this is definitely an "easy A" physics premed course like you can get not study and just complete the assignments to get by. But he literally does not teach anything. And we all know you cannot truly learn by reading and annotating a textbook. All the accompanying assignments (tutorial, challenge, Readiness Assurance) are so tangentially related to what you "learn" from the textbook. This reveals a large knowledge gap and shows that we're not "learning" enough from the textbook to answer basic physics problems. Additionally, the grading system in this course is ridiculously confusing, unnecessary, and weird. Also the emphasis on group projects makes this class extra unbearable. You work in 3 groups (randomized) during the semester, and it can truly make or break your experience. If you don't work well with your group, you can find yourself dreading doing all the assignments, especially the project report. They'll trip you up and say it's easy to earn an A but they can literally drop your grade down to a B literally just for missing a single assignment so be careful. You will not learn *anything* in preparation of the MCAT if you take this course. And if you have no physics experience prior to this course, everything will just be extra confusing for you. I took this course over the PS2/3 series because I wanted a chill semester where I wouldn't be scrambling for my grade at the end of the semester. While I did accomplish this, I would be lying if I said this was an enjoyable, transformative, knowledge–building experience. I simply did not learn a thing and it was terrible 0/10 DO NOT RECOMMEND!
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Physics as a Foundation for Science and Engineering, Part I

best_comment: The lectures are pretty good in general. Prof. Mundy is an experimentalist so she might not be super familiar with some detail but she gave pretty good intuition. Overall, some of the students found the course pretty slow. Some interesting topics like phonons and superconductivity are not introduced in detail. But for most student, I believe the pace is alright. I would recommend it as an intro to the field of condensed matter physics.
worse_comment: Do the problem sets on your own. Then ask questions in OH when you get stuck.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: This class is great for improving your intuitive understanding of optics on all levels. It's a fair amount of work, but the knowledge and understanding you gain from it is worth it.
This class is great for improving your intuitive understanding of optics on all levels. It's a fair amount of work, but the knowledge and understanding you gain from it is worth it.

course_title: Chemistry in Materials Science and Engineering 001
best_comment: This course is intellectually rigorous, but designed intelligently with students in mind. The course load felt just right to me and I loved that nothing was obvious on homework and quizzes. I felt challenged to think and supported by the learning in class. I took away a lot of great information and intuition from the course. Dr. Aizenberg is a supportive mentor and excellent professor.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Chemistry in Materials Science and Engineering

best_comment: This is a great class! Maxim is a talented lecturer and thoughtful professor, and the material he put together is very interesting. I would recommend it to undergraduates as well as grad students. The required background is not extensive (basic undergrad Physics and Biology), but if you put in the work it will be a very rewarding class. The weekly journal clubs take some time, but are completion graded and will improve your presentation skills.
subject: Applied Physics

best_comment: I think the material in this course is useful and very interesting, and the professor really cares about his students. However, the workload is very high and sometimes I would argue unnecessarily high which takes away from the learning of the actual material. I am not sure I got as much out of it as I would have liked and I am not sure the amount of time I spent on it was worth it. However, because the material is interesting and I am not sure if it is taught in any other class I might still recommend it.

Take this class if you are intrigued by the subject. It does involve a lot of work but you also learn a lot. The concepts covered in the course are quite diverse and have wide applicability, so definitely worth taking it, even if you are not from an immediate physics background or pursuing a physics degree. Depending on person teaching this course, you might be recommended to register for only this course in a term, particularly if you are grad student involved in research as the work load can be quite intensive. However, definitely worth the effort.
worse_comment: Don't let the midterm grading discourage you. Vinny has high expectations. Choose your group members who have similar research interests
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Inference, Information Theory, Learning and Statistical Mechanics 001
best_comment: This class has an excellent promise of teaching about solving inverse problems with statistical tools. That is definitely a very deep and useful topic. But the materials could use some more polish. The initial 1/3 is excellent, the middle 1/3 starts to feel weak, and the final 1/3 covering unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning is not well–organized. As we paced through a range of interesting topics, we barely had the time to even properly scratch the surface. As a result, please think twice the reason that you want to take this course: if you want to learn some tools and interconnected concepts, great, this course could do it, but if you want to develop a rigorous and cohesive understanding of machine learning and its connection to information theory of physics, I'd probably suggest taking a difference course from CS, Stats, or even applied maths department.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Inference, Information Theory, Learning and Statistical Mechanics

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids 001
best_comment: Great class, and you don't need any knowledge of solid state beforehand. The problem sets being every 10–14 days was great, and Subir's lectures are nice and clear (although sometimes a bit slow). Workload was light compared to some other physics classes I've taken.
worse_comment: Establish a wide net of problem set partners. Didn’t realize everyone in the class was doing this until too late.
subject: Applied Physics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids

best_comment: Great class if you're interested at all in low–dimensional physics. Problem sets are biweekly which is super nice too!
subject: Applied Physics

course_title: Drawing 1: Drawing as a Visual Language 1
best_comment: A great course for anyone who has an affinity for drawing they want to expand upon. The class teaches you how to look at art and widens your artistic pallet, introduces you to new artists and ideas, and helps refine your technique and skill. The course begins with drawing exercises on perspective, shadow etc. including several figuring drawing sessions with models. The later part of the course focuses on creating pieces and ends with the final project, an opportunity to create and curate a body of work. I learned a lot from my classmates, who all had their unique styles and directions that they developed over the class. Katarina does a great job of helping you break out of your habits and expand your visual vocabulary with very personalized feedback. This class also has a great atmosphere and benefits from its small size. It can be a lot of work, but if you are into drawing and can fit this in your schedule it’s good homework to be doing since all the assignments involve actually drawing (rather than writing or whatnot). Also you get free materials. Take it!

cool class would recommend –– definitely recommend getting to casting as soon as possible and specifically learning how to do two part molds/molds that are reusable and materials that may be compatible with that.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This class was great if you want to learn to use the silkscreening medium to further your interests in other artistic/academic domains. I would encourage you from the very beginning of the semester to really start thinking about silkscreening as a medium, and not simply as just another form of printing the artwork you already make!
worse_comment: It is very challenging for art concentrators and non–concentrators and it is very time consuming. The TF and Professor are not on the same page. The TF is very nice but  the Professor can be very cold and rude when approaching students about their work during class.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This class is really amazing if you have sculpture or 3–dimensional art ideas that you want to make as you have the creative freedom to do whatever you want around interesting artistic peers. However, I would say that this class, at least when I took it, felt a bit awkward and unsocial. While the teachers were helpful with fulfilling the ideas of the students, there was often not a very encouraging and supportive vibe, as well as a feeling of disconnect between the teachers and students, which made the class not the most comfortable sometimes, however, it was still quite an amazing and unique class.

This is a good intro course if you’re interested in photo. It’s a lot of class time so I wouldn’t take this on a super heavy semester because the amount of class time actually really impacted my semester and how busy I felt (It was roughly double the amount of class time as my other courses).  Claude is an AWESOME tf and such a talented photographer to learn from — he’s very fun and takes time to help you one on one in lab. Patrice is overall a good prof who is understanding of how much you have on your plate and is super knowledgable about photo while making it accessible to students who know nothing coming in. At times she personally rubbed me the wrong way especially in critiques but overall I think she is a good prof for the course
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: I HIGHLY recommend taking this course if you have any interest. Regardless of what you typically study, it's worth the adventure! The class has a wonderful environment, incredibly fun assignments, and also teaches a ton about how to look at the world, and about the world of photography in general. The professor is amazing, as well as Navid / the course TFs! Everyone is so kind and willing to learn!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: If you're interested in making films in any capacity, this course is a great place to start. The teaching staff was extremely knowledgeable, helpful, and supportive and the assignments built off each other really nicely. It can be a huge time commitment, but also a really rewarding and unique opportunity to work with 16 mm film.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

course_title: Introduction to Documentary Production: The Camera Stylo 1
best_comment: This is a fun, more loosely structured class that allows you the opportunity to get hands–on experience with a camera.  Adoma, is an instructor who cares deeply about film and about helping develop and support her own student's work. Editing isn't a focal point of this particular, neither are things like lighting or sound mixing.  But as far as developing your own film over a semester, studying in a welcoming environment, and seeing interesting short films that inspire your own thinking, it's a great course.

This is a great class to take if you're interested in learning a lot about filmmaking in a relatively short amount of time. By the end of the semester, you'll have a finished product that you'll (hopefully) be proud of, along with a new way of thinking about visual storytelling. Be warned that it's not a studio class – we did all our filming on our own time and spent our class time on discussion/workshopping/watching films – but I believe they're planning on using more class time for filming next semester!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: This class is an amazing overview of modern art. Professor Joselit's lectures were consistently engaging. This course helped me think differently about pieces I thought I was already quite familiar with!! I was bringing things I learned from this class into conversation with peers outside of class very often. It's great to realize when a course is engaging and interesting in a manner that extends beyond the walls of the classroom. And Mahan was an amazing TF who effectively led discussions every week.

course_title: Studies of the Built North American Environment since 1580 001
best_comment: This is the class that I spent six semesters trying to find. It is quintessentially Harvard in a way that few classes still are, and the professor is genuinely invested in his students. If you have the chance to take a course with Professor Stilgoe, I urge you to take it! His lectures are like drives down winding roads, with someone bringing each thing you pass to life with curiosity and a great wealth of knowledge, all the while fitting seemingly unconnected things together. It has been one of the most intriguing classes I have had the opportunity to take, and I am confident that I will often be reminded of comments and lessons from the course as I go through life.
best_gem_comment: this course has helped me see the world in a new way and I am so grateful. YOU MUST TAKE THIS COURSE!!!! Cannot recommend more highly. Stilgoe is a gem that has such a passion for teaching and love for exploring the world.

best_comment: Very interesting and amazing class –– great opportunity to experience art in the Boston area and get to speak with curators!

course_title: Thinking With Your Hand: Intermediate Painting 001
best_comment: This is such a rewarding class! Judith is an incredible instructor who does a great job individualizing her feedback to each student and tending to each individual need. She is so knowledgeable and I felt that after each conversation with her I learned something new or a new way of thinking. The long class hours are daunting at first and can be tough, especially when you're stuck creatively, but it is a really valuable class time which leads to really dedicated time to painting and also a warm and enjoyable classroom community. Give the this class the time and focus it deserves and you will get so much out of it!
worse_comment: This class is not easy at all. It’s hard. The professor is a great person, but she is very tough in a way that made me feel like I was in high school again. She mainly would only give negative or vague feedback. Several people in this class, myself included, felt that this professor did not believe in them because she frequently made comments insisting some students were not putting in the effort that they were, which was oftentimes confusing and discouraging. I personally did not feel like she believed in me as a student. I also did not understand her expectations for student’s time commitments to the class. There is no doubt that this class requires close to 20 hours of your week, and that time commitment certainly helped me to grow as an artist, but this professor would frequently make remarks suggesting she did not see me working in the studio… outside of class time…  I was spending around 25 hours in the studio most weeks. Because her actual feedback on assignments was usually so vague and expectations were so unreasonably high, accompanied by her often rude tone, it is really hard for me to feel good about this class.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies
course_title_2023: Thinking With Your Hand: Intermediate Painting

best_comment: If you're thinking about taking this class, you 100% should! I had never had the opportunity to discuss photography in tandem with climate change, but now having had the opportunity to do so, I've come to realize how incredibly important it is to view seemingly objective photos (like those featured in National Geographic) with a critical lens. Dr. Best is a wonderful teacher, and regular trips to the art museum make the class super fun and engaging. The class expanded my understanding of photography and artistic techniques, and the final project provided a great opportunity to explore an issue I cared deeply about.

course_title: Photography and Evidence of Things Unseen (Studio Course) 001
best_comment: I don't know if this class will ever be offered again at Harvard–– I was among the lucky 7 who were able to take it. If, in some alien universe, this class is offered again at Harvard, I cannot even begin to describe how necessary it is for you to take it. You will be pushed in all the right directions, and grow as a photographer while having the most fun imaginable. Dawn and Claude are simply the best, and they create an environment that is both rigorous and demanding in the work you produce and extremely fun and light–hearted. God, this class is in the top–3 I've taken at Harvard, if not top–1.

This is a great course if you have at least some basic drawing and video editing skills. If you have a good idea for an animation, this course provides amazing tools and resources to help you create it. The class is small, and the professor is great!
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: My favorite class I've ever taken at Harvard!! Having a CS background was incredibly helpful with the technological part of this class cuz some coding was required to learn Unity. Felt like we had an incredible amount of freedom with the art we could make and loved how much class feedback we got. TF and Professor both incredible & super passionate about XR. 10/10 class wish I could take it every semester

If you would like to learn how to work with other people to create scenes for films (or even plays), this course is great. Through class, you'll be able to develop your own project / scene and in the  process learn a lot about coordinating with others and learn valuable lessons about writing, casting, rehearsing.If this course is taught again by Professor Sotomayor Castillo, even more of a reason to take this class. She is so insightful, kind, and made me consider the importance  of simplicity.

Definitely take this class. The readings are fascinating and there is so much support for students to pursue a range of projects. There is also a level of care and commitment to community building that creates a great experience for critique and discussion. Great feedback on work.

course_title: North American Seacoasts and Landscapes, Discovery to Present: Seminar 001
best_comment: Definitely take this class! If you have any investment in the seacoast at all, it is worth talking about it with Stilgoe. It will challenge you to look at the world in a new way, and you will read some great books. I took this class completely for fun, and I'm so glad I stuck with it. It's definitely one of the most valuable experiences I've had at Harvard.

course_title: David Lynch and the American Imaginary 001
best_comment: This course is so cool. Dennis and Julia are great instructors who challenged every student to think deeply and differently about the films we watched. I never knew where class discussions would lead (in the best way), and I left every class feeling 1. like I learned something and 2. so excited for class the following week. This course was rigorous, but when I put in the work and time to watch the assigned films (even the ones not screened for us), it was one of the most worthwhile courses I've ever taken. It's clear that Dennis and Julia put a lot of time and care into the syllabus. If you have the chance, TAKE THIS CLASS!

This class is wonderful if you are looking for a way to pursue your art practice on your own while still having a community to convene with every week and come back to to share your thoughts/ideas/challenges. I would recommend that you already come with a pretty definitive project or point of exploration in mind though, given that this class is relatively unstructured. Stephen Prina is a fabulous artist and teacher and provides really valuable ways of thinking about art and the artistic process.
subject: Art, Film, and Visual Studies

best_comment: A contemporary philosophy class par excellence!

Usually with a class this amazing I'd write TAKE THIS CLASS in all caps, maybe copy & paste it a few dozen times, but be warned! This class is not for the faint of heart! Like, sure, you could take it pass/fail or do all your psets in a group with the kids who DO do the work or google everything all the time or something, and it *would* work, like you'd get a grade and everything, maybe a good one, I don't know, but that's not how this class is meant to be experienced at ALL. You're supposed to have questions and you're supposed to want to answer them and try and figure them out yourself. And that takes time! You've gotta collect all that data, which takes immense time and patience because the sky moves simultaneously too quickly and too slowly, and then you have to actually figure out how you want to represent that data in a way that you can actually draw conclusions from it and then you have to go and DO that and then you have to figure out how to adjust your model of the sky accordingly. My favorite part of the class was measuring things and being surprised and learning things for myself through experimentation and you just can't cram that kind of thing. This is not some easy QRD–requirement–meeting–class (I've heard PSY 1900 is the class for that), this is an journey! It's a whole adventure! It's amazing! I don't want to say "don't take this class if you don't have the time and patience to take it right!" because it's an absolutely STELLAR class either way (see what i did there?), but if you're gonna take this class, whatever your reasons maybe, PLEASE don't treat it as that one class you don't have to put any effort into. This is the class that rewards extra effort the MOST! In a way, it's a class deeply antithetical to the mindset of most Harvard students. Is it a pre–req for something? Nope! Is it required for any concentrations? Not that I know of! Is it gonna look good on your resume? I don't have a clue! Is it a class you can coast through without putting in any work and still get an easy A? I don't actually know, because clearly, I was one of the students who went way overboard. Is it practical for your daily life? I mean, if your life is really really cool, then yeah, but statistically the answer is gonna be no. Are the discoveries you're making particularly groundbreaking? No, people in the middle ages had a firmer grasp on some of this stuff than you will and the field as a whole is considered by many to be obsolete. Is it the kind of class you take strictly because you're amazed and full of wonder and you just want to learn for learning's sake and pour countless hours into something you find fascinating, even though it's not going to advance your career or esteem or whatever else people are so caught up about? YES. And I think we need more of that, you know? Take a class because you think it's cool and for no other reason! Pour time into it just because you're curious to find out the answer for yourself, even though you could totally just figure it out immediately with a cursory google search. Experience wonder again. Take this class.
worse_comment: This course is absolute chaos! The professor is a character, the PSets are ridiculous and often include funny asides such as "When your engine starts missing..." and the knowledge is really only relevant if you're preparing for all the satellites to fall out of the sky, thus making GPS useless, or you plan on time traveling back in time. I loved this course, despite some of the careless and annoying errors in the assignments.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: This is an amazing class! Eisenstein is an awesome professor, and his lectures are super engaging and interesting. The psets are totally doable, especially if you start them early (I was able to complete them mostly on my own throughout the week before checking answers/finishing up during the Friday section) and the class has weekly quizzes instead of a midterm, which makes it a lot less stressful. There is definitely more emphasis on qualitative concepts in addition to knowing how to solve quantitative problems, so make sure you have a solid understanding of both going into the final and you'll be fine. This class was super fascinating and honestly one of my favorites classes here at Harvard –– I would recommend it over Astronomy 16 if you're interested in trying out an astronomy course!
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Eisenstein is a wonderful professor who explains concepts quite well. He is very open to answering questions throughout the class and is very humble. This is one of my favorite classes that I have ever taken at Harvard, and is a gem in my opinion– the course content is beyond fascinating. You learn about everything from black holes, quasars, dark matter, dark energy, the expansion of the Universe, before the Big Bang, etc. (again, pretty much everything) The course will be what you make out of it. I highly recommend reading the textbook chapters and modules every week and taking notes on them. Try your best not to fall behind, and definitely don't skip the readings/modules– they're the key to doing well on the final exam and actually understanding what is going on in the class.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Professor Johnson is my favorite astro professor at Harvard, and 110 is a great example of why. He really cares about learning, and that goal is really emphasized throughout the course. The in–class "quizzes" are meant to make sure that students are keeping pace with the rest of the class and I never felt overwhelmed by the course content. The class is also pretty dependent on the students, so it's best to come in with a good faith attitude to the course.
worse_comment: This is a chill way to become much more acclimated to the field of exoplanets! Classes are really interesting and collaborative, and the assignments were low stress. Highly recommend to anyone with a bit of a background in astrophysics who wants to get a cohesive but low stress foundation in this subject.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Going to just copy/paste what I said in the "strengths of this course question" but: One of the best physics/astro classes I've taken at Harvard. Professor Xingang explains concepts in intuitive and easy–to–understand ways, and his lectures & lecture notes are very easy to follow. He always explains where he gets mathematical processes & results, and is willing and able to re explain concepts in different ways if someone didn't understand something the first time. He & Misha (the TF) were both incredibly responsive and helpful throughout the semester. In addition, it's just a really cool class––the subject matter is super interesting and you get to learn about the formation of the universe down to within fractions of seconds from the Big Bang. We derived some large equations that were simply quoted in previous astro classes I've taken, and it was very cool to see where those concepts and equations came from. All in all an excellent class.
worse_comment: This was a fun, relatively low stress course. The homeworks were interesting but not overly time consuming. The final was take home and open book, which took off most of the pressure and allowed for the problems to be more in depth than a usual exam.
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: Take the class if you like stars and/or computer modeling!
subject: Astronomy

best_comment: This class is taught by many guest lecturers, each of whom present on a different topic. The course material is very interesting, but there is a huge volume of material, and the two exams are very comprehensive. Basic knowledge of physiology is helpful.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

best_comment: This class helps you get a better understanding of how writing and communication are utilized in the science fields. You will get practice of writing a full grant in class and get feedback on each component section. You will learn how to improve ones' presenting skills.
subject: Biological Sci in Public Hlth

best_comment: This class helps you get a better understanding of how writing and communication are utilized in the science fields. You will get practice of writing a full grant in class and get feedback on each component section. You will learn how to improve ones' presenting skills.

best_comment: This will be a great course for you if you're interested in Infectious Diseases
