best_comment: This course lacks organization and consistency. The problem sets are mostly very very time consuming and challenging because they are not doable with lecture material alone. You have to struggle through every office hours if you want any hope of understanding what's going on or how to approach the homework. Course materials (answer keys, practice exams, etc) are often incomplete. Sometimes, they are updated/corrected in the middle of the week (or the middle of the exam!) because of the lack of organization. Lectures are sometimes decent, but they often begin 10–15 minutes into the class period and end 10–15 minutes after. The exams are morale crushing. I understand the need for challenging problems, and I appreciate "learning the ability to fail." However, the whole class poured COUNTLESS hours into studying for the final, and all of us walked out laughing and/or crying because of how impossible it was.That being said, you probably know what you're getting into and you're probably taking this because you're a bioengineering concentrator and you can't get out of it. On the bright side, Prof. Smith is a good person, extraordinarily intelligent, down to earth, and receptive to questions. Also, the teaching staff was very supportive and helpful. Don't hesitate to ask questions and get to know Prof. Smith. Definitely attend office hours, and if you don't understand a concept, don't put off figuring it out.
worse_comment: This course is really disorganized. It can be really frustrating. Class starts late and ends late. A lot of course information provided is vague. Feedback takes a really long time. Communication is lacking within the course. Course material/information is hard to find and sometimes not very helpful/incorrect. Finding clarity is quite a difficult task (even course staff is confused about what is going on sometimes). If you do not need to take this course, I would recommend that you do not take it.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: This course is a very demanding course (not possible to overstate that part), BUT if you want to do cell culture or bioengineering or anything like that then this is definitely the course to take. You will get such significant experience working with cells, and likely learn more applicable skills than pretty much any other course at Harvard. Professor Parker also has some good life / career advice and he is a great resource.

I highly recommend this course! I took it as an extra elective as a BME concentrator, but I suggest it for anybody interested in neuroscience, research, or technology and its applications. The focus of the course is the technology and methodology that has progressed the field of neuroscience, but we often discussed the biological principles as well. A background in biology and circuitry is helpful , but more necessary for biology than circuitry in my experience. I did not have much electrical engineering background and was able to follow along and learn about what was relevant to understanding the lectures. I found Professor Liu to be very friendly and an engaging lecturer and the TFs are very helpful and timely with grading. The course staff is flexible and understanding and greatly takes into account the student's time and preferences. Classes were mainly structured a lecture/seminar style with a lot of Q&A and discussion. As an undergrad, it is helpful to have grad students in the course who contribute a lot to the discussion and ask great questions. Professor Liu was able to answer a lot of our questions and hypotheticals with a satisfying and in depth answer, even when the conclusion of the research was "we don't know yet". Assignments were not a stressor for me at all. The journal club one page responses and presentations were on very interesting and crucial publications and did not take more than a few hours at most to do. It was a low stakes way to continue developing comprehension and analysis skills of scientific literature. The midterm and final presentations were similar in purpose to the journal clubs, and Professor Liu only wanted us to engage with and understand the most important papers in the field and he made it clear that it was not supposed to be stressful, and it wasn't.  As with every group assignment, it is definitely easier when the whole group is committed and timely. Make sure to NOT GO OVER TIME during presentations, since that's effectively the only way to lose big points. The final paper assignment is not too bad, but if you have never written a grant proposal or literature review before, it would be helpful for you to brush up on it. The course does provide examples and criteria though.  IMPORTANT NOTE: I took this course after it was not offered for a while and more people  than expected enrolled, meaning the staff was not able to accomodate everyone in the lab which was added that semester. Normally both lab and journal club assignments are required but they gave our class the option to do one or the other which made the time commitment significantly lower for me than it might be in the future. With that said, the lab is a very interesting and exciting part of the course, and even though I chose the journal clubs because of other heavy classes, I do wish I had the time for the lab.  Also, it was nice that I was able to grab flyby lunch before/after class at the SEC, and I happened by a lot of free food and events after leaving class.
subject: Biomedical Engineering

best_comment: Read the textbook and make sure you understand every homework problem. Use office hours and ask questions. Do not miss labs!
worse_comment: Probably the most brutal class I have ever taken. Very difficult homework assignments and exams that require a lot of work beyond simply comprehending the lectures. I ultimately found it rewarding, as it does thoroughly cover many concepts in Probability that you need for other courses in Biostatistics, but if you choose to take it, be prepared to struggle!
subject: Biostatistics

best_comment: This course is the crown jewel of the Biostatistics department. A lot of work, but provides incredible coverage of many statistical methods including linear models, computational methods, heteroscedasticity, binomial proportions, and GLMs for binary and count data. It was more theoretical than I anticipated, which was a happy surprise. The homework is highly relevant to both statistical research and practice. And to top it all off, Rachel is one of the kindest and most friendly professors I have met – I could not say enough good things about her!
subject: Biostatistics

course_title: Analysis of Multivariate and Longitudinal Data 001
worse_comment: This isn't a super applied class – we focus more on the theory behind the models than how to actually apply it to data
subject: Biostatistics
course_title_2023: Analysis of Multivariate and Longitudinal Data

best_comment: This was easily my favorite course this semester. I learned so much and left the course with an even greater interest in the topic. One of the best taught courses I've taken at Harvard. Professor Sumner is an absolutely brilliant academic and teacher, and she cared deeply about her students.
worse_comment: Take this course you won’t regret it.

course_title: Shapeshifting and Identity in Celtic Traditions 001
best_comment: This class is awesome! You learn a great deal about Celtic stories while the assignments are very reasonable. The readings are really fun and usually not too long, so I highly recommend setting aside time to do them. The discussions are high–level and you get to formulate cool ideas about fascinating stories. I'd highly recommend if you're looking for a fun elective!
worse_comment: If you want a warm class that you look forward to every year and don't necessarily have to stress, this is the class for you.

best_comment: I would strongly recommend this course to anyone interested in learning Irish (obviously). It is taught at a very manageable pace and the small class environment is very enjoyable and a great opportunity for getting to know the instructor and the other students.
subject: Irish

best_comment: Thesising is cool! You should do it.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: Thesising is cool! You should do it.
subject: Chemical and Physical Biology

best_comment: This class is definitely hard, but it's not as impossible as people make it out to be. In my opinion, the two keys to being somewhat successful in the class are paying attention in section and doing every last practice problem you can get your hands on. Section was soooo helpful for me because my TF had a great grasp of the material and really wanted to help us nail down the concepts. The practice problems they give you in section are so so necessary for doing well on exams, etc. Do them over and over and over again, and then go online and find more practice problems to drill. Honestly, like 65% of the exams is just being able to recognize mechanisms you've studied and apply what you've memorized from drilling problems over and over again. Smaller things to make sure you're attentive of: 1) doing all the psets (they're mostly graded on completion so it's nice to have that free 100 from your pset grade) and 2) paying attention in lecture and writing down most (if not all) of the notes; it sucks, but it really makes a difference in understanding the material, and unlike in most other classes, you'll end up reviewing your notes a lot, so it's definitely super helpful to have clear references to go back to. The exams are...fine; they're fair. Definitely study hard and early for the first exam because in hindsight, that was the easiest of the three and I could've done better if I'd prepared earlier. Definitely study early for every exam, though, but honestly, studying for exams is easier if you've been drilling practice problems every day. Practicing every day is honestly the most important key to this class.
worse_comment: This class was discouragingly difficult and fast, and in my opinion lived up to its reputation of being a "weed–out" class. I did love the teaching staff and how supportive they were, but I don't think I would recommend it unless you are required to take it or are really interested in chemistry. It's really stressful and if you don't have the time to put into practice problems and review on a daily basis, you will likely not do well unless you already come with a strong background in chemistry.  I had a very weak background and fell behind from the very beginning, which is probably why I had such a poor experience. The actual homework load is fine, but it is not nearly enough to prepare you for exams and you have to treat the practice problems as if they're required work too.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Take this class!! Chem major or not (if you need to take orgo for pre–med for example), take this class!! Professor Myers is a wonderful lecturer and the teaching staff is great. This course is definitely difficult and will require a lot of your time. There's no getting around that. There's a lot of material covered and Professor Myers often goes through lectures at a very fast pace (to the point where if someone asks a question, he either advises them to speak with him after class or answers the question but we stay 2–3 min late after class because there is just no time). The teaching style worked very well for me, it was a traditional "professor lectures at the board for 75 min and you take notes" which I'm used to and sections were great for catching anything I didn't quite get in class. Though Professor Myers may seem intimidating, he really isn't and genuinely wants to get to know students and just teach fun things in organic chemistry. Problem sets were certainly difficult and you can't do them without going to office hours. But it's usually manageable to complete the whole pset after 1  two–hour office hour session if you start the pset beforehand and only come to office hours with questions. I can't speak to how helpful the PSLs are since I didn't go to their office hours after unhelpful experiences in chem 20, but TF office hours were extremely helpful. The teaching staff in general is very supportive and receptive to questions. Exams were sometimes fair, sometimes pretty difficult. You definitely need to study hard for them and you should probably make peace with simply letting the rest of your life take a backseat the 5–7 days before exams. There is however an alternative grading scheme which drops your lowest exam and replaces it with your final exam score which can help if you had a rough time with one of the exams (this was Exam 3 for most people this semester).  Lecture Integration problems were great for reviewing material that was covered recently and keeping it fresh, and they're basically free points (add up to an extra pset grade and they're grade based on completion) so do them!! Also PLEASE go to review sessions! They are "optional" in the syllabus (attendance isn't checked) but they are so great for reviewing the material and working on problems to really cement your understanding of the material. Professor Myers takes time out of his schedule to host the review sessions and works through the problems with students at the board which is incredibly helpful ( a little embarrassing sometimes if you are standing at the board for 20 minutes as your synthesis is being reworked, but SO helpful!!). Exam questions are also sometimes pulled STRAIGHT from the review session packets so at the very least go to them to be prepared for potential exam questions. The final was very fair (this year and in years prior since previous finals are given to us as practice finals) and I feel like represented the course material and the class itself quite well. You have to study a lot and put the work in, but it is certainly possible to get very high grades on exams and psets and be very successful in the class. Lab was alright, 4 hours is tough but the TFs tried to make labs fun and also get us out early which was very very appreciated and made the experience much better than it could have been. This class made me excited to potentially take advanced orgo in the future and I am certain that I had a better experience in chem20/30 than I would have in 17/27.
worse_comment: It's a hard class. Even if you are a genius used to taking 6 hard classes each semester, don't do that with Chem 30.  I watched multiple peers try that and fail. Assuming you are required to take this class, here's what I wish I did on a weekly basis:1) Have a complete reaction sheet from Chem 20 at the beginning of the semester for quick reference.2) The evening after each lecture, write all of the new reactions from that day into a running reaction sheet.3) The day after each lecture, do the lecture integration problem. 4) Start psets at least 2 days before they are due.For exams, here is what I wish I did to study:1) Rewrite all mechanisms for reactions within the unit2) Write a "how to make" sheet for each functional group (e.g. How to make esters: include all reactions that have an ester product)3) Do a practice exam4) Redo all lecture integration problems and pset problems5) Do the synthesis sheet they give out for exams6) Do 2nd practice exam.I promise if you actually do this, or a similar routine, you'll be ok. Just look at something for the class every day, and give yourself at least a week to study for exams.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: I have to be honest — I wasn't quite looking forward to a 10 hr / week lab course, but it was necessary to fulfill my chemistry concentration requirement. I took it dreading the amount of work it would be. I have come out on the other side extremely proud and appreciative of all of the work I've put into this course, and I am still continuing the research I started even after the class has completed. By the end of the semester, I was so excited to go into class each week and see everyone / work on my project. Also, the DC advocacy trip was a highlight of my college experience. Professor Vollmer–Snarr and the rest of the teaching staff were all so knowledgeable and kind, which made the whole experience so much better. It definitely is a lot of work, both in and out of class, but if you pick a project that you are interested and invested in, you will genuinely have a good (and very memorable!) experience.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: I have to be honest — I wasn't quite looking forward to a 10 hr / week lab course, but it was necessary to fulfill my chemistry concentration requirement. subject: Chemistry

best_comment: If you thought chem 20/30 were fun, you will love this class. It has a much lower emphasis on memorizing synthesis pathways, and is based more in investigating the theory behind all sorts of things. This class will go into the weeds of gray areas that were glossed over in lower organic courses. It surveys a lot of topics and contains tons of information, but I think the core information that you need to understand for psets/tests is a reasonable amount. I recommend trying to keep up with lectures and teach yourself course content as you go, because it's a lot to catch up if you fall behind. The course materials were high quality and the exams were fair, and the course was never unfairly burdensome. Overall a great class with a kind course staff that I'll look back on fondly!
worse_comment: I learned a lot about "why" chemistry happens the way it does and how to think about reactions/mechanisms. That being said, there was a misalignment between what is taught in lecture and what is emphasized on exams. Exams focused heavily on mechanistic analysis, but because of the lack of office hours, practice problems, and sections dedicated to lecture material, we didn't get nearly enough practice with the kind of analysis required on exams. This ultimately left me dissatisfied and frustrated with the course.
subject: Chemistry

course_title: The Chemistry and Biology of Therapeutics 01
best_comment: This is a pretty low–stress, interesting and useful course to learn about why certain drugs work in the body, and how to make ones that work more effectively and efficiently. However, there are only two psets, and your entire performance in the course is pretty much contingent on your understanding of how to use the MOE (molecular operating environment). Hence, I cannot stress enough how important it is to pay attention in the early lectures at the beginning of the course when MOE is explained haha. Overall, though, this is a great course to take, and you'll get the opportunity to collaborate with others through the section component and the final grant proposal, which is also a group project. I would highly recommend taking it if you're looking for an interesting and useful (but not too stressful) chemistry or general science class, especially if you have previous biology and organic chemistry coursework under your belt.
worse_comment: Chem 110 is a class where you learn how to use MOE and some principles of medicinal chemistry at a very basic level. The problem sets are long but not too arduous, thankfully there are only two of them and the deadline is reasonable given the length.
best_gem_comment: Class is a gem for the credits it gives. You'll learn how to use MOE, which is not too hard. But MOE itself is a somewhat unreliable/inconsistent software for molecular docking, which leaves you wondering how applicable the skills you learn in the class actually are.
subject: Chemistry
course_title_2023: The Chemistry and Biology of Therapeutics

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Low stress, high reward. You learn so much and though the 5 hour classes seem daunting, it flies by so quickly.My favorite chem class at Harvard. Amazing vibes and Dilek is just so very kind, funny, and overall great. The paper as a culmination of your work is really cool too.My only advice is to do your post labs right after class to make your life easier.
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class, you will not regret it. Dilek is a gem of the Chem department and although the time commitment may feel overwhelming, this class will be your favorite 10 hours of the week.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: This is probably the best Chem class I have ever taken. Part of that could be because I always liked inorganic better than organic, but I truly had a wonderful time learning about metal complexes and small molecule activation. The psets are concise and make you understand what you should know without being excessive. Some psets require the reading or skimming of 15 papers, but at the end of the semester, my ability to read and understand Chem papers drastically increased from not having read a single Chem paper before this class to reading around 30 for my final project, and it not taking too long. Also, you will get the chance to see that molecules can be engineered beyond just their sterics, and the actual electronic structure can be tuned to give the desired reactivity. The exams are stressful, but understanding mistakes on psets will greatly help with preparation. Ted gives very good lectures, and gave me a new perspective on Chem and research as a whole.

Not many options for quantum out there but this class was really good. Suyang is amazing and the rest of the teaching staff were also so supportive. The concepts involve a lot of math so be prepared for that but there are so many office hours so help is easy to find. You definitely do not need math 21b to take this, it would be helpful but to worth taking 21b just for this class at all. Physical chem is a scary topic but this class made it super approachable. Grading is also not that bad.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: Not many options for quantum out there but this class was really good. Suyang is amazing and the rest of the teaching staff were also so supportive. The concepts involve a lot of math so be prepared for that but there are so many office hours so help is easy to find. You definitely do not need math 21b to take this, it would be helpful but to worth taking 21b just for this class at all. Physical chem is a scary topic but this class made it super approachable. Grading is also not that bad.
subject: Chemistry

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class to anyone who is interested in the intersection of biology and physics. From this course, you'll be able to learn how life's many processes are in fact based on simple physical principles. Also, from the assignments (which are both theory/programming projects where you apply what you've learned in class), you'll also be able to learn how these theories can be applied in a practical setting. Since this course covers diverse topics in physics that are relevant in biology, I think this is a unique course that will give you exposure to diverse areas of physics in just one class. Finally, Adam is an excellent lecturer who is able to guide us through these diverse topics, I would definitely recommend.

TAKE THIS COURSE! So amazing, I learned so much without having to cram the information due to the take home exams and 2 psets throughout the semester. I feel like I have come out of this class a better researcher and a better student, and the course staff was also so nice. The papers are also super interesting and you get to learn a lot about new pioneering chemistry in the field.
worse_comment: This class is a bit more technically difficult than I expected, and I spent more time on the assignments than I expected. The course staff is pretty chill, although some of them can be intimidating, but go to office hours and make friends in the class. Expect to be intimidated but to learn a lot!!!!

best_comment: It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.

It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.
That it is a great way to formalize the characteristics of an effective teacher.

subject: Chemistry

best_comment: PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE do not be afraid to approach Dr. Tucci and Dr. Matchacheep – they are the loveliest people you will ever meet! LPSA is a phenomenal introductory course to chemistry and biology, which everyone should take regardless of their background in these subjects. Coming into this class with only knowledge from AP Biology, I initially felt overwhelmed with the amount of chemistry I was learning, but with time I became accustomed to the workload and looked at science in a way I never did before. It is important to note that this course is not heavy on memorization (even though it may seem like it at times) instead, it teaches you how to apply the knowledge from class to word problems and questions you might encounter in a scientific setting. The layout of the course consists of three lectures (MWF 9:00 am–10:15 am), a section (1 hour and 15 min long), and a lab component (3 hours max although most labs only take 1 hour). There is one PSET due each week on Monday at 9:00 am, a pre–lab quiz due on Monday at 9:00 am, and a lab report due on Friday at 9:00 am. This all may seem daunting but to be honest, the workload is VERY manageable. There are three exams and a final exam and I can't stress this enough but DO ALL THE PRACTICE EXAMS. The tests are very fair and if you do the practice exams you will know what to expect since they are of the same format. They host review sessions every week before the exam and have a multitude of help rooms you should attend. The course for the most part is chemistry (2/3 of the course) and then switches to biology (1/3 of the course) at the end. Both Dr. Tucci and Dr. Matchacheep interchange, so one will teach a few lessons, and then the other will take over for some time. Dr. Tucci: –He is an enthusiastic man that makes this 9 a.m worth waking up for because he brings so much energy into the room. –He always encourages you to shout out your questions and will take time to answer them! – He tries his best to get to know you personally and will always greet you in the morning. –He holds one on one meetings that you can sign up for if you have any questions that aren't answered in class or after class. These are short thirty–minute sessions but he tries his best to get through everything that confuses you. Dr. Matchacheep: –Many people often approach Dr. Tucci for questions, but Dr. Matchacheep is always there to answer questions as well. Both are chemists and are knowledgeable in their own domains (fun fact she also teaches organic chemistry in the summer, so if you have questions regarding chemical interactions this is your woman!) –She will walk you through all questions you have and will always make it very interactive. She works each question step by step with you. –She is also willing to meet with you in person to explain concepts you might have not grasped (I spent an entire hour with her reviewing problems until I finally got them) –She walks around the lecture during learning catalytic questions, so even if you are sitting in the back you are able to ask any question you have.–She is very kind–hearted and will always respond to your emails with kindness, so please approach her! Both professors are great people and want you to succeed (I've spent numerous hours in their help rooms asking questions I had before exams). Don't shy away and always reach out for help! This is a very manageable course and it will pay off in the end.
worse_comment: This class is not impossible, but it's not an easy A. The tests are difficult, but if you study (and I mean seriously study) you will be fine. Do the practice tests, and make sure your psets are correct. The labs aren't difficult, and often aren't the full  period of time. Go to the lectures and pay attention because it's hard to catch up if you fall behind. The first half of the course is chemistry and the second half is biology.
best_gem_comment: TAKE LPSA!! I loved my experience in this class and I learned SO much from Gregg and Sirinya. Definitely take over LS1a – so many first–years told me they hated LS1a. LPSA is so much better taught, Gregg is an absolute gem, and the class is so much nicer on your grades. They want you to succeed and offer so many opportunities for extra help (e.g. converting lowest prelab score to full credit if you fill out a learning survey). There were ample practice materials for the exams, the exams weren't meant to trick you in any way, and everything was very reasonable. Though this class can be a lot (you're essentially meeting 5 times a week for most weeks: 9 am lecture 3x a week, lab, section), I would definitely recommend you take LPSA.

Dr. Matchacheep: –Many people often approach Dr. Tucci for questions, but Dr. Matchacheep is always there to answer questions as well. Both are chemists and are knowledgeable in their own domains (fun fact she also teaches organic chemistry in the summer, so if you have questions regarding chemical interactions this is your woman!) –She will walk you through all questions you have and will always make it very interactive. She works each question step by step with you. –She is also willing to meet with you in person to explain concepts you might have not grasped (I spent an entire hour with her reviewing problems until I finally got them) –She walks around the lecture during learning catalytic questions, so even if you are sitting in the back you are able to ask any question you have.–She is very kind–hearted and will always respond to your emails with kindness, so please approach her! Both professors are great people and want you to succeed (I've spent numerous hours in their help rooms asking questions I had before exams). Don't shy away and always reach out for help! This is a very manageable course and it will pay off in the end.
worse_comment: This class is not impossible, but it's not an easy A. The tests are difficult, but if you study (and I mean seriously study) you will be fine. Do the practice tests, and make sure your psets are correct. The labs aren't difficult, and often aren't the full  period of time. Go to the lectures and pay attention because it's hard to catch up if you fall behind. The first half of the course is chemistry and the second half is biology.
best_gem_comment: TAKE LPSA!! I loved my experience in this class and I learned SO much from Gregg and Sirinya. Definitely take over LS1a – so many first–years told me they hated LS1a. LPSA is so much better taught, Gregg is an absolute gem, and the class is so much nicer on your grades. They want you to succeed and offer so many opportunities for extra help (e.g. converting lowest prelab score to full credit if you fill out a learning survey). There were ample practice materials for the exams, the exams weren't meant to trick you in any way, and everything was very reasonable. Though this class can be a lot (you're essentially meeting 5 times a week for most weeks: 9 am lecture 3x a week, lab, section), I would definitely recommend you take LPSA.

best_comment: PLEASE, PLEASE, PLEASE do not be afraid to approach Dr. Tucci and Dr. Matchacheep – they are the loveliest people you will ever meet! LPSA is a phenomenal introductory course to chemistry and biology, which everyone should take regardless of their background in these subjects. Coming into this class with only knowledge from AP Biology, I initially felt overwhelmed with the amount of chemistry I was learning, but with time I became accustomed to the workload and looked at science in a way I never did before. It is important to note that this course is not heavy on memorization (even though it may seem like it at times) instead, it teaches you how to apply the knowledge from class to word problems and questions you might encounter in a scientific setting. The layout of the course consists of three lectures (MWF 9:00 am–10:15 am), a section (1 hour and 15 min long), and a lab component (3 hours max although most labs only take 1 hour). There is one PSET due each week on Monday at 9:00 am, a pre–lab quiz due on Monday at 9:00 am, and a lab report due on Friday at 9:00 am. This all may seem daunting but to be honest, the workload is VERY manageable. There are three exams and a final exam and I can't stress this enough but DO ALL THE PRACTICE EXAMS. The tests are very fair and if you do the practice exams you will know what to expect since they are of the same format. They host review sessions every week before the exam and have a multitude of help rooms you should attend. The course for the most part is chemistry (2/3 of the course) and then switches to biology (1/3 of the course) at the end. Both Dr. Tucci and Dr. Matchacheep interchange, so one will teach a few lessons, and then the other will take over for some time. Dr. Tucci: –He is an enthusiastic man that makes this 9 a.m worth waking up for because he brings so much energy into the room. –He always encourages you to shout out your questions and will take time to answer them! – He tries his best to get to know you personally and will always greet you in the morning. –He holds one on one meetings that you can sign up for if you have any questions that aren't answered in class or after class. These are short thirty–minute sessions but he tries his best to get through everything that confuses you. Dr. Matchacheep: –Many people often approach Dr. Tucci for questions, but Dr. Matchacheep is always there to answer questions as well. Both are chemists and are knowledgeable in their own domains (fun fact she also teaches organic chemistry in the summer, so if you have questions regarding chemical interactions this is your woman!) –She will walk you through all questions you have and will always make it very interactive. She works each question step by step with you. –She is also willing to meet with you in person to explain concepts you might have not grasped (I spent an entire hour with her reviewing problems until I finally got them) –She walks around the lecture during learning catalytic questions, so even if you are sitting in the back you are able to ask any question you have.–She is very kind–hearted and will always respond to your emails with kindness, so please approach her! Both professors are great people and want you to succeed (I've spent numerous hours in their help rooms asking questions I had before exams). Don't shy away and always reach out for help! This is a very manageable course and it will pay off in the end.
worse_comment: This class is not impossible, but it's not an easy A. The tests are difficult, but if you study (and I mean seriously study) you will be fine. Do the practice tests, and make sure your psets are correct. The labs aren't difficult, and often aren't the full  period of time. Go to the lectures and pay attention because it's hard to catch up if you fall behind. The first half of the course is chemistry and the second half is biology.
best_gem_comment: TAKE LPSA!! I loved my experience in this class and I learned SO much from Gregg and Sirinya. Definitely take over LS1a – so many first–years told me they hated LS1a. LPSA is so much better taught, Gregg is an absolute gem, and the class is so much nicer on your grades. They want you to succeed and offer so many opportunities for extra help (e.g. converting lowest prelab score to full credit if you fill out a learning survey). There were ample practice materials for the exams, the exams weren't meant to trick you in any way, and everything was very reasonable. Though this class can be a lot (you're essentially meeting 5 times a week for most weeks: 9 am lecture 3x a week, lab, section), I would definitely recommend you take LPSA.

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! Do the readings and engage during lecture – you'll get so much out of this class. Professor Stähli makes the content very accessible to all levels of familiarity.
subject: Classical Archaeology

course_title: Introduction to the Ancient Greek World 001
best_comment: This class is comprehensive and requires a good amount of work and attention, but it's worth taking if you're interested in Greek history and want an introduction to classics that doesn't involve knowledge of Latin or Greek. Still, it was a fair amount of work with a midterm exam and midterm paper as well as a long final research paper and final exam, so know what you're getting into before you decide to take the course. For classics concentrators who are required to take this course, enjoy it! Lectures can drag at times but there are some really great moments you're learning about.
worse_comment: I mean it's a requirement for secondaries and concentrators. My guess is that the class varies a lot year by year depending on the teaching team, so hard to give recommendations as a whole.
subject: Classical Studies
course_title_2023: Introduction to the Ancient Greek World

best_comment: Love love and love Rachel! It's a very friendly class, and it covers interesting material without requiring too much time. Only at Harvard could you learn about ancient emotion profiles in a fun way.

This is a great course to learn ancient Greek if you have any desire to do so! Even if you don't the language will force you to think in ways you may not have thought before; there is definitely a beautiful rigor to the language.
worse_comment: Understand the different tenses of speech.
subject: Greek

best_comment: Very chill class but very helpful in improving your reading ability for ancient greek.
subject: Greek

best_comment: This course can be quite hard, but adding vocab to the Anki app and reviewing daily can help make assigned readings less strenuous over time. It feels good to have read so much at the end of the course and you get an appreciation for the different dialects, genres, and styles. You might find an unexpected new favorite author, like Simonides!

Take this class! Or any other class with Professor Elmer, for that matter. Readings are pretty simple once you get the hang of things (dialects might be tricky at first if you don't have that much experience with non–Attic), and it never gets dull since, as a genre class, you get exposure to a lot of different authors. Most of class is usually spent on translation, if that's your thing, but you'll also talk a lot about the poetic traditions, etc. Definitely my favorite class this semester.

This is a class worth taking.  It is hard, though.  But the sense of achievement when sending out the final Homeric assignment has been a great experience.  If you like a challenge, and enjoy the feeling of making it, take this call, Jeremy is going to get you through it.
If you want to learn Latin at Harvard you've got to take this course. It's slow and pretty easy but you'll eventually get the knowledge.
worse_comment: This class requires a lot of studying outside of class. It is very difficult material.
subject: Latin

best_comment: If you've taken Latin far in the past (if you've taken Latin before you should be taking Latin 3) it would be a good refresher/might be a little repetitive, depending on how well you know Latin. For those who have never taken Latin before, the course moves pretty quickly (3ish grammatical concepts and 20is new vocab words a week) so be prepared. There is a little quiz almost every week, but if you keep on top of your assignments and know the vocab you'll basically be fine.
subject: Latin

best_comment: This course is quite fast–paced for beginner latin but the instructor and TFs are super sweet and helpful!
subject: Latin

best_comment: I think Latin 1 was a great introduction to latin which was very well structured, lessons were clear and easy to follow, and being able to translate passages from original sources by the end was incredibly rewarding.
subject: Latin

best_comment: Like any language class, it takes work, but it's worth it! I'm sure that this is probably a class that varies based on who is instructing and in the class each semester . . . but we were blessed with the best group of people. It made coming to class a highlight of the day.
subject: Latin

best_comment: this course is decently challenging, especially if you haven't taken Latin a while, but it definitely gets easier as you go along, and I felt like I got a lot out of the course, as my ability to read Latin improved significantly. also the course is listed as being taught by Ivy Livingston, but it is taught by a TF
subject: Latin

best_comment: Wonderful class! The opportunity to learn from Professor Thomas is obviously amazing. Class covers both a run–through of translations and intertexts, which are incredibly interesting: Virgil as an author uses extensive reference (e.g., to Theocritus, Callimachus, himself, etc.) — and it is a joy to discover each. There is a ~6–8 page paper at the end, where you can dive deep into a specific area, which is always interesting to do: I would encourage spending some time (whether in reviewing for class or exams or in the paper) to further analyze the texts and make connections between those themes discussed in class; there is always more to Virgil :) Also, it's always fun to search for scholarly articles on a part of the text one is interested in and find those from one's own professor.

This was an amazing course. Having started Latin in college, I was a bit worried about how my first 100–level Latin course would be,  but Professor Love made this course extremely accessible. The Latin reading amount was very reasonable, especially as my first 100–level course, as it was complemented by secondary scholarship reading material. Professor Love is extremely supportive and always willing to help inside and outside class. Highly recommend, especially as a first 100–level course!

This course is a significant amount of work but it is rewarding if you are interested in the Medea myth. I would note that this course veers more in the direction of a Latin "grammar" course than a Latin "literature" course, as we didn't devote much time to the literary aspects of our texts as I probably would have liked. Instead, it feels like a lot of grammar nitpicking, which is fine, but feels a little arduous and sometimes unnecessary. You will get better at Latin because of this course, but you might also frequently be frustrated by the level of perfection and work that it demands.

This was the best course I have ever taken at Harvard! Classes were interactive, informative, and fun. I'm glad I decided to take Greek for my foreign language requirement. Even if you don't need the language requirement, please take this class! No background is needed, and it's a truly memorable experience.
subject: Modern Greek

best_comment: This is a great introduction to the history and politics of Yiddish. All of the course materials are very engaging and this is a wonderful chance to push and deepen your knowledge of Yiddish.
subject: Comparative Literature

best_comment: Take this class! I entered "On Translation" without any major interest or experience in translation, but now I am fascinated by it! The readings are challenging but in a good way, and the discussion sessions are super interesting because the students came from very different backgrounds (grad/undergrad, languages, nationalities, interests...) and worked on a project that meant a lot to them. I translated poetry for mine, and that project was what I wanted to be working on all the time during the semester – it was both fun and a great learning opportunity. Professor Naddaff is the kindest person, she is so encouraging and even brought chocolate to each seminar! I'd recommend this class to anyone interested in language, literature, and culture!

course_title: History of the Book: Using Harvard's Treasures to Study the Material Text LEC
best_comment: Take this class!! If you're looking for a unique Harvard educational experience, it does not get any better. You get to touch and engage with really rare and fascinating materials (obviously the Gutenberg Bible, but also stuff like Shakespeare's first folio, ancient scrolls, Renaissance scientific books, etc.), and learn to see them with new eyes. The class itself is laid back but if you engage with the materials and take advantage of your time in the rare books library, you'll get a really meaningful experience out of it. Also, our class really bonded and even hung out outside of class, which I think goes to show how Professor Stern does a great job of building community.
subject: Comparative Literature
course_title_2023: History of the Book: Using Harvard's Treasures to Study the Material Text

best_comment: Take this class! It helped me learn much more about certain topics and it helped me find ways to express them! It teaches you a lot about how technology and convenience have been viewed throughout the years as well as makes you think about the current state of the world and our relationship with technology and convenience. If you like thinking about things like the meaning of life, I feel like you could truly enjoy this course, because it takes one specific stance (in terms of the meaning of life) and then looks at the world critically from that perspective. Very fun course with amazing readings, and I think that anyone who does the readings and pays attention in lectures would enjoy it a lot!
worse_comment: This course is thought–provoking and provocative as a whole. It explores contemporary themes. Take the readings seriously. You will get a lot from this course.
best_gem_comment: I could not recommend this course enough. The professor was amazing, engaging and relaxing. The readings were interesting and not very challenging. A true gem of a course. The course granted be a more well rounded outlook on technology and generally how I plan to live my life – I find myself thinking of the lessons taught in this course on a semi–regular basis in my everyday life – and have altered decisions according to it.

best_comment: Have you ever been to an opera? Personally, I haven't, but after having taken Complit 153, I think I have an idea of what it must be like. In an opera, a singer comes on stage and performs some piece of music with tremendous passion, and although you have no idea what they were saying, you still nod to your friends, say it's good, and applaud because you appreciate the art of it. Similarly, in Complit 153, Professor Weir enters the lecture hall, talks in highly elevated diction for an hour and a half about some sophisticated–sounding topics, and although you have no idea what he's saying, you still try to jot down notes and nod to your friends because you appreciate the art of it. But what exactly is this art? It is the art of quoting from other scholars: When he explicates an interpretation, he makes sure to include as many sources of Nabokov scholarship as he can. He often always throws in a dash of Russian as well, just to add some interlingual insight. It is the art of improvisation: Arrive early enough and you will get a sneak peek of Complit 153 behind the scenes. Fifteen minutes to 6:45, Prof. Weir enters the premises. Five minutes to 6:45, Prof. Weir walks in and flips frantically through all 60 pages of his notes. At 6:45, Professor Weir begins his performance. It is the art of speed: Prof. Weir always has many more notes than he has minutes in class, but they don't call him the "master chef" for no reason. He always cooks up an incredible stew, expertly blending together scholarly ideas, usually relying on the last 10 minutes as a speedround to "popcorn" from person to person as they collectively crowdsource just about every insight to be had. It is the art of abstraction: His handwriting is illegible. But most importantly, it is the art of the simple: Behind the facade of the multilined model with thousands of different facets, there's always a really simple Nabokovian principle. Some of my favorites include: all art is flawed art, unless it's Pushkin's or Nabokov's; Freud is awful and any character who agrees with him is awful; nature (especially the butterfly) is beautiful; and of course the hermeneutics of perversion. Comparative Literature can be so wonderful. This was my first comparative literature class at Harvard, but after taking it, I became confused as to why people call comparative literature majors "losers," unless a loser is just someone who wrestles with a text long enough to extract an insight about the world.In all honesty, this class has topics that are really interesting, but they are often presented in a way that blurs the fine detail and focuses on the big themes instead. I am a fan of the post–lecture 1–hour class discussion where we consider the artistic and political aspects of the text and this part is usually pretty well–done, even though the conclusion will be something obvious (funny). Lectures themselves often move too quickly as a result of the large number of literary buzzwords that are not explained in much detail (and time taken up by the class discussion). It is unfortunate that there is no textbook because there is no way to explore the material presented in class and get a better understanding except by combing through the books Prof. Weir quotes from, which are usually behind a paywall. Essays are pretty good both as a learning tool and in terms of content (they usually remind me of something from popular culture like Queen's Gambit or Stanley Kubrick that we then compare with the novel), although I wish the page length on them was just a little more high. I feel uncomfortable when I take notes for an essay and I am able to fit my notes on only 3 lines (with the paper in landscape orientation). In–class pop quizzes seem unexpected at first, but they actually happen just about every week an essay is due, so it's hard to be unpleasantly surprised. The weekly workload varies wildly, since Professor Weir assigns either most of a 200–page novel in addition to a two hour movie or just a couple pages' worth of selected excerpts to reread. He put the weekly homework on the course page weeks before we had to do this and this was actually what we did, leading many to be very happy. As a result work is pretty predictable, so don't be too sad if you don't have time to get it all done one week, chances are you can catch up in the week following.If you want to take this class, make sure you know a bit about Nabokov, make sure you know your Russian early–20th–century politics and Russian idioms, and that's basically it. It's quite accessible really, once you actually find it in the course catalog.
worse_comment: Nabokov is brilliant but his perspective might startle you

best_comment: Be aware that this is not a literature course, though listed as Comp Lit. It is, however, very interesting and provides many valuable comparative frameworks for thinking about literature. Junting is a great professor and will encourage you to take the course's central ideas and follow them up in a way which is interesting and productive for you.

course_title: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice 001
best_comment: David is an inspiring teacher whose enthusiasm seeps into every aspect of his seminar. His selections are always fascinating and a pleasure to read.  And his own generous and measured, though always playful, approach to his materials and his students is exemplary. If you are interested in learning about the history of Comparative Literature as a discipline and understanding the key debates at the heart of its field, this is the course for you. Be warned though, unless the course is reformed in the future, there is a lot more theory to be compared than literature!
subject: Comparative Literature
course_title_2023: Comparative Literature in Theory and Practice

best_comment: This is an extremely rewarding class.  It's perfect if you do not have much experience in CS because they give you a thorough introduction to all the topics and do not assume any prior knowledge.  I dreaded the idea of CS coming into the class because I didn't know really anything about it.  However, this class makes all the topics seem not only accessible and manageable, but also interesting, relevant, and useful.  There is incredibly good staff support––all the CAs and TFs are really knowledgable, patient, and helpful, and I always felt like there was somewhere I could turn for help.  The experience of the class as a whole is also highly worthwhile––the whole thing feels very much like a production.  The lectures felt to me like Ted Talks because they are so well produced, and there are lots of activities outside of class that are interesting to attend as well, such as the hackathon––even if you aren't that interested in the CS itself, it's fun to go just to admire the over–the–top production aspect of it.  I recommend the class even if you don't need it for a concentration requirement because it is a pretty iconic Harvard experience.  Moreover, it really does make you feel more comfortable with CS, and teaches you how to think in ways you might not have before.
worse_comment: Brutal bro. So brutal.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This is an extremely rewarding class.  It's perfect if you do not have much experience in CS because they give you a thorough introduction to all the topics and do not assume any prior knowledge. subject: Computer Science

best_comment: hello future students!!! this class is super cool. you'll learn a lot and you'll do some really cool psets, but you will also struggle a lot. for that, go to office hours!!!!! even if you don't have any questions at the moment, go to office hours!!!! there will almost always be other people on the same phase as you there and it was going to office hours almost every day where i met some really cool people whom i could work with outside of class and office hours. struggle bonding in this class is real and it's kind of fun. eddie is also super patient and kind and lovely to talk to in general – so go to eddie's office hours as well if u can!!!! they're also super wonderful about late hours and in conclusion, it is a ton of work and i probably cried twice a week (at least) because of this class, but i can still confidently say that i have learned a lot and made some really wonderful friends. if you do decide to take it, which i hope you do, you got this!!! much love and best of luck!!! <3 <3
worse_comment: Start on the problem sets early, and know that this will be a highly time consuming course. I took this with CS 120 and STAT 110, which was a big mistake. Problem sets take a lot of time, even though there's not a lot of coding required, and my schedule didn't allow me to start and finish the problem sets the way I wanted to. Don't be a hero and take this class with other hard courses.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: CS 73 is my favorite course that I've taken at Harvard for a variety of reasons.At a high level, the course seamlessly combines the domains of art and data visualization in a very powerful way. You learn how to approach data with an open mindset, creatively analyze and visualize data in beautiful ways, and appreciate the artistic visions of others. The presentations cover a variety of fascinating topics ranging from color in data visualization to incorporating interactivity. Despite this being the first iteration of the course, the class materials were extremely organized, and the topics discussed in class were very applicable to the homework assignments. The weekly group critiques are great for receiving feedback and learning from others. I could feel tangible growth and improvement over the course of the semester, and it's really rewarding to be able to see and share the projects you make.  The course can definitely be demanding at times, as the projects are pretty open–ended, but the overall process is extremely fulfilling. Finally, Professor Viegas and Professor Wattenberg created this class based on their decades of research + industry experience, and they have so much knowledge and wisdom to impart to students. Their excitement and passion about the course is contagious and they also truly care about the growth of each and every student.If you are someone who has interests in data visualization and/or art, I would highly encourage you to take this class!
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: CS 73 is my favorite course that I've taken at Harvard for a variety of reasons.At a high level, the course seamlessly combines the domains of art and data visualization in a very powerful way. You learn how to approach data with an open mindset, creatively analyze and visualize data in beautiful ways, and appreciate the artistic visions of others. The presentations cover a variety of fascinating topics ranging from color in data visualization to incorporating interactivity. subject: Computer Science

course_title: Design of Useful and Usable Interactive Systems 001
best_comment: If you've never taken a CS class and are curious about design, take this class!! It's a really beginner friendly introduction to HCI and product design, and you pick up some pretty useful skills! You become really familiar with Figma (you don't need to know how to use it before taking this course, all of it is taught in class), and you have the chance to work closely with your classmates on each of the three projects. The lectures themselves are a hit or miss; sometimes they're really engaging and provide pretty new and useful information (this was mostly in the beginning of the semester), but as the course progresses, the lectures themselves become a bit repetitive. I found the most rewarding part of the course to be in the projects themselves. If you're interested in a pretty light, but fun workload that requires quite a bit of creativity and teamwork, this is a great class for just that!
worse_comment: I found this course to be instructive in the first few weeks and then highly repetitive from then onwards. If you are looking for a practical design course where you are consistently designing applications in Figma this is not it. Instead, the courses focuses on how to think about design problems with very little focus on practical application.
best_gem_comment: Take this class!! Though considered a CS "gem", this course is extremely useful for future SWEs, PMs, Designers, or any tech–adjacent working person. Lectures and sections are fun and interesting and assignments are as fun as you let them be (you can kind of get creative). No CS experience necessary – many successful non–STEM majors take this course.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Design of Useful and Usable Interactive Systems

best_comment: Overall, I really enjoyed this class. The first few weeks were a bit slow in my opinion, but after it picked up, I loved the lectures and assignments. Readings were also really interesting. Waldo is a really great professor. He makes class super engaging and fun!
worse_comment: 1) Grading is wack: It's done by undergraduate TFs despite the fact that most assignments (due Sundays!!!) are essay–type assignments. You'll get a heart attack on your first paper when you get a 2.5 out of 5 before Waldo explains that 2.5 is what he expects!2) You really don't have to do all the readings to understand the class; since Waldo expanded the class to 48 people, you spend a lot of the time trudging through boring explanations of technology that the Gov concentrators don't understand (no joke, someone once asked if going into Incognito stops your ISP from tracking you).3) Waldo is great! He is here to make sure you have fun, but some assignments are annoying because it's really just Waldo flexing how much he knows.
best_gem_comment: Class is an absolute gem!! The professor is so funny and the topics are genuinely interesting :) Work load also isn't a lot and an amazing CS class!!
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: You need to have a decent foundation in Python before taking the class.  Knowing how to use your terminal, shell scripting, and Git is helpful for the first couple weeks but I didn't and I ended up totally fine; it will seem like a lot at first but don't get discouraged and after a couple weeks you'll catch on and have learned so much.  Hands down one of the classes with material most applicable to jobs in swe and data science.  Highly recommend you will learn a ton and Fabian is really smart and super active on Ed to answer questions
worse_comment: This is a far too practical class. Only take it if you really need to learn about Python and how to use Git quickly (for a summer job or such). I would only recommend this class to Graduate students, not because it is hard, but because it is not useful to undergrads. Spend your time learning theory: this class spends too long on specific syntax that will change year over year. The quizzes are torture, the participation grading is competitive (as is grading overall), and the content is all over the place.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: This advice goes particularly to students who are not CS/AM/STEM and have not had previous experience with coding. I came into this class as an Economics concentrator, without ever having taken CS50 (admittedly because I was scared of computers), and only a brief encounter with using python and pandas for a network analysis. I had a lot of experience with economic research in R, and the PhD student I worked for recommended CS109 as one of the most useful classes he had done in his doctoral degree (also hadn't learnt python before). I came in scared that I wouldn't have the background to succeed, but sticking with this class was THE BEST DECISION I made. If you don't have much experience with coding, use HW0 as an opportunity to learn. It's very comprehensive, if you find a friend who can also help you understand the concepts and you use the Data Science Bedrock materials Pavlos provides, you'll learn Python really quickly. By the end of the class, I felt extremely proficient in my coding abilities, could complete all the homeworks quickly and without any problems, and honestly am super grateful that I had the opportunity to practice so much coding in college. The material I learnt was also extremely helpful for other classes, such as Ec 1126, and it helped me develop hard skills which I later plan to use for research/jobs.I left this class now in Am/Ec and considering a secondary in CS because there are simply too many other courses I want to take. This was a great introduction to data science and I highly recommend anyone who wants more experience with handling data to take this course. If you're not super comfortable with coding, just make sure you are willing to put in the hours (particularly in the beginning) and you'll do fine.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. This class takes lots of time, not because the material is difficult but because of busywork.  Professors aren't interested in teaching, class is 100+ students, Ed crashes all the time, online quizes don't work, assignment grading has no actual feedback... many problems with this course. It's much better to watch external online videos and learn by doing. The amount of work/learning ratio is really really low for this course.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: This advice goes particularly to students who are not CS/AM/STEM and have not had previous experience with coding. I came into this class as an Economics concentrator, without ever having taken CS50 (admittedly because I was scared of computers), and only a brief encounter with using python and pandas for a network analysis. I had a lot of experience with economic research in R, and the PhD student I worked for recommended CS109 as one of the most useful classes he had done in his doctoral degree (also hadn't learnt python before). I came in scared that I wouldn't have the background to succeed, but sticking with this class was THE BEST DECISION I made. If you don't have much experience with coding, use HW0 as an opportunity to learn. It's very comprehensive, if you find a friend who can also help you understand the concepts and you use the Data Science Bedrock materials Pavlos provides, you'll learn Python really quickly. By the end of the class, I felt extremely proficient in my coding abilities, could complete all the homeworks quickly and without any problems, and honestly am super grateful that I had the opportunity to practice so much coding in college. The material I learnt was also extremely helpful for other classes, such as Ec 1126, and it helped me develop hard skills which I later plan to use for research/jobs.I left this class now in Am/Ec and considering a secondary in CS because there are simply too many other courses I want to take. This was a great introduction to data science and I highly recommend anyone who wants more experience with handling data to take this course. If you're not super comfortable with coding, just make sure you are willing to put in the hours (particularly in the beginning) and you'll do fine.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. This class takes lots of time, not because the material is difficult but because of busywork.  Professors aren't interested in teaching, class is 100+ students, Ed crashes all the time, online quizes don't work, assignment grading has no actual feedback... many problems with this course. It's much better to watch external online videos and learn by doing. The amount of work/learning ratio is really really low for this course.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science

course_title: Introduction to Algorithms and their Limitations 001
best_comment: Take it if  you have to or are interested in the material. It's a good class though challenging. Salil and Adam are very flexible, fair, understanding, and open to feedback. Lots of Office Hours and Sections that were generally very helpful. Psets are hard and often long but they're not impossible and the grading is fair. I haven't taken CS121 or 124 but I am glad I took 120 instead of 121 and I think it will help me in 124. I took it without taking CS20 (although I took 22A) and I was fine. You do need to know something about proofs and have a programming background (cs50 & 51 is enough ofc) but you don't need cs20 if you don't want to take it. Exams were fair (unlike in CS51, i felt like I could do everything on the exam even if half of it was not perfect) and psets really help you prepare for exams so you don't have to study that much. I'd recommend having notes or like a cheatsheet where you write down all of the theorems and definitions because it does cover quite a lot and then you might need some specific things in the exam and you need to know them by heart so it's good to have a resource with "everything you should know." I'm glad it's over but I think I made the right choice taking this class and if you are interested in the material you might even enjoy it!
worse_comment: I think CS121 is probably a better course. You will learn much more even though the material might not be as relevant.The difficulty and length of the problem sets decreased substantially after problem set 2. I think that's because the course staff wanted to make the problem sets more reasonable, but it lowered the standard of learning. I don't see how 10–15 hours spent on a problem set is unreasonable for a type of class like this. I think the course staff's expectation that students only spend 6–8 hours on each problem set is dumbfounded. Problem sets are for understanding the material on a deeper level; in this course, this was limited because problem sets became way too short and easy to complete. Honestly, I would say this course might be easier than CS20 in some respects. If you're debating whether to take CS121 or CS120, and you've taken CS20, you should take 121. 20 is enough for 121, and 121 isn't even graded more difficult than 120; people just say to choose this course because they don't want to do the work. Last note: take CS121 instead of this.

course_title_2023: Introduction to Algorithms and their Limitations

course_title_2023: Introduction to Algorithms and their Limitations

best_comment: Like for most concentration requirements, I think there are a lot of divided opinions regarding CS 121, but it was honestly one of my favorite classes that I took this semester. I wasn't expecting to enjoy theoretical CS at all, but I found a lot of results/concepts from this class really intriguing and unexpected (e.g., Rice's theorem, Y combinators, PRGs, Turing machines, etc), especially as someone who came into this class without any exposure to theoretical CS. I'd definitely recommend at least considering taking 121 – I know that CS 120 has become a much more popular option now that enrollment for that class isn't capped, and while 120 probably does a better job of preparing you for tech interviews than 121, I think that CS 121 introduces you to some really interesting concepts that aren't covered in 120 (e.g., PRGs, etc).That being said, 121 isn't without its own flaws/differences – unlike MIT's TOC course, CS 121 uses Boaz's textbook, which still contains some typos and takes an unconventional approach to TCS. I thought that starting with NAND circuits and generally taking a more circuit–based approach was interesting and insightful, but I know some people who say they really would have preferred the standard approach to TOC covered in textbooks like Sipser. I also felt a bit lost at the very end of the course when we covered quantum computing – I think it was covered a little too quickly and assumed a little too much from the students wrt how much they would know about quantum notation/theory.I still think the pros way outweighs the cons though: 121 is really interesting to begin with, and it's clear that Boaz cares a ton about his students and how well they learn the content in the class. There's so much extra credit in the class on psets and exams that it's super easy to get a 100 under psets (capped at 100) and its very doable to get 100+ on exams. CS 121.5 sections (where they invite profs and postdocs and the like to give related lectures) are super interesting (would definitely recommend trying to go to a few, even if you're unsure if you'll understand it all!), and 121 sections in general are really useful for pinning down the content. Problem sets are also interesting – they do a really nice job of tying course content together, and the results can be really insightful.If you're on the border of trying 121 out, I'd go for it! Definitely would have regretted not taking it this semester!
worse_comment: This class has an unreasonable participation requirement, a useless textbook, incompetent TAs, and a professor who does not care enough to supervise his own exams.
subject: Computer Science

course_title: Fairness and Privacy: Perspectives from Law and Probability 001
best_comment: The class is definitely challenging but extremely rewarding. Even if you don't think you interested in theoretical CS, if the content/topic of this class is of enough interest, I definitely recommend taking it. The joint law school aspect is very unique and a cool experience. While the assignments are difficult and can be stressful to complete, the grading of this class is very fair. Overall highly recommend to everyone just because the content is so interesting and relevant to the real–world, but would recommend with reservations if you are not comfortable with theoretical rigor (of the level of CS124).
worse_comment: This was the worst–run class I have taken at Harvard. The only good part of this class was learning from Cynthia Dwork, who is clearly a true genius. However, all the other parts of this class (especially the EXTREMELY LAZY TFs) ruined it. I think the professor should have done something to keep her staff accountable after multiple students complained when it became clear that the TF and CA were being intentionally lazy and trying to avoid their responsibilities, by scheduling only 1 hour of office hours per week at 12pm on Wednesday/Thursday (which students couldn't even go to). Additionally, the materials for the course were very lacking; there are no course recordings and the lecture slides are not really readable since they have too little information on them. Finally, the problem sets were very hard (and TF/CA are inaccessible), and feedback took forever (more than 4 weeks in one case). Additionally, I felt like the law school joint classes were disappointing, maybe because I expected to learn something legal but instead just had to listen to law school students blab about their own personal experiences and opinions. Also, for some reason even though this class was at 9am which was bad enough, it was decided that the joint classes should start at 8:45am on Mondays... That being said, I thought this class did a pretty good job at exposing us to ethics in CS and those considerations, although not really the legal side of things.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Fairness and Privacy: Perspectives from Law and Probability

best_comment: One of the best courses, if not the best course, I've taken at Harvard. If you're thinking about taking the course, do it! Find some friends to take it with you, clear space in your schedule, and deep dive into the course. It's definitely worth it; don't be deterred by any reviews. A few reasons the class stands out:1) Stratos and his lab are some of the most chill, yet cracked people I've ever met—just look at the awards they win. This translates to easy–to–understand lectures and a good introduction to research. Lectures teach you how to walk step–by–step through the different operators you learn about, as well as how to break down any high–level database concept into the fundamentals: cache utilization, branching, etc. (I would suggest taking CS 61 before this course; I will note that I found the project easier than the psets in CS 61). Furthermore, doing database research is comparable to the work you do in lectures.2) You learn how to code—independently. Unlike in CS 61, where the projects were contained to 1–2 weeks of work, no one besides you in this class (not the TFs nor Stratos) will know your entire database implementation because you'll be working on it throughout the semester. Besides the handout code—which you can revamp to your heart's content—you decide which functions to create and how they work, how to parse inputs, and how to return results. Attending lectures should provide a rough outline for you to follow, but besides that, you learn how to debug your code. (Please, please, please install Valgrind immediately after starting the course. I promise you'll save 2 weeks' worth of time you'd otherwise spend debugging weird errors and dealing with memory management in C. You can either launch an EC2 instance or run it through Docker). Modularize your functions, unit test new operators, and spend time thinking about the high–level concepts (you should really only spend 30% of your time on this project actually coding); this project isn't bad once you realize how to break a big task into a collection of smaller ones. 3) The grading is very generous with extra credit, namely, on the midterms. You don't need to sweat your grade!
worse_comment: I think this class was my favorite cs class I’ve taken in this school. Every lecture was so eye opening and I to my own surprise absolutely loved the content.However, I also think that this is the worst performance I’ve had in a class. The project is insanely hard. I got stuck for weeks in a row at a problem caused by one line multiple times throughout the semester and I was not able to finish the project. You’re going to love it when you actually are able to implement the crazy things in your project. But more likely you’re going to be extremely frustrated at everything for 3 months straight.I don’t regret taking this class (said assuming I don’t end up getting a failing grade) but also the project was the biggest mess I’ve ever seen.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This course is one of the easier CS classes out there, and it's pretty hand–holdy. Definitely make sure you have some coding experience before you take it, and be prepared for some busywork, reading and lecture quizzes, and sometimes intense psets. Labs are helpful in the course, though many of them involve a lot of copy – pasting code they give you which makes things easier in the moment but helps less with long–term retention. Less support from course staff than other CS courses too. Definitely recommend taking the course though as it's fun and useful, especially to help with a lighter semester.
worse_comment: The class is very helpful, but it can be a lot of work. I don't recommend taking it with other more difficult CS classes.
best_gem_comment: Take this class if you're interested in visualization! If you're willing to put in real work, it can be really rewarding to make a cool final project and have something to leave this class with. I wouldn't consider it a gem, but it's certainly less technically demanding than most other CS classes (coming from a non–CS concentrator).
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Honestly, I was surprised by how much I enjoyed this class. Both professors were amazing (two of my favorite CS professors ever!!). Lecture was always super clear and easy to follow. PSETs actually reflected what we talked about in class and were good practice of the material. All TFs were super helpful. Material itself was super interesting and I loved how the professors constantly brought in real life examples. My only complaint is that I felt like the midterm asked questions about super specific things and did not focus on the big picture of what we talked about. The practice exams for both the midterm and the final were not reflective at all of what the actual exams were like.
worse_comment: Start the coding section of the problem early.
best_gem_comment: Great overview of AI, well–balanced between practical applications and theory! Covers a lot of interesting topics that you're more than likely to run into. I was a bit hesitant on taking the class at first, since 1) it would overlap in requirements with CS181 (you technically never have to take both) and 2) I had only taken CS51 and Math22, and would be taking CS182 with Stat110 concurrently (requirements say CS182 was to be taken after Stat110). But I'm glad I did! I don't really care for the very heavy theory in CS181 and definitely preferred the even split between theory and coding on psets, and I got through all the content just fine with my background (the only thing you need from Stat110 is Bayes).Also, the professors and TFs are really nice. Prof. Gil left in the middle (she had a baby!) and we all got the cutest Ed post of her and her newborn son saying hi to the class. Prof. Procaccia is the sweetest human being alive and he keeps the lectures interesting (it's clear he has a lot of experience teaching––he told us a story about how, after many years, he realized his CMU course on AI was unnecessarily convoluted and hard, and how that has led to his approach on teaching now). The TFs are a small but mighty team.Would definitely recommend taking this class, especially above CS181! A true gem in the CS department.
subject: Computer Science
