subject: Computer Science

best_comment: For those looking for a class that's easy or implementation–heavy but theory–light, this is not the one for you. It's heavy on math and statistics—but honestly does a pretty good job building up the core RL fundamentals from scratch. There really isn't a ton of good RL material on the Internet; rather than learning things like MDP's and policy gradients from half–baked Medium articles, this class will teach you the fundamental concepts, rigorously demonstrate how they work, and motivate things from a first–principles perspective. You will emerge from this class capable of reading almost any RL paper. With that being said, it's a bit of a mess. The teaching staff was disorganized, and the lecture slides often had notational errors (although this was usually Sham, not Lucas). In other CS classes with a singular focus (e.g. 121), you get this nice tapestry of ideas throughout the semester that build on one another and serve as core to the course. The same is true in the *material* of 184, but not the execution—as a student, you have to put in a lot of mileage discovering the intricate connections of things that really could just be said in lecture. The homeworks were generally fine, but I was never clear how they would be graded + the programming components could be much better.
worse_comment: Difficult course. Don't take if not prepared to work with the mathematics
subject: Computer Science

subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Overall this class was pretty chill for the most part. Lectures were well organized and I learned a lot about Pytorch, python, AI paper layouts and presentations, different ML tools like weights&biases, hydra, etc... Looking back at my previous classes, this was by far the course where I gained the most hands on experience, and probably the most practical in terms of how the skills would transfer to industry. You definitely learn how to put together a research paper, and how to look for new ideas from existing papers. I think the greatest thing I got out of the class is being able to digest AI papers and understand the high level approaches, and now being able to go and build my own pytorch models. The majority of the class was great, and the assignments didn't take too much time and allows you to regurgitate the material. The main pain point of the course is the final project, where we had to try and improve upon the performance of Pranav's chex x–ray classification model CheXZero. That was the main goal of the project and we had to come up with our own ideas and approaches. Overall it was a cool idea, but I think it was too broad and unscoped, and many of our initial attempts failed. This was especially annoying because running the code would take a very long time, so a lot of time would be spent just waiting to see if an idea could work. Additionally, CheXZero was recently published in Nature and it seems really hard to do something groundbreaking that would improve upon the model within a few weeks, especially when our AWS accounts were resource–limited so we did not have the compute power to even get a model that could be directly compared with the original. I think overall there was very little guidance for the project and we were fumbling around in the dark just trying things randomly in hope that something stuck. Out of the 5 groups, I think only 2 ended up with something that had some small improvement, but it still felt like everything was very hacky.Overall it is a decent class, especially for being new. Pranav is super cool and has done a lot of amazing work. If you take this class you will definitely learn a lot, but be prepared to spend a lot of time on the group final project (groups of 3). It is a very back–heavy class as you probably spend at most 5 hours on each assignment, but the project will take a long time because of the time it takes to train and run the code.

course_title: Algorithms at the Ends of the Wire 001
best_comment: If you're interested in how industry–relevant algorithms (set membership querying, cardinality estimation, link prediction, search engines, range filtering, hashing, etc.) scale on big data inputs, this is the course for you! Prof. Mitzenmacher has an exciting lineup of state–of–the–art research for you to read about and discuss with peers. While you do have to dig deep into these research papers and write summaries about them every week, the papers themselves are generally engaging to the point where writing about them doesn't feel too tedious! The assignments (psets) take time, but are not burdensome (you can feel yourself better understanding ideas from the papers as you apply them through problem–solving). The final project is a hefty undertaking, but a great opportunity to challenge yourself if you're interested in research. I took this course as an undergraduate, and it has strengthened my resolve to continue with research and potentially go to grad school in CS. Prof. Mitzenmacher and the rest of the course staff are accessible, supportive, and highly knowledgeable.

course_title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Analysis of Boolean Functions 001
best_comment: If the material sounds interesting, then take it. It is a good course.
worse_comment: This class goes into a lot of cool topics –– Fourier analysis of boolean functions, social choice theory, low–degree testing, circuit complexity, hypercontractivity, pseudorandomness –– but it's not super well taught.

course_title: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Information Theory in CS 001
best_comment: TAKE ANYTHING THAT MADHU TEACHES! That's it. Amazing lecturer, amazing person, just incredible. Madhu is exactly what a professor should be: extremely knowledgeable,  brilliant lecturer, kind to the student, and cares deeply about educating the next generation. I admire him for being a true leader in the theory CS community, and for the amount of care that he puts into making sure that theory CS is a welcoming space for everyone. A lot of male professors will use empty words and say that they care about gender diversity; but in practice, they do nothing and continue to alienate minorities from their fields. But Madhu, unlike most of these professors, actually takes action: he makes sure everyone is comfortable in class, he encourages questions from the students, he always responds to these questions with a smile even if they are elementary, and it was so fun to go to his office hours. I always looked forward going to class and I only wished they lasted longer! I wish I could take so many more classes with Madhu –– he is such an inspiration and someone I really look up to. He always generated enthusiasm for the class material and it made me so excited about continuing to study theory CS. Thanks for everything! You really are bringing change to the next generation of computer scientists.
worse_comment: Office Hours were basically required to finish the assignments. The course isn't really teaching information theory from first principles in a rigorous manner. It assumes some intuition and asks you to fill in the details in your own time.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Topics in Theoretical Computer Science: Essential Coding Theory

course_title: Topics at the Interface between Computer Science and Economics 001
best_comment: This class has honestly been one of the highlights of the semester –– if you come into it willing to read papers pretty thoroughly and discuss them, you'll get a lot out of the course. A lot of things definitely flew over my head quite a bit, but you can definitely ask clarification questions and spark discussion in class and shouldn't be shy to. Yiling is really great and helpful and loves discussion, and all the people taking this class will be coming from a variety of backgrounds across CS/econ/math/applied math and a variety of educational backgrounds as well, which is really fascinating. Overall, I'd recommend this class a ton as long as you feel ready for it!
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Topics at the Interface between Computer Science and Economics

best_comment: 242 covers a lot of very interesting and very relevant ML topics. It was way less hardware–oriented than I expected (given HT's background), instead focusing more heavily on novel software/paradigms for efficient ML. That said, you can really learn a lot if you put in the effort. There's lots you can do with the final project, and the course staff are quite invested in helping you pick/develop ideas and research. HT is also just a baller –– quite a funny guy (in his own way), and really encourages you to be a great researcher.
worse_comment: Take this course if you are interesting in learning novel approaches to making machine learning more efficient and are okay with being self–guided for most of the time. It's hard to recommend this course based on my experience with it but I'm sure that this course does appeal to some select few. The lectures are dense, often run over time, and not very engaging if you aren't 100% invested in the material. The homeworks are fairly interesting but I didn't love how everything was structured around a group that you form towards the beginning of the semester. 30% of your grade comes from a final project on which I feel we didn't get enough support other than regular check–ins where we were rubberstamped through with the aforementioned group. Take this class if you want to do research at a graduate level in the subject matter (which is the cutting edge of machine learning research, not "Computing at Scale"), but not with a teaching staff who are incredibly knowledgable, but be aware that this is not the most engaging course.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: The class is a good opportunity to learn more about the state–of–the–art in a given field. Note that the exact topic the class focuses on changes from year to year. The topic plays a big role in determining how the class looks like, so you should take that into consideration when deciding whether to take CS 243.The weekly workload is fairly light –– you have to read one paper per class (two per week), and then leave a review. You can probably get away with just skimming the paper (can help in tough weeks), but please, please do your best to read the papers . The whole point of the class is discussion, so if you're not going to read the papers, you might as well take something else.The final project is as much work as you want, but either way it is a significant amount of work. Plan to spend a lot of time in the last 4–5 weeks on the project. You will have to propose a topic, do research on related works, design a system for your idea, implement it, evaluate it, interpret the results, draw conclusions, present your project, and then finally write a comprehensive report about it. This is a lot of work; don't procrastinate. There is little guidance with the project, so you should have some experience with doing independent projects.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: The class is very instructive and entertaining. You will get out of the class as much as you put in, so make sure you choose a project that you are passionate about and start working on it early.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Take this class if you are interested in programming language semantics. CS 252r is a different class every year, but this year it was a pretty self–directed class. Most of the class was doing presentations and readings. Nada and Ana were great. The class is what you make of it!
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: This class assumes a very strong background in software engineering, but if you have the right background, you will be fine. It is very busywork heavy, and the first half of the semester required you to create 1–2 interfaces (todo lists, recreate doodle, when2meet) every week with new frameworks each time. Some of these frameworks are not very well used or documented either (Svelte?) so that wasn’t fun. On top of this, I wrote about 1000 words of paper responses per class that followed a specific framework, and these were fairly useful in understanding HCI research but felt like a pain on top of other assignments. On top of that, we also had to do pair research every week, where we essentially got matched to other students on a website based on what we need help with that week, and help each other out for an hour before writing a response on what we learned. Once again, could be useful if it wasn’t on top of so many other assignments for this class alone. I did enjoy learning about user studies in HCI research and it was fun to execute one throughout the semester and for our final project. If you like to create cool side projects with different frameworks, this class is definitely for you, since my final project just felt like testing out a cool side project. It really caters to people who independently like to develop cool, useful interfaces. Just beware of all the busywork that is required.
worse_comment: The course assignments were too much. Having 2 things due Monday, 3 things due Wednesday, and 1–2 things due Friday was so undoable and defeating. The tier 1 assignments were at first cool to get to learn about different softwares/languages. The above and beyond criteria for that was unfair given how much work had often went in to even get the MVP running. When the tier 1 assignments started overlapping with Tier 2 and tier 3 it was very hard to balance. Tier 2 assignments were okay but had so little instruction or guidance that they became more annoying than a cool exercise. Tier 3 was confusing for everyone really until the last 3 weeks of the class. It was an added stress having been mentioned so early in the course. The pair research assignment was maybe the most upsetting of all. I get the teacher wanting to learn what areas it looks like people need help on. But, forcing us to then submit assignments on what we learned and then grade them was very unfair. Finding 30 minutes to meet was already a challenge, and a lot of times people made of random things to get help with. It was all the more surprising that after this, people could then get 15/20 points for having met with someone but not describing what was learned to the teacher's satisfaction. All of these combined made the class feel like more like a punishment than learning experience; students felt like they were in middle school, so distrusted to do the assignments that every assignment then had to be graded. It felt like there was no rest in this class or time for reflection.
subject: Computer Science

best_comment: Amazing class where you have a free pass to learn about technology and the positive effects it can have. Super helpful if you're at all curious about social impact or just the general societal impacts you can have. Definitely a must take in the CS curriculum.

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: I think (and hope) this course is required, but I suggest, as much as possible, actually engaging with your peers and the material. This class is meant to be very easy and that makes it possible to slide by without ever really engaging, but I think there is real personal value in choosing to engage and doing so gives you a chance to create the culture and community that you want to see for your cohort. Go to office hours, talk to people, it's a great chance to form relationships that can give you a support system outside of your little academic corner.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture

course_title: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture 001
best_comment: I think (and hope) this course is required, but I suggest, as much as possible, actually engaging with your peers and the material. This class is meant to be very easy and that makes it possible to slide by without ever really engaging, but I think there is real personal value in choosing to engage and doing so gives you a chance to create the culture and community that you want to see for your cohort. Go to office hours, talk to people, it's a great chance to form relationships that can give you a support system outside of your little academic corner.
subject: Computer Science
course_title_2023: Seminar on Effective Research Practices and Academic Culture

course_title: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment 001
best_comment: This course has little to no deviations from what it's advertised as. You learn a lot about the Fluid Earth. However, I also learned that personally, the Fluid Earth just isn't something that I am particularly interested in (not necessarily a reflection on the course!). Don't come in as someone with a love for the outdoors and nature and conservation and ecology and expect to love this course at all. Lecture feels longer than it actually is. The professor is great, clearly a genius in her field, and can explain concepts really well one–on–one, but her lectures just weren't interactive enough to keep me fully engaged. However, if you have a genuine interest in most of the material, you might have a different experience. Sometimes, it seemed as if content was still a little unclear. Stephen, my TF, was a lifesaver in this regard (and in the course as a whole). Stephen is really great at breaking down complicated topics, is patient enough to explain material step by step, would go above and beyond in answering emails, staying after lab to answer questions, hosting office hours, would always provide helpful encouragement, and generally wanted the best for everyone. Countless times I've found myself understanding a topic I thought I'd never understand thanks to Stephen. In general, reach out for help, stay after lecture (the professor is better at explaining material then), start on PSETs early to make the most out of section and office hours, and you will be just fine. If this isn't a concentration requirement and you just happen to love conservation/broader material on climate change, take another course.
worse_comment: I took this class because I was interested in the topic being taught– the fluid Earth, ocean dynamics, and atmospheric science. Although some concepts were interesting, this class truly taught me that the professor makes or breaks the experience. The class was not taught well by the professor, so my overall experience of this class was negative. I wouldn't recommend it, but if you are to take it, be prepared to teach a lot of things to yourselves and leave lectures confused almost daily. Even the TFs would seem confused during lectures and would sometimes have to correct the professor.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2023: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment

best_comment: Great course and Prof. Johnston is someone who is both a great lecturer/facilitator and someone who is able to explain complex topics simply, all while engaging the class.  Assignments are very generous and the grading policy maximizes learning.  Would highly recommend taking this course if you are interested in all of the different cycles and feedback loops in the ocean that affect the climate and vice versa!
worse_comment: This course is a bit of a mixed bag. As interesting as the course material is, you may often find yourself coming away from lectures unsure of what you've learned.  This is due to the loose way in which lectures are taught, which involve a lot of self–teaching with students at the boards. If you don't have a background in ocean chemistry, it can be difficult to determine on the spot what processes are dominant or how the math of it all works. I wouldn't recommend this course to any non–STEM majors, and I would only recommend it to those who have a prevailing interest in the subject matter such that you can overcome the shortcomings of its lectures.

course_title: Introduction to Planetary Materials and Earth Resources 001
best_comment: This course is great for non–EPS concentrators, and Stein and Zack are both nice and knowledgable. In fact, we even had a 2nd TF (kinda) in the form of Hairuo, so the teacher to student ratio is excellent.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences
course_title_2023: Introduction to Planetary Materials and Earth Resources

best_comment: This class is a really cool way to get a solid foundation in planetary sciences without too much pressure or stress. The psets aren't that bad, but the midterm required a fair bit of studying. Definitely recommend :)

This class is very self–guided through weekly textbook chapter readings and student presentations. If that works for you, then great! If not, maybe this isn't the class for you. Each class is 50 minutes of lecture by Prof. Martin, followed by 25 minutes of student presentations. The lectures are pretty interesting because Prof. Martin does a great job with teaching and keeps it  engaging, but at least half of the class was usually zoned out during the class presentations and they don't really amount to anything unless you're the one presenting. Section was good and crucial for doing the psets, as we basically just did parallels of the pset questions but with different values. It is, therefore, very easy to do well in this class. The other homework was in the form of reading a chapter of the textbook and submitting a discussion post about it before the class in which we were going to learn about that chapter's content. The textbook was dense and hard to digest, and I don't think it actually taught me anything at all. The lectures are based on the textbook chapters, however, and I definitely did learn during lecture. Also, Scot is enthusiastic and accessible, and he's able to answer any question you have for him.  Finally, I was really not a fan of the final project. Basically all that we could do was just a literature review of an environmental topic, but we were then expected to have some sort of quantitative analysis and propose a solution to "save the world."
worse_comment: Work together with other students on homework assignments, and pay attention during lectures and section discussions.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

course_title: Human Environmental Data Science: Agriculture, Conflict, and Health 001
best_comment: Take this class! Best I have taken at Harvard. It's a significant work load, but the topics are fascinating, assignments interesting and final project is really fun (make sure you have a good group though!). Professor Huybers is a wonderful instructor, who is humble about his work (which is a refreshing change of pace) and passionate about timely topics and making a change.
worse_comment: Most important thing is probably having some coding and stats experiences as the course can be very overwhelming and difficult without that.

best_comment: The class is detailed, relevant, and fun. Steve is an especially dynamic lecturer and supplemented the class material with his own personal expertise on different topics, field campaigns, and environmental policies. I highly recommend this class.
subject: Earth & Planetary Sciences

best_comment: This class is great! Although it is listed as a graduate–level class, the material is very accessible to upper–level undergraduate STEM concentrators. I would particularly say that any senior studying physics is very qualified to take the course. The material is also very engaging. The course covers in great physical detail the processes that govern climate, weather, atmospheres, and oceans on Earth. This course is definitely a must for anyone considering graduate school in Earth/Climate Science, especially from a physics perspective. Professor Kuang is extremely knowledgeable, does a great job of showing real–world examples for all of the topics covered, and overall generates lots of enthusiasm  for the material. I would highly recommend this class!

This class is a really cool way to get a solid foundation in planetary sciences without too much pressure or stress. The psets aren't that bad, but the midterm required a fair bit of studying. Definitely recommend :)

course_title: How we understand Precambrian environments: a grounding in modern elemental/isotopic cycles 001
best_comment: This class gave me a lot of fundamental insight on the world of stable isotopes throughout Earth history. I came into this class knowing a little about isotopes, but came away from this class with a different view of how dynamic isotope systems can be especially when considering deep time. I'd highly recommend this class, it was a fun experience and allowed for me to hone my science communication skills too. I can say that now I have a basis of knowledge to apply in my future graduate studies –– scientific and otherwise!

course_title: How we understand Precambrian environments: a grounding in modern elemental/isotopic cycles 001
best_comment: This class gave me a lot of fundamental insight on the world of stable isotopes throughout Earth history. I came into this class knowing a little about isotopes, but came away from this class with a different view of how dynamic isotope systems can be especially when considering deep time. I'd highly recommend this class, it was a fun experience and allowed for me to hone my science communication skills too. I can say that now I have a basis of knowledge to apply in my future graduate studies –– scientific and otherwise!

Make sure you're able to commit to the class. The coursework is relatively light, but class itself takes place every day –– and it can get overwhelming. Prioritize lecture classes over drills, and take advantage of OH! The instructors are incredibly warm and inclusive –– it's super rewarding to speak with them outside of class.
worse_comment: It's an amazing class!!! Take it take it, but make sure to PUT IN THE WORK. literally, you will fail the final exam if you don't give it at least 20 mins a day (starting from week 3).
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This class is a ton of fun, very engaging and educational, but unless you have a good knowledge of Mandarin coming in, do not expect this to be an easy lift. However, I will say that the teachers are pretty generous and kind when it does come to grading.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Chinese is a difficult language to learn, but the materials and teaching staff for this course make it fun, welcoming, and as easy as I think It can be! All the teachers are friendly and really want you to succeed and learn Chinese, and are always happy to help you do so. The small groups for leacure and section really make it easy to participate, and it doesn't feel like a big deal if you don't know an answer or get it wrong, so go for it! If you are at all curious about learning Chinese, you should take this course!
worse_comment: Be prepared to work. Its only a one hour long class, but it is a five day a week class with two quizzes each week. It is a fast moving class that covers a lot of material, so you have to be on top of your work if you want to avoid falling behind.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you put your best into your class, you will enjoy it like crazy. A lot of your performance will hinge on studying out of class, especially before Monday, so you can be prepared for the new week's content. This will make you much sharper answering questions in class and makes everything feel so fun and easy, you will be so much more relaxed in class, and the casual phrases just roll off your tongue rather than trying to rehearse lines you read in the book or pause repeatedly to think. The best part is, this only requires about an hour each week, maybe less, and the teachers will do the rest for you by teaching in class. You will end up bragging to your friends about how fun Chinese class is.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: This is truly one of, if not, the best class I have taken at this school. The teachers are absolutely amazing, and they are truly here to help you learn Chinese, regardless of where you begin. They will teach you, make the class comedic and fun, applicable to real conversational Chinese, rather than conversational, and just makes the entire process of learning this language so fun, comfortable, yet still extremely productive in learning a large amount of material. No matter how overwhelmed you may get, there is plenty of practice and help provided by the course that ensures that you will catch up and be up to par with your classmates, of course assuming that you do actively participate in class and overall materials. You build a great community, as you do see them every single day of your semester. All that being said, please do your work, study the material, keep up with the class before it is too late, this class is what you make of it, so with just a little bit of effort, you get such high rewards. Truly, if you are at all interested in learning Chinese or Chinese culture, or just to truly have fun while learning something extremely useful, take Chinese!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you already speak Chinese at home (regardless of origin) but genuinely want to learn how to read and write more in the language, TAKE THIS CLASS. You will learn at an accelerated but manageable pace that will definitely help your Chinese reading/writing skills improve in just one semester. The course is definitely designed for those who already have a basic grasp of Chinese (ie not total beginners, can differentiate pinyin sounds). I could barely read anything more than Chinese numbers when I first started, and now I can comfortably read most basic passages in Chinese (you'll understand when you see the textbook for this course). The teachers are wonderfully warm and friendly, and make the class environment really enjoyable. The workload isn't too heavy/difficult, but definitely requires several hours of commitment per week (especially the homework sets). However, I would say the payoff is amazingly worth it. The fact that you're reading this probably means you're already considering Bx, so go for it!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: At home I would always respond to my parents' Chinese questions in English, so my speaking was weak and really slow going into this class. After taking it, I have noticed a significant improvement in my speaking abilities, and now I'm pretty comfortable speaking to my parents in Chinese. It's a great, fun, comprehensive class that will guarantee to improve your Chinese if your level is like mine. All grammar and vocab is really strongly consolidated through the 5 classes per week and pretty long weekly homework assignments (these generally took me and others around 4 hours per homework to complete) – and that's a lot of essential and useful grammar structures, since the course covers 12 grammar structures a week. The textbook is also really interesting – the stories aren't dry like you might expect from an introductory course, and there are super insightful Chinese culture nuggets dotted around throughout the textbook. I would really recommend this course if your speaking isn't that good and you want a solid accelerator course to improve your Chinese speaking and reading!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: If you are a heritage Chinese learner but feel like your Chinese is rusty or you haven't had much experience reading or writing, TAKE THIS CLASS! The teachers are fantastic and always bring so much energy into each lesson, and I genuinely believe that my Chinese has improved dramatically over the course of just one semester. One thing I will say about this course is that it occurs every day and the building is pretty far, so it definitely is a big commitment to take this class and it will take up a decent amount of your week. In addition, the hand–written homework assignments every week can get pretty draining, so be prepared to spend some hours on that. Another thing is that the lectures are all done in traditional Chinese (even if the homework, drills, and tests can be done in simplified Chinese), which caused some of the material learned in class to go over my head. However, overall I am very glad that I took this course and I feel much more confident in my language abilities, especially going into tougher higher–level Chinese classes in the future.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course to the point where I was looking forward to waking up in the morning to attend! Professor Sena creates an environment in which students felt very comfortable to ask all sorts of questions whether they are regarding the language, cultural context, or other difficult parts that they don't understand, and I felt like I was learning so much from this very friendly and discussion based environment. I usually struggle with language classes but I have not felt this way in this course despite the difficulty of the material, because the vibes are so good and I feel like I can really immerse myself in the content.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: I could not recommend this class more enthusiastically. Students will come away better equipped to read, understand, and translate Classical Chinese; more confident in collaborating with classmates in engaging with the language; and with a substantially–improved familiarity with their *own* areas of study thanks to Dr. Sena's flexibility vis–a–vis allowing students to choose translation texts freely.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: I became much more confident with my Chinese speaking and listening as a result of taking this course. The CHNSE Ba/Bb sequence gave me an adequate foundation, but 120a took it up a notch and I've become much closer to becoming fluent.  The instructors are the nicest people ever––they truly care about each and every student and are rooting for you to succeed. They go out of their way to be available inside and outside of class to answer questions, ranging from language to Chinese culture. The assignments were all helpful and there were a plentitude of opportunities to get extra credit.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Please take this course! The Chinese department is extremely well–organized and responsive to any questions and concerns that you may have. They will always respond to your emails very quickly and are understanding and accommodating of any situations that may pop up, since this course meets every single day of the week. If you do all the work as intended, such as showing up to class everyday, pay attention and actively participate, study for the twice a week dictations, and do the weekly homework assignments, it is extremely hard to fall behind, and you don't need to do much studying outside of this. The course is well designed and extremely manageable and I have definitely noticed an improvement in my Chinese level after taking this course, since now I can understand much more of the dialogue when I'm watching Chinese shows or consuming Chinese media.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Definitely worth it to take Chinese 120a! I took Chinese BA and BB, and it's pretty much the exact same expectations and workload, so if you've taken them, you'll know what to expect, which is really nice. I got into my study groove and just sailed through the semester on it. There were definitely times (many times) throughout the semester where I felt like I was WAY worse at Chinese than I'd been before, but it wasn't actually true ––– I'm just getting to the point where I know so much Chinese that I can also understand how much I don't know. But I'm truly getting so much better at this language, and it's a huge sense of accomplishment to feel like I get something tangible out of the work and time I put in. The class teaching staff is also amazing!! so it's not a stressful course and is well supported and fun!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Definitely worth it to take Chinese 120a! I took Chinese BA and BB, and it's pretty much the exact same expectations and workload, so if you've taken them, you'll know what to expect, which is really nice. I got into my study groove and just sailed through the semester on it. There were definitely times (many times) throughout the semester where I felt like I was WAY worse at Chinese than I'd been before, but it wasn't actually true ––– I'm just getting to the point where I know so much Chinese that I can also understand how much I don't know. But I'm truly getting so much better at this language, and it's a huge sense of accomplishment to feel like I get something tangible out of the work and time I put in. The class teaching staff is also amazing!! so it's not a stressful course and is well supported and fun!
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Do cumulative review now and then of grammar & vocab (including learning the assigned vocab, previewing the grammar, & practicing reading––which tends to help with both, as well as with intuition for constructions––before class); really take advantage of the lecture slides when preparing for assignments like tests & exams; try to come to class with a bold & gregarious attitude – this is the culture & what may be necessary to feel comfortable speaking
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Do cumulative review now and then of grammar & vocab (including learning the assigned vocab, previewing the grammar, & practicing reading––which tends to help with both, as well as with intuition for constructions––before class); really take advantage of the lecture slides when preparing for assignments like tests & exams; try to come to class with a bold & gregarious attitude – this is the culture & what may be necessary to feel comfortable speaking
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Chinese 130a is similar to the 120 series but different too. The way the course is run is exactly the same, and the quality of the teachers is just as wonderful. However the material gets super super hard, and a lot of the vocabulary starts sounding similar and meaning similar things. As someone who did really well in Chinese 120 (A, A–), Chinese 130a is not the same. Even the vocabulary starts becoming more niche and less useful, like "euthanasia" and "real estate" and "country bumpkin." The vocabulary is clearly very specifically designed for particular topics of discussion. If you want to use Chinese professionally in a humanities aspect, this course is great and will help you learn the vocabulary necessary for social studies conversation. However, if you don't want a citation and just want to learn more Mandarin, I would unfortunately recommend that you look elsewhere.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: Def take if you want the citation, similar to 120 but more content, great teachers, would recommend if you want to learn more mandarin and feel more comfortable with the language.
subject: Chinese

best_comment: KEEP TAKING CHINESE! It is always the most fun, best taught class of the semester for me and you gain a really cool community through  your classmates. I will never stop recommending this department to people I know.
worse_comment: This class is a step up in work load from Chinese 120.  The structure of the class is essentially the same but you learn more vocab and move faster. Just try to keep up with the vocab as much as you can or you'll be forced to cram it all in before the review tests and exams.
subject: Chinese

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: This course is phenomenal. The Harvard Chinese Department is truly amazing in creating courses that really help you improve your Chinese while still being fun and creating a comfortable class environment. Almost everything about this course was done right. The lectures and sections were always fun, yet informative. Structural boundaries were in place to make sure that lessons did not go off topic, but enough leeway was given to create a comfortable and fun environment where students felt willing to speak up and learn and make mistakes. The units were great in covering lots of vocabulary and content on real life issues. Finally, both of the teachers were very responsive, attentive, understanding, and relatable — our class even had a hot pot lunch outing after the class was finished because of how close everyone got and how much we loved our teachers :) Highly recommend.
worse_comment: be ready to work and do it consistently – if you're not committed to learning the language, you will never succeed
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Pre-Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Introduction to Chinese in the Humanities 001
best_comment: Take this class!! Honestly it may seem intimidating at first (especially looking at the original language of the texts) but the teaching staff works with you and walks you through it and you will honestly learn so much. You're grasp of more formal Chinese will increase significantly and it will give you much more confidence in being able to speak on more serious issues in Chinese (but also honestly English too since I really do believe the class help me think about and understand modern issues better in general).

If you're coming from 130a/b, I really encourage you to take Chinese 140a/b! 130a/b starts to scratch the surface of formal Chinese and more "elegant" language, but 140 goes to a far greater depth, giving you tools to handle business situations or conflicts gracefully and politely.  In the past, I was hesitant to discuss controversial topics in Chinese because I felt that I couldn't fully express the complexity of my ideas/perspectives with my somewhat limited vocabulary and sentence structures. After taking this course, I feel much more confident in tackling nuanced and sensitive topics, since I've learned grammar structures and vocab that can help me express my ideas clearly and elegantly.As for the logistics of the course, the teaching staff are absolutely wonderful as always. The lectures are so engaging and touch on many different topics, ranging from pop culture to international relations to Chinese culture, so you'll have many opportunities to practice different kinds of grammar structures and vocabulary. This course does tend to have slightly more assignments than 130 (discussion posts, reading, etc.), but the extra practice is well worth it. All of the assignments and tests are at an appropriate difficulty level; in other words they are difficult enough to challenge you and help you improve, but very manageable and can fit in a busy course schedule (for reference, I spent an average of ~5hr/week most of the time, maybe a couple hours extra on weeks with big essay deadlines). I honestly love the Chinese department so much, and I can't speak about this course highly enough!
subject: Chinese

course_title: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: I can't recommend this course enough! Yu laoshi and Cai laoshi are very kind and super engaging in class. The workload is definitely manageable—while you do get a fair amount, as long as you put effort in, you'll be just fine. And the teachers are always very available and willing to help.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners 002
best_comment: Chinese 140XA is a really fun and engaging class! Every day, I looked forward to the class, especially due to the bond we had formed amongst the class. Some of the topics can be tricky and hard to understand, but the laoshi's are all super nice and friendly, and it made the trek to Vanserg that much more bearable. I highly recommend taking the class, whether it be for citation or just for fun.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Advanced Modern Chinese for High-Proficiency Learners

course_title: Readings and Discussions in Academic and Professional Chinese 001
best_comment: The entire Chinese language program at Harvard is fantastic, and I really recommend taking Chinese classes, even if you feel that it is a large time commitment! The program is well–structured, and you truly do learn a lot.
subject: Chinese
course_title_2023: Readings and Discussions in Academic and Professional Chinese

course_title: The Historiography of Early Chinese History 01
best_comment: This was such an amazing, amazing course! I think the one of the best ways of learning about the world is by learning about a part of the world that you don't know much about. The course is mainly on Western thought toward China and helped me break down preconceived notions about China and "the East." Hands down the best course I've taken at Harvard so far. Professor Puett is actually one of the best people on the planet. He is so kind and understanding. He also has a way of always validating your thoughts even when you feel like they are dumb. As an undergraduate who has taken the class, I would say it's very doable and would highly encourage other undergrads to take the course.

this class is an intriguing foray into the world of Li Yu, as well as into the rich space of theatrical and creative thinking that characterizes the Ming and Qing periods. It does rely heavily on xianqing ouji, which is a must–read for anyone doing Chinese literature as a primary research field, but don't be scared of how weird the book might seem––it's really good!

course_title: Media Cultures in the People's Republic of China 01
best_comment: take it! prof. Li is great!

course_title: Threads: Histories and Theories of Clothing and Fashion 01
best_comment: I highly recommend this course if you are interested in fashion or history. While I didn’t have a strong background in either, the course was an excellent gateway. Every lecture was interesting and I felt like the Professor was always eager to answer our questions or promote discussion. The section is honestly the best part of the course. Getting to view garments in museums or doing hands on fabric dyeing added so much to the experience.
best_gem_comment: This course is definitely a gem of Harvard. The students who take it are so engaged and knowledgeable about fashion across time, and so the class discussions are always lively and participatory (no silent, awkward classroom vibes). Professor McCormick and Carolyn, our TF, also poured so much of their hearts into making the class experience flow super smoothly, and really encouraged us to think across weeks in the course, so it definitely is one to take if you would like to engage in synthesis–level thinking. The course staff were also super reachable outside of class and receptive to student ideas. This is also a really accessible introduction to HAA –– I had never taken an HAA course before taking this course. Take this course if you have any interest in fashion, embodiment, and body.

best_comment: This is a great class if you're interested in the intersection of political science, history, and China. Although the title of this class is the "Cultural Revolution," the material covered in lecture actually spans from early communist China to the beginning of the Reform and Opening Up. Lecture can sometimes be boring, especially if you're not particularly drawn to China. Professor Koss, however, is an excellent lecturer and wonderful person. Definitely go to his office hours. The most important element of this course (grade–wise at least) is the final paper. There is lots of autonomy in choosing your topic, and you can basically write on whatever you want as long as it relates to the Cultural Revolution.

course_title: Historiography of Modern Japan and Korea: Proseminar 01
best_comment: This is an excellent class but requires you to be thoroughly interested and knowledgeable in both Korean and Japanese history at an academic level. Historiography can sometimes feel arcane and deeply academic, so you must enjoy the content or it will be difficult to get through the readings/classes. As much as this is true for all classes, it is particularly true for this one. Most students in the class are masters (RSEA) or early PhD students. The course material and discussion quality reflects the calibre of its students. Hence the readings are long and hard and you will very often feel lost but by the end of the class, it will feel worthwhile in that you will have accumulated a very deep understanding of the different historical arguments surrounding big topics in Korean/Japanese history. That is what this class teaches you: to differentiate between historical arguments made by different authors on the same topic. It teaches you to become a more discerning and critical reader. But to achieve this, you must have a strong foundation in both Korean and Japanese history. Some experience in historiography would be helpful too. If you are interested in doing a PhD / going into academia, this is a good class to take.

course_title: Historiography of Modern Japan and Korea: Proseminar 01
best_comment: This is an excellent class but requires you to be thoroughly interested and knowledgeable in both Korean and Japanese history at an academic level. Historiography can sometimes feel arcane and deeply academic, so you must enjoy the content or it will be difficult to get through the readings/classes. As much as this is true for all classes, it is particularly true for this one. Most students in the class are masters (RSEA) or early PhD students. The course material and discussion quality reflects the calibre of its students. Hence the readings are long and hard and you will very often feel lost but by the end of the class, it will feel worthwhile in that you will have accumulated a very deep understanding of the different historical arguments surrounding big topics in Korean/Japanese history. That is what this class teaches you: to differentiate between historical arguments made by different authors on the same topic. It teaches you to become a more discerning and critical reader. But to achieve this, you must have a strong foundation in both Korean and Japanese history. Some experience in historiography would be helpful too. If you are interested in doing a PhD / going into academia, this is a good class to take.

I would highly recommend Japan BA if you are interested in learning Japanese. The class is particularly diverse in the students who take it. My class came from a variety of the graduate schools, and even undergrad students had diverse interests and reasons for learning Japanese. I came in without having learned Japanese before, and although the learning curve initially is a bit higher than those who have been exposed to the language previously, I truly did not feel hindered or at a disadvantage. This was the most well–thought out, well–planned, course I have ever taken. You will be amazed at how much you learn each week. The quality and joy for learning that Kageyama sensei and our awesome TFs nurtured throughout lecture and section was truly incredible. Another important aspect of the course to note is that there is an abundance of additional resources that perfectly align with the course on the Canvas page. Take advantage of them! The textbook and accompanying app for audio (you can download it for free) matched lecture perfectly and were excellently prepared as well. I have never felt so supported in a course and unlike other courses where the book or reference material doesn't match class, all the units are very systematic and if you ever get confused or need clarification, the book is guaranteed to have the answers to your questions. The course staff also holds "Nihongo Chat Hours" every week if you want more practice speaking or just one–on–one time to review. The course is one you need to dedicate time to, but it will be a rewarding and fun experience. You'll see how deeply Kageyama sensei and your TFs are dedicated toward giving you an authentic, rigorous, and eye–opening experience in learning Japanese language and culture. They are some of the most professional and caring course staff I have had the pleasure of working with, and it shows in how much all of us in class felt we wanted to do our very best for them. Overall, taking Japan BA was an invaluable experience and it's one of those courses that has deeply impacted my continued interest in Japan and for other cultures in general.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: This was hands down my favorite class of the semester. Kageyama–sensei, Sakomura–sensei, and Nakatani–sensei are all fantastic. You will learn so much (and you can "practice" by watching anime!) This is the BEST way to fulfill the language requirement (but it is so much fun so you might end up like me and decide to take it every year from now on and try to study abroad in Japan (on Harvard's money!))Some tips: –if you're bored over the summer before the semester starts, try to learn the Japanese alphabet––hiragana (and katakana) if you have time, you don't need to––they teach you, but knowing it really gives you a leg up, here's a super good website for hiragana: https://www.tofugu.com/japanese/learn–hiragana/ (they also have a katakana one)–don't get behind in the vocab, in addition to the workbook always take time to memorize the vocab––it is so much harder to learn the grammar and understand lecture if you get behind on the vocab, quizlet if your friendAbsolutely take this course, it was so much fun :)
subject: Japanese

best_comment: I cannot reinforce how much you should take this class! Kageyama–sensei is the best Japanese teacher in the world, and she truly cares about each one of her students and will make sure that everyone in her class will succeed (and learn way more Japanese than any other student could ever learn in 3 months).
subject: Japanese

best_comment: The course itself may seem like a big commitment with daily meetings and daily homework assignments, but the spread of the workload across the week makes it much easier to hold yourself accountable to doing all the necessary work to keep up with the class, and even if it can get rigorous at times, you will definitely learn a lot as long as you're willing to put the effort in
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Yagi sensei is a bit quieter than the other senseis, but definitely the nicest :–)
subject: Japanese

best_comment: Another amazing course by the Japanese professors. I've never had a bad day in this class, and I wholeheartedly recommend it to anyone considering taking Japanese. Yagi Sensei and Nakatani Sensei are amazing and their chemistry works so well to create a course that taught me so much over the past semester while being incredibly fun. Be prepared to do a lot of work however: This was a steep increase in difficulty from the previous courses which I could often coast by without doing much at all.
subject: Japanese

best_comment: This course can be a mixed bag because it inherently has to cater widely to the needs of a diverse range of students. The highlights are a real focus on practical competencies like, e.g., formal email writing and turning down/accepting a job offer. Assignments often feels more like busywork than skill–development. Class is spent less on discussion/debate than might be expected for a high–level course.
subject: Japanese

course_title: Readings and Discussion in Japanese Social Sciences 001
best_comment: This is a great course, but be prepared to work hard and stay engaged. Asakura–sensei is incredibly friendly and approachable, so don't be afraid to reach out. You can tell that she puts in a lot of time and effort to prepare the course materials, so definitely take advantage of all the textbook material you're given.
subject: Japanese
course_title_2023: Readings and Discussion in Japanese Social Sciences

course_title: Authorship and Literary Creativity in Early Modern Japan 01
best_comment: Excellent course to take as an extension to history studies or as a field prep for Japanese Literature

This is a great introductory language class. It is really well taught and they make sure you have a good foundation before continuing if you put in the effort. The head instructor as well as the section leaders are great as well.
worse_comment: The course requires a lot of time out of your week in order to prepare for all the weekly quizzes and exams. It is difficult to study for said quizzes and exams because the course (lecture and section) materials are not published onto the Canvas site, and retaking quizzes and exams is not permitted.
subject: Korean

best_comment: If you're interested in Korean or simply looking to fulfill the language requirement, I would really recommend the course!! Professor Kim and all the TFs are so amazing and helpful with whatever you might need, and foster a great environment in class and in section. The class itself isn't too hard, so it's easy to balance with other courses. Definitely take it if you're thinking about it!!
subject: Korean

best_comment: Definitely take this! It's an incredible intensive introduction to the language. Teacher Lee is so nice and supportive. She has high expectations for the class, but that really pushes you to grow. She cares a lot about her students. She even did a letter–writing exercise where we sent our families letters in Korean, and it was honestly so sweet and thoughtful of her to encourage us to apply our learning.
worse_comment: If you are placed into Korean BX, take it. As a senior who never considered taking a language at Harvard, my biggest regret is not having taken this course earlier because there are very few classes that will teach you material that you will carry with you beyond graduation.
subject: Korean

best_comment: Definitely take this class if you're invested in Korean culture! I will say it does take up a lot of time in the schedule (lecture of MWF and section T/TH, so you're in Korean every day lol) but that's why you should definitely make sure you're actually invested first. Besides the time commitment, it's definitely worth taking and your skills improve a lot by the end.  It's pretty content–dense so if you feel like it's a lot to take in at once you're not alone. But definitely reach out to the teachers, they're all super nice and ready to help students all the time!
subject: Korean

best_comment: This class is amazing! The professors are amazing and you will improve a lot, especially in how fluently and naturally you speak. It does take a lot of work and has a decently heavy workload–– you could probably manage it with another heavy class but almost definitely not two other heavy classes. The grading is not necessarily harsh but you're by no means guaranteed an A or A–. Definitely worthwhile to take!
subject: Korean

course_title: Pre-Advanced Modern Korean for High-Proficiency Learners 001
best_comment: This was a good class, and I would recommend it to Korean heritage students who want to challenge themselves to get better at Korean in an accelerated manner. There is a lot of homework – at least one thing is due every day of class. Although the homework isn't particularly "hard", it does take up a lot of time all added up, so keep that in mind. The speaking sections were very helpful, and special in that you get direct feedback after just speaking! I liked how this class focused on our needs and the teacher tailored the curriculum to help us learn the most. I did take some issue with the communication aspects of this class. Some assignments were in the syllabus but not mentioned again, and sometimes there was conflicting messaging on Canvas or no place to upload assignments. As it is an intense language class, there wasn't much lenience, which was frustrating at times. Overall, though, I enjoyed my experience as it helped me 1) get better at Korean 2) make Korean friends in a small class setting.
subject: Korean
course_title_2023: Pre-Advanced Modern Korean for High-Proficiency Learners

best_comment: Take this class!!! This is the best class I have ever taken. Professor Park is truly the most wonderful and kind instructor ever. You will not regretting taking this class.

My background: had never taken an econ class before; international student; more interested in theory (Social Studies) than in more quantitative social sciences (not econ concentrator)– Pro (different engagement levels): During the semester, you don't have to put too much effort if you're not 100% interested in the class. You have to separate time every week to do the PSETs (which are not very long, but the lecture doesn't prepare you to tackle the questions I felt, so it requires a bit of struggling to find out how to do it), and do some other fairly easy assignments such as 500–word essays, small debate, etc. You do have to take time to study for the midterm and final, though, since it's a lot of content to cover.  But apart from that, you can dedicate as much as you want, basically. Some people go to every in–person lecture, PSET collab section, in–person review sessions, special events, office hours, etc. I wasn't this connected with course, but you can make your way in it as you prefer. You can make it a relaxed course and then cram for 4 days for the final. It works. – Pro/grow (connection with the content): Sometimes the content seemed boring/superficial to me, but after the end of the semester (and studying for the final exam), being able to look back in perspective, I feel like I learned interesting and useful things. It's less of a critical space than I wanted to investigate the assumptions, though, but taking it in my first semester was helpful to have this view towards my other classes and allow me to have more perspective into my interest in econ. – Grow (environment): Personally the environment wasn't very intellectually stimulating for me. People are not actively present in sections, you hear everything in the whole econ major stereotype such as advocacy for legal organ selling, etc. If these are your type of people you can perhaps feel more connected than I did.  It's good though that it's a big first–year class, so there's all the adrenaline of entering Sanders for the first lecture, etc. – Pro (material): There's a lot of material to study from. It's very self–explanatory. There's also lots of help. The course is very well structured. Overall, I don't regret taking at all! If you're more interested in it than I was, you might love it, since I already liked it a lot!
worse_comment: Some people fiend over this class & I don't get the hype at all!!! The class is fairly easy, so long as you do your best to watch the lectures & read the textbook as needed. However, I thought the class was pretty underwhelming and it convinced me I have 0 interest in econ. A lot of the content feels like random small details that they throw at you to try to make the applications seem relevant, but this is not super effective when the foundations are not taught well. Most of the psets are on models & graphs, but these applications are barely covered in lecture, not super well covered in the textbook, and sections often feel very disconnected from the rest of the class (random debates and essays lol). Also, mandatory unit reviews/exams sucked the soul out of me and single–handedly ruined my week whenever I had to take them. Anyway, take this class if you wanna convince yourself you hate ec :D
subject: Economics
