subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this class! I think it's a very different experience to take ECON 10B off–cycle, when there are just a few dozen students and not hundreds of students. You can get a lot more individualized attention and ask questions in lecture, and it feels like a really nice community. I also think it's important to know that you don't need a background in micro in order to take macro. Maybe it would make things a little easier to have taken an economics class before, but I thought this was totally manageable without micro, so I wish someone had assured me of that earlier so I didn't have to worry about it.Overall, I had a really wonderful experience in this class! Understanding macro even at a basic level makes me feel so much stronger. If you take this class, you actually understand at an intuitive level how the labor market works, and what it actually means when someone says the dollar's getting stronger, and how the Fed will fight inflation, and why some countries are so much richer than others. I feel like I have a much more granular and thoughtful understanding of the world now. Also, if Andres is teaching it again, then definitely take it, because he's so knowledgeable and funny and cares about his students a lot! I'm really glad I took this class, I really couldn't recommend it more highly.
worse_comment: I will preface this by saying that I think a lot of the problems with the course occurred because it was being taught off–cycle. While Professor Maggi clearly cares about the material, this class was extremely disorganized. Tfs were never present in class, few office hours were offered, section did not consist of strengthening knowledge about material (but rather, reviewing problem sets that we had already turned in the week prior). Problem sets and exams didn't do a great job of testing knowledge about the material. However, this was the first time this class has been offered off–cycle, and I'm sure that it will be better if offered again in the future.
subject: Economics

course_title: Personal Finance: Making Better Decisions and Building a Better Financial System 001
best_comment: Professor Campbell is such a great and thoughtful instructor! He truly cares about students' learning and comprehension of the material. This class emphasized how much financial literacy can change people's lives and the course staff was super dedicated to making sure that we have access to the best information on the topic and the best instruction. This is one of the most useful classes at Harvard. Take it!
worse_comment: Not as gem–y as it sounds, the psets can be quite difficult, so make sure to go to office hours. But after all the struggles, you will actually learn something!
best_gem_comment: this class is super good in providing knowledge that is very practical and applicable to real–life. it is not necessarily easy or a gem though, sometimes the p sets are frustratingly poorly worded/ difficult/ nit picky but overall if you try you can get a good grade and learn some really practical info.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Personal Finance: Making Better Decisions and Building a Better Financial System

best_comment: Take this class! Seminars are so fun, engaging, and a great way to learn in a small group setting from a wonderful professor
subject: Economics

best_comment: Kiran is the best!!! She will go above and beyond to help you, regardless of how busy she is. I was struggling a lot with my final paper and always felt incredibly supported by her and never embarrassed to ask for help. The in–class discussions were pretty fruitful and helped me understand the course material better. Feedback on assignments really helped me understand how to write for economics. I could definitely see how this course can convince people to want to write a thesis—it offers a great preview of the research process, and it breaks down the pieces of a research paper pretty well. Sometimes the assignment due dates felt very rushed and last–minute, so make sure you start everything early to give yourself ample time to brainstorm ideas and make everything look good. All in all, I'm pretty grateful for how much this class taught me in regards to research and development economics, and I owe my positive experience to Kiran for sure.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This class is fantastic but be prepared to do a lot of work. Professor Felter is amazing and really cares about his students. He tells great stories and has cool insights from his career as a lawyer. There are a LOT of readings though and papers to write almost every week alongside the course wide psets. It definitely is not a light class, especially if you want to get the most out of it and the discussions.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This is fantastic class that will demand a lot from you, but will also give you a lot. Definitely assume this class will take up a lot of your time, but know that the more you put into it, the more you will get out of the class. There is a lot of writing, but it is very helpful practice and Prof. Felter gives you tons of helpful comments. And make sure that you go to office hours for the R/Stata PSets, the OH staff are very helpful.
subject: Economics

best_comment: This was my favourite class this semester. Class discussions were engaging, the selection of readings was varied and always interesting, and Cirrus did an amazing job at guiding the conversation and helping students through the process of writing an economics paper. Highly recommend it to anyone interested in technology and economics!
subject: Economics

course_title: Economics of Work and Family : Junior Seminar 001
best_comment: This class is a little more work than it is advertised as (due to the weekly response papers) but still very interesting and fun. Professor Goldin is an amazing scholar and it was a privilege to be able to learn from her and learn about/discuss pertinent economic issues with her. However, I will note that this class is more lecture–based than most small courses and does not involve a ton of discussion between students. I did learn a lot regardless and appreciated feedback from Professor Goldin and our TF, Grace, on my academic ideas. Great experience!
best_gem_comment: A fantastic junior seminar. This class will make you appreciate economics as a discipline so much more. Also, Claudia is a gem of a professor; if you’re an Econ student, don’t miss the opportunity to take a class with her.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Economics of Work and Family : Junior Seminar

best_comment: Only take if you're prepared for a good bit of work and have an idea in mind
subject: Economics

best_comment: Definitely helpful to have 985 while writing Econ senior thesis
subject: Economics

best_comment: Kiran is the absolute best thesis preceptor out there who will make sure you are on track and push you while making you feel comfortable and assured throughout the way.  The class camaraderie that develops throughout is also great, and Kiran was part of helping foster that. Also love her clementine and brownie snacks!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Writing a thesis is by far the most rewarding project I have done in college. It is very empowering to apply all of your learnings from past classes to a research question that genuinely interests you, and driving the research for it.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Martin's section is great and you will get plenty of good feedback. This class is required but is actually really helpful in terms of the structure it gives to the thesis process.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Slavik is a very thoughtful, effective seminar leader.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Slavik is a very thoughtful, effective seminar leader.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Writing a thesis was the best decision I made at Harvard. Thank you, Judd and Thomas, your support and guidance throughout the writing process!
subject: Economics

best_comment: Writing a thesis was the best decision I made at Harvard. Thank you, Judd and Thomas, your support and guidance throughout the writing process!
subject: Economics

best_comment: i really liked having both a humanities and economics element to this class, but the material was not novel. if you have taken economics classes before and are a well–read citizen, a lot of this class will be semi–repetitive. it did cover important topics and would therefore be a great survey class (and perhaps a great gened), but the assignments had very little to do with what we did in class or the exams, and required you to know very niche readings (out of a unreasonably long syllabus). a few of the guest lecturers were great but lecture itself was slow and hard to engage with.

i really liked having both a humanities and economics element to this class, but the material was not novel. if you have taken economics classes before and are a well–read citizen, a lot of this class will be semi–repetitive. it did cover important topics and would therefore be a great survey class (and perhaps a great gened), but the assignments had very little to do with what we did in class or the exams, and required you to know very niche readings (out of a unreasonably long syllabus). a few of the guest lecturers were great but lecture itself was slow and hard to engage with.

This comment is coming from a STEM heavy major, so take it as you will.This was my first economics class at Harvard (or ever). I didn't have a good understanding of microecon before (except for just knowing what supply–demand is), but this class definitely improved my understanding of it. I definitely recommend taking this class and I wouldn't worry about taking ec10a before this (unless you need it for concentration requirements).  The only math you need is knowing derivatives. I definitely recommend reading the book a lot since I mostly relied on the book to answer the MCQs and it increased my understanding of the subject a lot. I also recommend having a nice pset group that you can take the MCQ with since this year the quizzes were really confusing. Go to Office Hours for the LP and you should be good. They also had EQCs this year which are also helpful on top of office hours.
worse_comment: Do not take this class with Bockyo. Literally the worst professor. His lectures are so boring like the most boring I have ever taken at Harvard. Don’t get me started on the exams. I studied for over 70 hours for the exams and if you don’t know one part of the long problems, then you won’t get the rest of them. It’s so dumb. I’ve never had a class with exams like that. If you don’t get one part then you can’t do the other parts??? What is that??? That’s not even testing knowledge. It’s repetitive and not comprehensive. Worst class. I got As in Ec10b and ec10a and econometrics and I think I’m literally gonna get a C because I couldn’t do one part of the final, which means I couldn’t do any of the parts on the question, which means 1/3 of my grade on the final is for sure knocked off! Exams must be fixed! So many people I spoke to agreed with me and I’m sure more than half of the people in the course are not okay with exam formats.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Please make sure you know single variable calculus. Partial credit is a real thing, so once you get over the derivatives you can really focus on the content. The course was actually super challenging, but that made it so satisfying to actually come out (moderately) understanding things.
worse_comment: This class is awful. Prepare to get gritty and struggle. The professor this past year was brutal and made everything ridiculously hard. I wish that the people in the future have it better because this was literally as bad as it gets
subject: Economics

best_comment: Taking this class along with Stat 110 was the biggest mistake of my sophomore year. This class consumed my life. Once i stopped caring about the psets (which for before the midetrm I went to OH to complete) and completed them on my own, my time dedicated to this class was better but not by much. The lectures are extremely poorly structured, hard to follow and there were rare moments where I actually derived anything out of them. The book (up until the midterms), CA lecture notes, CAs and (out of luck, thank goodness) my TF helped me make it through this class. The book covers content only up till the midterm which was extremely useful for building conceptual knowledge but post the midterm, as the content (in my opinion) got harder, that stopped and so did my attempt at trying to better undertsadnd concepts. The CA lecture notes post the midterms were extremely helpful as the slides in singularity are grossly ineffective.  My section was the only reason I could survived this class. My TF  singlehandedly carried the class and paced the sections in an excellent way, ensuring that students have a strong conceptual understanding of the concepts. I wish he could also have that influence on the lecture component of the class becuase if it was possible in sections to make the class appear well structured as he made it, I’m sure lectures could have been designed better too. The psets are unnecesarily hard, the modelling projects were nightmares. The lack of feedback on the same, the openendedess, ambiguity and lack of support (even the CAs did not have access to answer keys) made the projects AWFUL.  I survived the class and want to say that I derived great friendships and (some) apppreciation for the way of approaching economics via math but hoped that the class was better sturtcured for all my peers and I to have had an overall better experience.
worse_comment: Do not take this class. Absolutely terrible. Everything is unclear, you get no help, you will have to pull all nighters and consider leaving the exam half way through because you literally cannot start working on any of the remaining questions. You know it's bad when you see 50 students staring into the wall during an exam that is supposed to be extremely stressful. The midterm has 3 parts worth 100 points in total. One True/false/uncertain where you can get 24 points. You will likely get somewhere around 15. Then, there are 2 math problems where each question is dependent on the previous question. To get an A– on the midterm you needed 31. So yeah, most of us left the exam having answered the true/false and tried our best to get a few partial credit points here and there, leaving most of the exam blank because we could simply not do any of the questions. This is a very unfair way of testing. It meant that a few points made a huge difference. One true/false question would determine your "grade" on the midterm. There was almost no distribution since everyone left the exam mostly blank. I understand the value in having a difficult exam to be able to differentiate between all students rather than having an exam where everyone gets 100. But this is taking it too far. All the hard work and studying we put in was for nothing since we didn't get to show anything that we can actually do. I sat there and had done the true/false and then got stuck on question a/b on both math problems. I got so mad I wanted to just throw my exam in the trash and leave. so so so bad. It's rude. And the professor even seemed to enjoy it when he discussed it in class later. Yes, we get it, you understand this perfectly but there is nothing funny about students feeling miserable and failing their exams. FYI, I think I will get an A in this class simply because I happened to have taken an elective in one of the topics that happened to show up on the final exam a lot. I am also a math concentrator.
subject: Economics

course_title: A Libertarian Perspective on Economic and Social Policy 001
best_comment: This is a great course! This is probably both the lowest workload course I’ve ever taken and the one that has been most relevant to everyday discussions/beliefs.  Basically no work, but if you want to, you can learn so much and the lectures are really interesting.  This class definitely made me think about my economic and political views on various issues.  Miron is a great lecturer and encourages people to question/challenge him.  I feel like I better understand what my preferred level of government intervention is from taking this class, which is cool.
worse_comment: although the content covered is very intersting, the lectures are not very engaging and only few people gopro: low effort needed
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class! Probably the easiest Ec elective you are going to find and made getting a secondary in Ec super easy. Not as much of a gem as I was expecting but if you make sure you know the empirical evidence from the readings as well as section and lecture material going into the exams you will do great!
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: A Libertarian Perspective on Economic and Social Policy

course_title: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems 001
best_comment: This class lowkey sucks. I was pumped about taking the course after reading the description but it sorely disappointed. The first half of the class is about Roland and his peers' research into injustice and discrimination in America. I respect their work and thought it was decently interesting, just be prepared that this is half the class and the midterm asks a ton of nitty gritty questions from deep in the readings. The second half of the class is about "VC" , and if you know absolutely nothing about the structure / functionality of VC / PE firms and are interested, it may help you connect some dots about how it works. If you already know a decent amount about that stuff, you won't learn anything new or interesting most likely. While I am really interested in VC / PE, the course is fully, 100% focused on IMPACT investing. So be prepared... I just personally think a lot of it is BS and I'd rather spend my time learning about how to actually make money and develop pure investment IQ and then hopefully use that to help people. That is just me though, if you are very interested in helping people over making returns, check this class out. The final is fun if you think of an idea you care about, but it's basically just a long pitch deck on a company you make up that has to be economically profitable AND have a social impact. The actual content of the class is not horrible by any means, but Roland and Jamina are horrible at managing this class. Our midterm format changed like 3 times and also neither of them ever respond / are helpful over email. Grade wise I think it is a tough class to get an A in. Will have to work pretty hard on the midterm and final for an A–, B+ is pretty do–able if you are somewhat competent. Overall, it's aight. Not the worst class ever, but probably not as good as what you're imagining it to be.
worse_comment: This class is SO DISORGANIZED AND CAUSED SO MUCH STRESS. I took the class because Fryer said there would be no midterm exam and that both the midterm and final were projects. But then he made the midterm a test, but he said it would be take home. then a days before the exam, he changed it randomly to in person no open notes– which is crazy . Then he retracted it and pushed it to a week later and made it in person and open notes, and then 2 days before the new exam, he said we will only be allowed 2 pages of WRITTEN NOTES– which is CRAZY. then he retracted it lol to be in person open notes. BUT THEN the exam was SO DIFFICULT AND NOTHING like what he taught in class. the modeling questions on the quiz were NOT taught in class, and you can’t do the exam with an EXCEL SHEET. most people got 50% on the exam (and FRYER said that it would be “SUPERRR EASY” and he wouldn’t give us ANY indication on how the exam would be). And then for our final pitch project, he said it needed to be 50 ish pages long, which is fine but he gives NO RUBRIC OR INSTRUCTIONS. It was so horrible (the class) and i don’t recommend it. Though i think i did get an A, maybe he curves the class, i don’t know. but take the course at ur caution
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Using Markets to Solve Social Problems

course_title: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior 001
best_comment: The class is pretty easy, but the material can be a bit dry/slow at times. Overall though, the content can be quite interesting and gives a great interface between social behavior and game theory.
worse_comment: Go to section, especially if you don't have a strong math background
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior

course_title: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior 001
best_comment: The class is pretty easy, but the material can be a bit dry/slow at times. Overall though, the content can be quite interesting and gives a great interface between social behavior and game theory.
worse_comment: Go to section, especially if you don't have a strong math background
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Game Theory with Applications to Social Behavior

course_title: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies 001
best_comment: Take this class!! You will learn cool ways to mathematically model real–life social problems and also get the opportunity to apply the modelling skills to a problem that interests you. Yannai is a wonderful professor who is passionate about his material and incredibly accessible, definitely enriching the course experience. Weekly time commitments tend to be very low, which means it's a good course to balance with courses that have a lot of regular assignments. Just make sure to attend lectures, be willing to tackle problems using maths (though there can be substantial maths at the Math 21a/Stat 110 level, Yannai makes sure to explain them clearly), and enjoy the experience! Could not recommend enough if you're looking for an interesting econ elective without worrying too much about time commitment.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Incentives in the Wild: from Tanking in Sports to Mining Cryptocurrencies

best_comment: Ec 1123 is definitely not as hard as people make it out to be. I got worried when I read the previous year's Q reviews, but it was definitely not as difficult as some reviews made it out to seem. You definitely need a really strong statistics background (either Stat 100/104 level or AP Stat, if you remember enough and are willing to spend some time at the beginning of the semester reviewing the stats concepts — note that Stat 110 won't help you at all here). Don't let the Stata element scare you away — it's definitely not too difficult to learn, and you only need it for one question per pset. If you have questions about Stata or any material, make sure to go to the TF office hours (especially Salvador!! (I'd recommend Lucas too but he's graduating this year)). Prof. Pettenuzzo is also really helpful, and is very willing to explain any concepts/pset questions if you ask.Maybe the best advice I can give is to read the textbook!!!! I read through the first half of the textbook before the midterm and the second half before the final, and found that it really helpfully covers all of the material from lecture while providing a bit more reasoning and packaging the material slightly differently (so you can improve your understanding of the content).Oh and also go to section!! It's not required, but you'll find that it's really helpful because it does a great job of distilling the lecture material and giving you the content that will be the most important for the psets.
worse_comment: Stay on top of the problem sets because the exams are difficult.
subject: Economics

best_comment: There were many strengths in the course. I think the main strength was associated with the content and how the information in the class was critical for people wanting to be economists or who are interested in quantitative social sciences. I appreciated not just learning how to do something, but also delving into the theory and the reasoning behind why economists do things the way they do (on topics relating to data), making explicit the assumptions that are made and the weaknesses behind given methods. However, I wished that at times, we focused more on the big picture (i.e. applications) and were less focused on the mathematics.  I also think the Professor was another strength of the course. I thought that he presented information in a clear and logical way (and encouraged questions), generated enthusiasm for the class, and was very approachable.  I think it would have been helpful if there were more course materials besides the notes. The Professor presented the notes in lecture by writing on the board, but if there were more materials for this class (eg videos, a textbook, etc) that would be helpful for reinforce your understanding of the content.
worse_comment: This is a hard class. It’s not super time intensive until you get to the exams, which are brutal. The most important thing is to not fall behind—don’t skip lecture (which isn’t recorded) and go to section. There are so few resources to get back on track if you miss out on a topic. The notes aren’t helpful at all if you’re missing out on the underlying intuition.  The exams also look nothing like the homework questions or the notes, so it was easier to prepare for the final, knowing what to expect, but the midterm was awful.  avoid this class if you can.
subject: Economics

course_title: Authoritarian Superpower: The Political Economy of Modern China 001
best_comment: I don't think I have ever learned more in a class at Harvard than I have through Econ 1133. The course provides an extremely effective walkthrough of China's domestic systems (e.g., politics, economics, ethnic relations), and I found its lessons extremely interesting. I particularly enjoyed the response papers, as each one allowed students to become well–informed on a subject of great importance.The greatest asset to the course, however, is its teaching staff: Professor Yang is clearly one of the great rising talents within the realm of economics, and it is a sincere privilege to have learned from such a brilliant mind. I was also extremely impressed with my section teaching fellow, Hemanth Asirvatham, who demonstrated an excellent command of knowledge on China, and was highly effective at eliciting enthusiasm from students in section.
worse_comment: The response papers are subjective and vary and the class didn't provide any good examples after they updated the guidelines. Stay on top of the response papers and study for the final and this class is a gem.

course_title: Closed Borders and Crowded Buses: The Economics of Human Mobility 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! One of my favorite ec electives I've taken at this school. First and foremost – Gabe Kreindler is amazing. Really smart and incredibly kind/knowledgable. Topic is really interesting, and by the end of the course you're up to speed on CURRENT research across a number of really interesting mobility and migration economics topics. What are the economic gains from international migration? Domestic migration? What is the impact of increasing access to public transit on the labor market? etc etc. all really interesting things, and the empirical research is methodologically interesting as well. You develop a much better understanding of empirical study design, IVs, discrete choice models. This course is organized in a really satisfying way which feels a little different from other ec electives I've taken. Most of the meat of the course is in learning about empirical research and study design. Therefore, the class is organized more around discussing tons of different recent empirical papers, rather than learning a ton of theory and maybe reading one or two empirical papers. Limited background is necessary for success. If you come in having taken probability, stats, and micro theory, you will have a good time. P sets are easy; exams are very doable.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Closed Borders and Crowded Buses: The Economics of Human Mobility

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!! It is not quite an economics gem, but it's 4 psets, a midterm, and a final. These are the most fair exams I have ever experienced, where you are asked to use concepts from class and problem sets. Stefanie Stantcheva is a wonderful professor who is great to learn from, and the TF, Antonio, is great at explaining math! This course is my favorite undergrad course I've taken so far.Make sure you have a decent understanding of micro and/or derivatives before you take the course, though, but nothing should be more difficult than 1010a concepts+stuff, just applied in different context. 1011a is helpful, but definitely not required!

This class was enjoyable — the workload is super reasonable, and you get to hear lots of great real–world stories from respected policymakers with experience at the highest level.  Lectures are the most enjoyable part of the class, but also don't have a ton of relevance to the exams; for that, make sure you go to sections. The course content is focused on the highest–profile topics in U.S. economic policy, and they do a good job keeping it up to date, especially with how much economic thinking has shifted since COVID. However, the course doesn't go too deep on any particular policy, and it's not super theory–heavy.
worse_comment: Topics were cool but exams are hard esp with lots of HKS students so curve isn't great. Sections were a little chaotic with assignments and not having materials posted all the time to refer to after.
best_gem_comment: This is a great class!! Not difficult but very rewarding. You learn about lots of interesting economic and policy–oriented topics that are extremely relevant to today's world, and both professors are extremely experienced/knowledgable. Lectures are interesting and debates between the two professors especially are a gem. Exams are not difficult at all if you follow along section material and do the practice exams beforehand. The policy memo is also a great learning experience. One thing I would say is not ideal is that TFs can be hard to reach and don't host office hours often.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Take this course!!! Professor Kotz is a great professor and you can tell that he's very passionate about what he's teaching and genuinely cares about his students. The response paper and final paper may seem daunting at first, but there is a lot of support from the teaching team through office hours, so long as you reach out to them! The academic conference is also not something you should be afraid of, but instead use as an opportunity to get useful feedback from the teaching team and your peers! Overall, I feel like I learned a lot in this course about the economics behind the EU, as well as really interesting details about current events in Europe. I definitely recommend this course to anyone who is either a. interested in economics' extension to Europe, or b. trying to find an interesting and fulfilling way to complete the econ writing requirement.
subject: Economics

best_comment: To me, one of the most unique and important things I gained from this course is how to think about and explain complex problems with immediately understandable analogies––this is perhaps the most important general learning tool I have taken away, and it is one of the key hallmarks of Larry's wit and brilliance. The second major thing I learned is how to understand and react to weekly macroeconomic and financial markets changes: things like new data releases on inflation, the JOLTS survey, BLS data, etc. I most appreciated the opportunity to sit in on Larry's teaching and hear him reason through all the current macro bombs that happened each week, the broader macro questions we were asking, his work on secular stagnation, his take/explanation on the papers of others, and his live feedback to the students that presented almost every week. This constant exercise of hearing Larry speak and reason through his thoughts and analogies was the MOST valuable takeaway from this course, and would not be received in any other economics experience elsewhere. It was a great privilege to get such constant, consistent, and timely live feedback from Larry and Paul on our presentations, as well as to have them advise us on one paper that we are working towards throughout the entire semester. The weekly student presentations on the papers we read were important as students should have a frequent exercise in the presentation of academic papers; it enforces close engagement with the material, solidifies understanding, and points out areas of confusion. However, most of the papers were over our heads, and it is certain that most students did not have a strong understanding of the academic papers. I wish we had more pedagogical experiences learning to understand these papers from Larry and Paul, after students presented, instead of us trying to make sense of the papers (often the blind leading the blind). If we could increase paper understanding to 80%+, then that would be an incredible achievement and benefit to future students. Lastly, like my peers have said, this course would benefit from an equalization of the floor at the onset of the class by having Larry and Paul teach about foundational macro finance principals in the first few weeks. The students that were not in FED challenge or did not have the privileges of joining FED challenge had a harder learning curve to makeup.
worse_comment: Don't take this course. Prof Summers just sits there and lectures at you for two hours each week about any topic he wants. There is no structure, no discussion, no feedback on assignments. It was very disappointing and I do not think I took anything away from this class that was useful. I really would not recommend anyone take it unless you want to sit in a room for two hours each week (sometimes more as the class often went over time) and listen to Prof Summers discuss anything he may want that day.
subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: This is not an easy course by any means, but it is an excellent class. Professor Antras delivers very interesting lectures and Anhua (who was the TF during my time) was excellent at explaining the mathematical concepts in the course. Don't miss sections if you want to do well. If you want to learn about international trade, and are willing to put in the work, you should definitely take this course.
worse_comment: The most annoying thing about the course is I felt that it wasn't HARD – the content was quite straightforward throughout. However, the grading scheme for PSETS/exams seem a little off (you can lose many points easily for not memorizing a tiny detail on a slide, which I feel like is rather unfair for assessing students' understanding).
subject: Economics

best_comment: Definitely take this class –– workload is manageable and you just get SO much out of it. Prof. Lee is the best lecturer I've had thus far –– he's super engaging (even though a 3–hr class seems intimidating, time really flies in his class), explains everything REALLY well (and some stuff was confusing! but I really think a lot of this knowledge will stick in my head for a while), and is overall just super knowledgable, really cool, and excited about the field. This falls easily in my top 3 classes I've taken here. Loved getting to learn more about imperfect competition and game theory stuff, and had some really cool units on various topics (e.g., advertising, innovation, network effects...)
worse_comment: The content in this course is difficult and the exams are hard. Take this course if you can keep yourself engaged the whole time in lecture.
best_gem_comment: Professor Lee makes this class a gem — you get so so much out of it without having to put that much time in because he's such an effective lecturer and a great person to talk to in general. There is no busy work, and all the lecture content is interesting, helpful for understanding markets, applicable to current events, etc. Do not let the 3–hour lecture scare you, and yes move around your class schedule to make this one fit. It is so worth it if you liked micro, want some an Econ elective that's a pset class (but not Ec 1011 level math by any means) with a medium amount of work.

best_comment: Really excellent class. People complain that Ed focuses too much on grind algebra w/o intuition. Maybe a little, but far less so than in 1011a, which is itself still a worthwhile class. More conceptual than people tend to give it credit for, and game theory is a lot of fun.
worse_comment: There is so much content and it comes so fast that you will invariably fall behind during lecture. Do not worry. The primary purpose of the midterm is to have you review for the midterm. I learned most of the content in the two weeks before the exam. Do not try to write down the calculus with Ed. It is not possible. Instead, try to get the broad strokes of what steps he is taking and if you have time try it at home. The verbals are really hard, and there is no right answer. The first purpose of the verbal is to set up the problem (who are the agents? what are they optimizing? what is in the budget set? etc.). The second purpose of the verbal is to get a model where you can say ~something~. Answer the question that your model can answer, even if it isn't exactly the question asked in the problem set. I wouldn't worry so much about making the model general, at least to start. Focus on tractability and then go from there.
subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: grad macro is incredibly different from undergrad macro, and in a way, I like it. 2010c is significantly more microfounded than 101xb, and there are zero traces of solow/is–lm. that's because so much of frontier macro involves massive undertakings that require a lot of mathematical priors – microfounding gives rise to distributional concerns, which then involves integrals and markov chains and transition functions; thinking rigorously about 'evolution across time' gives rise to dynamic programming and intertemporal optimization. my sense is that 2010c (both David and Adrien's part) focus on developing these concepts and share landmark models through the lens of these tools. I enjoyed this very much, because it means that you are not simply rote memorizing the outcomes of the permanent income hypothesis, you are internalizing all the assumptions that are made in the model and understand how to derive it on pen and paper. it means that you get to learn a set of skills that you can use on any inter–temporal optimization problem, and can even extend it to situations with many individuals making personal decisions that aggregate in some way to give solutions that are not immediately apparent. it also means that it's much easier to accept the assumptions as compared to undergrad macro – but beginning at a lower level of aggregation also means a lot more work to get the aggregate results you desire.and 2010c is a lot of work! at the same time, taking it as an undergrad, I never particularly felt at any point that it was inaccessible to me, it's just that the tone of grad classes is just really different than undergrad classes. eg. grad classes like 2010c just keep on going and the pace is frenetic, so you have to be able to devote time and energy to keep up with that
worse_comment: If you want to do macro, investing time into coding problems is very worth it. Algebra not so much, given reasonable effort.
subject: Economics

subject: Economics

best_comment: Professor Avery is an excellent instructor. He made this material substantially less painful than I believe it otherwise would have been. As a result,  I learned a lot, and the class meaningfully exceeded my expectations for it, but otherwise, broadly speaking, what you see is what you get. It's grad micro with an applied (rather than theoretical) emphasis. It's taught well, but even so, ymmv.
worse_comment: This is a very difficult but necessary course if you plan to make an economics concentration in your PhD.
subject: Economics

best_comment: The course is a very helpful survey of frontier behavioral economics topics. Lectures give detailed intuition, and the problem sets are useful in solidifying understanding. I strongly recommend it for students interested in behavioral theory.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Great course for a quant requirement, not too technical, so I think it's useful for most social sciences
subject: Economics

best_comment: This is a course based on Gary Chamberlain's legendary notes, whose writings are notoriously dense, yet there is a reason why this course is one of the foundational Harvard Econ experiences, since it establishes a rigorous framework to then be able to follow discussions in contemporary econometrics. For undergrads considering the course, I would say that it is a great survey of 'serious' econometrics, but it requires very good familiarity with empirical research such that you can motivate on your own why these methods would be useful. It's a tough course but Elie is a very understanding and dedicated teacher. Also, Chris Walker was the best TF I've seen at Harvard in my 4 years.
worse_comment: This is a difficult course, and the language of the course is very different from other quantitative classes so be prepared to learn a different framework for statistical arguments that you may have seen before.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Anna was a great lecturer and brought her expertise to the material. The class also very useful to people outside of macro and finance and made you more comfortable with many statistical concepts. She's just visiting for the year and not staying forever/teaching it next year, and it's a terrible shame!
worse_comment: This is a wonderful course on time–series econometrics exposing students to a variety of tools widely used in the macro literature. As such, any student who is interested in macro economics and does not have prior knowledge in time–series analysis should take it.One note: This is a course that focuses on techniques. Hence, it does not go as much into practical economic identification issues in the literature (e.g., what kinds of unobserved shocks can be a problem to invertibility in a typical VAR setting trying to infer IRFs to monetary policy shocks, etc.). For that, one needs to take a macro course.
subject: Economics

course_title: Empirical Research in Labor and Public Economics 001
best_comment: Great course for students interested in applied micro.
The class is a great overview of main research fields within political economy and is definitely useful for anybody who might be interested in doing research in the field
The class is a great overview of main research fields within political economy and is definitely useful for anybody who might be interested in doing research in the field

course_title: Spatial Mobility and Development: Evidence and Quantitative Models 001
best_comment: 1. If you are interested in any development related topics, including transportation, schooling, immigration, climate adaptation infrastructure, etc., this course  covers frontier research in these topics in a spatial setting. 2. You can learn how to build structural models, how to estimate them, how to conduct empirical analyses, and how to use GIS models, some useful math/modelling tricks. Very worthwhile!3. The instructor (Gabriel) and the TF (Tilman) teach well–organized materials very clearly. 4. I feel the course is very inspiring.
worse_comment: Coding skills are needed, otherwise problem sets are not that doable.
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Spatial Mobility and Development: Evidence and Quantitative Models

best_comment: The lectures are long and relatively dry but very comprehensive with useful notes to look back to later. Comprehensive intro to empirical macro but not much intuition in the first half, which is on methods and is pretty dry.
subject: Economics

course_title: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy I 001
best_comment: an overall great class that could use some tweaks – the lack of psets were a bit scary since it was difficult to keep track of how well I understood what was going on (a lot was going on), and the final was a bit over–harsh since they tested problem–solving a new extension, which we did not practice for. but the greats were great. how do we decide as a society what the tax rate should be? what should the tax rate be with respect to income? can we set the tax rate upon different characteristics other than income? how do we socially weight the utility of different members of societies? how do we make sure that people are not avoiding taxes? how do we make sure that tax codes don't incentivize laziness? within each of these questions are packed a great deal of political combustiveness, and public debate tends to drown out what we set out to do – to figure out what best to do as a society. this class will help you put the policy beliefs you hold in your mind into math, and maybe your opinion will change or perhaps it will stay the same, but either way, you will have a much greater precision of thought in thinking about issues of justice, equity and redistribution
subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Public Economics and Fiscal Policy I

best_comment: Would highly recommend taking this course at MIT instead of Harvard. The course is unorganized and very difficult. You will have to spend many hours outside of class teaching yourself all of the material. The only way to succeed is to teach yourself everything and treat lecture like a review session/time to ask questions (although questions are also sometimes received in a hostile way). Overall, stay clear and take this somewhere else!!!
worse_comment: Problem sets can take a lot of time and can be torturous.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Would highly recommend taking this course at MIT instead of Harvard. The course is unorganized and very difficult. You will have to spend many hours outside of class teaching yourself all of the material. The only way to succeed is to teach yourself everything and treat lecture like a review session/time to ask questions (although questions are also sometimes received in a hostile way). Overall, stay clear and take this somewhere else!!!
worse_comment: Problem sets can take a lot of time and can be torturous.
subject: Economics

best_comment: There is a lot of fast–paced math; it is a difficult course. It comprehensively covers a lot of asset pricing so is a good intro to the field, but if you’re not personally interested in asset pricing it can just become a lot of math with little motivating intuition by the time you’re on step 10+ of the math.
subject: Economics

best_comment: I took this class as an undergrad. It definitely took more work than an average class, but with a strong interest in finance I found the work to be highly rewarding and great preparation for graduate studies. I recommend that if you decide to take this class as an undergrad, you should be highly comfortable with microeconomics, econometrics and mathematics, and I believe some background knowledge of topics in corporate finance is also needed.
subject: Economics

best_comment: Readings are helpful, but not necessary. If I did this over again I would have started on the paper proposal in earnest earlier; the deadline creeps up quickly at a busy time at the end of the semester.

course_title_2023: Early Stage Research and Discussions on Deep Learning and Big Data in Economics

best_comment: If you are interested in child psychology and the experimental design of psychological studies, this is a helpful course. The readings are interesting, although not very necessary to complete outside of class since they are all reviewed during lecture. The lectures can feel a bit dry sometimes, but Harris is definitely knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the subject material. The essays are actually very interesting to write, and allow a great deal of flexibility and creativity. Feedback is also very thorough. The professor and tfs are very accessible, and also offer opportunities to engage with research. There is no section component, and overall the workload is light and assignments very doable.
subject: Education Studies

best_comment: This course feels a lot like a seminar in the sense that you're encouraged to raise issues to Professor Elgin during the lecture and be engaged in a dialogue –– I found this key to enjoying the lectures and learning as much as I could from them. Professor Elgin is also incredibly committed to your success and understanding of the material –– she takes every question seriously, and oftentimes notes that you might be asking more underlying questions within your question before you even realize it!Assignments weren't too demanding, just two papers over the course of the semester and brief commentary on readings. And you have ample time to complete all these things and talk to teaching staff about your papers, so you never feel rushed.You don't need to have a background in writing philosophy to succeed in this class; rather, you just need to come in with a willingness to engage with the material, and it's even better if you talk to the teaching staff about it. Everybody involved in the execution of this course is working on something really cool in the education space, and they make themselves available to chat about the field, graduate school, their work, and assignments. You can tell the teaching staff really care about this course.
subject: Education Studies

course_title: Education and Resistance in Community-based Youth Organizations  001
best_comment: This is genuinely one of the most meaningful courses I have ever taken. Dr. Baldridge is an extremely engaging and intentional instructor, and Christian and Zenzile provided such valuable contributions to our discussions and our learning experience throughout this semester. I would highly recommend taking this course to gain a broad understanding of youth engagement beyond the classroom. I am leaving this course with a much stronger understanding of this field and a toolkit for critical approaches to youth work. I cannot say enough about how well organized and beneficial this course is. Strongly, strongly recommend!
subject: Education Studies
course_title_2023: Education and Resistance in Community-based Youth Organizations

best_comment: I thought I learned a lot about the educational experiences of immigrant populations and the contentious nature of this ongoing discussion. It is hard to know what the "Right" answer is, which is another reason I loved this course because I felt that our professor was giving us an opportunity to piece this puzzle ourselves rather than other professors that criticize and force their own opinion on students. I think I left with a lot of new information and skills, but also important questions that I hope to continue to explore.
subject: Education Studies

best_comment: This iteration of the course was very much a work–in–progress, so bear that in mind when reading these responses as the next iteration will likely look fairly different.I came into the course thinking I'd learn the physics of sports as limited to physical equipment, say how a ball moves through the air. The course actually didn't cover that much physics in class, relying on take–home readings/assignments or self–directed research to cover content (make sure to do this work if you want to learn the content!). Rather, much of the first half of the semester was dedicated to figuring out the idiosyncrasies of the motion sensor provided and how to analyze the data in Python. Also, there was a focus on biomechanics that I wasn't quite prepared for.The project for the second half of the semester was interesting, but be sure to pick good teammates and a topic you're actually interested in so you still have motivation to clean messy data and analyze it to get useful results (on par for any project–based course though). You can really take the project any direction you'd like (any sport/physical activity, any focus including physics of equipment and biomechanics, etc) as long as you're prepared to put in the time and effort to see it through to completion.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Quantitative Physiology as a Basis for Bioengineering 001
best_comment: This is a requirement for bioengineering so you probably can't get out of it, but if you have a decent amount of math/bio/coding background this course will be on the lighter end + might be a bit tedious/repetitive. Take advantage of the guest lectures/faculty chats to ask a lot of questions, and feel free to reach out to Linsey as a resource (she is very supportive and fair). The lecture style is a bit dry (most of the information is on the slides, etc) but the course support staff–– TFs, lab assistants, and Linsey–– are all great and very helpful.
worse_comment: The psets relied heavily on you attending lecture. If you had to miss class for some reason you were screwed for the psets and quizzes because the lectures were not recorded and there was no way to get help because office hours were very limited, especially for the first 3 months of the semester.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Quantitative Physiology as a Basis for Bioengineering

course_title_2023: Quantitative Physiology as a Basis for Bioengineering

best_comment: This class is a great opportunity to dip your toes into the entrepreneurship water. Everyone in the class is supportive of one another and noncompetitive. There are great opportunities to network and learn from seasoned entrepreneurs. The ORB portion of the class was a great addition. Each class was so inspiring, and you get as much out of the class as you put in! Great community.
worse_comment: Course feels disorganized at times, maybe because the class was made bigger (and thus less personal) this year.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project 001
best_comment: I truly cannot represent how awful this course is in a Q guide review. DO NOT take this course unless you have to. I highly doubt this response will be published, but this class was mentally taxing to an extreme. Twice every week, I went to the SEC for 165 minutes and left in a worse mood than I would be in pretty much any other time of the week. This class is not particularly time consuming until the last weeks when the project is (undoubtedly) barely going to get done on time. You will learn how to work in a team, and build great communication skills that might help you in a collaborative work environment, but there will be people you lose all professional respect for when they inevitably don't pull your weight, so choose your direct teammates carefully. The course is generally poorly managed, with little direction or constructive feedback given. Hopefully you get a better client that CAMHS with which to undertake an engineering project, and hopefully your class size isn't 20 people.
worse_comment: Not to stress about it. Assignment turnover from Monday to Wednesday can be brutal. Same amount of work required between monday and wednesday as wednesday and monday.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Engineering Problem Solving and Design Project

best_comment: You have to and will take this course if you are an SB engineering student, but that's not to say you cannot properly prepare for it. The difficulty of this course will be very much dependent on your project. Find a good advisor and settle on a topic as soon as possible, but be sure it's something you will enjoy working on! In terms of useful skills, I will say that general bookkeeping is probably the most useful skill for this course. It will help make making presentations much more streamlined for you, and documenting your thought processes will be very important and useful.
worse_comment: It's confusing sometimes but just keep working on the design and the rest works out

subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is great! You meet so many new people and make so many new friends.  Teaching staff is wonderful, and you have a true impact on the world :)
best_gem_comment: This is not a class to pass up on! Although some may consider this course a gem, becoming involved with the work done here is incredibly rewarding. This course is what you make of it; the more hours you put into the work the more you will get out of the project.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I would recommend taking this course! You assign yourself your own grade (though you must be very honest with it). With that being said, how much you get out of this course is a function of how much time you put in. Out of the AM distribution courses, this has been my favorite class. There are 2 quizzes and they are exactly like the class worksheets/psets. So as long as you review and fully understand the worksheets and psets, you will be TOTALLY OKAY (there’s also a cheat sheet). The psets aren’t the hardest, just go to OH and work with a partner and you will be fine, the skill checks are super easy and make sure you are keeping up with course material (you can retake the skills checks and Sarah gives you example questions – so you are guaranteed a 100%). The final project was honestly a grind, but that’s because it was hard to reproduce a paper – make sure you choose a good group and good paper/project (and START EARLY – you have an 8 page individual paper). Overall i’d definitely recommend taking this class :) it was great :)if you put in your 100% you will definitely get a good grade. but if you don’t, then that’s up to you
worse_comment: The psets are annoying but can help with understanding. The skill checks are pointless but you need 80% correct. The lack of published notes/handout answers is so ridiculous when it comes to studying for the two tests.
best_gem_comment: Excellent course! While it is self graded, don't expect it to be a gem or an easy A. The course structure means you have to actually understand the concepts and be able to solve problems in order to maintain your self grading privilege. However, this is done in a way that isn't super stressful and ensures you learn at the same time, which is a balance not many courses manage to get right!
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods 001
best_comment: This course does a great job building up optimization from first principles. I felt like, from beginning to end, each class made a reasonable jump that pushed the course content forward while also building on foundations from previous classes. Because of this, I felt like I really understood the content by the end! I also thought that the workload was very well distributed across the semester. Quizzes and pset due dates alternate weeks, so each week feels like it has about the same amount of work. In general the workload was on par with a good pset class–– enough to do sufficient practice with the material but certainly still manageable. It was really nice that quizzes were distributed throughout the semester as this made each one feel much more manageable and less stressful than a big midterm and final. If you're interested at all in the topic, I definitely recommend this class! I came away feeling like I could genuinely set up and solve real–word problems with optimization, which feels like a super useful and applicable skill.It is important to think about the format of the class, which is somewhat flipped classroom. We had readings that we were expected to do before each class along with a brief reading check. We would then do problems as a group in class. Personally, I found it most useful to skim the readings and do enough to answer the reading check, then go to class and work through the problems (which were useful in going through the content), and then return to the reading after to actually take comprehensive notes. Finally, I just wanted to say how lovely Margo is! You could tell that she genuinely cares about the students. Throughout the class, she made a few adjustments to the schedule to better tune it to the group and make sure our workload was at a good level, something that I always really appreciate about a professor. I definitely enjoyed taking this class.
worse_comment: Getting behind in this class is fatal. It is imperative that you do pre–class assignments on time, attend office hours if possible, and participate every day in class. The vast majority of learning is done on your own and comes from thoroughly reading the pre–class assignments. Quizzes are straightforward and easy if you have a solid understanding of the concepts. Problem sets are difficult, and the extreme optimization project is the most difficult/worst part of the course. Utilize class time to ask questions because the office hours are limited and you will likely not be able to get a tutor at the ARC.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Introduction to Optimization: Models and Methods

best_comment: The most useful engineering course Ive ever taken. If you are a Mech E you have to take this but you will enjoy it so much! You can understand basically any mechanical system ever after this class. Loved the experience and really enjoyed Boris. Just gotta put some time into it and go to class to learn.
worse_comment: A lot of concepts in the course seem difficult upon first learning, but after sitting down and going at those problems a few times, they will be understood relatively quickly. Going to office hours is something I often found necessary since there weren't any sections.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course 001
best_comment: Some of the guest lectures in this class were very interesting –– others were just plain boring. The professors were nice but some of them just didn't really know how to handle such a big class of people, which resulted in people just not paying attention. If you're looking for an easy/semi–interesting class where you get to just hang out with your friends, then this is a great option. I took this class with a bunch of friends and it was nice to get to work on our group projects together. In terms of the two group projects, the instructions for them are unclear at best. You just have to use previous years' assignments, do something similar, and hope for the best. The feedback that we got on our projects were super brief but honestly the TFs were trying their best to deal with what they were given so I don't blame them.
worse_comment: This was a gem, but it might not be anymore. They were angry by the end of the class. You have been warned.
best_gem_comment: Many people consider this class a gem and it really is to a certain extent. You have to work with a group the entire semester and how things turn out really depends on your group. The assignments aren't hard but they just have to get handed in. There is also mandatory attendance which is a bit annoying but the easy assignments, lenient grading and (mostly) great lectures makes up for this. For the midterm there are several sections that could either be done weekly or handed in all together when the midterm is due; I suggest the weekly assignments instead of cramming everything during midterm season. While many take this class for gem purposes there is also an opportunity to learn a lot! This class did a great job in showing students the ins and outs of innovation. I learned a bunch about how businesses are run and how ideas are executed well. It is also a class that will really make you feel like you go to Harvard during certain points!
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course

best_comment: This is one of the best courses I have taken at Harvard. Donhee is a great lecturer who really cares about his students. If you get the chance, you should take this class.

I really enjoyed this class! It was definitely challenging in its content, but everyone in the class is there to help and support you. Professor Hills cares deeply about his students and guides you through every step of the journey. He is really approachable, and I really appreciated when he stayed back (even sometimes past midnight) to answer our questions and help with our learning. The TFs and the CAs also cared about our learning, and it was a really welcoming community. Definitely a super rewarding experience!
worse_comment: The biggest thing determining wether you like the class or not is the love for what's being learned. Otherwise, the amount of work can be overwhelming if you don't love it.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: My opinion is mixed. The good things are that Lina and the course staff (especially Krithika!!!) are wonderful and are especially helpful and reachable. Lina was always so approachable and great at offering suggestions to help. The recommendations Lina made for final project after only a few minutes of consideration were spot on and helped us refine it; she truly has controls figured out. Krithika was such an amazing TF and was always quick at responding to my questions. She's so nice and I could tell her vast knowledge of the topics. I think you learn quite a bit in the course about control theory although I think it can go deeper, especially into the math. We never really saw proofs of any of the theorems we used in the course and I take issue with this. We should know more of what's going on and I wish Lina assumed that we had more mathematical maturity. For this reason I think the lectures could be better and more intuitive– lectures are "required" but I feel like I could read the lecture notes and the textbook without going to any of the lectures and have the same understanding of control theory. The textbook also had proofs of the theorems we used so I went there usually when the proofs were omitted from class which was most of the time.The final project was a strength of the course; it is not like other courses' final projects. You start this one the first few weeks of the semester. Every few weeks, instead of a problem set due, there is a final project milestone due where you work with your team on the final project and apply what you just learned the past couple weeks to the final project of your choosing. This is a wonderful idea and I'm glad this existed. When it comes time to hand in the final report all you have to do is fix up some of the project and maybe add some more things if you want and that's all–– because you've already done the core of the work for the milestones earlier in the semester. I think more courses should do this.There are a few administrative things which stressed me out a lot. There was a problem set (notorious, if you know someone who took this class, even last year or the year before, they will immediately know exactly which problem set you're talking about) which would have taken a few hours if it weren't for the stupidly high amount of tedious algebra the course staff insisted we do. No other problem set was like that. There was also the second midterm to be done entirely during the confines of reading period. This was a de facto final so I'm unsure why the staff decided to stress us out even more and have us do it during reading period. The final project was not so urgent as to necessitate pushing the "midterm" to be during reading period.
worse_comment: THIS IS NOT AN EASY CLASS!!!!! people might say it is easy but that is only for if you have already taken ES 152, MATH 21B, COMPLEX ANALYSIS, ES 156. I would delay this course to senior year
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: I loved this class.  Prof. Ba is fantastic and is so knowledgeable and just very fun to learn from in the classroom.  His structure of splitting the class with a break in the middle makes it so much easier to digest lecture, and the time flew by during this class period every time surprisingly quickly.  The material is engaging, it isn't easy given the higher level concepts, but it definitely is doable alongside other difficult classes.  The weekly work felt a little relentless possibly because OH were scheduled right before the work was due most of the time, so we all ended up cramming a lot of the work into the day before due dates, but the grading is nice, and getting an A is certainly not out of reach for most people. Just pay attention in class, don't get distracted on your computer, go to section, and take advantage of the time with the great course staff! Shubham, Manos, and Demba are gems and this class was fantastic.  Sometimes the psets got a little disorienting because it felt like we had never seen the material before, but looking back, they were so helpful in seeing how the concepts are applied.  Although it sometimes felt like the psets weren't aligned with the lecture schedule.  Review your linear algebra before coming in.  And your derivatives and series knowledge!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This was my favorite course at Harvard so far! I don't think the lectures are super interesting, but I think the material is super interesting and important for anyone who wants to go into the field of robotics. Every job interview I had this semester for a robotics company, I was able to showcase the theoretical knowledge I gained through this course.That being said, YOU DO NOT BUILD YOUR OWN ROBOT. A bunch of mechanical engineers that shopped this course were disappointed to learn that 1– you don't build anything, but rather learn how to program, and 2– that the lectures are very theoretical (kind of similar to ES155 where it's basically applied linear algebra).I think this course helped prepare me for job interviews and working in the robotics industry in general in the future. The HWs were fair, and not too easy but matched the material taught in classed and helped me understand the material. The labs were extremely helpful in providing students with hands–on experience and enough "proof" for employers that you are capable of working in their perspective companies. Taking the graduate version, the final project enables a hands–on experience in both writing mathematical reports and performing an individual project. Additionally, I thoroughly enjoyed the guessed lectures and learning from people conducting research in the field and leading it. Also, the book accompanying the course was great!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class gives you great experience in Harvard’s clean room spaces and you not only learn about MEMS, but you also get to design and fabricate which has been a lot of fun! You will have to work in teams throughout the entire semester (only one assignment was done individually) so if you are a lone wolf when it comes to studying then this is not the course for you. Fawwaz has a conversational style of teaching which requires student participation, so be prepared to ask questions. The final project did take a lot of time (think 5 hours every day over 4/5 days) but most other weeks were only a few hours a week. Other than that, this class has been lovely to have in my schedule and I think this course will improve greatly as the teaching staff seemed self–aware of how the class was perceived throughout the semester.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class is much better than it used to be based on old course feedback. I actually thoroughly enjoyed the content and thought it was a well justified challenge. The Psets were all reasonable and office hours were excellent (DEFINITELY attend them).  I never spent over 8 hours on one. Sometimes I went to back to back days of office hours and got them done in <4 hours. I promise the OH helps immensely so attend them. And the TFs are the best. Exams are definitely a challenge – I highly recommend you take your Psets seriously to do well on them and be sure to use the textbook as your best friend. The problems in the textbook are great foundational practice and walk you through the answers. Reading quizzes are easy and actually beneficial in keeping you up to date and are graded on whether your read of not rather than on if you get all questions right (i.e. if you dont know an answer, just put something from the chapter down to prove your read). This course is a challenge but you walk out with a ton of thermo knowledge that is much more comprehensive and better than many other engineering courses. Labs are annoying but easy – use them as grade boosters.
worse_comment: Listen if you have to take it you have to take it. Idk who will be teaching it in the future but no matter what its a tough subject. Do the homework, do practice problems, go to office hours, use the textbook.If you don't have to take it then maybe don't.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This class was really fun in lecture. Professor Clarke is clearly enthusiastic for the subject matter and brings cool things like space shuttle tile foam to class for you to pass around and hold. Be prepared for the in–class participation, but also be aware that it's not meant to be a super serious class––be happy to get things wrong! (And oftentimes your hunches will be wrong....haha.) Would recommend if you want a general overview of machining processes and material properties with a focus on optimization. And the TFs are nice, so shoutout to them keeping us in line and helping us out!
worse_comment: THIS CLASS IS NO LONGER A GEM, IT IS A NIGHTMARE.I pray that if you have to take this class that it is better organized than it was this semester. This class started out fine, teaching us about the process of materials selection under different constraints and how to do it methodically instead of just using materials that are familiar to you. Then psets mysteriously stopped being assigned and everything went downhill from there. Prof Clarke added a midterm (bc last semester people got upset bc grades were so heavily dependent on final projects that tiny errors in the project crushed people's grades) and it was a DISASTER. The new midterm took people 20–30 HOURS to complete (even the people who went to all the TFs' office hours) when it was supposed to take less than 10 because the problems were written in confusing and unsolvable ways to the point that the teaching staff decided to not even grade those questions, meaning all the students' time was wasted. The final projects were "open–ended" aka expectations were super unclear. You would have an easier time just reading the textbook than trying to understand the lecture slides because it was the same content,  but the lecture slides took shortcuts and didn't define variables.Other icks about this class:– no consideration of the ethics of sourcing various materials in a geopolitical context– Prof Clarke repeatedly calling students (especially women of color) by the wrong names– Prof Clarke being mildly sexist (if a guy and a girl did the same thing, he would only acknowledge the guy's contributions)– the lecture slides are really unpleasant to look at if you have trypophobia – Prof Clarke immediately assuming multiple students and a TF were mistaken when they pointed out an error in his slides and arguing with them for like 20 minutes instead of pausing to double check his math (spoiler alert: the students were right)
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: This course is a very demanding course (not possible to overstate that part), BUT if you want to do cell culture or bioengineering or anything like that then this is definitely the course to take. You will get such significant experience working with cells, and likely learn more applicable skills than pretty much any other course at Harvard. Professor Parker also has some good life / career advice and he is a great resource.

I highly recommend this course! I took it as an extra elective as a BME concentrator, but I suggest it for anybody interested in neuroscience, research, or technology and its applications. The focus of the course is the technology and methodology that has progressed the field of neuroscience, but we often discussed the biological principles as well. A background in biology and circuitry is helpful , but more necessary for biology than circuitry in my experience. I did not have much electrical engineering background and was able to follow along and learn about what was relevant to understanding the lectures. I found Professor Liu to be very friendly and an engaging lecturer and the TFs are very helpful and timely with grading. The course staff is flexible and understanding and greatly takes into account the student's time and preferences. Classes were mainly structured a lecture/seminar style with a lot of Q&A and discussion. As an undergrad, it is helpful to have grad students in the course who contribute a lot to the discussion and ask great questions. Professor Liu was able to answer a lot of our questions and hypotheticals with a satisfying and in depth answer, even when the conclusion of the research was "we don't know yet". Assignments were not a stressor for me at all. The journal club one page responses and presentations were on very interesting and crucial publications and did not take more than a few hours at most to do. It was a low stakes way to continue developing comprehension and analysis skills of scientific literature. The midterm and final presentations were similar in purpose to the journal clubs, and Professor Liu only wanted us to engage with and understand the most important papers in the field and he made it clear that it was not supposed to be stressful, and it wasn't.  As with every group assignment, it is definitely easier when the whole group is committed and timely. Make sure to NOT GO OVER TIME during presentations, since that's effectively the only way to lose big points. The final paper assignment is not too bad, but if you have never written a grant proposal or literature review before, it would be helpful for you to brush up on it. The course does provide examples and criteria though.  IMPORTANT NOTE: I took this course after it was not offered for a while and more people  than expected enrolled, meaning the staff was not able to accomodate everyone in the lab which was added that semester. Normally both lab and journal club assignments are required but they gave our class the option to do one or the other which made the time commitment significantly lower for me than it might be in the future. With that said, the lab is a very interesting and exciting part of the course, and even though I chose the journal clubs because of other heavy classes, I do wish I had the time for the lab.  Also, it was nice that I was able to grab flyby lunch before/after class at the SEC, and I happened by a lot of free food and events after leaving class.
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Be ready to participate in class! The class is a low stakes environment to ask questions and think critically about why people make the scientific decisions that they do, and that hinges on people's willingness to talk and ask questions.

course_title: Advanced Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course 001
