best_comment: Some of the guest lectures in this class were very interesting –– others were just plain boring. The professors were nice but some of them just didn't really know how to handle such a big class of people, which resulted in people just not paying attention. If you're looking for an easy/semi–interesting class where you get to just hang out with your friends, then this is a great option. I took this class with a bunch of friends and it was nice to get to work on our group projects together. In terms of the two group projects, the instructions for them are unclear at best. You just have to use previous years' assignments, do something similar, and hope for the best. The feedback that we got on our projects were super brief but honestly the TFs were trying their best to deal with what they were given so I don't blame them.
worse_comment: This was a gem, but it might not be anymore. They were angry by the end of the class. You have been warned.
best_gem_comment: Many people consider this class a gem and it really is to a certain extent. You have to work with a group the entire semester and how things turn out really depends on your group. The assignments aren't hard but they just have to get handed in. There is also mandatory attendance which is a bit annoying but the easy assignments, lenient grading and (mostly) great lectures makes up for this. For the midterm there are several sections that could either be done weekly or handed in all together when the midterm is due; I suggest the weekly assignments instead of cramming everything during midterm season. While many take this class for gem purposes there is also an opportunity to learn a lot! This class did a great job in showing students the ins and outs of innovation. I learned a bunch about how businesses are run and how ideas are executed well. It is also a class that will really make you feel like you go to Harvard during certain points!
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Advanced Innovation in Science and Engineering: Conference Course

best_comment: This class is a good way to learn the theory behind stress analysis basics... as the name suggests. Lots of math but generally enjoyable.

This class has a great combination of theory and implementation. You will leave this course with a strong understanding of the finite element methods and how to use them for analysis in both Matlab and Abaqus. This course also gives students the opportunity to apply the content learned to their research for the end of semester project.
worse_comment: Understand that this course is very time consuming but valuable as it teaches skills and knowledge regarding ABAQUS and nonlinear finite elements. I learned most through problem sets — I got out as much as I put into the class. There’s a problem set every week (50%)  in addition to a final project (also worth 50%). Lectures were well–taught and straightforward.

best_comment: The course is fantastic, just make sure that you have a strong probability background. The more math, like analysis, the better.
worse_comment: This course may be offered by electrical engineering faculty, but it is not an electrical engineering course. It is a mathematics course. If you are not interested in advanced theoretical mathematics and are not comfortable with measure theory and convex optimization, do not take this course. That said, it is a well–designed and well–taught course that will seriously improve your math skills if you choose to take it.
best_gem_comment: This was both my favorite and most difficult class this semester! Flavio is legitimately a star professor and he is probably the best lecturer I had out of the six lecturers I had this semester. I can easily tell his expert knowledge on information theory and adjacent fields like signal processing, machine learning, and communications. He was excellent at explaining things which is crucial in such a difficult class. I think this is a gem if you're interested in the subject matter and willing to put in the effort. He is also very flexible and willing to give you more time if necessary on a problem set, which he understands very well are very difficult. This is a mostly pure math course but there is no doubt that this course is applicable to a vast area of engineering, computer science, and applied math. Machine learning is a common application and reason why people take the class which is good but Flavio also covers a lot of other applications like statistics and communications.

course_title: Mathematics of High-Dimensional Information Processing and Learning 001
best_comment: An excellent class, and Yue is an excellent lecturer and a very helpful person to talk to about research. I strongly encourage you to take it (even if you're an undergrad!).

This was my favorite course at Harvard so far! I don't think the lectures are super interesting, but I think the material is super interesting and important for anyone who wants to go into the field of robotics. Every job interview I had this semester for a robotics company, I was able to showcase the theoretical knowledge I gained through this course.That being said, YOU DO NOT BUILD YOUR OWN ROBOT. A bunch of mechanical engineers that shopped this course were disappointed to learn that 1– you don't build anything, but rather learn how to program, and 2– that the lectures are very theoretical (kind of similar to ES155 where it's basically applied linear algebra).I think this course helped prepare me for job interviews and working in the robotics industry in general in the future. The HWs were fair, and not too easy but matched the material taught in classed and helped me understand the material. The labs were extremely helpful in providing students with hands–on experience and enough "proof" for employers that you are capable of working in their perspective companies. Taking the graduate version, the final project enables a hands–on experience in both writing mathematical reports and performing an individual project. Additionally, I thoroughly enjoyed the guessed lectures and learning from people conducting research in the field and leading it. Also, the book accompanying the course was great!
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Gu is an amazing professor! I learned how to read and discuss papers in this class and his comments are always insightful. Totally recommend the class
subject: Engineering Sciences

best_comment: Great course if you want to learn about the field of optics and photonics. Very useful for future research in the field. Marko is patient and willing to take questions so the course can also be adapted to your interests up to a point. Would highly recommend the course for an application/research focused introduction to optics. If you are looking for a Jackson style course with lots of analytic calculations and solving Maxwell's equations in different regions explicitly, I might recommend a different course.
worse_comment: I think this class isn't fit for undergraduate students unless they have a deep understanding in physics that is much deeper than the required PS 12/15 series.

best_comment: This class gives you great experience in Harvard’s clean room spaces and you not only learn about MEMS, but you also get to design and fabricate which has been a lot of fun! You will have to work in teams throughout the entire semester (only one assignment was done individually) so if you are a lone wolf when it comes to studying then this is not the course for you. Fawwaz has a conversational style of teaching which requires student participation, so be prepared to ask questions. The final project did take a lot of time (think 5 hours every day over 4/5 days) but most other weeks were only a few hours a week. Other than that, this class has been lovely to have in my schedule and I think this course will improve greatly as the teaching staff seemed self–aware of how the class was perceived throughout the semester.
subject: Engineering Sciences

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: If you're hoping to learn specific writing techniques (e.g. grammar, syntax, flow), then this probably isn't the class for you. However, if you are hoping to learn about overarching principles of scientific writing—such as how to make a timeline for writing a journal publication, how to make clear figures, and how to determine authorship—then this class covers all that and more. Suzanne and Dan really care about this class and put in so much effort to make it an enriching experience for everyone, and it's a great class to develop confidence in your overall writing abilities.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: If you're hoping to learn specific writing techniques (e.g. grammar, syntax, flow), then this probably isn't the class for you. However, if you are hoping to learn about overarching principles of scientific writing—such as how to make a timeline for writing a journal publication, how to make clear figures, and how to determine authorship—then this class covers all that and more. Suzanne and Dan really care about this class and put in so much effort to make it an enriching experience for everyone, and it's a great class to develop confidence in your overall writing abilities.
subject: Engineering Sciences
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Get Real: The Art of Community-Based Film 001
best_comment: This is an amazing class for people with little to no experience in filmmaking but want the opportunity to learn, co–create, and expand their ideas of what documentary filmmaking can be! The instructors are wonderful and the class is inspiring and so fun.

This course was awesome and VERY worth taking if you get in. It's a lot of work (about a 500 word article each week with a good amount of reporting you'll need to do for each, and longer articles twice in the semester). Jill is super interesting to learn from and has a great perspective, but she also doesn't give super thorough feedback and can be hard to reach outside of class. Overall, a fantastic experience and highly recommend. The class is what you make of it though, so you have to actually put effort in and care about the class in order to get anything out of it.
worse_comment: Come into it with an open mind. Be willing to criticise the news you read. And be willing to argue with Jill – she enjoys it and the class needs it!

best_comment: The 10 poem application may seem a bit daunting, but this class is well worth it!! The small class size was fantastic, my group had a great sense of community (even gathered outside of class a few times to read poetry and get meals), and a really positive and constructive work environment was created. Josh is the best, runs class discussions well and gives very detailed and personalized feedback every week about your poems.
subject: English

course_title: Blood, Sweat, Tears: The Art and Craft of Horror Writing 001
best_comment: Just an all around excellent workshop. I'd been meaning for literally my entire Harvard career to take one of the english department's creative writing workshops and finally actually did it, and I am so, so glad I did. I learned a lot as a writer and also a lot about the Horror genre, one I was only just barely familiar with and starting to branch into. I feel much more confident with my skills within this genre. The professor and the rest of the students did a great job of creating an environment with amazing feedback and respectful, helpful criticism. Honestly just a great class and I'm so glad I took it.

This class will teach you to look at form and language differently, not only in your own writing and in others' poetry, but in life too. One of the joys of this class is that you may find yourself paying closer attention to surprising scraps of language in daily life and taking delight in them. The quality of feedback in a workshop always depends on the cohort, but Tracy is a wonderful model in how to give kind, honest, and constructive critique. In my experience, the community that forms is one where every student is really invested in every other poet's growth, and that allows us to take risks, to bring in poems where we tried something new that didn't work to learn from them, and to learn from one another's strengths.
subject: English

best_comment: This is a wonderfully transformative class. it will really help develop you as a writer and help you truly understand what makes good writing. You will feel more confident in your writing after taking this class.

course_title: Writing Fiction: Elements of Craft, Style, and Meaning 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this course to those who want to improve their writing skills, increase their love of reading, and get the opportunity to get some of the best mentorship available at Harvard.

course_title: From Fact to Fiction: Finding & Shaping a Story: Workshop 001
best_comment: Take this workshop!! By the end of the semester, I felt like we had really bonded as a class, which is always a sign of an amazing workshop. Claire is lovely, helpful, and supportive without letting you off easy; she will push you to grow and be a better writer. The readings are great and several of their authors visited our class to talk/answer questions, which was so cool. And the fact–based aspect is really unique – not something you'll necessarily encounter in your average fiction workshop. Over all, this class was frequently the highlight of my school week; would highly recommend.

course_title: Interiority & Experience: Writing Character-Driven Fiction: Workshop 001
best_comment: Professor Messud's courses are terrific fun! You will be challenged to write and read creatively and critically, and you will have a lot of fun creating your own work and reading your classmates' work. Workshop courses do require commitment to giving feedback and setting aside time for writing, so make sure you are enthusiastic/ready to give this commitment!
subject: English
course_title_2023: Interiority & Experience: Writing Character-Driven Fiction: Workshop

course_title: Genre Fiction Workshop: Sci-Fi, Fantasy, Speculative Fiction, Horror, The Ghost Story, The New Weird 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. NEEL IS GREAT. MAKING TIME FOR WRITING AND READING EVERY WEEK IS GREAT. TAKE IT. READ. WRITE. BE HAPPY.
subject: English
course_title_2023: Genre Fiction Workshop: Sci-Fi, Fantasy, Speculative Fiction, Horror, The Ghost Story, The New Weird

best_comment: Jill is a treasure to the Harvard community. She carries with her so many stories and insights about journalism as a craft and as a profession. I grew immensely in her class, and her feedback and teaching played a huge role. Take this class if you can! It’s a rare and life–changing opportunity to challenge yourself and make a connection with an incredibly kind and experienced writer.

I came into the class never having written any screenplay, and I came out with two short films I was proud of. That itself was an accomplishment and I was able to use this class as a motivator and facilitator to finally put pen to paper. Overall, the class is low–stakes and low–stress, a great place for beginners like me. That being said, I think discussions and lessons lacked real energy. The seminar was not the vibrant brain–trust, writers–room vibe I had in mind when originally applying, and I left the class always wanting a little more. I am not familiar with similar seminars offered by the English department, so I'm not sure if that type of atmosphere is offered elsewhere. Additionally,  we were assigned weekly indie short films we rarely dived deep into, and there was only one assignment where we actually had to read a produced script. I hope that changes for future students. Though I'd recommend going in on one–on–one for personalized OH to get the most out of the course.
subject: English

best_comment: This class has been one of the best I've here at Harvard. I am glad I got the opportunity to be in this workshop and learn and write alongside the most creative and interesting people. Darcy was a fantastic instructor, and through each weekly meeting I felt myself getting more comfortable with writing about myself and things that have happened in my life. This course changes your perspective on what matters in life, what's worth remembering and retelling, and how you choose to remember and retell. I think everyone should take this course as it pushes you to think introspectively about your past experiences and puts you in an environment where it's okay to feel vulnerable and speak and write about uncomfortable topics. Having classmates and Darcy give feedback on your writing is very rewarding, and you also learn just as much from your own writing as you do from the work of your peers.

Take this class if you can!!! Darcy is a great teacher, and I genuinely feel like I learned so much about the craft of creative non–fiction from his insights and from the example essays we read each week (an incredible selection that I will definitely return to). The structure of this class is a little more rigorous than those of previous creative writing courses I've taken. Each week you'll read a not–insignificant amount and have to write a response (whether that's analyzing published work or synthesizing your suggestions/edits for your peers' writing), so you can't just show up without preparing anything. That being said, it was totally worth it — it was really fun diving deep with good writing, and it made class discussions SO rich and enjoyable. Most of the time it felt like I was part of a fun intense book club and I genuinely wanted to bring my A game each week, since people were such helpful editors and gave such kind and useful feedback for my work.

course_title: The Novel Lab: Studying Long-Form Narratives in Fiction 001
best_comment: Loved this class! Definitely take this! Readings are great and the final project is a lot of fun to work on since you're working on your own novel
worse_comment: This is, without hesitation, the best class I have ever participated in. I cannot recommend it highly enough.

course_title: The Novel Lab: Studying Long-Form Narratives in Fiction 002
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! The readings are excellent and fun and the discussions are great. Paul is the best teacher you could ask for. You will learn about the craft of novels and get to a point where is feels very possible that you could write a good one, and then you will! for like thirty pages at least. Absurdly absurdly valuable course for anyone interested in the practical craft of novels or a career as a writer.

You will learn so much about yourself as a writer (adapted from my final reflection).  We read so many stories diverse in genre, author identity, and style, which led me to finally begin coalescing elements of the stories I wanted to tell. Meng is wonderful –– she encourages you to tease out your writing strengths while conveying areas of opportunity, all without a prescriptive lens.And truly, all my classmates inspired me to explore beyond my current writing, and I'm so grateful for the supportive and honest writing community we've created.I have much more confidence in my ability to experiment, and also draw upon my strengths, to surprise myself & others with the stories I have to share!

TAKE THIS CLASS if you have the opportunity to!! The class is superb in every aspect, from the teaching to the guests to the assignments and readings themselves. Professor Pollan is at the top of his field in science journalism, and he generously shares his insights/advice with every student, from giving an insider perspective on how the journalism/editing industry operates to reading each student’s drafts and giving paragraphs of detailed feedback. We got the chance to speak with guests (experienced editors, writers, and scientists) throughout the course, getting detailed and diverse perspectives on every step of journalism, from reporting and finding sources to how to best craft a pitch. By nature of the subject, the class is very interdisciplinary and brings together students across the sciences and humanities in a very small and close–knit setting. If you are a student interested in both science and writing this is the class for you! We were exposed to breakthroughs and headlines in an enormous number of scientific fields, from agriculture to quantum physics. Simultaneously, we got to hone our journalism and creative writing skills through the “narrative” part of Narrative Science Journalism—careful thought must be put into constructing a person–centered story arc from the science. Apply to the class, even if you have little previous experience in journalism—as long as you have a strong background and interest in science and writing, Professor Pollan will make sure you are acquainted with all the conventions, strategies, and jargon of reporting/journalism. In addition, because it is a journalism class, be prepared to devote a lot of time outside of class to reporting: finding sources, conducting interviews, and traveling to nearby sites related to the story. The more time you invest in reporting and writing your story, the more you will take away from the class.

course_title: The Sound and the Story: A Workshop in Nonfiction Narrative for Audio Production 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class – cannot recommend enough!! Jill Lepore is a fantastic fantastic professor. She is so warm and generous with her time and advice. She creates a space for workshopping ideas and writing that is fun and inclusive. The only caveat is that it is a very self–driven course. Most of the class (slightly above 50%) is just workshopping your/peer projects. This means that you need to devote a LOT of time into the class!! You cannot turn up to class without having workshopped your piece. And there is nowhere to hide when a dozen others+prof is picking apart your work. It is obvious if you have not done the work you should have done. Everyone always hugely underestimates how much time creative projects take. Especially in audio form, you often spend many many minutes editing precious seconds, maybe even milliseconds. It takes forever!! If you want to develop your writing and your audio editing skills, you MUST carve out a significant portion of your time for this class. This will be one of your heavy classes! But you will get a lot out of the class if you put the effort in. You will develop a more discerning ear – you will just be able to hear more of the layers in the sounds of the world. Even beyond gaining a critical appreciation of audio media (e.g. podcasts, radio), I have found that I can hear more layers in the pop songs I listen to and pick up subtler sound details when watching movies or even just pick out bird songs a bit better when walking through the park. It's quite a nice feeling. You also learn to use Adobe Audition, which is a nice practical skill. tldr fantastic fun class but a LOT a LOT of time commitment

course_title: “Telling and Retelling”: Reshaping and Remixing Myths and Fairy Tales 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class, it was a really relaxed environment, a fun and interesting subject, and so rewarding. I felt much more confident about my work after I had gotten feedback and used it in revision. This workshop is perfect for writers who are trying to develop their style and talent.

course_title: Writing for Television: Developing the Pilot: Workshop 001
best_comment: This is one of the best classes at Harvard. Take it if you get the opportunity. The time commitment and course load is extremely reasonable. The assignments are always interesting and relevant, and are most of the time something you'd do for fun anyways. The professor (Sam Marks) is incredibly engaged and engaging. He's very knowledgable and cares deeply about your craft. I learned so much in such a short period of time. I also made a bunch of new creative friends through the class. I'm so glad I took it.

course_title: Imagination Under Siege: Creativity in Times of Crisis 001
best_comment: If you are interested in questions of language, memory, imagination, etc, take this course! You will not regret having Professor Luiselli as your teacher — she is fantastic. This has been the best course I've taken here, and definitely the best creative writing course on campus. I've appreciated the great conversations she facilitated for us as a cohort; I left every class feeling like I'd learned something new. Unlike other creative writing courses I've taken on campus, this one pushed us all to think critically about our relationship with writing and the themes of the class. My writing has definitely grown, and Professor Luiselli made sure we had the tools and time to push ourselves with our work.

This course profoundly impacted me. Teju Cole not only teaches creative writing and analyzing photos, but how to learn and how to speak with intention. The class quickly became my most valued of the semester for how inspired I would leave the classroom, and how the reading, writing, and discussions were fruitful and enriching. I dove deeply into my own personal life with my projects, as did many in the class. It was beautiful to witness the growth of the confidentiality, trust, and connections among the students and the professor as we dealt with difficult subjects through the making of art and conversation.

Only take this course if you think you might concentrate in English, or are super interested in modern literature. There are better English classes to take if you want a fun class with enthusiastic classmates. Half the people in the class were either extremely arrogant and constantly showing off, or super critical of the books we were reading. It was impossible to appreciate books I liked because I had to contend with people, both in lecture and in section, who wanted to talk about why they hated the book (often in an unproductive way). By the third or fourth debate we had about whether the author of a book should even have written it at all, I was just done. Apparently, the state of modern literature is hypercritical and completely mired in identity politics to the extent that we can't talk about anything else (not that those discussions are unimportant, but I do occasionally want to do some close reading in a literal English class). The professors tried their best, I think? But the negativity of the students just overpowered them.With that being said, I loved the books we read in the course, loved my TF, and loved all the assignments. It's always fun when all your course assignments get to be creative to some degree. If you're an English concentrator and need to take this class, you'll be fine. Just don't get the wrong idea and be put off– most English classes have way better vibes than this one.
worse_comment: We didn't learn how to be better writers in this class, nor did we really learn how to be better thinkers or readers. We heard lots of brilliant things spoken to us by our professors, and for that, I'm grateful. But I did not grow at all in English. And that is really upsetting. Would not recommend this course and the fact that it is the intro course to the English concentration is quite disappointing.
best_gem_comment: Beware! Although it might seem like a gem, the class started off strong, but slowly got less interesting. The lectures began by being super interactive and engaging, but slowly, but surely, became boring. I would only take this class if you really enjoy reading, or if you are okay with no being the most interested in the lectures.
subject: English

best_comment: Only take this course if you think you might concentrate in English, or are super interested in modern literature. There are better English classes to take if you want a fun class with enthusiastic classmates. Half the people in the class were either extremely arrogant and constantly showing off, or super critical of the books we were reading. It was impossible to appreciate books I liked because I had to contend with people, both in lecture and in section, who wanted to talk about why they hated the book (often in an unproductive way). By the third or fourth debate we had about whether the author of a book should even have written it at all, I was just done. Apparently, the state of modern literature is hypercritical and completely mired in identity politics to the extent that we can't talk about anything else (not that those discussions are unimportant, but I do occasionally want to do some close reading in a literal English class). The professors tried their best, I think? But the negativity of the students just overpowered them.With that being said, I loved the books we read in the course, loved my TF, and loved all the assignments. It's always fun when all your course assignments get to be creative to some degree. If you're an English concentrator and need to take this class, you'll be fine. Just don't get the wrong idea and be put off– most English classes have way better vibes than this one.
worse_comment: We didn't learn how to be better writers in this class, nor did we really learn how to be better thinkers or readers. We heard lots of brilliant things spoken to us by our professors, and for that, I'm grateful. But I did not grow at all in English. And that is really upsetting. Would not recommend this course and the fact that it is the intro course to the English concentration is quite disappointing.
best_gem_comment: Beware! Although it might seem like a gem, the class started off strong, but slowly got less interesting. The lectures began by being super interactive and engaging, but slowly, but surely, became boring. I would only take this class if you really enjoy reading, or if you are okay with no being the most interested in the lectures.
subject: English

best_comment: I would not recommend this class for non–English concentrators just because there are some technicalities and a lot of focus on historical forms. But for English concentrators, try to join Professor Lynch's class! I loved her enthusiasm and passion, and she is so lovely to talk to in office hours. Some readings were better than others, and some felt like a "oh okay I guess this is required," but overall I enjoyed the class and there was a very reasonable workload.
subject: English

best_comment: Must be self motivated to get anything out of this course. Only two assignments: one midterm essay, one final, with no prompts provided.
worse_comment: It's boring, but it's required.
subject: English

course_title: Digital Race Studies: Storytelling, Power, Community 001
best_comment: English 90DR is the best seminar I have taken at Harvard, and one of my favorite classes period. Professor Dikcis is deeply understanding, accommodating, and compassionate to students. She fostered an extremely welcoming and open culture of sharing, which resulted in deeply interactive and lively discussions in class. I really appreciated how extremely thoughtfully and intentionally the syllabus was curated. It covered a diverse range of literature, media (from Twitter hashtags to maps, Youtube comedy sketches to poetry with code), topics, and issues in relation to race and society — both in historical and modern contexts, which the English department sorely lacks. The final project is a digital storytelling project, which was extremely fun to research and create. HIGHLY encourage anyone and everyone to take this class!

This class is wonderful for English students seeking to complete the 1700–1900 concentration requirement! It does a great job handling the Brontes (powerhouses of the 19th C) as well as 19th C literary styles and forms broadly. Professor Scarry is clearly passionate about these unique writers and makes the class fun and exciting for newcomers to the Brontes. If you are not an English student, this is a very accessible class to get into 19th C lit/the English department at large. The discussions are welcoming and the close–reading essays provide creative opportunities for students to interpret the texts on their own. I really appreciate this class!!

Take this class!! Professor Deloria is a wealth of knowledge, and his passion for the subject is infectious! It's also so rewarding to learn about the history of Native people from the lands you go to school at, and the things you learn about Harvard's history will change the way you think about and interact with the institution. I really loved this course! The only thing I disliked was the quantity of reading, which was pretty overwhelming in the beginning and middle of the course. However, I loved everything else! I especially loved the instructors' efforts to get speakers to come in and enhance our learning. I also loved how we were encouraged to use all the resources Harvard had to offer to enhance our research.
subject: English

best_comment: Take this class!! Professor Deloria is a wealth of knowledge, and his passion for the subject is infectious! It's also so rewarding to learn about the history of Native people from the lands you go to school at, and the things you learn about Harvard's history will change the way you think about and interact with the institution. I really loved this course! The only thing I disliked was the quantity of reading, which was pretty overwhelming in the beginning and middle of the course. However, I loved everything else! I especially loved the instructors' efforts to get speakers to come in and enhance our learning. I also loved how we were encouraged to use all the resources Harvard had to offer to enhance our research.
subject: English

course_title: Metaphysical Poetry: The Seventeenth-Century Lyric and Beyond 001
best_comment: This is a very good course for those who want an introduction to metaphysical poetry (and even to poetry generally). You may be asked to write a poem for each class meeting, which I found enjoyable and edifying –– you learn things from writing poetry that you cannot from just reading it. Those who have read the poetry of the seventeenth century at some length may find themselves rereading poems, but they will also find new poems to enjoy. (And there is something to be said for reading poetry again after having spent time away from it.) This course is fairly accessible even to students with little background, which is good to know coming in for discussions. I'd recommend the class: Professor Teskey is a wonderful discussion leader and has an excellent eye for teasing out themes in poetry.
subject: English
course_title_2023: Metaphysical Poetry: The Seventeenth-Century Lyric and Beyond

course_title: Empire and Revolution, Sex and Gender, Race, Slavery, and Abolition 001
best_comment: This class was excellent: a well–curated selection of literature from a time period that seems to be quietly departing from Harvard syllabi, thoughtful discussions, and above all  Professor Engell's instruction –– both in leading the discussions and in offering feedback on his students' writing. I'll emphasize the second: barring extremely poor writing, teachers at Harvard will often ignore an essay's style and focus solely on its content. But feedback on style is critical to becoming a better writer. Students in this class know to expect writing marked thoroughly with black pen, from the familiar brackets (meaning something like "are these words necessary?") to suggested rephrasings or thoughts on punctuation choices. These are not minutiae: such small improvements to prose add up to significantly better writing. I'm grateful to have taken this class for the discussions and readings, but also for the opportunity to improve my own thinking and expression.

This class is great. It's a "vegetables" course as it's required for you concentration, but I thought it was truly lovely. Enjoyable to do the readings and reflections and very easy on a weekly basis. Only one paper!
worse_comment: If you're going to be an English concentrator, you have to take this class anyway, so I don't know how much I can tell you to sway your opinion either way. I didn't mind this class, but it wasn't my favorite. It's definitely useful; you won't feel like you're wasting your time. But not super interesting either. The good news is that because every week is a new topic, if you don't like a topic you only have to spend a few hours thinking about it.
subject: English

best_comment: TAKE A CLASS WITH JOANI. She is the absolute best––better than some professors, even. She is a fabulous, thoughtful, brilliant teacher. This class with be HARD–– Joani is a serious scholar, and will demand a lot–– but always with the best of intentions. You will leave this class prepared to write a thesis, or even ready for grad school. It is a ton of work, so make sure the rest of your schedule is light, and then dive in deep. This will require more time and effort than you've ever put into a class, but it will also be amazing. You get very close with your peers and Joani. It was so worth it.
It's a difficult course with a heavy workload but if you have a good leader (like Jeffrey Careyva!) then you will have a really fantastic and meaningful experience.

course_title: Introduction to Old English: Charms, Herbals, Folk Medicine, Miracle Cures 001
best_comment: The course is a bit difficult but is still doable. I think if memorization is difficult for you then this may not be the best course to take, but I feel as though that is likely the case with most languages courses. Professor Donoghue is really passionate about Old English which makes it really fun for students. Obtaining exposure to really old texts is also a super interesting aspect of the course! Learning about a different time period and being able to see for yourself how much the English language has changed is really cool. As for the workload, the translations each week take longer than you would think. For example, it would take me several hours to translate 13 sentences because of having to go through the textbook glossary to see what the words mean. Also, it is absolutely necessary to consistently study the grammar rules throughout the semester in order to prepare for the final exam. All in all, though, if you are looking for an interesting course to fulfill the language requirement or simply to take on your own time, I would say this one is a good option.
worse_comment: You are going to be confused, and you are going to feel lost. This is okay! Your peers will be an invaluable resource in this course, and talking through issues will help more than you might think it would.
subject: English
course_title_2023: Introduction to Old English: Charms, Herbals, Folk Medicine, Miracle Cures

best_comment: I LOVED IT. Super great class. Watson makes this a super enjoyable experience (with some goofily crude jokes along the way). This was a super entertaining course, moving from tales about marriage to tales about death to tales about farts. And Watson is always pushing and encouraging you to meet with him, he really makes sure that you are following the course and the materials of the course, and is super patient about learning Middle English, which was a lot easier than it originally seemed with Watson's help. BIG recommend for me.

The section component of this class was wonderful. Adam is the best TF I've ever had and made sections a joy to go to. Lectures were also fun because of the mix of group work with the professor's presentation. Learning about Shakespeare's plays as somewhat scandalous/radical works was interesting.
worse_comment: This is a gem! but a boring class. I would not recommend this class. Lectures were not exciting. Adam, our TF, was the best part about this class.

course_title: The Classic Phase of the Novel 001
best_comment: This is such a great class. Yes, you will have to read a lot, but to be completely transparent –– you only write essays on 3–4 of the novels, so you can skip one that falls during a busy period like midterms if need be (and just skim important chapters before section). But I actually loved reading the books and did read 4 of the 5 in full. When else will you actually read these super famous and incredible books, much less have engaging and interesting lectures to help make sense of them? Professor Fisher doesn't make you "close read" and draw out random meaning from tiny details like we are trained to do in high school English, instead, he takes the novels and their messages seriously and talks about marriage, free will, crime, family, science, and what the authors are saying about these topics. I loved this class and the novels so much and I had never taken an English course before and did well so you can do it too!
worse_comment: This class is great for people who love reading long novels and who have taken a class with Professor Fisher, but students should be prepared to do A LOT of reading, because once you fall behind, it's impossible to catch up. It's also tough if you don't like one of the books because you're stuck with it for a bit. This class wasn't my favorite because the lectures could be a bit hit or miss, compared with some of Professor Fisher's other classes, because often I felt like they would get a little repetitive or less interesting by the third or fourth lecture on a book.

course_title: Introduction to Asian American Literature: What Is Asian American Literature? 001
best_comment: I really enjoyed this class! The professor and teaching staff are so great and really want to see you succeed, and the readings are super interesting. The assignments are also very chill and there is an opportunity for extra credit at the end.  I took this class without ever having taken an english class, and I found it easy and interesting, so I would definitely recommend, especially for anyone looking to fulfill the second semester english for the premed requirement.

Professor Burt is excellent: very engaged, clearly very smart, and does her best to make this a fun and rewarding class for each student. Many of the works on the syllabus were also excellent, and the course staff is also flexible on extensions and making sure your outside–of–class health and wellbeing is preserved. Overall, wonderful course.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! So fun and the readings are actually interesting and entertaining. GEM for sure and worth the time! Plus Stephanie is a wonderful teacher and the TFs are amazing.

best_comment: Take it!!!! This is an absolutely wonderful class, and I looked forward to lecture so much every time (and felt emotional when the class ended). Professor Wood's close readings in lecture often blew my mind, and I feel like I've learnt so much about how to close read and enjoy literature through him. Really a FABULOUS course! He is so funny and engaging and focused and passionate and has really revelatory readings so you can always expect to go to lecture and have the text opened up for you in a whole new way.

I took this class on a complete whim to fill out my 4 courses for the semester, and it is easily my favorite class I've taken at Harvard!!! I am not an English/humanities concentrator and have not done a lot of writing in college, so I was initially a bit nervous about the reading/writing workload. The readings and in–class discussions were so fascinating and the feedback and encouragement I received throughout this course was amazing. I really looked forward to this class every week and I feel like I became a much better writer because of it. I'm honestly sad I can't take this class again next semester... Professor Stauffer is an absolute gem and I cannot recommend English 187AA enough!

i really liked having both a humanities and economics element to this class, but the material was not novel. if you have taken economics classes before and are a well–read citizen, a lot of this class will be semi–repetitive. it did cover important topics and would therefore be a great survey class (and perhaps a great gened), but the assignments had very little to do with what we did in class or the exams, and required you to know very niche readings (out of a unreasonably long syllabus). a few of the guest lecturers were great but lecture itself was slow and hard to engage with.

i really liked having both a humanities and economics element to this class, but the material was not novel. if you have taken economics classes before and are a well–read citizen, a lot of this class will be semi–repetitive. it did cover important topics and would therefore be a great survey class (and perhaps a great gened), but the assignments had very little to do with what we did in class or the exams, and required you to know very niche readings (out of a unreasonably long syllabus). a few of the guest lecturers were great but lecture itself was slow and hard to engage with.

I suspect that this may seem like a class on a very niche topic, but I would like to tell anyone who may be thinking this that the overlap between the categories "queer" & "medieval" is vast, diverse, rich, weird, wonderful, and surprising. You certainly do not have to be a medievalist or have an interest or commitment to queer theory to find this class fascinating and productive!

course_title: Milton and the Art of Criticism 001
best_comment: Prepare primary readings the summer before, and choose your topic of interest for the final early.
worse_comment: This is a great course for thinking about the relationship between art, artists, and criticism of both, a central skill for humanistic thinking. It's also a crash course in research skills as you learn how to search for critical texts from the three centuries of Milton criticism, identify the most promising for your interests and class discussions, and skillfully summary and generate discussion from those texts.

best_comment: This was my favorite course this semester.  I'd highly recommend it or another course taught by Prof. Ravinthiran!

course_title: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment 001
best_comment: This course has little to no deviations from what it's advertised as. You learn a lot about the Fluid Earth. However, I also learned that personally, the Fluid Earth just isn't something that I am particularly interested in (not necessarily a reflection on the course!). Don't come in as someone with a love for the outdoors and nature and conservation and ecology and expect to love this course at all. Lecture feels longer than it actually is. The professor is great, clearly a genius in her field, and can explain concepts really well one–on–one, but her lectures just weren't interactive enough to keep me fully engaged. However, if you have a genuine interest in most of the material, you might have a different experience. Sometimes, it seemed as if content was still a little unclear. Stephen, my TF, was a lifesaver in this regard (and in the course as a whole). Stephen is really great at breaking down complicated topics, is patient enough to explain material step by step, would go above and beyond in answering emails, staying after lab to answer questions, hosting office hours, would always provide helpful encouragement, and generally wanted the best for everyone. Countless times I've found myself understanding a topic I thought I'd never understand thanks to Stephen. In general, reach out for help, stay after lecture (the professor is better at explaining material then), start on PSETs early to make the most out of section and office hours, and you will be just fine. If this isn't a concentration requirement and you just happen to love conservation/broader material on climate change, take another course.
worse_comment: I took this class because I was interested in the topic being taught– the fluid Earth, ocean dynamics, and atmospheric science. Although some concepts were interesting, this class truly taught me that the professor makes or breaks the experience. The class was not taught well by the professor, so my overall experience of this class was negative. I wouldn't recommend it, but if you are to take it, be prepared to teach a lot of things to yourselves and leave lectures confused almost daily. Even the TFs would seem confused during lectures and would sometimes have to correct the professor.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2023: The Fluid Earth: Oceans, Atmosphere, Climate, and Environment

course_title: Ecosystem Patterns and Processes: Parallels in Natural and Built Environments 001
best_comment: I really recommend taking this course! This semester was the first time the course was being taught, but it far surpassed what I had expected. This course is everything you would imagine an environmental science and engineering class to be: we learned a lot of science, we learned about what actually goes into solving environmental issues, we talked about the limitations of current science and engineering–based solutions and considered ways to improve them, we had labs and field trips that combined science and engineering, we discussed public perception vs attitudes held by scientists/engineers vs implementation vs legal/economic complications, etc. It was a perfect combination of quantitative and qualitative course content with a hands–on lab component. We learned a lot, and Bryan is a really good teacher so it didn't feel like too much. And if there was something that you found to be less interesting, we would move on quickly enough. In addition, the course was very manageable as there wasn't too much work, and the work that we did have paired nicely with what we had been learning about. The final project was super open ended (although Bryan might change that in future years) so it's a good idea to start thinking about it or brainstorming in advance.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering
course_title_2023: Ecosystem Patterns and Processes: Parallels in Natural and Built Environments

best_comment: This class is very self–guided through weekly textbook chapter readings and student presentations. If that works for you, then great! If not, maybe this isn't the class for you. Each class is 50 minutes of lecture by Prof. Martin, followed by 25 minutes of student presentations. The lectures are pretty interesting because Prof. Martin does a great job with teaching and keeps it  engaging, but at least half of the class was usually zoned out during the class presentations and they don't really amount to anything unless you're the one presenting. Section was good and crucial for doing the psets, as we basically just did parallels of the pset questions but with different values. It is, therefore, very easy to do well in this class. The other homework was in the form of reading a chapter of the textbook and submitting a discussion post about it before the class in which we were going to learn about that chapter's content. The textbook was dense and hard to digest, and I don't think it actually taught me anything at all. The lectures are based on the textbook chapters, however, and I definitely did learn during lecture. Also, Scot is enthusiastic and accessible, and he's able to answer any question you have for him.  Finally, I was really not a fan of the final project. Basically all that we could do was just a literature review of an environmental topic, but we were then expected to have some sort of quantitative analysis and propose a solution to "save the world."
worse_comment: Work together with other students on homework assignments, and pay attention during lectures and section discussions.
subject: Environ Science & Engineering

course_title: Human Environmental Data Science: Agriculture, Conflict, and Health 001
best_comment: Take this class! Best I have taken at Harvard. It's a significant work load, but the topics are fascinating, assignments interesting and final project is really fun (make sure you have a good group though!). Professor Huybers is a wonderful instructor, who is humble about his work (which is a refreshing change of pace) and passionate about timely topics and making a change.
worse_comment: Most important thing is probably having some coding and stats experiences as the course can be very overwhelming and difficult without that.

best_comment: If you're an ESPP concentrator, you should take this class early and get it out of the way. You'll learn the most if you're coming in fresh, but I found as a senior there was almost nothing new here other than specific case study examples. If you're not a concentrator, I would think hard before taking it. This is not an environmental politics class, it's an STS class, so think about if that makes sense for you. The internal power dynamics of the class are toxic. If you're happy to sit down and be quiet, then you'll get through the class just fine, although be aware that it's a ludicrous amount of reading and you really have to do all of it in some degree of depth for the midterm. If you're actually interested in engaging deeply with the content, questioning things, trying to truly complicate them, then this isn't the place for you. Professor Jasanoff is nice if she likes you and not if she doesn't.
worse_comment: Take this course if you are very interested in ESPP. If it is not very interesting to you the class feels very boring and hard to sit through lecture. The weekly assignments take about 4 hours, but it was very doable. It is also easy to study for the final and midterm. The research project/paper was the most interesting component to the course because it was cool to apply ESPP to the real world. However, I am an ESPP concentrator and I've found that classes that are ESPP are very uninteresting so far. The topics were pretty interesting but felt hard to understand just because the lectures were not very engaging. Section however was very engaging and interesting! Overall I would say just take this class if you really think you want to do something with ESPP, but if not it is pointless.

course_title: The Law and Policy of Climate Change: Influencing Decision Makers 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Whether you are pre–law, environmentally oriented, or just have any sort of interest, it is an incredible course taught by an amazing professor. Definitely one of the best courses I have taken at Harvard. Professor Joroff is so kind and willing to help students to learn. Don't be intimidated by the long class, it goes by really quickly and for the rest of the week you're done! assignments aren't heavy nor is the readings so it is a hugely high return class.
worse_comment: If you are interested in environmental law but are unsure what that means in practice, take this course
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2023: The Law and Policy of Climate Change: Influencing Decision Makers

course_title: Addressing the Global Climate Crisis: Challenges for Both Developed and Developing Economies 001
best_comment: Take it! Prof McElroy is super enthusiastic and passionate about the course material, and Haiyang is a very kind and accessible TF
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol
course_title_2023: Addressing the Global Climate Crisis: Challenges for Both Developed and Developing Economies

best_comment: THIS CLASS IS AMAZING! Probably my favorite seminar I've taken at Harvard – take this if you're interested in climate responsibility and want to candidly discuss these topics with a few other students once a week. There's not much work on a week–to–week basis, and I'm really excited about the term paper I produced at the end of the semester. There's not too much guidance in assignment instructions, but I think it's just because it's a new class and will develop over time. Peter is great and has such deep insights in this industry. Guest lectures can get a little dry sometimes, but overall I really enjoyed this class. It's definitely not limited to ESPP concentrators – one of the greatest strengths of this class is its diverse set of student perspectives.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: This is great way to combine to take something you are interested in and do a deep dive on it however you want with guidance from advisor and ESPP.  So fun to feel like you can apply knowledge from past classes to put together something really representative of your time at Harvard in a topic you are passionate about.
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

best_comment: Pretty good and eye–opening class. The lectures cover many different topics, but not in much depth. While in the moment the lectures were engaging, oftentimes my classmates and I wouldn't really be able to clearly state what we learned after class. You have 2 assignments per week + readings, which aren't too bad, and prevent you from slacking off too much. One of the weekly assignments is to do research for the term project, so the work is distributed nicely over the entire semester. Ken is a kind and receptive professor, but cold–calls a lot. I also got to know my classmates better because it was a small class
subject: Environmental Sci & Public Pol

course_title: Issues in the Study of Native American Religion 001
best_comment: Difficult topics and readings, and really excellent visiting lecturers. If you're interested in learning about the religious dimension to contemporary issues that Native American communities face, I would highly recommend this course.
worse_comment: I personally would tell Native students to be very cautious when taking this course, and I am not sure I would recommend it for Natives. I felt uncomfortable most of the time and left almost every class angry or frustrated with what other students in the class had said. This class was definitely interesting but was also one of the most ignorant spaces I have encountered at this school thus far.

course_title: Love's Labors Found: Uncovering Histories of Emotional Labor 001
best_comment: This class is fantastic! Don't take it if you can't commit to doing the work/readings––it's definitely a heavier load because it's a high level seminar. Professor Light is brilliant, so great at community building, and an over all great teacher. She supports everyones growth and is clearly so glad to be facilitating these conversations.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2023: Love's Labors Found: Uncovering Histories of Emotional Labor

course_title: Quechua, Indigenous language revitalization and Global Indigeneity 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE! Américo Mendoza–Mori is an incredible professor who creates such a great learning environment and is always willing to help you if you have questions. The content and materials in this class will introduce you to things you have not thought about, and it will change how you look at and understand the world. The readings are all super interesting, and also manageable. This class is AMAZING, I highly recommend.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! PLEASE! Such a gem in terms of accessibility, representation, and time investment. Currently the best class at Harvard
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2023: Quechua, Indigenous language revitalization and Global Indigeneity

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE WITH ELEANOR!!! The creative final project is really so meaningful and the showcase with everyone's work is fantastic. If you do decide to take it, it would be better to start your final project early if you genuinely care about the topic so that you can have a more meaningful experience with your project!

This class is an incredible introduction to migration and refugee policy. As an undergraduate, I thought that the overall workload wasn't too difficult to keep up with it. I loved how the class facilitated so many opportunities to not just learn from Professor Bhabha and the amazing guest speakers, but to also learn from other students in the class, many of whom have rich and interesting backgrounds  in public policy and social justice.

course_title: “A Place called Home”: Histories of Spatial Discrimination and Ethnic Migration in the United States 001
best_comment: This class could definitely use a little bit of tweaking, but overall it was pretty good. It was my first class in EMR, and compared to the amazing things I had heard from friends about other EMR classes, this one was a little bit disappointing. Having said that, I still definitely learned a lot and enjoyed the class. It really doesn't demand too much time, and class discussions were usually pretty interesting.

course_title: Topics in Latinx Studies: Imagining Latinidad 001
best_comment: Take this class! It is pretty low effort and  it allowed me to speak on several topics as a Latina and it allowed me to hear the experiences of my peers as well. There is an amazing selection of media, as Americo mixes academic literature with popular culture making everything super relatable and relevant to our generation. I also enjoy the conversations we are able to foster inside of the classroom. Lastly, there were amazing outside opportunities like 2 guest speakers, a pop up Mariachi Veritas performance, an event with Latinx high school students and a museum visit which really allowed the learning experience to materialize outside of the classroom.  There aren't many assignments for the class, as there are weekly discussion posts, a written take home midterm and a final paper (10–12 pages). It is all doable and there are good resources at hand to help with both the midterm and final.
subject: Ethnicity, Migration, Rights
course_title_2023: Topics in Latinx Studies: Imagining Latinidad

best_comment: It's a great introduction to academic essay writing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: There are definitely a lot of pros and cons to taking Expos 10. If you aren't very comfortable with your writing skills, I would recommend taking this route because it will improve your writing tremendously.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is well suited for the student who wishes to get the basics of writing down and the student who is a good writer but wishes to further strengthen and improve their writing. It does require some work, however doing that work will benefit you in the end as it works towards the essays at the end of each of the three units this course consists of.
worse_comment: If you are not sure about your writing skills, take this class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I was personally not looking forward to Expos but this class ended up being my favorite of the semester. Felt like I had loads of fun while also learning so much. Dr. Hanes is an absolutely amazing professor.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take it. If you feel like you need a course that will ease you into college writing this is exactly the course for you. The transition from high school writing to college writing is a significant one and it's important that you have the skills to help you succeed in your next four years here.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos 10 gave me a solid base for creating a thesis and developing academic texts. It is an introductory course, do not worry if you do not have previous experience because the professor teaches you the process step by step. Take advantage of the resources available, for example, the one o one conference you have with the professor. Take this course if you think you need to practice your academic writing skills, and want an almost individualized guide from teachers. I do not regret taking Expos 10. I would take it again if I could.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You’ll see your abilities grow over time, specially if English isn’t your first language. That said, if you want to optimize the number of courses you want to take here, then go directly to Expos 20. That is not against Dr Jehn, because he is an amazing writer and reader and his comments will make you become a much better writer—trust me
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: An excellent course to take in your freshman fall, and especially if it is taught by Jonah Johnson. All your class meetings and conferences will be very interesting and useful! He explains academic writing in a way that makes the process very intuitive and understandable. Additionally, he is very knowledgeable on a wide range of topics (including sports, history, the process of learning, and how languages work), so he can really find mutual interest with each student and build a personal connection. Jonah was extremely understanding when it comes to deadlines and scheduling conferences. He always made sure that Expos work is flexible enough so that it doesn't interfere with important deadlines and exams for the rest of our courses. This course is perfect for freshman fall as it is enjoyable and it has a relatively low amount of work.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you aren't sure about your writing abilities take this class. It will help you find areas of your writing that can be improved where you may have thought they were strong. Additionally, the format of this class is useful because when it comes time to write a paper in this class, you will already have everything you need already written and all you have to do it put it together.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! Professor Mardirossian is amazing. She is incredibly supportive, helpful, and a fair grader. She will humor even the most awfully structured and bad essay ideas and work extensively with you to make it coherent and a good piece of writing. This course is structured in a way that will help you succeed and grow as a writer. If you put in the work, it won't be hard to leave with an A. The workload is light and often the assignments build on top of each other. You will begin writing your unit draft only to find that you already have 1/3 of it done.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would recommend taking this class because you get a solid foundation in college writing. The Professor was also very understanding and helpful and gave great feedback on how to improve my writing skills.
worse_comment: Take this class if you have no idea what critical writing is, otherwise, I think you would be fine if you took Expos 20.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Expos Studios 10 was a good course. Although sometimes it felt like busy work I enjoyed the pacing.
worse_comment: Take it if you are not confident in your abilities
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is amazing! You won't come out of this thinking it's been a waste of time. Genuinely very enjoyable and will help build writing confidence. The amount of time you get to work on you writing 1 on 1, with classmates or as a discussion is incredible. Make the most out of office hours you get, which you get loads btw!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class only if you feel uncomfortable with writing. Professor Vilbig is great professor although his response time could definitely be better. I would recommend anyone taking this class to make sure to take notes on the actual pdfs as it can make it easier to follow along what the professor is talking about. It can be boring at some points of the semester, but you gain good knowledge into what a good essay should look like.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If they are willing to use an extra course slot, Expos 10 is not a bad choice.
worse_comment: If you know you can be uncomfortable with writing take Studio; more individual work and feedback on essays, smaller steps in writing the essay. Expos 20 would have moved at a faster pace and been a lot more fluctuating in the workload.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is pretty easy as long as you do the small assignments throughout you should be fine. The essays there is good feedback that is given by the professor at least from Professor Strauss. But. sometimes the commentary can seem vague but once you have your conference the comments make sense as long as you ask questions in how to implement them.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is very beneficial for refreshing your memory about general composition skills, and it is a great class to take in the first semester to help ease into the college course load.  (Bonus: This counts towards the Pre–Med English requirement).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is a really good intro to writing. Just remember that  if you take exspos 10, then you also have to take it in the spring
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course emphasizes educating its students in the curriculum rather than just challenging them or leaving them to study for themselves.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Dr. Napier is an effective teacher who gives excellent constructive feedback. I highly recommend his section!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This was definitely my favorite course of the semester. Even if you get placed into Expos 20 (like I did) this class is so much fun and so worth it. Even though anybody could take this class without having any college–level writing experience, everybody can learn from this class. Now, I look at writing in a way that I never did before. It was definitely a reasonable workload that helped to ease me into college life.
worse_comment: I would tell students that if they are not comfortable with their writing skills then they should take this class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would 100% recommend taking Expos 10 if you don't feel that your writing skills are on par with what you'd like them to be. I would recommend it in complete confidence! This course has helped me immensely with my writing skills, and I now feel much more confident than I did before about my writing and have grown to like writing more than I had previously. There is a lot of work in the course and assignments, so keep that in mind, but having a close–quarter workshop–style class where you can receive peer editing and close mentorship from your professor is excellent.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an amazing class, and Dr. Zecca is a great professor! Although I had doubts about taking this class, I am truly glad that I did because I had a great experience. Out of all of my classes this semester, I probably learned the most from this class. 10/10
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: It is such a super interesting course! At first, I really thought gothic fiction wasn't for me, but all the readings was engaging and fun to read. Pat is an amazing professor and she truly cares about her students as people and writers. She is the perfect person to have as an instructor if you really want to improve your writing skills.
worse_comment: Make sure to communicate with your professors –– especially if you are having any difficulties with deadlines or just a hard time with course work at all. Communication equals the start of a resolution to whatever issue you are facing.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Jacobs Religious Pluralism Expos class was my favorite class this semester. There are not many readings or much work outside of when drafts and revisions are due, and the class has taught me so much about what it means to write an effective paper. Like any other Expos class, you will have to put work in during revision week,  but I learned so many interesting things about religion in the government, and everyday lives that I will take with me throughout my life and changed my perspective on religion in the United States. Not to mention that Jacob is an AMAZING instructor!! I am so happy that this was my top choice, I highly recommend!! Best of Luck :))
worse_comment: Take it, take it, take it. It's so interesting and completely changed the way I think about writing. It's challenging but never overwhelming or super stressful. Jacob's right, it changes the way you see religion and government forever.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The class is overall very solid and will teach you a lot about writing in the end. You may not realize it while you're in it, but by the time you write the research paper, you will have felt that you have improved as long as you keep in mind the feedback that Collier gives. I came in with a good idea of how to write literary analysis essays, but I felt I needed to transition to the analytical style taught in expos. There were times when I felt consistently confused on what was going on and eventually would figure it out 2 days before the essay was due. Essay weeks were rough. I would spend like 8 hrs/day for 2–3 days writing and editing, but again, this was mostly due to my first time writing in analytical style. During non–essay weeks, class was very chill, readings were brief but interesting, and discussions were great. Out of all the expos, this is the one to take.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class was amazing. Most freshmen don’t enjoy their first year Expos class, but everyone in my class absolutely loved it! This was partially because Willa is an awesome and engaging teacher, and partially because the course itself is super cool and goes through lots of interesting stuff, including field trips and interactive experiences. 10/10 recommend!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. Professor Cole is an extremely interesting speaker, created a collaborative environment that really brought the students together, and substantially improved my skills as a writer. The readings are fascinating and class discussions are highly engaging. I believe the assignments are manageable and encourage us to express how we understand the texts, though towards the second half of the course we don't have many assignments to turn in (for better or worse). The smaller assignments also build very well into our final essay. Professor Cole is a fair grader and is very accessible (many opportunities to discuss drafts and ask questions). This was by far my favorite class of the semester (which I heard isn't very typical of Expos), so I would HIGHLY recommend ranking this Expos highly!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This overall is a good class. It's not an amazing class, that will make you excited about taking it, but it's also not a bad expos class. It a good one to fill the requirement, you learn and the assignments are not bad. The only real reading you have to do is of 1894, analyze it enough to write some papers about it, and the second unit is basically researching and writing about a topic that you find interesting that relates in some way to 1984 (this means almost any political science topic will work). If you like the field you will definitely enjoy it, and if you don't is also fine. Good class to fufill the expos requirement.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This Expos topic is AMAZING! I would highly recommend even if you are just remotely interested in feminism. You do go quite in depth into the topics surrounding feminism, but the readings are not too bad, they're all actually relatively short and pretty fun to analyze. The community within the class is really positive and enthusiastic and as a result, I always looked forward to coming into class. The discussions we have are always really intriguing and the supportive environment adds a lot to the experience. Dr. Gold is so incredibly kind and positive and I always loved her energy in classes. She is also incredibly helpful throughout the whole writing process and is always down to have a conversation with you if you're struggling to put your ideas into words or in an organized structure. TAKE THIS EXPOS!!!
worse_comment: Start writing early. Take Dr. Gold's feedback seriously. Go to OH. Sign up for individual meetings.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: For many incoming freshmen, Expos classes are something to be dreaded and the hope is to end up with a class you "mildly enjoy." Yet, for the few freshmen lucky enough to take Expos with Dr. Gold, the class is instead one you look forward to – for both the learning aspect and the overall enjoyment! Not only does Dr. Gold care about her students, by selecting readings we want to read and allowing us to apply feminist theory to whatever topics we care about (from the Kardashians to Kpop to the NFL), but she is truly a scholar in her field whom we can learn so much from. Dr. Gold provides audio–visual feedback that WILL improve your writing, and she works to ensure that every single student improves their writing.  If you are looking for an Expos to take to learn from, improve your writing, and actually enjoy, take it with Dr. Gold!
best_gem_comment: I absolutely, wholeheartedly recommend this course (definitely a gem both inside and out)! Dr. Gold is an AMAZING professor; she is very supportive, encouraging, understanding, and enthusiastic about the material she teaches. She provides detailed feedback on drafts and walks students through the steps of writing a good paper. From a logistical standpoint, the workload is not heavy at all compared to other expos classes while the material is very fascinating. This course also provided me with an intellectual foundation of feminism and forever changed the way I view the representation of women in current media. Tip: definitely rank this class as your first choice because the lottery is competitive.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: – This course will push you, but you’ll come out a better writer.– Good choice for both humanities– and STEM–oriented students.– If you’re not that interested in the environment and climate–change, this course may not be for you. However, it includes enough material on other subjects like ethics, philosophy, and romantic literature so that even those who aren’t thoroughly interested in the environment can enjoy the course.– The instructor may give vague feedback and comments, but this is to your benefit! You will become a more independent writer and develop new skills that will help with the rest of your writing at Harvard, whether that’s in the humanities, social sciences, or hard sciences.
worse_comment: Unit 1 sucks.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is definitely helpful in improving your writing, but you have to be open to feedback and change. Sometimes things aren’t clear at first when starting an essay, but you have to just trust the process. Office hours are helpful simply for organizing your thoughts and getting a bit of extra help on essays.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Dr. Herron is truly a wonderful teacher—personable, patient, and passionate about the topics discussed in this course! This was my first experience with the sociological perspective on writing and Dr. Herron really opened my mind to a new way of thinking and writing that has definitely impacted my path. Make sure you take the time to do the readings, which can be long sometimes but SUPER INTERESTING, because the class discussions were so intellectually simulating and perspective changing. This class was genuinely my favorite this semester; not many people have a great expos experience and I truly believe if you take this course, you will definitely have a significantly better time. Can't give enough praise for Dr. Herron too, such an awesome teacher who really cares about his students!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class was one of my most enjoyable classes. I loved the people and felt so comfortable with Eliza and all my classmates. It was very easy and comfortable to participate.
