Eliza's feedback was the most valuable to me; she truly put in a lot of effort to give helpful comments. It is evident how much work she put into helping students and wanting them to succeed. It is also very relevant to today in the sense that learning about climate fictions is very important.
worse_comment: Would not recommend. Preceptor is very kind, but assignments are lengthy and frankly unnecessary. I feel that my writing has gotten worse, as the class prioritizes quantity in words over quality in content. Class (mandatory attendance) is a waste of time, and I could spend the hour doing something more productive (but this may be true across all EXPOS sections).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Don't be fooled: Expos is not the cakewalk that it appears. Although it's a mandatory requirement for all freshmen, the rigor of the class varies highly depending on the preceptor (teacher). Eliza is an absolutely phenomenal teacher and a lovely individual, but that does not mean that you will need to put out some of the best writing you can create. Personally, I was a very strong student in my high school English department; I have always loved writing and received a few prizes for it. I came into Expos with the hubris that I would treat the writing like it was high school and slip through a boring college requirement. Getting the grade that I wanted made this the most demanding class I took this semester, and I hardly feel like my writing grew. This class is stressful if you walk into it with closed eyes, so be aware that Expos will be demanding and relatively unrewarding in terms of writing.With all of that said, this section is elite. If you're an environmentalist, these readings challenge your assumptions and force you to grow your thinking! Also, you'll be in class with other people who are generally environmentalists and bring great perspectives to the work. Eliza's great; the content of this section is great.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you love science fiction, this is the course for you. A perfectly reasonable workload paired with great teaching makes for a fun semester.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you're looking for a more creative approach to accomplishing your Expos requirement then I 100% recommend this class. The books, articles, and essays you read throughout this class are genuinely so interesting. Whether its literature, history, psychology, sociology, or anthropology,  you quickly realize how much you can actually learn from vampires, which leaves a lot of room for you to decide what angle you want to take with the essays you write. I've always been more on the STEM side, so I wanted to take an Expos class that kind of strayed away from that world in order to use it as a break from science and math and I think that was one of the best decisions I made. Dr. Martin is also an amazing professor and provides incredible feedback that I truly think is the reason I have such a positive perception of this class. I can genuinely see my improvement from beginning to end and I owe a lot of that to his teaching style and dedication to providing useful feedback.
worse_comment: You will not regret choosing this class! I do believe that everyone should take this class. Monsters and vampires are projections of Humanities fears and desires. Therefore, to understand or master the study of vampirology is to understand society. you will understand what drive people, what scares them You will understand the intersection  of humanity and monstrosity.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The discussions are super interesting to listen to, but if you're not a constitutional genius (which somehow almost everyone else in the class seemed to be) and your parents aren't lawyers who can bounce around ideas about case law with you, you might be like me and not really have much of substance to contribute to these discussions. But even though I mostly stayed quiet, class was very fun and interesting. Ross grades pretty harshly, and this is definitely NOT an easy expos. If you want an easy expos, don't take this class. The weekends before essays are due you likely won't be able to go out, and much of your Thanksgiving will be spend doing research (unless you're a constitutional law/writing genius of course which you very well may be). HOWEVER, it is a very rewarding class, everyone is super super engaged so the discussions are fascinatingly insightful and not forced, and you do learn a lot. It's good to take if you're pre–law. This class is very hard, but it can certainly be worth it.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! This course is challenging but very rewarding.  Readings and discussions are fascinating, especially if you're interested in law and politics. Although the legal cases are intimidating at first, they become a lot more manageable as you learn more about case law. Class discussions are engaging and open, even when talking about heavy or intellectually challenging subjects. Dr. Martin does a great job leading conversation and creates a real sense of community within the class. His grading standards are high but fair, and he does a good job providing thoughtful feedback that pushes you to improve as a writer. This class may feel difficult at times, but it will improve your writing and analytical skills more than almost any other course. If you are interested in law or want to grow as a writer, this would be a great course for you :)
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is hands down the best expos class you can take. Keating is an incredible teacher and highly knowledgeable. He's super organized, classes are fun and interesting, provides great feedback, essays are manageable but not easy, and the topic is super relevant. You will have a great experience if you are lucky enough to get in this class!
best_gem_comment: Stay ahead on assignments. This is the BEST expos course, GEM. Professor Mckeon is great and keeps the class engaged.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The class covers super interesting material. Each unit provides interesting readings and the smaller assignments done in this class build up to a interesting essays that are enjoyable to write.
worse_comment: Work hard on your revisions on your essays. Don't plagiarize.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: GEM GEM GEM (provided you're interested in sociology or Marx).Rachel is the nicest, best instructor on this planet, and will reduce your readings to the absolute minimum necessary for discussion while also giving you the option to read more if you're interested. Readings are mostly taken from labor sociology books and papers (Cech, Kunda, Braverman), which are fairly standard in difficulty, although the Marx section is a bit denser (but Rachel makes it easier and provides alternative sources in case you find it a bit too hard). You will be doing a non–trivial amount of close reading, so this is not the Expos section for you if you want to just cruise by while not doing the readings, but if you allow it to, it will definitely be a paradigm shift for you in all walks of life that contain work, from your future career to your view of headlines in the present and the near future.There are three essays of increasing length, and Rachel does make grading stricter as the semester progresses, but the amount of feedback you receive makes it completely fine, and holds your hand to an appropriate amount to prep you for college writing. Keep an open mind about your writing, it's not as good or watertight as you remember it ;)Discussions were honestly the best part of this course: this course attracts such a wide variety of people from all walks of life and all political opinions that seminars are both very broad and surprisingly deep, and can get you to extend your idea of work beyond what you know from your own experience. Definitely a contrast with other Expos section, where the same opinion is parroted ad infinitum and the 75–minute sections feel like they take up your whole morning.Rachel is also super flexible and available outside of class time, and is more than willing to talk about things other than the course that you are interested in, whether that is out of sheer curiosity, to advance your paper, to figure out what you want to do in life, etc.I'd be lying if there isn't a voice in my head that is telling me to switch my concentration to sociology.TL;DR: If you're at all tangentially interested in political philosophy or sociology, TAKE THIS EXPOS. Non–trivial amounts of reading (maybe like 50 pages total per reading assignment, spread across 2 or 3 sources), but everything else makes it so, so worth it, and Rachel's incredible. Honestly the best class I took at Harvard this semester.
best_gem_comment: GEM GEM GEM (provided you're interested in sociology or Marx).Rachel is the nicest, best instructor on this planet, and will reduce your readings to the absolute minimum necessary for discussion while also giving you the option to read more if you're interested. Readings are mostly taken from labor sociology books and papers (Cech, Kunda, Braverman), which are fairly standard in difficulty, although the Marx section is a bit denser (but Rachel makes it easier and provides alternative sources in case you find it a bit too hard). Keep an open mind about your writing, it's not as good or watertight as you remember it ;)Discussions were honestly the best part of this course: this course attracts such a wide variety of people from all walks of life and all political opinions that seminars are both very broad and surprisingly deep, and can get you to extend your idea of work beyond what you know from your own experience. Definitely a contrast with other Expos section, where the same opinion is parroted ad infinitum and the 75–minute sections feel like they take up your whole morning.Rachel is also super flexible and available outside of class time, and is more than willing to talk about things other than the course that you are interested in, whether that is out of sheer curiosity, to advance your paper, to figure out what you want to do in life, etc.I'd be lying if there isn't a voice in my head that is telling me to switch my concentration to sociology.TL;DR: If you're at all tangentially interested in political philosophy or sociology, TAKE THIS EXPOS. Non–trivial amounts of reading (maybe like 50 pages total per reading assignment, spread across 2 or 3 sources), but everything else makes it so, so worth it, and Rachel's incredible. Honestly the best class I took at Harvard this semester.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: There is awesome support from the professor available. Make sure to plan ahead and stay on top of due dates so you can fully use this help!
worse_comment: Work hard early and get a head start on your assignments.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I have to be honest, the readings will be hard unless you absolutely love the topic. If you are a war history fan, I would take the class, but otherwise, I would not put it on your list for fear that you will get the class. It is easier to write about something you're passionate about, curious about, or can forsee yourself being passionate or curious about. If not, it's going to be an uphill battle, as I learned this semester.
worse_comment: Take 20 because you get it over with and 10 wouldn't be worth it
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This course was incredible in teaching me how to improve specific parts of my writing and adapt to the styles of college writing. David (instructor) is engaging, passionate, and fun, and the topics that we learned about ranged from Icelandic sagas to family photography to self–discovery on various geneology related topics. I came out of the class a better writer and feel that my writing is more polished that it was when I started. If you're looking for a fun expos class to take that doesn't take up too much of your time, I suggest this one with great enthusiasm!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You should take this expos!! As far as the content, there is something for everyone. I came in being interested in exploring the third unit, but I found myself to be very interested in both the Icelandic family sagas and photography units. David presents the content in a way that is fascinating. Beyond that, David is an extremely approachable professor and fair grader. He makes clear what his expectations are and what should be changed between the revision and final essay stages. He also responds to emails and has frequent office hours. This is a really great expos class to take to gain a better understanding of college level writing and fulfill the requirement. I would highly recommend it. As far as expos goes (for this class or another), my advice would be to start early on the essays and assignments because deadlines can sneak up on you. Also, the writing center is a great resource! Even if you can't get an appointment, I'd recommend taking advantage of their drop in hours because that was very helpful for me. Finally, when you receive feedback on your draft, expect to have to dedicate time towards implementing that feedback. The feedback is often more large–scale versus small changes, so you will generally have to dedicate a good amount of time to your essay after receiving feedback on a draft.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I think this class is challenging but in a doable and interesting way. I was apprehensive at first at the idea of this being a philosophy class but the expos class style means you are supported throughout so you do not feel out of your depth. There is quite a lot of reading at time but then there can be weeks without any, so it does balance itself out. Jen is super friendly and wants to see everyone succeed but you do have to put some effort in, and there are probably easier expos classes for sure.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this course. This course was excellent, as it both vastly improved my writing and gave me a deep understanding of the philosophy of friendship. Through her lectures and feedback, Jen taught me how to express my ideas in a way that was concise and easily understandable for my readers. She continually emphasized the importance of "writing for the reader," which is a concept I plan to apply in all of my writing going forward, as this style of writing allows me not just to share my ideas, but to convince my audience of my ideas.  Jen was also very accessible, and she took a great deal of time and care when giving me her feedback on my essays–––her comments really set me up to succeed.Another major strength of this course was that Jen made it very easy to understand difficult concepts. Some of the reading in this course is difficult, but after each reading, Jen fostered illuminating discussions that enhanced my understanding of the text. She welcomed student input, and many times when I didn't understand something, I actually ended up learning it from one of my classmates. Jen also always made herself available after class to talk through any outstanding questions I or my classmates had.Many people see Expos 20 as just a requirement, but this was actually my favorite course this semester. The only problem with it is that it doesn't last for more than a semester! The content we cover is engaging and relatable to everyone, even if you don't have a background in philosophy. At the end of this course, I find myself wanting to study this topic more. I am currently not a philosophy concentrator (nor am I concentrating in anything in the humanities, for that matter), but I feel that this course is very much a philosophy gateway drug.
worse_comment: Take advantage of office hours, simplify your argument to the most basic form, proving each claim, in service of the larger argument. Take your time, and discuss structure in office hours.
best_gem_comment: Was a great course as an introduction to philosophy and completing the Expos requirement. The workload is very manageable and not time–consuming at all. The preceptor Jen is very dedicated to her job and holds great respect for the student no matter what level of writing they are entering. Definitely a GEM!!!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: When I was reading the Q reports for Expos courses this fall, there seemed to be a popular opinion among Harvard students that Expos is a pain and nothing more than a required course you have to get through to graduate. But in my experience, the Expos experience is invaluable to being prepared to write at a college level. This class was honestly one of my favorites this semester. I've never had the experience of taking a course centered around the topic queerness surrounded by other queer people–– though, of course, don't expect this to be a queer studies class. At the end of the day, it is a class that teaches you to write, and what you will end up writing about will be interpretations of different types of queer media. Dr. Pietras is very helpful during the revision process of your essays, but you need to make sure that you go to draft conferences with a draft that you have put some thought into. Even though the drafts aren't graded, it is difficult to get feedback that will help you turn in a polished final essay if the draft was just a few pages of writing without thought that you don't plan to influence the final essay. Don't be afraid to approach him with questions throughout your writing process, and when he has office hours, grab an appointment, even if you're not totally sure what you will talk about. Expos is one of the few writing–based classes where you have this level of involvement from your instructor throughout the writing process and ABOUT the writing process–– i.e. giving you strategies to improve your writing and streamline the way you write/edit. If you work hard in this course and show your instructor that you care, your writing, including structure, argumentation, and ability to persuade, will improve. Take this Expos!!!
worse_comment: Please do not take it. The lectures are unhelpful, the assignments are meaningless, and the feedback received on essays is not valuable enough to outweigh the negatives of this course.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: The capstone research essay was the highlight of the course for me, but you have less time for it than you'll think you do. Try thinking about what source you'd like to investigate earlier on so you can spend all the actual assignment time on really sinking your teeth into your source and your research on it!
worse_comment: I'd honestly steer you away from this course.  The course was an overall frustrating experience for several reasons.  First, class time was very boring, and about a half an hour of class each day was just devoted to the Preceptor reading slides off the board word–for–word.  Second, feedback was provided in a very slow manner.  We would often only receive the feedback from our papers one day before our next paper or draft was due.  This made any application of said feedback super challenging.  Third, the feedback that we received wasn't very helpful or direct.  I was frustrated by the feedback that I received as it was vague and sparse.  Fourth, the feedback was not very tailored to my actual needs.  One of my most frustrating experiences in this course was reading my feedback side by side with a peer in the course, only to notice that our feedback was nearly identical.  Fifth, the materials for the course were not all very interesting, especially given the theme.  Some of our materials didn't even mention queerness at all, and seemed to be reused from a past course on Nostalgia.  Finally, getting help in this course was very angering.  The preceptor was very reluctant to help students during or outside of class.  When approached during class with a question the Preceptor often refused to answer, or did so with hesitation.  We were allowed to send one email asking about one very specific aspect of our paper, and were occasionally allowed one 20 minute meeting to discuss our draft.  For a course designed to teach students a new skill the overall lack of help along the way seemed like a poorly guided decision.  I will say that I learned a lot about interpretive analysis in this class, but that is what I expected of this course.  The process of said learning, however, was far more challenging because of the and Preceptor than it was the content.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I LOVED Dr. Quigley's Expos class. Some of the most interesting content of the semester! I love psych (but wasn't able to take Pscyh 1), and this class more than enough made up for it! Dr. Quigley herself is such an intelligent, well–spoken, kind, and helpful professor. She is also extremely knowledgeable about the writing process and gives her students the BEST and very fair advice on how to improve papers. I'm not so sure why so many freshmen dread Expos–––this class was one of my favorites. You get to make tight–knit connections with a lot of your peers (which may be more difficult in large lecture classes). And Dr. Quigley creates such a welcoming and friendly environment. This class is a must–take! I highly highly recommend!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I may be biased, but I believe that this is the best Expos class there is. Dr. Q is an incredible instructor for both writing and an introduction into the field of psychology. You will learn so much from this class and actually enjoy doing it. Class discussions are relaxed but engaging, and Dr. Q facilitates a wonderful environment for you to have one of your first classes at Harvard in. It is an especially great course for any STEM concentrators (regardless of your interest in psychology) because many of the readings come from scientific journals and you learn how to write for STEM. Also, in regards to reading, this class is less reading–intensive than most of the other Expos classes I have heard about, which is great because most Expos classes are about the same amount of work, the only variable part is the reading. Feedback on essays is thorough and specific, but once you get over the initial shock of actually having your work critiqued (if you're like me and did not get a lot of that in high school), you never feel embarrassed or bad about your work because everything is framed in such a way as to help you get better. All–in–all, I would highly recommend this course to anyone remotely interested.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a great choice for expos. Professor Raymer is super nice, and the material is incredibly interesting. At the end of the day, try to pick an Expos section that sounds interesting to you. If you don't enjoy the material, expos won't be fun, but if you're engaged with it, it can be a very good class! With that said, the material in this course is very interesting and very engaging. We began by investigating the ethics of gene editing, looking at the issue from a wide variety of perspectives. There are some super interesting readings, for instance a couple that wanted their baby to be blind – there's just so much to unpack in this topic. We then moved into the topic of death, and how to approach the end of life. Did this get a little dark at times? Yes. But it really raised some incredible questions, and I'm glad we dove into this issue. For instance, I'm completely making up the numbers here, but let's say there's a treatment that gives you a 10% chance to survive beyond 5 years, but 90% of people on this treatment die within 6 months quite uncomfortably. Now, if you decide to stop fighting the disease, but instead focus on comfort in the end, you have a 70% chance of living to 1.5 years in hospice care. These aren't real numbers, but the idea behind this can often be quite true. So how should we approach the ends of our lives? Focus on extending them as much as possible, or living a fully as we can? And what is the responsibility of medical practitioners in cases like these? How do you balance giving hope versus being a realist? How should we think about our own deaths, and the dying of our family members. A lot of very interesting things. Finally, we moved on to our research projects. People studied a whole range of topics, from euthanasia to DIY biology to human–animal chimeras to healthcare, and it was a great chance to dive into a very interesting area.Professor Raymer would have our final papers due one week after we received our feedback from her, which was incredibly helpful – it gave a chance to really take advantage of her suggestions and work them into our papers well. She was very willing to help with questions, and her feedback itself was very useful. This class was really great – highly recommend!!
best_gem_comment: Great class definitely rank it as highest for your expos selection! Raymer is literally the nicest and more caring professor at Harvard this class is a gem!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an amazing Expos section! If you are interested in biology, technology, philosophy, and/or ethics, this expos will have something to pique your interest. The readings are really well curated (even if a bit dense) and the class discussions are lively, so if you do the readings and participate, you will have a great time. And, Dr. Raymer is an amazing preceptor: she is expertly knowledgeable about biology, ethics, and writing, gives excellent feedback to help you in your writing process, and is a very nice person (and pretty lenient in class)!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I would tell future students that it is an excellent course to take to improve as a writer and the classes are a lot of fun. I did not wake up dreading to go to Expos, and while some of the essays demand a good amount of time, they weren't a drag to write. Unless you have a strong attachment to the source material of any other course, I would definitely recommend this course over the others.
worse_comment: Be prepared to be graded relatively harshly compared to other expos classes. This class seems to be more difficult than other expos classes because of this difficulty in grading. Make sure you get a head start on your essays in order to ask the preceptor as many questions as possible.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: A great choice for Expos, would recommend it if you're interested in immigration! Covers a really important history! Course material could get a little repetitive at times, but overall a great class. Routon is a wonderful preceptor who cares a lot about her students and is flexible and understanding.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is hands–down the best Expos course out there. The information you get to learn is absolutely crucial as humans of the world, but also very intriguing and eye–opening. Repeatedly, our class was shocked that we had not learned this information previously regarding the history of immigration in this country alongside the crises involved in that history. Each week, there is simply two journal responses from very manageable and interesting course readings, and then three essays total in the course which can be of your topic of choice under the given prompt so there is a lot of room to explore your interests. Finally, I have never met such a kind and positive professor than Dr. Routon; she makes the course what it is and the collaborative space is so friendly and rich in learning thanks to her. She is incredibly flexible in deadlines and will help you out with anything you need, whether it's course–related or even life advice in general. Dr. Routon (who is so kind to let us refer to her as Erin) never fails to make everyone smile and laugh, and she always lights up the room with her presence. Highly, highly recommend this Expos course without a doubt! Best class of my first semester at Harvard.
best_gem_comment: Great professor! Kind, supportive, accomadating. The readings are incredibly insightful. Definitely a gem EXPOS.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: PLEASE PLEASE PLEASEEEEEEEEEEE TAKE THIS EXPOS COURSE!!!! I BEG YOU!!! Dr. Saha is one of the greatest professors at Harvard!!! She is not only an excellent educator, but such a compassionate and kind person––she will help you with anything you need (even when you've finished taking her class). Her writing instructions are clear and the projects are SO MUCH FUN. I'm not even kidding we got to make this super cool video project with a plant–based celebrity!!! And the research topics are SO interesting. Even if you're not vegan you will take so much away from this course and its tangential focus on the environment, politics, human rights, etc...and now I've learned how to become both a better writer and a better person. PLEASE TAKE THIS EXPOS!!!!! <333
worse_comment: THis course is worth taking for sparsha alone! However, if you are a firm non vegetarian, you might not enjoy this course. As a meat eater, there were times where I felt a bit out of place and criticized but it worked out
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS EXPOS AND PUT IT AS YOUR NUMBER ONE!!! This is a GEM and I can rave about it on and on. 1) Dr. Saha is an amazing professor. She guides you through EVERY step of the writing process, and her constructive criticism is extremely helpful. I can confidently say that she has made me a better writer. Also, section discussions are interesting and she knows how to keep the conversation from lulling. 2) The material is so interesting!! I'm pre–med and mainly had a general interest/curiosity in the topic because I didn't really know much about it at all, but I left the class with a newfound passion for the subject and I turned out to be genuinely interested in the material. 2) The workload is relatively light, especially when compared to other Expos classes. Throughout the entire course, we have read mainly a handful of excerpts, with all of them being less than twenty pages each and also were very thought–provoking.  The most reading you'll do is probably when researching sources for your essays.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: THIS IS THE ACTUAL BEST EXPOS!! Sparsha gives us outlines for both the argumentative paper and the research paper! I never had experience with research isn high school and after this class, I feel super confident about having the resources to pursue my own. She’s super supportive in and out of class, she’s one of those profs you’ll stay in contact with even after your 4 years. She’s an amazing person who truly cares for her students!! Even if you aren’t into animals or vegan (I’m not either), the topic is so broad that you’ll definitely find something to write about that you’ll enjoy. Animals and Politics is the gem of expos and maybe even the gem of gems. It’s for all type of students, athletes, overachievers, researchers, or someone trying to just get through expos. This class is MUST take, it must be the top on your ranked choices, I promise you won’t regret it!!
worse_comment: Even if you aren't super into animals or politics, this is a phenomenal Expos to take. The instructor is incredible, the workload is relatively light, and you will learn a lot!
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Even if you're not extremely interested in animal rights per se, Sparsha is extremely nice and supportive, the content is interesting, and the passion she has for the topic comes through in everything we do. Sparsha does a great job facilitating your writing skill development through manageable, structured assignments. Would definitely consider this class to be a gem. The video capstone project was unique within the expos program and an opportunity that no other class was able to experience.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: I highly recommend this course. I am honestly a little puzzled reading previous Q guide comments about this course. I found myself thinking about the concepts we discussed in class a lot, such as the nature of suffering, punishment and criminal justice, and the relation of contemporary political issues to hells and underworlds. I was actually randomly assigned this course after missing the expos sectioning preferences deadline, and at first was really worried about the course workload, grading etc. based on rumor and the syllabus. However, in hindsight, I'm very happy I took this course. Professor Scheffler is actually a very reasonable grader – my peers were averaging A– in their papers. He also gives INCREDIBLY detailed and useful feedback on response papers, such that there is absolutely adequate support to do well in your papers, despite the slight scarcity of office hours (sometimes his comments are longer than your entire response paper). He is also excellent in facilitating discussions in class. He has an amazing ability to sum up and evaluate people's contributions super clearly and offer counterarguments when appropriate, which I found helped my understanding of the texts a lot.  The workload is totally reasonable as long as you spread out your work throughout the weeks (and not do what I did and spend 30 hours straight in Cabot cramming in the final paper – that was one hell of a katabatic journey XD). I found the papers pretty enjoyable to write about (I wrote about Dante's Inferno, and the films Pan's Labyrinth and Parasite) and was happy we got to study some films, not just texts. Personally, I enjoyed the modern stuff about hell the most (at the beginning we cover some older/classical texts like Homer, Gilgamesh and Milton).
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is an excellent but challenging course.  Overtime the subject matter grows more and more interesting and Adam does a great job generating interesting discussions and facilitating classroom bonds.  You will get out of this what you put in.  Theoretically, you could get away with not doing the readings, but it just won't be as fun or interesting.  Adam is very accessible and clearly cares about the running of the course.  Everything he does feels intentional and there is no busy work.
worse_comment: It is definitely a great class but the grading can be a little harsh.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class can definitely feel challenging as paper standards are high, but the content is truly super engaging and interesting––you read magazine articles, watch films, read novels, and even have the chance to read scholarly journal articles for a topic of your choosing. I feel like there's a lot of creativity and freedom associated with this class, which I've heard from my peers is not always the case with other Expos courses. I also feel like it's an ideal class to take as a freshman because of how Prof Shank tries to cultivate a close–knit, fun environment––particularly with fun icebreaker questions at the start of every class (I know how painful that sounds, but I promise that these questions are actually very interesting and you learn so many random, hilarious things about everyone's lives). I would definitely recommend this class but be prepared to put in a lot of work into your papers going in.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is really awesome –– if you are looking to get your expos requirement out of the way I would really recommend this class. The essays are quite a bit of work and are challenging to do well on, but I think that is more Expos as a whole than this class specifically. If you don't mind putting work in, this class is so worth it because it is genuinely interesting and Professor Shank is a really engaging, funny teacher. The class community is great as well, I got to know all of my classmates and came out of the class friends with the majority of my class. I really feel like my writing got better and I was able to learn about a super interesting topic that I really enjoyed.  It'll be fun to go to class and you will learn a lot, although the essays are tough. The work is worth it!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: You'll have to do a lot of writing (and reading) for this class, so if the subject matter does not interest you it may be harder to motivate yourself to do the writing and otherwise stay engaged with the class. That being said, i think most people would find the readings to be pretty interesting and thought provoking (although they can be long and dense). I'm not interested in CS, tech, or surveillance whatsoever and only took this class because it fit my schedule, but i found that this class forced me to thoroughly engage with an issue (privacy and surveillance) that i had not previously given much thought despite its impact on my daily life. Dr. Sinnott is an amazing, and experienced, instructor who does a great job of providing feedback (especially in writing conferences so make sure to take advantage of that) and interpreting dense readings so that you can understand them. Your success in this class depends on how engaged and committed you are. Also, note that expos 20 (in my opinion) is designed to tweak your writing, not overhaul it, so you may need to lower your expectations. Overall, I'm very happy I took this class despite its difficulty. Not only has my writing improved, I've realized the importance of a revision process, learned the tenets of a cohesive and effective argument and walked away with a greater awareness of surveillance that will change the way I think about privacy and how I act in real life.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: If you are interested in privacy issues, you should absolutely consider this course!  Dr. Sinnott is a wonderful instructor.  I found the grading very fair, and the feedback was excellent.  I would not go in with the attitude of this course being an "easy A," but if you enjoy the course you'll put in the effort and succeed grade–wise and gain a lot in terms of writing ability.  Ultimately pick your Expos with your interests in mind and how they align with the course topic.Also consider that this course deals with U.S. legal considerations, so international students may find that there is a little bit of a learning curve (e.g., what is the Constitution/Bill of Rights/Supreme Court) that domestic students don't have to deal with.  That being said, the course does mention European laws as well, and if you're interested in the material don't let this deter you.Dr. Sinnott's background makes her course a bit more targeted to straightforward writing (versus more artsy constructions favored in disciplines like English), which I certainly found to be a positive.  She teaches you to write clearly.
worse_comment: This class is interesting if you like the topic on privacy and surveillance. The reads are what you would expect. Grading isn't super easy but not super unfair either. Work on the essays a lot.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a fantastic expos section! Julia provides extensive useful feedback on drafts, helps answer any questions you have during conferences, and is a fair grader. She's extremely understanding and kind. I learned so much from this class and highly recommend it. You will have to put in time and effort, which is the case with any expos, but this section is very rewarding. I learned a ton from this class and saw substantial improvements in my writing. Readings are also engaging and not terribly time consuming.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class will push you. Sometimes, especially in the final essay deadline season, it might even make you question your relationship in writing. However, at the end of the day, not only will you come away with a community that you can always  lean on, but you will also become a better writer than you ever thought was possible. In the hard seasons, you will have a professor who genuinely cares about you and wants you to succeed. He will work with you through the challenges, and give you grace when you need it. You will also meet incredibly strong and inspiring people who have themselves been through mass incarceration, giving you a better understanding for the system than any book or article ever could. To this day, I still get chills when I think about some of the stories our visitors shared. I find myself humbled at the reality of our system today, while also being filled with a sense of hope that maybe our generation can begin to help make a dent in ending mass incarceration, and bringing humanity to those behind bars so that they can one day come back into their communities and positively contribute to them, too. By the end of the course, you will understand the complexities of our system, and all of the injustice behind it. and, hopefully, you will come away wanting to do something about it. At least I did, and this course, through its social engagement capstone project, will give you a place to start. If accommodations and accessibility are concerns, rest assured that Hudson will work with you and insure that you have what you need throughout the course! I highly recomend taking this course. The work load is pretty light until you get to essay writing, but this course is so much more than just a writing course, and will teach you so much about mass incarceration and life itself.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This Expos course is, as you might expect, heavy in subject matter. It is also academically difficult, but I think that that is appropriate for the topic and for the course as a whole: it teaches you so much about writing and about why writing even matters. And Hudson is incredibly supportive and caring throughout the way. He is thoughtful and intentional with how he communicates with students and in helping us build community. He challenges you to write more and better than you have in the past, but he is also your greatest supporter through that learning process.The engaged part of this course is phenomenal. Having visits from community members who are actively involved in finding solutions to the issues of mass incarceration is so valuable. You get to meet incredible people, many of whom are formerly incarcerated, who share their stories and their drive for enacting change.This course inspired me to stop turning away from hard issues and instead look for the people who are affected, the people who are trying to find solutions. It has given me confidence that I can learn about and research incredibly complex issues, and then think critically about them and actually have something new to add to the conversation. If you are placed in this course, I hope you get as much out of it as I have.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is amazing. Everyone raves about it for a good reason. By far the best class I've taken at Harvard. It's such a nurturing learning environment and everyone is so encouraging. Bailey was an outstanding preceptor. You won't find another class like this at Harvard. I've grown so much from this class, and I will be forever grateful I was able to take this class.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This class is such a fantastic way to push out of your comfort zone– not only does it improve you as a speaker but it improves your confidence, ability to interact with feedback, and to think critically about how you communicate with others. It's also a super fun and generally not super intense class!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: THE BEST HARVARD COURSE: Before the class, Public Speaking spawned more anxiety in me than I could reasonably manage, and I was crippled by thoughts about how I sounded or whether people would notice non–existent mannerisms. I was just scared, like it seems like many people are. This class fixed all of that––and more! In Kate's tremendous section, I grew to have a confidence not only with speaking but also with sharing my inner voice with other people. Through a poetry class at Harvard, I had already learned how to put my thoughts onto paper. Yet never had I felt comfortable saying them out loud to other people, let alone standing at the front of a big room with many people and commanding attention to tell a story or message. That was completely new!I leave the class confident in my voice, and I feel the effects every day, whether I'm talking with friends, at clubs, with family, or in professional settings at work. The confidence of a Harvard–educated public speaker, maybe?  Who knows. Yet somehow the class really did transform my attitude toward myself and what I can do, so long as I prepare adequately, through its experience–based four speeches over the course of the semester, combined with weekly student and instructor feedback. During class sessions, the class can feel like what I imagine a theater class can feel like: fun, varied warm ups,  a spirit of "YES! And?." It's no surprise, given that my preceptor, Katy, seems to have spent a lot of time with a Shakespeare company. But that type of class structure and thinking, so refreshing to someone with a more technical, stem/finance background, really opened me up to a new way of thinking. Our class got so close, over the course of the semester, that we all went thrifting with each other in our free time––twice! This class is definitely a no brainer. Have a great time!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!!! I know you guys see a bunch of comments like this, but Nick was a fantastic preceptor who cares about his students. The class community is amazing, and you honestly become a much better public speaker.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: This is a solid elective. I would say that the public speaking tips in this course are a bit generic and mostly common–sense – but it is helpful to have an intentional space to practice this. The speeches (writing your own and listening to others) are also pretty fun and a good way of getting to know a diverse set of your peers. However, know that this class mostly prepares you for giving prepared speeches as opposed to extemporaneous public speaking.Nick is a dedicated instructor, but he is a bit disorganized (poor time management in class doesn't allow everyone to get the same amount of time, doesn't return feedback on speeches). Hopefully, some of those things will be ironed out as this is his first semester teaching at Harvard. From what I've heard, his vibe as an instructor is also a bit more serious than other sections.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE EXPOS40! Public speaking is such an important skill and something you won’t get comfortable with/ good at without lots of practice. The feedback is really helpful, the professors are passionate and well–qualified, and you’ll make great friendships in your class.
worse_comment: Can be quite stressful
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Take this class! Even if you hate public speaking. It's a very safe environment to practice and become more comfortable public speaking. You get to know your classmates pretty well so you feel comfortable speaking in front of them and receiving feedback from them. I definitely feel more comfortable public speaking and I learned a lot of techniques for speaking outside of public speaking, like how to network and how to answer common job interview questions.
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU GET IN! I cannot emphasize enough how much this class has made such an impact on my experience here at Harvard. EXPOS 40 is a great opportunity to practice speaking in a supportive, non–judgmental environment, and you gain so much valuable feedback from your peers and preceptor (which I think is the most valuable part of the class). Throughout the class, you also participate in a bunch of fun improv exercises that allow you to get out of your comfort zone and try things in speech that you haven't done before. Don't be scared of the speeches––that's why you're most likely interested in the class, and this is a class where the main goal is to give you opportunities to practice speaking (so don't be afraid to try new things in each of your speeches). And don't be worried about the grade––if you show that you are making a valiant effort and are engaged, the grade will work out for itself. Zach is amazing and really chill, so if you get into his section consider yourself really lucky!
subject: Expository Writing

best_comment: Definitely one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard! I looked forward to class every week and would wholeheartedly recommend that you take Expos 40!! The structure of the class really facilitates a strong class community where everyone trusts each other and gives really kind, but helpful feedback. Each preceptor teaches the class a little different, I thought Zach did an incredible job. I feel like my public speaking ability improved over the semester, both from giving speeches and listening to all my classmates deliver theirs. Everyone I know that has taken Expos 40, regardless of their preceptor, has absolutely loved the class — you should take it.
worse_comment: Be prepared to take risk. It is normal to be concerned about the opinions of others, but do not allow others opinions' to completely dictate your actions.
subject: Expository Writing

course_title: The Vikings and the Nordic Heroic Tradition 001
best_comment: This is an awesome course! You learn a great deal while the assignments are quite reasonable. The readings are really cool but can be quite long, so make sure to set aside time to do them (they are definitely worth it). I'd highly recommend it if you're looking for a fun elective.
worse_comment: Class is a gem, guy grades hard though, but dope class, vikings is cooler than math
subject: Folklore & Mythology
course_title_2023: The Vikings and the Nordic Heroic Tradition

best_comment: All around a very fun and interesting class covering a wide range of topics in tattoo history. Loved the readings we did and enjoyed the freedom we got with our final projects
worse_comment: If you are on the fence about taking the course, take it! Hands–on learning about history and tattoos can't get much better.
subject: Folklore & Mythology

course_title: Black Holes, String Theory and the Fundamental Laws of Nature 001
best_comment: This was my favorite class by far. The topics are fascinating and Andy is an incredible instructor. He does a wonderful job of making his class a welcoming space, and encouraging his students to ask questions, no matter how small. If you're worried you don't have the background for it or that you'll be lost, don't worry, you don't need any experience in the subject and Andy is prepared to answer any and all questions. Just make sure you actually commit the time to sit down and do the readings. I couldn't recommend this class more though, it's been a major highlight of my freshman year.

course_title: Research at the Harvard Forest—Global Change Ecology-Forests, Ecosystem Function, the Future 001
best_comment: I cannot stress this enough, TAKE THIS CLASS!!! A lot of freshman seminars aren't as life–changing as they seem––except this one. You learn so much without the readings or work required by other freshman seminars. The only time you meet as a class is once a month for a weekend in your new happy place, the Harvard Forest, where you learn about the actual natural world around you almost entirely hands–on. It also is an amazing way to adjust to your first semester in college as you basically get a vacation as a class. You also bond greatly with your classmates, and I've had some of my best experiences of my freshman year so far with this class. Dave is of course amazing as well and makes the class even more enjoyable. This class is the "Transformative Experience" they always talked about, and it has single–handedly convinced me to double major in IB. If you enjoy escaping the business and stress of campus for a lovely weekend where you get to go on walks and learn about how amazing trees are, this class is for you!!

Take it! It was, by far, the most interesting and engaging class during my first semester.  The watch parties for the movies are quite fun, and there is always something new to learn during class. The professor and TF are incredibly accessible and kind, something that makes it very comfortable to ask questions and engage in discussions with your peers. You also play super interesting games related to the movies and the content of every class for a chance to win prizes. I always looked forward to this class every week because it was a great introduction to the classes at Harvard, and the content is very practical too. You can go on field trips to Harvard´s seismic station, watch movies in a theater in the Geological Hall, and talk to faculty who are doing groundbreaking research. Amazing class!

This was a very relaxing and fun way to get an introduction some pretty difficult math and physics concepts – but make sure that you are genuinely interested in the covered topics! Dr. Vafa is an extremely knowledgeable professor who is very clearly passionate about the topics he teaches in this course. He had no interest in burdening us with unnecessary, tedious work, but rather wanted us to listen and absorb the concepts that he brings up throughout the class and have fun applying them to the puzzles that he presents each week. I would, however, recommend that you have a very solid foundation in physics and math if you are interested in this course. I am by no means a physics or math major – I was taking this class out of pure interest – and I think that was something that may have held me back compared to my classmates because I definitely felt like we were moving at a very fast pace and I seemed to struggle with the concepts more than others.  However, that shouldn't stop you from taking the class, especially if you do have a strong background in either subject!! The class is fun and Dr. Vafa is great :)
best_gem_comment: For the target demographic of the class, this class is amazing. It definitely requires a decent knowledge of physics and math in order to get the most out of the class and it is very much worth taking. The workload is super light (weekly "pset" of a couple puzzles and a short reading to ponder and only checked for completion) and the little time that is required to spend outside of class is time that I gladly spent mulling over some puzzles, to the point that I would call the class a gem if it didn't necessitate a relatively strong background in physics and math. The problems Vafa gives are very interesting and his teaching is humorous, light–hearted, and engaging at the same time. If you like physics, math, and/or puzzles, I would highly recommend you take this class.

best_comment: If you are interested in pursuing medicine, but you have no clue as to what type of medicine you would like to pursue, I think this is a very good course to take. Personally, I didn't know if I would be interested in surgery but this course gives you a good idea of what the profession is like. Honestly, I am very glad I took this course.

course_title: Microbial Symbioses: From the Deep-Sea to the Human Microbiome 001
best_comment: Overall, this class was interesting, but it is a lot of work for a freshman seminar. There are a lot of readings each week, in addition to weekly writing responses and occasional presentations. But, on the other side, professor Cavanaugh is great and you will learn a lot from taking this course! If you are interested in microbes and pursuing science, I highly recommend.

course_title: Finding Connections: Perspectives on Psychological Development and Mental Illness 001
best_comment: MY FAVORITE CLASS OF THE SEMESTER!!! I loved loved loved this seminar and Dr. Rappaport! Dr. Rappaport is so sweet, intelligent, and has a great sense of humor. She facilitates wonderful discussions, and there is SOOO much you can learn from her expertise and knowledge of psychiatry. I loved hearing her stories. She also really cares about what you have to say. She will read your reflections with very careful attention and give back very thoughtful comments. Once I told her about my love for Indian food in a reflection and she bought and gave me chai the next class. I'll never forget that. She even recorded my final presentation and sent it to one of her patients. She'll make each student feel super special and like we belong here.Also, I loved getting to know all of my classmates–––I prefer having small classes like this because you can make some really good friendships and get to know students at the deeper level. Dr. Rappaport created such a welcoming and friendly environment, and everyone was allowed to be vulnerable with each other. It was so powerful to hear each other's stories. This was also an incredibly chill class. Like no stress at all! I cannot even stress to you how amazing this class was. PLEASE take it the next time it is offered.

course_title: How the Brain Becomes the Mind: A Bottoms-up and Top-Down Perspective 001
best_comment: This class is very rewarding – Dr. Byrne is an amazing person to get to know (you may even get to meet his wife at their home for a Thanksgiving dinner!), and he will teach you not only about the brain, but the implications behind studying the brain, contentious ideas, how to get started with research at Harvard, and his career journey. I loved the final paper towards the end of class (which is due before Fall Break, so it doesn't clash with reading/finals period), especially because I got to research about a topic regarding the brain I was interested in and had the opportunity to hear about what other students were interested in as well.

This course was incredibly interesting and Professor Georgi is personable and engaging, but the content of this seminar is advanced to the point of near incomprehension. I would recommend this course if you are interested in beautiful physics phenomena and have a strong foundation in mathematical and physical concepts, but I would hesitate to recommend it without this strong background.

This is an amazing seminar, and our group was able to get so close and form friendships outside of class!! Absolutely take this course if you have an active dream life, have been curious about your dreams, or simply want to discuss dreams with others. This was one of my favorite classes this semester, and it's a great way to spend 2 hours a week discussing something that really engages you.
worse_comment: This class is basically no work, but can be quite boring at times.

best_comment: This course is a great introduction to the field of astrophysics, and Professor Randall is an excellent instructor for the course! She is incredibly knowledgeable about almost all things astrophysics and is more than willing to discuss anything within the field that the class finds especially interesting. This is a presentation–based class, so keep that in mind if you choose to enroll. Overall, you should come out of this class with a greater understanding of the history of astrophysics and the current state of the field.

course_title: Changing Our Mind: Evolving Thoughts on Brain Regeneration 001
best_comment: This was a terrific freshman seminar – TAKE IT! Paola and Amie are wonderful, and it really is a great opportunity to learn about some very exciting topics. Lectures were always interesting, and we had some very cool labs as well (seeing human brain organoids and an Axolotl lab).  If learning how to turn human skin cells into electrically active human brain organoids, discussing brain plasticity, learning about brain–machine interfaces, talking about the bioethics of chimeras, etc. sound interesting to you, you'll love this course. And how can those not sound interesting! Paola and Amie were so nice and are really skilled at what they do.  They care a lot about the course, and the students in it! They aimed to make it an engaging course, not only being lectured at but with students actively participating in the conversation, and I think they succeeded quite well.One thing to keep in mind – you'll get out of this course what you put in. You didn't need to do any of the readings to go to class, which was very nice, but all of the suggested readings and resources are incredibly interesting, and well worth the read. I am sorry I did not spend more time engaging with them, and I still got a LOT out of this course without, but I do intend to go through all of the readings when I have a chance, because the topics are just that interesting. So, this course really is an INCREDIBLE offering, everything a freshman seminar should be, and then some. Take it if you can, you will not regret it.

course_title: Global Health: Comparative Analysis of Healthcare Delivery Systems 001
best_comment: This is a great class with great opportunities to grow closer to Dr. Saini and the amazing guest speakers he brings in.

I would highly recommend this class to future students – it was a really fun, lighthearted, but also deeply interesting course, and I learned so much. There was a lot of flexibility around choices for the final project (either a research paper or a creative project, such as a dance or a song), so it’s an ideal class for creative personalities. The professor was so friendly, and brought fresh fruit for us every single week, which was very kind and generous. Overall, a fantastic class.

Super fun class, definitely recommend – even if you're not sure if you like philosophy! Prof. Chen organizes the weekly discussions really well, there's a lot of discussion in small groups so you get to know others pretty well, and you'll definitely take something away from it at the end of the year whether it be about the meaning of different parts of life or about how you yourself look at things. It's a great time, would choose it again.

HIGHLY HIGHLY RECOMMENDED FOR THE PHILOSOPHICALLY CURIOUS/CONFUSED.You don't need any background. Just be interested in philosophy or the skeptical argument or general doubt or some existentialism. If you're prone to debate or you like discussion, all the better, it will serve you well.  And if you don't have background or have not previously thought about this all that much, be prepared to be confused about life forever.It will get to be a lot of decently heavy philosophy text readings, but as long as you try and understand the general idea, you will get a LOT from discussions in class. Learn from your peers, and open your mind to considering some crazy situations. There will be a lot of hypotheticals. Assignments are not too bad at all– you can put in as much or as little as you want, into both assignments and the class as a whole.Professor Elgin knows exactly what she is doing and how to guide you to and through some pretty heavy non–conclusions/doubts. She provides great feedback and leads discussion well. She also somehow knows something about everything and will connect skepticism and philosophy to, like, every other subject all at the same time. If you are interested, you might emerge forever confused with life, but in a really good way. Loved this course a lot.
worse_comment: I honestly didn't enjoy this class very much. Coming into Harvard, people told me to take a freshman seminar outside of my area of interest and that it would change my life, but I was very disappointed. Discussions didn't feel very lively – more like a lecture interspersed with student questions – and I found myself pretty disengaged. I wouldn't recommend this class.

course_title: Trials from Classical Athens and Modern Legal Debates 001
best_comment: THIS COURSE IS AMAZING! Professor Lanni is an academic who is truly passionate about the classical Athenian law, which is honestly contagious to her students. My class had wonderful, perspective–changing discussions about Athenian trial speeches and modern law topics (jury nullification, restorative justice, transitional justice, provocation doctrine, theories of punishment, decriminalization of sex work, etc). This class was very lowkey—your work every week would basically consist of just readings with two bigger writing assignments (but really aren't that bad, like can be done in a few hours). Professor Lanni was also just an awesome teacher who cultivated an electric environment for our class and really took the time for her students. Highly recommend this class, it's genuinely so good!

course_title: Borges, García Márquez, Bolaño and Other Classics of Modern Latin American Fiction and Poetry 001
best_comment: Great course! Mariano is super friendly and enthusiastic about course material. Course is also very much discussion based! Was very interesting hearing from peers on views about readings. Also, final projects were super fun to put together and to see from peers.

I had a really fun time during this course! I really loved the people (both the instructors and the students). I think the people drawn to this course are a really cool group and I am really happy to have met so many friends who I see out of class. This course offers a nice break from other more taxing classes. You essentially get to draw 3 hours a week. That said, if you don’t really like art or want a class that you can say you really “learned something” from or is traditionally “harvardy” it might make less sense. In addition, while you don’t absolutely have to spend a lot of time on the class (it is pass fail), you have to commit time if you want something to be proud of. Most likely, you will want to show people your final project. If that is the case you probably will have to come in the studio for around 4–6 extra hours a week to work. I don’t think this is a bad thing though as most of your classmates are working as well so it’s really fun! But if you want a low commitment class I don’t think this would be ideal. I really liked learning about animators in addition to animating. (That said, when I took the class there was an animation screening every week outside of class so that’s also an extra 2 hours of commitment but I really enjoyed them!!)

course_title: The Chinese Language, Present and Past 00
best_comment: This course is perfect for people who might not study linguistics but still want to learn about the field from a top linguistics professor or are interested in learning more about Chinese language and history. The workload is really manageable, and Professor Huang is super supportive and approachable. You really learn a lot about Chinese linguistics and get to know your classmates well; Professor Huang invited us out for Chinese/Taiwanese food, and we learned a lot about our classmates and teacher beyond the class.

course_title: Complexity in Works of Art: Ulysses and Hamlet 001
best_comment: I loved this course!  It was definitely one of the best classes I have ever taken––up at the top of the list with my very favorites.  Professor Fisher was eloquent, intelligent, brilliant, and clearly knew the content better than I imagine any other individual could; the class was stimulating, exciting, and enlightening, and the first place at Harvard that I really experienced the brilliance of Harvard.  I literally walked in, and felt like I was at home.  The brilliance of the people and the professor around me hit me with an exciting wave, and I had more fun in  conversation than I'd had the past day of orientation activities.  The discussions were the best I've ever had, and I loved listening to Professor Fisher speak.The one thing I will say is that we did have to write weekly response essays, which were a bit grueling and difficult to keep up with; every weekend, I'd end up having to stay in for a good portion of the time to nail out the reading and essay.All in all, it was a ton a work, but one of the best course I'd ever taken.  Choose the rest of your classes wisely when you take this course, love literature –– and this will be a favorite for you, too.  I would HIGHLY recommend this course, apart from my caution on the workload.

Great course for an introduction to historical linguistics. Do not take if you are interested in computational linguistics. The course material is a lot of reading and lecturing. It is fun if you are really interested in Linguistics and are considering a concentration/secondary in it.
best_gem_comment: This class is a GEM! Jay is literally one of the smartest people I have met in my entire life and he totally changed the way I perceive languages and where they come from. This class has a reasonable workload, is always incredibly intriguing, and is something I would definitely recommend to anyone interested.

best_comment: This seminar is a good option if you're looking for a class with an interesting topic and a lighter workload than your other classes. It's also very thought–provoking, and the more engaged you are, the more enjoyable it will be. I would warn that the seminars themselves can be boring a lot of the time, but I still enjoyed them overall, and Professor Erspamer is incredibly intelligent and kind.

course_title: The Art and Craft of Acting 001
best_comment: This class is an absolute blast and Remo is a fantastic teacher! For me, this class was a time of respite from a few very difficult, time consuming courses, so I really enjoyed every moment in this freshman seminar. We also got to see live shows almost every week, which is an incredible opportunity. Luckily for me, the shows always landed on the afternoon after one of my big problem sets was due, so I got to decompress every week by watching theater. The small nature of the class ensures that you get close with your fellow students; creating community is one of the most important parts of the first semester, so for that reason alone I'd recommend this freshman seminar. I honestly don't have much to say aside from singing this class's praise. If you love acting and theater, I can't recommend it more!
best_gem_comment: Trust me on this one and absolutely take this class if you can!!! SUCH A GEM! You will grow so much as a person and an actor and create such tight bonds with the rest of the class. Remo is the best teacher anyone could ever ask for. No past acting experience needed for this course just a willingness and enthusiasm to try new things and play! I am so grateful for this course and it really made my first semester at Harvard so enjoyable!!

course_title: Appraising and Reimagining Middle and High School Math Education 001
best_comment: This is a great seminar to take! There are weekly readings (about 1 hour per week) with an occasional blog post. The readings are not mandatory, but you should do them because Robin is too sweet, and she does not deserve students who don't prepare for class. The readings aren't always directly discussed in class, but a lot of the content relates to the general topic of discussion. Every week, the topic switches to a different aspect of education (like implicit bias, testing, summer school, etc.). Robin leads the discussions for the first couple of weeks, but eventually, individual students will be responsible for presenting topics and facilitating class discussions. The class is great because the discussions are very thought–provoking, and you get to learn a lot from other people's experiences with math education. On top of that, Robin is a wonderful professor who asks phenomenal discussion questions! She brings snacks to class a lot too. :)
worse_comment: This seminar is absolutely amazing! Not only is Robin one of the sweetest people I have ever met, but this class brings a whole new perspective to math education. It highlights the faults of the methods of teaching majority of us were exposed to and allows up to think on solutions.

best_comment: THIS CLASS IS FANTASTIC.  I genuinely think it changed my life, in terms of career path and sense of self.  Susan is a wonderfully empathetic and kind person who can lead a discussion effortlessly and dedicates so much care to her students.  You get incredible access to law school facilities and Susan is so accessible to meet one–on–one or help you make connections with other HLS faculty and industry experts.  Most importantly, though, you will learn so so much about human rights, international law, and how to be a good advocate.  There is no one who wouldn't benefit from the opportunity to take this class.  DO IT!
worse_comment: There are weeks when it may seem physically impossible to do all the readings. Don't sweat just ensure you're getting the main ideas from the events and topics discussed (google, look for more synthesized materials, etc.).

best_comment: This is one of the only freshmen seminars that count as an elective for government concentrators. If you want to have an easy class that will be actually interesting, with passionate debates, and an excellent professor, this is the way to go. I recommend it if you are taking another time consuming class, such as GOV20 or LS1A. However, if you already have a lot of easy classes, I think this could potentially be a waste of time IF this does not count for your concentration. Overall, I would recommend this to everyone. I left hyper conscious about manipulation in the media, polls, etc, while simultaneously meeting an excellent group of friends.
worse_comment: This class requires a lot of critical thinking skills along with patience. There will be students with differing opinions from you and this class allows you to vocalize your opinions and discuss why others might think differently than you.

course_title: U.S. Climate Change Policy and the Energy Transition 001
best_comment: I had an excellent experience in this seminar with Prof. Stock and encourage anyone who is interested and engaged in the fight against climate change to take it. Over the course of the semester, we learned about policy initiatives and private–sector approaches to solving climate change. Plus, we heard first–hand from many guest speakers, who joined our class most weeks. You will gain an appreciation for the complexity of environmental policy in today’s partisan system, an economic background on carbon emissions reduction policy strategies, and an understanding of various types of businesses working to help fight climate change. Readings are assigned weekly, and while some of them are a bit long and technical, most of them are interesting and useful for that week’s class. We had only two assignments all semester: one solo 30–minute presentation that explores one week’s topic, and one final 10–minute group presentation. This first assignment is especially long, but besides the two or three weeks with additional work on these presentations, the workload is fairly limited (only a couple hours of reading that can be skimmed if needed). Prof. Stock is a major player in the environmental economics and policy world, and the opportunity to get to know him and learn from him was incredible. The community of students in the class was also amazing and probably my favorite part of the course. I’m leaving this seminar with eleven friends with so many shared interests who I know are going to change the world. I only wish he facilitated more open discussions for us to exchange our perspectives on the material – these were some of my favorite moments from the course, but they were rather few and far between. Besides that, I really enjoyed taking this course and recommend it wholeheartedly.

course_title: When Bad Things Happen Early in Life: Effects of Early Adversity on Brain and Behavioral Development 001
best_comment: I loved this class! I  gained more empathy and understanding of the diverse experiences that children can have growing up, which is especially valuable when you go to such a privileged institution. I recommend if you are interested in psychology and neuroscience (and you can decide how in depth you want to go with each) as well as even education (it counts for credit in the education secondary). The class also became really close because of how serious the topics were, but we were all engaged and put a lot of care into these discussions. The only thing I would say is that, although the grading is super easy (you'll pass don't you even worry) there is quite a bit more work than most freshman seminars. It was fine for me because I spread it out throughout the semester (I recommend this!!) but I know a lot saved everything to the last minute. For full transparency (I don't know what it will be next year) but we had 5 short short reaction papers, two 45–min lectures to give, and a final research paper.

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 001
best_comment: Take this class if you are passionate about economics or passionate about learning more about economics! This is truly a course that can change the trajectory of your study of economics. Throughout this course, you will gain an understanding of foundational economic thought and will be able to debate hot–button issues with a diverse range of people. This is a seminar that is not an echo chamber of the same views making it that much more valuable. The books were great, albeit sometimes long or a little dry. The debates about each of these books were always a pleasure. Mankiw was also quite insightful throughout the class and teaches you new information while also serving as a sort of debate moderator. If you take this class, you will also find a great group of economics–interested friends!

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 001
best_comment: Take this class if you are passionate about economics or passionate about learning more about economics! This is truly a course that can change the trajectory of your study of economics. Throughout this course, you will gain an understanding of foundational economic thought and will be able to debate hot–button issues with a diverse range of people. This is a seminar that is not an echo chamber of the same views making it that much more valuable. The books were great, albeit sometimes long or a little dry. The debates about each of these books were always a pleasure. Mankiw was also quite insightful throughout the class and teaches you new information while also serving as a sort of debate moderator. If you take this class, you will also find a great group of economics–interested friends!

course_title: The Economist's View of the World 002
best_comment: If you are looking for the best freshman seminar, this is almost certainly the one you should take. The class is structured such that each week (sometimes every other week) students read a book discussing a different aspect of economics. Here is the list of books that we read this past semester:– The Worldly Philosophers (Robert Heilbroner)– Capitalism and Freedom (Milton Friedman)– Equality and Efficiency: The Big Tradeoff (Arthur Okun)– Leave Me Alone and I’ll Make You Rich (Dierdre McClosky and Art Carden)– A Brief History of Equality (Thomas Piketty)–  Open Borders: The Science and Ethics of Immigration (Bryan Kaplan)– Career and Family (Claudia Goldin)In addition, each week a different student writes a NYT–style op ed about an economic area of choice. These op eds are incredibly fun to write, read, and edit, and often produce very heated contestation from both sides of the aisle. Honestly, even if you don't like economics, Professor Mankiw makes this class lively and intellectually engaging. He does a great job moderating the discussion, and he is very fun to debate, especially if you do not agree with his political leanings. If you do take this course, you will get out of it whatever you choose to put in. It is very possible to do well in the class simply by reading the introductions and conclusions of each book and quickly typing up an op ed.
