If, on the other hand, you instead put in the work to read each book cover–to–cover, craft an excellent op ed, and participate fully in each discussion, I can guarantee that by the end of the course you will have a much more developed and articulate understanding of the many economic challenges that currently plague our society. Finally, if you do decide that you want to take this course, you must rank it at the top of your list, otherwise Professor Mankiw won't even evaluate your application. Also, he picks six left–leaning students and six conservative students in each section in order to increase political diversity. Make of that what you will.

course_title: Political Legitimacy and Resistance: What Happened in Montaigne’s Library 001
best_comment: Take it! If you are genuinely interested in philosophy and history, this class is absolutely perfect. It's definitely intellectually demanding, but we always had room to get things wrong and discuss and improve. It is one of the classes that will stick with me throughout college. The professor is absolutely fantastic. He made the class fun, exciting, and honestly pretty casual for the kind of material we covered. Lots of inside jokes and obscure references. The class often felt like a performance or a debate, but in a really genuine and constructive way – not like you had to memorize lines. Really fantastic.

course_title: The Holocaust in History, Literature, and Film 001
best_comment: This class allows you to engage with valuable resources that cause you to establish various emotional connections. You cannot hide from the truth as you begin to put faces to the Holocaust.  I am incredibly grateful for the opportunity to take this class. It is an excellent opportunity to engage with a challenging subject area in a rewarding manner. With the class based on discussion, it is also valuable to debate, reflect, and come to conclusions on difficult areas that test your thought process in multiple areas. The Professor is incredible at stimulating discussions and providing insightful comments and resources that maximize your experience.

course_title: Measurements of the Mind: The Creation and Critique of the Psychological Test 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class! Marla is so welcoming and helps create an environment where you feel encouraged to share your ideas. I learned so much about psychological tests and the final project was also very fun!
worse_comment: While the readings can be tough, it's not that much per week. The workload is on the lighter side with weekly readings, a few short papers (including one researching a psychological test of your choosing), and a final project (which you make your own test)

best_comment: Great class all around, this course is truly one of a kind. Teacher is great, eat interesting food, HW is very light.
worse_comment: Take this class if you need a GEM in your schedule! Class for around an hour and then lunch altogether. I did enjoy the course material, but if you want a real learning experience, I wouldn't necessarily recommend.

best_comment: This class is super great and you will learn a lot about the ocean while taking it.  Be prepared, the first half of the semester is largely about mythology and some of the discussions of the materials presented in class can get somewhat tangential but you will still learn a lot and the class is super enjoyable.  Also, the professor is great and is super nice and wants to see you do well and pursue your interests not only in his class but also across the university and in all four of your years at the college.  I would definitely recommend taking this course if you have any sort of interest in the ocean!

If you like learning about everything space related from astrology to string theory, this class is for you! If you only like some space related things, you're going to have some weeks where you really dislike the class, so I would only really recommend it if you have interest in both the humanities subjects like astrology and like the divine comedy and learning about astrophysics.

course_title: Understanding the Seemingly Impossible: A Revolution in Biology 001
best_comment: This course is a really fascinating look through papers about RNAi over ~5 years or so. Definitely a nice, relatively easy class that's worth taking if you have a strong interest in research and/or molecular biology. However, it does advance into more complex science fairly quickly so having some background in the subject matter is quite helpful. Also, Professor Hunter is super nice! Take note that the readings and seminar discussions can become a little dull unless you really engage with the subject matter.
worse_comment: This course is really helpful to future STEM concentrators, especially those wanting to do research because it really teaches you how to read a scientific paper. It can be a little hard to understand the content at times, but since it is a freshman seminar, there is really no consequence to being lost or confused. Good course!

course_title: Models of the World: Explaining the Past and Predicting the Future 001
best_comment: A gem. Super easy, homework each week took like 10 minutes and readings are light. Only one true "assignment" for the entire semester, which is just one 10–page paper and a 15–minute presentation. Models we discussed were genuinely interesting and spanned across disciplines, which was cool. Professor is also so, so incredibly kind (she brings snacks!) and cares about getting to know you.
best_gem_comment: Definitely a gem as far as seminars go! Very easy and quite interesting content, though it isn't super engaging or interactive.

course_title: Skin, Our Largest, Hottest, and Coolest Organ: From Cancer to Cosmetics 01
best_comment: This class is very interesting and is definitely a fun and easy seminar to take! However, it is largely based on presentations, so if that is not your thing, I would recommend a different freshman seminar.

course_title: Natural History Museums and the Anthropocene 001
best_comment: Take it!! This course was so interesting and also quite fun. We spent a lot of time exploring the collections of the Harvard Peabody museum, the herbarium, and the museum of comparative zoology. It was such a cool experience to see the behind–the–scenes of what goes on at museums because it's something that most people never get to see. Chuck is a great professor and was always willing to listen and hear our ideas. He knows so much about the class content and gave us some really fun, low–stress assignments. One of my favorites was a homework where we made a specimen collection of a plant anywhere near Cambridge, then identified it and made mounted specimens. Overall this was definitely one of my favorite courses. It's low–stress, super interesting, and has an amazing professor!

Please take this class! I promise that it will be the best class you take your first semester here at Harvard. Not only do you get to learn from one of the kindest and most enthusiastic people on this planet, the one and only Ned Friedman, but you will also create an incredibly deep appreciation for the natural world around you. You will be able to go to the arboretum at no cost, which also provides an amazing way to get off of campus and spend time in a very peaceful space, which was a great asset to me during the instability of the first semester. This class is great for both STEM and Humanities students (coming from a Humanities student), just make sure you're willing to learn more about trees, yourself, and the world around you.

This class isn't exactly what I thought it was going to be, but it was a good experience. It's definitely not a blow–off class though; expect to put work in (especially if your class does a comic) and really understand the readings and comics that we read. The discussions are really fun and interesting though, and there's a nice community among the small class size. Also, try looking for the books on HOLLIS (Harvard library catalog) before buying them because they can get quite pricey – the earlier the better because you want to get them before your classmates do (usually there's only 1 – 2 copies).

I really enjoyed this freshman seminar. Gojko is an amazing instructor and class was always interesting. The readings can be challenging at times due to length or difficulty of the subject depth, but I'd recommend to do all of them to maximize your experience from this course. Other than the homework readings, there's basically no other assignments involved which takes away a lot of stress, especially if you have a busy schedule in your other classes. You'll meet super cool guest speakers, which is a great component of the course. Overall, through this course you'll learn about the scholarship of analyzing ancient economic practices and perhaps some connections to modern day business practices, and this class is set up in a way that is low–stress, and I always looked forward to it each week. This is a wonderful gem of a freshman seminar.
best_gem_comment: I really enjoyed this freshman seminar. Gojko is an amazing instructor and class was always interesting. The readings can be challenging at times due to length or difficulty of the subject depth, but I'd recommend to do all of them to maximize your experience from this course. Other than the homework readings, there's basically no other assignments involved which takes away a lot of stress, especially if you have a busy schedule in your other classes. You'll meet super cool guest speakers, which is a great component of the course. Overall, through this course you'll learn about the scholarship of analyzing ancient economic practices and perhaps some connections to modern day business practices, and this class is set up in a way that is low–stress, and I always looked forward to it each week. This is a wonderful gem of a freshman seminar.

course_title: Reading the Novella: Form and Suspense in Short Fiction 001
best_comment: I 100% recommend this course! Professor Bolton has made my Harvard experience so much better! He is very passionate about the novellas he teaches and is the nicest Professor ever. The course load is not too bad. Every week we have to read a new novella and write a journal entry, but there is more than enough time to do this as the readings are not too long (as they are novellas). Professor Bolton fosters a very welcoming learning environment and the class was very enjoyable. Our seminar also got closer throughout the seminar which made classes more fun.
worse_comment: This class is not a huge time commitment as it were; there is one novella a week with a corresponding two page journal entry and four short (two page) essay assignments throughout the semester.

course_title: Major English and American Poets: Human Predicaments and Resolutions 001
best_comment: This course is lovely. Professor Rudenstine knows an incredible amount about the poetry itself. It is so clear that he has lived with these lines—and his insights are precious. There were times in class when he explained a line or stanza so well that I could do nothing more than just smile.  The workload is quite manageable. Most weeks, the homework is just to read a set of poems. This usually took me a few hours. If you take this course, I encourage you to put in an honest effort toward the poems. It'll be difficult to meaningfully contribute in discussion if you don't really understand the poems.  There are a few essays, but those two are enjoyable. We wrote ours on "Filling Station" (Elizabeth Bishop) and "Midterm Break" (Seamus Heaney), and both were poems that I'll remember for a while. There were also a few dinners outside of class that we shared together, and those were thoroughly enjoyable. Aside from the clear benefit of being able to enjoy a meal outside of the dining halls, it was also fun to get to see everyone outside of a classroom setting. I think these dinners left me with the feeling that I knew the people in this seminar better. I encourage you to take this class—provided that you are interested in poetry (but if you're not, this should never have been an option). The poems in this class are truly superb.

For anyone interested in classics or the late republic, I highly recommend this class. For anyone not interested in either of those two things, I  still recommend the class, but a bit less highly. Professor Hudson is incredibly passionate about the topic and extremely knowledgeable. I really enjoyed my meetings with him throughout the semester, and hearing all that he had to say about the topic. The class is very reading heavy, but besides that, there is practically no work besides the two essay assignments. Even if you don't have experience with the topic, you will be okay because Professor Hudson does a great job of helping you immerse yourself in Roman society.

Linda is an amazing teacher who is extremely passionate about her course. In my opinion, this course most definitely is a hidden gem. I would strongly recommend taking this class if you like book seminars and are interested in queer topics.
worse_comment: If you come from an area where there is largely no queer representation, you should absolutely take this class.
best_gem_comment: Linda is an amazing teacher who is extremely passionate about her course. In my opinion, this course most definitely is a hidden gem. I would strongly recommend taking this class if you like book seminars and are interested in queer topics.

course_title: Zombies and Spirits, Ghosts and Ghouls: Interactions between the Living and the Dead 001
best_comment: This class provides a super intriguing look at the afterlife through readings, guest speakers, and readings. There is a weekly 3–5 page paper plus reading / movie, but both of these are, for the most important, fairly enjoyable to complete and low pressure. My favorite assignment was watching a ghost movie of our choice, but some of these more entertaining assignments are interspersed with longer, denser readings. Overall, however, the classroom discussions are super engaging and enjoyable, and all of the speakers were fantastic. If you have any inkling of an interest in religious studies, the concept of the afterlife, or just getting to watch movies for a class assignment, this is definitely a solid course for you.
worse_comment: I would tell students that this class will expose them to multiple cultures in different time periods and will cause you to think about what it means to be human since death is a large topic of the course.

course_title: Buddhist Enlightenment: Visions, Words, and Practice 001
best_comment: It is what you make of it. There are A LOT of readings, and if you do all of them, you will definitely learn a lot. Regardless, I think everyone in the class walked away with a much greater understanding of Buddhism than what we started with. It was a bit boring at times, and I think the course could be improved with more interactive things like more meditation sessions, but it was still very interesting. The best part of this class was definitely Prof. Abe, everyone loves him. Definitely take this class if you want to learn more about Buddhism, and take a chill class with a great prof.

course_title: Memory Wars: Cultural Trauma and the Power of Literature 001
best_comment: This seminar is amazing! The professor is fantastic, and though the material is heavy, it provides a great understanding of the power of literature to inspire empathy and change. Easily my favorite course of the semester. The discussions really bond the class together — plus Professor Suetterlin brings snacks!
worse_comment: Be ready to question all your previously held notions of what right and wrong is and how it can manifest itself.

best_comment: This is such an interesting class, I absolutely recommend taking it! Dr. Love is the best and guided us through so many amazing discussions about classical literature and art, race, ancient figures, philosophy, and so much more. The projects are really interesting if you pick something that you want to learn about, and the group presentations are so fun to listen to.

course_title: Looking for Clues. Ancient and Medieval Art @ Harvard 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSEEE!!! I struggled first semester coming into Harvard, but this class made Harvard feel like a second home.  It was a class I was always excited to come into. Professor Georganteli is one of the kindest people I have ever met, and we have shared amazing conversations. She makes time to truly get to know her students,  which was very valuable this semester. Also, if you are looking for concentrating in anything like Archaeology or Art History (or even if you just want to take a fun seminar class), Professor Georganteli makes it crucial to introduce her students to many people and present many opportunities, like summer programs. This class was a safe space, and I always felt like I could talk. Moreover, all the trips were extremely fun, especially the one to the ceramics studio. Overall, this seminar was easily my favorite class this semester and no one should miss it!

Taking a freshman seminar is a really nice way to meet people and this class was very conducive to getting to know your peers in a more formal setting. The class is not too much work, but is enjoyable if you like to read and have group discussions.

course_title: Immigrant Memoirs: Women’s Lives from Eastern Europe to America 001
best_comment: Readings are the core of this class since the classes are 99% open discussions about the memoirs you read (approximately one book per week). This seminar is a great opportunity to engage in literature about European immigrant women's experiences and reflect on your own experiences by writing a personal memoir. Professor Kremer is very supportive and willing to share her personal experiences. With that being said though , you will not get as much out of this seminar if you don't do the readings and it will be a waste of time. Otherwise, if you enjoy reading and discussing about books, this would be perfect for you!
worse_comment: This class was okay. I didn't love the readings and didn't think there was anything life–changing about the discussions we were having.

best_comment: If you want to learn more about gender and justice literature, I highly recommend this class. The professor is amazing, always available and willing to help. The class environment is also super welcoming, and I always felt comfortable sharing my thoughts. The readings can be demanding but manageable, but they are really interesting overall.

If you want to learn about education as a matter of policy or a social science, this probably isn't for you, but if you're interested in the philosophy of non–traditional and arts–based education, you will likely love it! Doris is a great facilitator in seminar, and her interdisciplinary approach and background makes the class feel fresh and exciting. This class will force you to reconsider what it means to learn and to educate and will expose you to a wide variety of texts and thinkers. Readings are manageable and in–class discussions are always interesting, with some great guest speakers coming in. If you are interesting in education as a matter of the humanities, take this class,

course_title: Recent Experimental Architecture: From AutoCAD to Ziggurat 001
best_comment: This class is a lot more work than you would expect for a Freshman Seminar. Class discussions are interesting and you'll find yourself engaged, but they don't necessarily prepare you in a technical manner for the assignment, meaning you will have to self–learn a lot of Rhino. The in–class demonstrations are helpful with introducing the basics, but you basically have to choose between following along and committing to memory or taking notes, as lectures aren't usually recorded.  There aren't any written notes to refer back to, so it's very important to pay attention during class. Beyond the basics, it's up to you to learn the rest of Rhino. Rhino itself can definitely be finicky. If you don't have a Windows desktop, either find a computer on campus at a lab to use (they are free of charge) or get one for yourself. You will have many breakdowns trying to get Rhino to work if you aren't on a device with enough computing power and compatibility with Rhino. Finally, expect that you might take a lot of time working on some assignments or completing some readings, but they won't ever be reviewed or discussed. This isn't common, but it happened for the one and only essay of the year, which I was led to believe was a big milestone for the course. However, you will definitely come out of this course more familiar with design, geometry, abstraction, and the fine arts. You won't necessarily come out of it with more technical skill though, but I think you get just about what the course is advertised as.

course_title: Apocalyptic Grief: Love, Loss, and the End of the World 001
best_comment: If you're the sort who loves late–night conversations about subjects that are fundamental to human existence – love, loss, hope, grief, for example – and loves dissecting media for its themes a bit too much, then you will absolutely love this course. Every week, we read a new text (mostly fiction, which includes films) and have a table–discussion about it for 2 hours, book club style; and while discussions are fun, the best part is always listening to Matt's own interpretations which range from thought–provoking to mind–blowing. That said, because of the emphasis on discussion, if you want to take this course, it'd be a benefit to everyone if you actually read the weekly readings and engage in thoughtful discussion. For that reason, I think there's some level of work expected to be put into the course – some of the novels can be pretty long (I learned to be a faster reader for this class alone)! But the readings are mostly pretty fun to read (and if they aren't just know that Matt's take on said reading will probably completely change your perspective on it).The content of the course tends to be rather heavy, but I think an existential crisis or two is worth the deep inspection of truths about humanity and society that is often so sobering and clarifying. I personally would say that some of the revelations can be life–changing.All in all, I strongly, STRONGLY recommend this course – but with the caveat that you must be ready to read the weekly readings. It's what makes it fun, anyway!

If you are interesting in 21st century comedy, like I was, know that this class does not focus on that at all.  But I still loved this class.  We read a lot of interesting works, but do know that you have to very interested in comedy to take this class as the readings are AT LOT.  Other than that, this class is great.  The professor is very nice and this class attracts a great group of people.  The response posts that you have to do every week may be slightly annoying but you can get them done in 15–30 minutes.  Also you can have a lot of fun with the final project

course_title: The Good, the Bad, and the Beautiful: The Ethics of Art 00
best_comment: Take this class. I'm not kidding. I don't know if or when it'll be offered again, but if you come across it, you must take it. It is such a fantastic class and the professor is incredible and kind and so invested both in the focus of the class and in getting you to become invested in it as well. The readings can be lengthy but they are entirely manageable and very interesting, and the essays are relatively short and a great introduction to philosophical writing. Even if you have no interest in pursuing Philosophy as a concentration, take this course. You'll learn so much in a very low–pressure environment, and the professor is now one of my favorites :)

course_title: The World of Tomorrow: Constructing and Inhabiting the 21st Century 001
best_comment: Among the best professors you'll find at Harvard. Arthur is amazing and a truly once in a lifetime kind of person! Take this class if you have any remote interest in cities!!!!!! Also fantastic guest speakers and field trips!

course_title: Americans at Work in the Age of Robots and Artificial Intelligence 001
best_comment: This course will be worthwhile if you are interested in the topic and if you are willing to put in the effort. This course primarily deals with the economic issues related to automation (such as unemployment), rather than with the technological developments related to automation, themselves. Discussions are a bit structured at the start, but you eventually move into debates on policy proposals (like UBI, etc), which are very exciting and engaging. The readings can take a lot of time to read, and if you want to get the most out of this class, you should read and understand all of them. The good thing is that Professor Friedman's door is always open, and he is very kind and knowledgeable. This is not a blowoff, no–prep freshman seminar. But, if you put in the time, you will get a lot out of it.

Do not take this class. If you are actually interested in econ, take something like ec 1010 or 1011. You will do probably about the same amount of work, but will get way more out of it. If you aren't so interested in econ but are curious about dilemmas in the world's economy, this course will be an utter letdown. After having taken the course and doing all of the readings and showing up to every class, I cannot tell you a single dilemma that we focused on specifically and we didn't even talk seriously about inequality until the very last week of the class. I am incredibly disappointed with this class and would strongly urge you to take something else.

course_title: Rituals and Living the Good Life 001
best_comment: This is a great course, and it's also a great way to learn about what the everyday looks like in an academic career. Professor Norton is wonderful and shares a ton about the experiments he runs and student advising. If this is a path you're interested in, I highly recommend this course.

course_title: Everyday I’m Hustlin’: Pop Culture, Youth, and the African City 01
best_comment: The teacher is very knowledgeable and has traveled, has really good, invaluable insight to add to the class!  Incorporation of music and film into the course was cool! The homework is very manageable. My reservations: it felt more like a lecture than a discussion often times, and so I felt there was not enough time for me to develop my understanding of the course subjects in discussion with other students. There was however, lots of space to be creative and imaginative through course assignments.  If you are very very interested in thinking about African cities from a scholarly, conceptual, and nuanced perspective, take this class. If you would like more practical understandings of culture, policy, and more, there might be another class that better suits your interests!

This class is very scientific; weekly assignments consist of reading and summarizing 1–2 psychological studies.  This course allows students to build a strong foundation in implicit bias and the science behind this mental phenomenon. I recommend this course to students interested in brain science and developing new studies but not necessarily to students primarily interested in current events involving implicit bias. The workload is manageable and very interesting for students interested in psychology. If you are considering psychology as a concentration, this is a good seminar to evaluate whether the subject is a good fit for you.

I would strongly encourage any first years to take this seminar!! It's very low on workload which makes it easy to manage alongside other courses, and any work you do sets you up for the discussions in class. The class is 2 hours, but as long as you are interested in the topic it will fly by. The other people in the class always have amazing experiences to share, and as long as you come to the class with an open mind and willingness to share your own perspectives, you will truly get so much out of it... definitely a freshman seminar gem!
worse_comment: I highly recommend this class especially if you are interested in any forms of political violence, colonialism, terrorism, etc! Definitely brush up on a few historical events before though to be able to experience the readings to their fullest.
best_gem_comment: I would strongly encourage any first years to take this seminar!! It's very low on workload which makes it easy to manage alongside other courses, and any work you do sets you up for the discussions in class. The class is 2 hours, but as long as you are interested in the topic it will fly by. The other people in the class always have amazing experiences to share, and as long as you come to the class with an open mind and willingness to share your own perspectives, you will truly get so much out of it... definitely a freshman seminar gem!

course_title: Corporate Power & Human Rights—Community Resistance and Social Movements 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend this seminar to every person reading this. The discussions are in–depth but fully manageable for any level of prior knowledge of human rights and legal issues. You can come into this class with no experience in the area and learn so much. Every discussion is a positive environment where even the smallest contribution is valued. The class community among the students is incredibly well fostered and the course materials and assignments are not all readings and discussions (we did simulations, watched videos, had mock debates, and more). I would take a course with Tyler every semester for the rest of my Harvard experience if I could! I learned about how negotiations between companies, governments, communities, and NGOs work and how difficult they are (having participated in a 3 week negotiation simulation in this seminar which was amazing!) and how to center community in worldwide issues with human rights. This class emphasizes what it means to be a part of a community and how all communities can be lifted up around the world through legal and other means. Please take this seminar–– it is not too much work, has a great environment, is an interesting topic, and is well done overall!!

course_title: Mindfulness: A Path to Success, Happiness and Health 001
best_comment: This class is a total gem :) The workload is very light and class itself is quite relaxed. However, it is structured as a purely lecture–based course with lectures that become more and more repetitive over the course of the semester. A few weeks into this course, it may start to feel like you're learning the same things over and over again. If you need an easy, light–workload course to take this is a great one, but there are definitely other courses out there that will be more engaging and educationally stimulating.
worse_comment: Do not take this class if you are not interested in psychology. It is a lot of work for a freshman seminar, and if you are not interested in this topic, it is a pain in the ass with all the readings and papers.
best_gem_comment: This class is a total gem :) The workload is very light and class itself is quite relaxed. However, it is structured as a purely lecture–based course with lectures that become more and more repetitive over the course of the semester. A few weeks into this course, it may start to feel like you're learning the same things over and over again. If you need an easy, light–workload course to take this is a great one, but there are definitely other courses out there that will be more engaging and educationally stimulating.

course_title: Religion and the Black Protest Tradition 001
best_comment: The professor was so caring and intentional with her words. She cared not just about us as students but about us as presenters, writers, and people. She was always available to discuss our projects. Also the curriculum was superb; the interdisciplinary structure of the class was excellent and I feel like Ive learned a lot about different ways to approach history. The class can be a lot of work with a lot of reading and writing, but she puts a lot into you and you will get a lot out of it. You will get however much you put into this class out with practically no upper bound.

course_title: We the Jury: Deliberation and Justice 001
best_comment: This seminar should be your number one choice if you are interested in U.S. law, or repelled by it. Professors Nesson are incredible teachers and students themselves, and are wonderful facilitators of nuanced conversation that can change your perspective on complicated topics by shining appropriate light on overlooked details. They are delightful hosts, engaging conversationalists, and will encourage you out of your comfort zone to expand your scholastic horizon. However, you must have an open mind, coming into this seminar. In cases of extreme complexity, there is no tolerance for picking a side based on emotion alone – you are prompted to back it with fact. And they bring their adorable dogs so thats definitely a win.

course_title: We the Jury: Deliberation and Justice 001
best_comment: This seminar should be your number one choice if you are interested in U.S. law, or repelled by it. Professors Nesson are incredible teachers and students themselves, and are wonderful facilitators of nuanced conversation that can change your perspective on complicated topics by shining appropriate light on overlooked details. They are delightful hosts, engaging conversationalists, and will encourage you out of your comfort zone to expand your scholastic horizon. However, you must have an open mind, coming into this seminar. In cases of extreme complexity, there is no tolerance for picking a side based on emotion alone – you are prompted to back it with fact. And they bring their adorable dogs so thats definitely a win.

Professors Nesson are incredible teachers and students themselves, and are wonderful facilitators of nuanced conversation that can change your perspective on complicated topics by shining appropriate light on overlooked details. However, you must have an open mind, coming into this seminar. In cases of extreme complexity, there is no tolerance for picking a side based on emotion alone – you are prompted to back it with fact. And they bring their adorable dogs so thats definitely a win.

TAKE THIS CLASS!! Not only is Professor Hill a super fun and understanding teacher, she is also amazing at facilitating discussions around what the class is interested in. Honestly, this class is amazing regardless of how much previous knowledge you have. Professor Hill does a great job at incorporating psychology and theory in everyday experiences so it is very easy to pick up and learn new concepts. Also, if you want to go out for food not only once but TWICE in a semester, and have weekly candy on top of it, this class is for you.

course_title: Race, Science, and the Law: Knowledge and Power in the U.S. and Beyond 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! While the coursework itself is flexible in terms of how much or how little you work on it outside of class without your grade being affected, you will want to read everything that Professor Jackson provides because it is so interesting. I found the workload to be 100% manageable and never was stressed out as a result of this class, and because there are no exams, you don't feel a pressure to absorb everything you read. The classes themselves are pretty much a loosely–guided discussion, so it depends on who is in your block, but my classmates were all incredibly bright and had interesting things to say about what we learned. Definitely recommend!

course_title: Is Privacy Dead? Privacy, Surveillance, and Freedom in the Digital Age 001
best_comment: Substantial readings but they are all super interesting and are summaries in class. HIGHLY recommend doing them because it adds to discussion but not quizzed on them.Discussions in class are a ton of fun. Everyone in this class is super different and has wildly different perspectives on matters of privacy. This was probably my most diverse class here.Every time I leave class feeling like my brain and broken and been put back together again in the way possible way.Not all readings are directly related to privacy, this class approaches privacy from many different angles, but they tie together during discussion.Also, the prof. sometimes brings up other relevant opportunities that students can check out.Oh and I can’t forget! One of the best parts of this class was a personal museum visit with artworks specifically selected and pulled out of storage for our class purposes. Highly recommend the class to everyone.

course_title: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems 001
best_comment: So in some ways I felt like I got catfished by the course. Professor Khanna and Balsari are incredible and they teach the first couple of weeks and I loved it. The case method was a lot of fun and the readings were incredible. Then came what can unfortunately only be described as a waste of time. Lecturers on thinking like a planner, scientist and especially artist provided no additional benefit to the creation of any one of our assignments or our final projects. They were boring, unengaging (with 15 minutes of dull silence at the end of lectures waiting for "do you have any questions"), and while at times interesting, added no additional benefit to our project. At the point that I had figured this out it was too late to drop and so I stuck with it. Don't get me wrong I'm glad I stuck with it but I felt catfished.In terms of the homework, heed the wisdom of the other comments, the team that you're in will define this course. Try your best to befriend grad students and go with them because they often have significantly more experience doing a business plan than you and you can piggyback on that knowledge. You can do that or work with your friends but where possible try come into this course with an idea first and a team later as this prevents teams wanting to split up (as was pretty common).All in all I'm glad I took the course but I wish I had know this all before I took it.
worse_comment: Not a gem. If you have heard of ES139, this is very similar, but the grading is not nearly as generous.
best_gem_comment: This class is by no means a gem, but it is worth it if you put in the time. Your group will make or break your experience in this class. Put time into your project – it will be one of the most rewarding experiences you’ve had at Harvard if you commit to it.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems

subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Contemporary Developing Countries: Entrepreneurial Solutions to Intractable Problems

course_title: The Art and Politics of Propaganda: The Nazis and Their Legacy 001
best_comment: This isn't a gem! The quizzes can be tricky, and for a while, I was seriously considering taking this pass/fail. But the lectures are amazing, the film screenings were the highlight of my week, and the class material couldn't be more relevant (and Professor Rentschler does a great job proving this throughout the course). As far as Geneds go, I certainly felt like I improved as a thinker. I certainly feel like I couldn't have learned about some of the class content in any other setting and without the instruction of Professor Rentschler. While it felt needlessly challenging at times (the first quiz was my lowest grade at Harvard!) I still think this class is worth it. I would very much encourage you to take this if you're willing to put in a little more work than you would do any other "gem" gened.
worse_comment: This course is too much work for what it's worth. There are so many other Geneds that meet the aesthetics and culture requirement that are a MUCH smaller time commitment that this class. The material is interesting to an extent, but the lectures are not interactive and can get monotonous and with the amount of required reading and screenings its really difficult to actually engage with the material properly instead of just skimming and putting the films of 2x speed. Also just a slight disclaimer that may be quite obvious given the subject, but this class does not shy away from really difficult and traumatic films which is important for a full understanding of Nazi propaganda but be mentally prepared for that if you do take this class.
best_gem_comment: This isn't a gem! The quizzes can be tricky, and for a while, I was seriously considering taking this pass/fail. But the lectures are amazing, the film screenings were the highlight of my week, and the class material couldn't be more relevant (and Professor Rentschler does a great job proving this throughout the course). As far as Geneds go, I certainly felt like I improved as a thinker. I certainly feel like I couldn't have learned about some of the class content in any other setting and without the instruction of Professor Rentschler. While it felt needlessly challenging at times (the first quiz was my lowest grade at Harvard!) I still think this class is worth it. I would very much encourage you to take this if you're willing to put in a little more work than you would do any other "gem" gened.

course_title: How to Build a Habitable Planet 001
best_comment: This class is not taught to be a gened course, it is taught like an introductory planetary science course. Strong background knowledge is needed to understand the material and the content–– I would advise you to think strongly about if you understand fundamental chemistry, biology, and geology before taking this class. It was not easy, but is interesting if you have ambitions in the planetary sciences and want to know about the world. The lectures are not recored and slides and the textbook do not contain all material needed for the exam–– you have to listen to the oral presentations done by the professor to succeed in the course. This can be frustrating if you must miss a class because you are sick, or you you did not hear what he said. There are very fun demonstrations and labs done, you feel like you are back in your high school science class–– this is definitely the highlight of the class. The professor has some very adamant moral beliefs–– he is a strong vegan and will somewhat preach this to you in the course. He is also very stern and not easily approachable, typically answering your question with a question instead of helping you understand materials better. Additionally, if he does not like you or disagrees with you path of study or career choices (should you tell him) he will make that very apparent. Instead of encouraging more people to enter the sciences, he instead shames those who are not. However, the teaching staff (the two TFs) are incredible, both of them are very easy to talk to, very intelligent, kind, and will help you understand the materials in a very constructive way.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: How to Build a Habitable Planet

course_title: The Caribbean Crucible: Colonialism, Capitalism and Post-Colonial Misdevelopment In The Region 001
best_comment: You should definitely take it! It was a lot of fun, I learned a lot, the materials are excellent, and Prof. Patterson is super engaging and fun to listen to lecture. We also got lectures about reggae and reggaeton from a Berklee musicologist, which is a lot of fun if you like music.
worse_comment: The workload is relatively light, but you need to stay on top of things or else you will struggle with the exams and essay.
best_gem_comment: I enjoyed this class. The professor is very knowledgable about the Caribbean as a whole, and you can tell he was a figure that was quite respected in the Caribbean political arena. We learn about some very interesting leaders from Cuba, Jamaica, etc., and it's very cool to see the professor talk about them by recalling on his past experience meeting these people and going through the experiences we're learning about. Not a hard class at all and out of the 3 GENEDs I've taken so far, I'd consider this to be the most of a gem. Great class overall!!
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: The Caribbean Crucible: Colonialism, Capitalism and Post-Colonial Misdevelopment In The Region

course_title: Conflict Resolution in a Divided World 001
best_comment: This course has a lot of hype. It is a difficult course to lottery into. Is the hype proportional to the actual learning and execution? It is a well–run course for sure, and the teaching team sincerely values the feedback, but I may be in the unpopular side of the opinion in saying that it isn't dramatically the far away best course I have taken. I'd encourage anyone to lottery to this course because of its unique concepts, but it won't shape you into a new person.One one hand, it teaches unique concepts on a topic that is not really talked about, conflict resolution. It really is eye–opening to a good extent. It is like putting words to ideas and behaviors in a manner similar to psychology in attempting to explain how negotiation and conflict resolution work. The professor, Dan, is extremely eloquent and a very effective communicator, but almost too effective so that we become used to it. The teaching team is extremely dedicated as well, taking the time to review every assignment and plan everything very intentionally. They also take feedback seriously but almost to the point where it is too much input, as entire lessons are tried new even though their effectiveness is not clear.On the other hand, the course sometimes feels dry in the lectures in that it is a 3 hour class and difficult to go on for a long time just seated. Activities sometimes help but even two hours is challenging at times, especially given the 3–5:45pm class time. Grading is also somewhat slow, taking a few weeks for each assignment, though immediate feedback is not always necessary. Additionally, many of the activities felt like there was not sufficient buy–in. The reason why conflict resolution is so difficult is because it is impossible to separate one's own perspective from the rational and emotional considerations. In any of these exercises, one could simply decide that the "so what" to losing or not doing anything is nothing, and so there is not sufficient effectiveness to some of them. It may be said that you get what you put in, but in these cases, maybe part of it is realizing not all conflicts are worth my time and assigning artificially inflated value to them is counterproductive. The course also suffers a bit from a self–aware sense of being one of the most desired and highly regarded courses, which makes it get an intangible vibe of being more important than it actually is and making sure every student treats it extremely seriously.
worse_comment: People spend ridiculous amounts of money in expensive courses to learn the Harvard method of negotiation, while for us, it is accesible (if you win the lottery) and will count towards your requirements. It is rare to find a course where you will feel you are becoming better as a person and improving you social skills like this one. Thus, there is little reason not to take it. However, if you need to get an A, carefully consider the tradeoffs. This course does not have a heavy workload (you don't really need all of the readings), but GRADING IS NOT LENIENT.  Almost all of it will be based on your ability to write essays, which is extremely annoying as the course is not about that and you don't really learn much from that. Be careful. It probably ruined my 4.0
best_gem_comment: It’s a good class, as I’m sure you can tell from the consistent rave reviews. It’s not really a gem, on purpose; they want you to be invested in it and not just there to get the grade and get out. So if you are taking it just for the requirement, maybe do a different class. If you are interested in the content, you have the chance to learn from someone who is very very big in the field of conflict resolution.

best_comment: This course is well taught and well worth it. You learn so much about sleep and how it affects you! I think I will carry some of the things I learned in this class with me in life. Not to mention some of the topics are very interesting. On a few rare occasions there would be discussion of some complex biological process but it is summarized easily for you many times by the lecturers.Prof. Czeisler and Prof. Scheer are a great duo to learn from! Czeisler is hilarious and knows how to explain things well. Scheer is also good at being relatable.I think some people in the course this year said it was "no longer a gem," but to be honest, it is a class with light workload that is interesting and easy. You are compelled to attend lectures and do the readings, but you do not have to understand everything in the readings. Depending on the TF you got for your section, it could be a great time!
worse_comment: This class was honestly so boring.  I know the professors are a little on the older side but their slides often made no sense, their lectures were boring or incomprehensible, and they expected all of us to have a hefty science background (as was apparent by sometimes difficult quiz questions). I also don't love the frequent quizzes (they aren't helping me learn) and I am not eagerly anticipating the final exam. I was not a fan of this class and I am glad lecture was only once a week. If it was twice a week I wouldn't be able to bear it. Total snoozefest.
best_gem_comment: This course is well taught and well worth it. You learn so much about sleep and how it affects you! I think I will carry some of the things I learned in this class with me in life. Not to mention some of the topics are very interesting. best_comment: Would highly recommend this gened! It's not necessarily a gem since there is a bit of work. You have to complete a podcast project, final paper, midterm analysis paper and make weekly postings, but this can be manageable if you organize your time. They do also have weekly screenings (2 hr chunks of time that you have to attend where you watch anime and take notes on an index card), plus participation in general does contribute to your grade. The reading material is also a bit dense, but honestly, you can get away with not really reading them since all the material gets covered in lecture anyway. I would recommend you stay on top of reading until at least the midterm though since it does make the midterm paper a lot easier. The information in general was super interesting and the professor is clearly really knowledgeable though, so it's honestly a really enjoyable class! I would say definitely take this if you're into anime or looking for an interesting class to take, though do be advised you may have to do like an average of 3 hrs of work per week (this is considering like the total amount of time you'll have to put into papers over the semester + the podcast project overall, though like most weeks you'll just spend like 30 mins writing up a weekly posting).
worse_comment: I would not recommend this course, it was actually not that fun. Lectures were so boring and I fell asleep so often. It kind of ruined watching anime for me, and I really disliked 75% of the animes that we watched in class. There's really only one chance to show your own love of anime, and that's in the podcast project. Other than that, you don't really talk about the fun animes or ones you want to talk about at all.
best_gem_comment: Would highly recommend this gened! It's not necessarily a gem since there is a bit of work. You have to complete a podcast project, final paper, midterm analysis paper and make weekly postings, but this can be manageable if you organize your time. subject: General Education

best_comment: This course really is fantastic! Matt and Dan are fantastic teachers and they love to engage with their students. The course content is interesting and will likely challenge your beliefs about the world, its structures, and the human past. Don't be fooled, this course is not one you can slack off in. You really need to show up to class ready to engage with the content. But if you're willing to put in about 3 – 5 hours of work per week for this gen ed, you will be rewarded. I'm super happy to have had this experience. Also, the TFs are phenomenal!
worse_comment: I liked this class, however, be prepared to write 3 essays. They aren't super hard, but can be stressful.
best_gem_comment: If you are interested in taking this class for GenEd credit, I highly highly recommend you lottery for it. The course content is really interesting, the teaching staff cares so much about the students, and you get to see super cool real artifacts during section! Lectures, in–class discussions, and readings are all really engaging. It's a great class overall. If you want to take a fun GenEd, this is the class for you! However, if you are looking for a gem, this is probably not the class for you. There are usually 2 readings per week –– some have short assignments associated with them and all are necessary for the 3 midterms ("quizzes") –– but the bulk of the work comes from the gallery project that runs throughout the semester and requires hefty research and writing for the 3.5 papers that are related to it. Also it's definitely easy to get a B+ or A– in this class, but it's not an easy A either.

best_comment: Act Natural is lowkey one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard. A lot of classes in the creative fields here can be intimidating, but this class felt super accessible thanks to the chill course staff and fun texts peppered throughout the syllabus. I had no formal acting experience going into the course, but was able to take away a lot of practical ideas from this class and honestly feel inspired to maybe try acting for realsies one day. In addition to acting, the class also digs into related subjects like performance theory and artificial intelligence. I enjoyed these forays, albeit they were discussed at a fairly surface level (it's still a GenEd).
best_gem_comment: This course is an absolute GEM that I highly recommend. Zero acting experience necessary! This class is definitely more oriented towards observing people's habits and physicalities rather than play–acting, which made it more interesting. I felt like I was participating in a social experiment (i.e. similar to The Rehearsal). The lectures are a bit long but you play a lot fun acting games, which allows you to build community with your class and/or section. There are no exams, papers, or midterm/final, which definitely makes this course stress–free.
subject: General Education

course_title: The Global Heart Disease Epidemic: Stopping What We Started 001
best_comment: This course is amazing! I highly recommend it. It is a gem of a GenEd! Rich is extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the subject matter. Go to lecture! Super interesting material. Study the slides/lecture material and you will be sure to do great on the midterm and final! No trick questions. You do a healthy living challenge that basically leads you to choose a healthy habit (drinking water, sleeping more, exercising, eating healthier, etc.) and track your progress over a few weeks. You will be surprised at your results! This is probably the class I have learned the most from here at Harvard in terms of how to take care of myself and actually implement healthy living changes in my daily life. I find myself telling my family a lot of the things I have learned and sharing some healthy habit tips with them. Super grateful for the opportunity to have taken this class (and to learn CPR!!!)
worse_comment: It is interesting but a lot of material for a gen–ed. Lots of studying required for midterm and final. Grading is somewhat harsh. Not a gem.
best_gem_comment: This course is amazing! I highly recommend it. It is a gem of a GenEd! Rich is extremely knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the subject matter. Go to lecture! Super interesting material. Study the slides/lecture material and you will be sure to do great on the midterm and final! No trick questions. subject: General Education
course_title_2023: The Global Heart Disease Epidemic: Stopping What We Started

course_title: Faith and Authenticity: Religion, Existentialism and the Human Condition 001
best_comment: One of the courses that I am most likely to recommend to anyone at the college.  As a philosophy concentrator I found it relatively relaxed but incredibly rewarding, and as a philosophy concentrator I constantly hear people who are concentrating in other fields say that they want to take a philosophy course at some point. I'd say this is the one to take. The readings are excellent, and while not the lightest ever in terms of load they are never overwhelming, and the assignments are not too difficult if you engage with the content. The Lamberths are great guides through these texts and are very good lecturers. They have slightly different lecturing styles that work very well in contrast to each other.  Highly recommend as a rich but not overly stressful class for humanities students and as an excellent and rewarding gened for people outside of the humanities.
worse_comment: The course when I took it had an overwhelming amount of readings. I told myself I had the motivation and wanted to learn, but when there is too much and you have three other classes, this falls to the back burner. Lectures too were not very helpful in understanding the readings because there is an assumption that everyone in the class knows extensively about religion and philosophy. That's why I switched to taking it Pass Fail.

course_title: Faith and Authenticity: Religion, Existentialism and the Human Condition 001

course_title: African Spirituality and the Challenges of Modern Times 001
best_comment: It was poorly organised but in general this class can be a gem if you make it one. You don't have to do the readings to do well in the course assignments. There is one group presentation, one creative essay/interview assignment that's only 2 pages and then the midterm which is two easy short answer questions and one final paper that's 10–12 pages. It sounds like a lot but it's better than it seems.
best_gem_comment: This class was a GEM and was one of my favorites that I have taken here at Harvard! In terms of some of the essays, creative assignment, and presentation, choose topics that you think are really interesting and that speak to you. It will really enhance your experience with the class!
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: African Spirituality and the Challenges of Modern Times

best_comment: This class is probably the best way to fulfill the arts and culture requirement for GenEd. The course is not a burden, but  material covered is interesting and relevant if you choose to engage with it. Gregg is great, very enthusiastic and knowledgable. There is obviously a reason why this course is so popular and lasting.
worse_comment: I liked this class. I barely went to class and did only readings necessary to complete assignments (often none), but somehow still managed to learn about greek myths and I enjoyed the class. Warning: the sections are 1:15 and often in a weird building in campus (far away), which can be brutal.
best_gem_comment: Honestly, this class is what you make of it –– most people can coast by without doing the readings, so the class can be very little work if you want it to be, even though you probably won't end up getting much out of it in the end.  Lectures are basically useless and pretty much serve as a nice study hall so definitely go to section –– this is where you'll get most of the info you need for the course. Depending on your section TF (mine was great) the grading is pretty chill, and the creative exercises are fun!  In conclusion, take this class if you want an easy gem to round out your semester.
subject: General Education

course_title: Equity and Excellence in K12 American Schools 001
best_comment: Amazing class, sad to see Merseth finally retire. Obviously the class won't be the same if anyone else teaches it, but would definitely still recommend taking it if one of the course staff continues to teach it (Beth). In my 4 years here I've never interacted more with a class and have learned so much through the lectures, readings, and guest speakers. The class is definitely rough around some edges and lots of controversy surrounded different topics, but I think Merseth handled everything gracefully and acknowledged her mistakes and listened to the students. I admire her for leading a course like this that covers so many touchy topics, especially around identity. You might not agree some things she says or some of the readings, but the goal is to ultimately get students to think about these issues proactively, and have a discussion around them. It has been an incredibly valuable experience and definitely has me thinking about what type of impact and change I want to enact after college, even as a senior. The guest speakers are incredibly inspiring, and the community of the class is so amazing. I have nothing but good things to say about this class. I hope some version of it is brought back in the future, though I'm sure it won't be quite as chill as this year (all you had to do was like an hour of readings for each class and 3 really easy essay assignments, one of which was pass/fail). I'd guess if Beth teaches the course there will be more readings and regular assignments.
worse_comment: The topic of this class is very interesting and one that really does bring alot of questions to you if you spend time thinking about it. That being said, the discussions and questions that were brought about during lecture/section was very interesting. But one thing that I don't really like is having alot of questions but not enough solutions. I personally felt like I didn't quite learn as much as I wanted and alot of the things that were talked about were information that I kind of already knew. Maybe it was because how much I had heard people talk about and had very high expectations for it.
best_gem_comment: this is definitely not the gem it used to be

course_title: Why Is There No Cure for Health? 001
best_comment: ONE OF THE BEST CLASSES IF YOU ARE INTERESTED IN HEALTHCARE AND ECONOMICS. This class can be a great introduction to the complexities and details of the healthcare system and the economics behind it (you will learn about epidemiology, pharmaceuticals, health insurance, and some basic statistics). Some knowledge in economics and statistics might be helpful, but certainly not needed (they will teach and introduce all the concepts). The class meets twice a week, has section once a week, and is structured in three different units. There are pre–lecture quizzes before every class, 3 PSETS (you can also get the economics writing credit if you complete extra work in addition to the PSET), 3 unit group presentations, a final project. This GenEd is not a Gem (it is not an easy A),  it does require a lot of time commitment (PSETS are long and Unit Presentations have to be well–done) and the TFs can be harsh graders (they are really trying to help you understand the concepts and terminology)— you will get what you put in. However, despite the fact that it is on the more challenging side, it was my favorite class this semester. Professor Cutler is amazing and all the TFs are always willing to help you! At least once a week, Professor Cutler brings in a guest speaker; the speakers are the best way to gain insights and different perspectives in the world of healthcare. Everyone has different opinions with this class, often students complain about the workload and how the TFs grade the assignments. However, If you are debating on taking this class because of the grade you might get, but you are really interested in healthcare, TAKE IT! You will not regret it!
worse_comment: I would tell future students to take the class even if they worry that their knowledge doesn't correspond with the subject of the course.
best_gem_comment: gem if you stay on top of your projects and psets!
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Why Is There No Cure for Health?

course_title: How Music Works: Engineering the Acoustical World 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! The lectures are a bit complex, but they are just fun to listen into because the labs don't really have much to do with lecture material (my friend who just swiped in and was on their laptop the entire semester still got an A). The labs are WONDERFUL and the projects are super fun. Very much a you get out what you put in so you can put in very low effort for an A or really go ham on the projects. Rob is also one of the NICEST profs ive had and will answer any question and help out. He came to help out my friends project himself and spent more time with them than other groups spent on their own projects. Really an amazing class.
worse_comment: As a musician and STEM major, I thought this class would be a super interesting blend of my interests. Unfortunately, I was wrong. I really disliked this course. I hated most of the labs; they always took at least an hour or two more than  the scheduled lab time to complete. I am not an electrical engineer, and I found it really really frustrating to have to build circuits and then try to debug them forever. Most of this class will be looking at equations you don't understand instead of discussing what makes music fun. I really liked some of the guest lecturers, but besides that, I did not enjoy this course.
best_gem_comment: 100% recommend this course!!! No exams, labs are great, interesting, low–stress, and graded extremely fairly, and you just get to let your creativity flow in the various instrument builds throughout the course. Only thing I'd say is that the final project can get a little overwhelming at times, as it consists of a build and a long reflection, but overall still reasonable. A definite gem of a course, and a great way to knock out a Science GENED requirement.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: How Music Works: Engineering the Acoustical World

course_title: The Border: Race, Politics, and Health in Modern Mexico 001
best_comment: Take this course!! Professor Soto is one of the best lecturers I've ever had. Her lectures are packed with such important and relevant information, but she teaches in a way that's like story telling, and I would always want to hear more at the end of lectures. She sounded so knowledgable and passionate about the topics covered in class and made the entire class feel so welcome and acknowledged. You do not need to know much about Mexico or the Border, but go in with an open–mind and willingness to listen because this class has really made me feel so much more informed about Mexico, its history, and its relationship with the U.S and other countries. There are weekly readings that were usually manageable, but can feel overwhelming at times with other assignments and if you start them late and do not spread them out, but it really wasn't that bad and you don't need to read them super in depth to understand what's happening in lecture/section. I do think you should read/skim most of them though because it really adds to your understanding of the topics and are all very relevant and interesting – and there's quick weekly discussion posts where you need to write a short reflection about a reading or readings that you found interesting. There were just a few papers to write that are super fair and short for the most part; these were clearly made with specific learning goals and I feel like I learned a lot after completing them. The teaching staff is so nice and usually flexible within reason, and there are also no exams (if attendance remains at a certain level throughout the semester, we almost had a quiz once because less and less ppl were showing up to class). Overall, this class really changed my perspective of the Border and I learned so much about Mexico; I was debating on taking it or not because I don't like learning history (there was only some history for background but it gets sm better after that first few weeks).  I will never forget this class and I'm so grateful I took it, and you should take it too!!
worse_comment: Take this class if it interests you, but if not, you will likely be disappointed by the redundancy and at times excessive writing.
best_gem_comment: ABSOLUTELY AMAZING!! If you have the opportunity to take this class, please do it! The lectures are always engaging, and you learn so much every single time without fail. Profesora is also incredibly kind and so passionate about what she teaches, she is one of the best lecturers. I will be thinking about this course for a long time, it is definitely a Gem for sure.

course_title: Classical Chinese Ethical and Political Theory 001
best_comment: At the very first lecture (and in the course trailer), Professor Puett says that the goal is to change our lives holistically –– to learn how to flourish more in the world as human beings. The course did that for me. I was constantly reflecting on the lectures and trying to put into practice the concepts we were learning about in order to make myself a more thoughtful and grounded person in my personal and academic life. I feel genuinely more alive and more human after taking this course. I take deeper breaths, I stop to recognize that someone near me is having an 'off' day, I am more forgiving of myself. I could go on and on. It also feels like an accomplishment to have read some of the most foundational texts of the classical chinese tradition. TAKE THIS COURSE. Unless you NEED visuals during a lecture, please please do yourself a favor and take this course. It's not a ton of weekly work, but yet you still demonstrate your understanding in a variety of ways. Without too much work, the course does exactly what a good education should do –– makes you a better person in the world without demanding busy work to reach that aim.Michael Puett is gold on Harvard's campus. Everyone should take a course with him during their Harvard career. He is brilliant, joyful, and energetic. His lecturing style worked very well for me personally as an auditory learner. It was also so lovely how all of his lectures built off of and specifically tied back to all of the previous lectures (instead of assuming that we always had time to re–orient ourselves and review material before class in the middle of week)!
worse_comment: Rethink your decision before you take this course! This course is highly dependent on the section's leader; Hence, if you get a bad section leader that will only give 2A– in the class and all others a B/C, YOU'RE SCREWED. It also have a tremendous amount of essay to write compared to other GENED I have ever taken in my life, and those essay are closed–book, so if you are a STEM student with limited background in writing, YOU'RE SCREWED. Furthermore, the grade curve here is harsh. Overall, I recommend with reservation for this class in regards to their discrepancies in grading as well as unfairness between different sections.
best_gem_comment: It's a gem if you are at all interested in Chinese ethics (no prior knowledge needed). Professor Puett generates a lot of enthusiasm about the subject matter and is great at helping you understand the main ideas of the difficult readings. Assignments are also minimal (and fun! I especially loved how flexible the final project was) and graded pretty easily.

course_title: Who Lives, Who Dies, Who Cares? Reimagining Global Health 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! The readings are heavy at times, but you do not need to read all of them to do well in class. However, you should read as many as you can because they are truly very interesting. The lectures are engaging and Professor Keshavjee, Kleinman, and Becker are amazing and experts in their field. This class will change the way you think about the world and the field of global health. The midterm is also very reasonable and if you attend lectures and keep up with general ideas it is very easy to do well!
worse_comment: Take this class! You will cry, you will feel angry but you will learn a lot. This class really exposes you to the harsh inequities in healthcare and teaches frameworks (social theories) to examine the reasons behind those inequities.
