course_title: Confronting Climate Change: A Foundation in Science, Technology and Policy 001
best_comment: I cannot recommend this class enough for people who do not know a lot but want to understand climate change. This course gives a great overview of the elementary science of how we know climate change is a problem (first 3rd of class) and what the impacts will be (second 3rd of the class). Then, you learn about what the solutions will be and what policies are needed (final 3rd of the class). The class is really low in workload (and stress) but gives you so much information about climate change. Prof. Schrag is extremely dedicated (and a great lecturer) and very nice (ex. offers a huge extra credit opportunity!). If you already know a lot about climate change, this may be basic. But, I found it to be a great start to now be able to explore specific issues more in depth.
worse_comment: This class barely has any work. However, know that the professor is sometimes unbearable in that he is very knowledgeable about the subject (climate change) but extremely arrogant. It's his way or the highway. He is soft spoken, but can be condescending. This class has a lot of graduate students, and a lot of times, they would try to test or propose a different argument or perspective. Granted, some of the graduate students are also super arrogant, but the professor frequently interrupts the speaker without them comprehensively express their thoughts and try to make everyone in the class think the speaker is wrong and the professor is right. Sorry, but a lot of these topics do not have a right or wrong. It's all blurred and grey, so if you want to hear this guy trying to boost his ego for 75 minutes 2 times a week, go ahead. The grading rubric is completely arbitrary. Your midterms are out of 10 points, and sometimes you get one point taken off because you didn't say a specific word. So, imagine losing 3 points, which for any other midterm wouldn't be too bad, but for these midterms, that means you get a 70 already.
best_gem_comment: TAKE IT!!! Dan is an awesome lecturer and you learn a lot!! I enjoyed going to his class and looking at the extra materials. Highly recommended! Truly a gem where you get to learn a lot!!!

best_comment: This class is a great introduction to folklore studies. Though it can be hard to stay engaged at 9am lectures, they often contain funny videos and really out–there topics like  "necropants" that make lectures entertaining. Readings can be a little slow, but looking over them helps prepare you for class. Folklore collections are definitely a little difficult to compose at first because most students haven't done anything like them before, but they really help you gain an appreciation for Harvard Folklore. This class is a fun choice if you want to learn about how narratives and story–telling reflect and shape cultures.
worse_comment: It's fun, lectures are a bit boring if you aren't interested in the material on your own.
best_gem_comment: Honestly, this class wasn't for me. If you enjoy learning about Scandinavian/American folklore this is the class for you, but that wasn't me. The assignments are pretty easy, though they can feel unstructured at times. The trips were really fun and make the class stand out. Not quite a gem but definitely take it if you are somewhat interested in the material and don't want to much work. Also, only do the readings necessary for section the others are way too long.

course_title: Making Change When Change is Hard: the Law, Politics, and Policy of Social Change 001
best_comment: This course introduced a lot of interesting ideas that felt very applicable to the world around us. I definitely think about things differently having taken this course! This is a great gened in that it really pushes you to think in different ways and has a clear argument/perspective throughout the course. I'm sure I will continue to think about the ideas we learned going forward regardless of where I find myself.The lectures were sometimes a bit unorganized and could have been focused a bit more on concepts and examples to illustrate (e.g. laid out more like a structured essay). Otherwise, I found them to be engaging, and Prof. Sunstein definitely made them fun by throwing in some good jokes and generally being approachable and lighthearted.The readings had a good variety, although I found some much more useful than others. (This was likely because they were aimed at a wide audience, so some were much more technical than others). Overall, I didn't feel like it took too long to complete the regular readings and pull out the main ideas from each. As the readings were the main assignments, I found this courseload very manageable.Our section, which was led by Eric, was great! I felt like we did a really good job reviewing the concepts and thinking about them in the context of real life. Eric did a good job facilitating interesting discussions as well.
worse_comment: Its a good class, but grading is a little arbitrary. Exams are non–negligible (24 hour final and 5 hour midterm, and you have to write a significant amount). Overally, you still learn a lot but it is not super easy. Lectures are a little difficult to follow.
best_gem_comment: A definite gem, but likely far from the most engaging Gened. While Cass is a beast in academia and the material itself is quite fascinating IMO, his lectures are somewhat disorganized, and he has a habit of rambling, making it hard to pay attention or follow the material sometimes. Take time to prep for exams, which are essentially just writing a couple thousand words in a reasonable timeframe (but will probably sap up half a day).
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Histories, Societies, Individuals
course_title_2023: Making Change When Change is Hard: the Law, Politics, and Policy of Social Change

best_comment: This class is pretty good, especially if you're already interested in urban planning. A lot of the subjects covered – governance, organic growth, transportation, housing, etc. – are very timely and applicable to our everyday lives, and the readings do a good job of presenting different perspectives/opinions on these important issues. The professors are both very experienced and knowledgable about all of the content material, and it's clear that they are very passionate and interested in this work. However, at many times the course seemed a bit disorganised. The lectures sometimes were unengaging (I feel like it would have been an amazing experience to engage with the professors in a smaller, more–seminar–style setting), and sections were to be honest not very useful. I did not feel that most of my classmates prepared appropriately for each week's discussions which was largely just prodded along by the TF.
best_gem_comment: Course was very poorly organized. Lectures felt unstructured and were very unengaging. Assignments were short and grading was friendly. Definitely a gem but don't take it if you're trying to learn something interesting.

best_comment: This class is pretty good, especially if you're already interested in urban planning. A lot of the subjects covered – governance, organic growth, transportation, housing, etc. – are very timely and applicable to our everyday lives, and the readings do a good job of presenting different perspectives/opinions on these important issues. best_gem_comment: Course was very poorly organized. Lectures felt unstructured and were very unengaging. Assignments were short and grading was friendly. Definitely a gem but don't take it if you're trying to learn something interesting.

course_title: Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to Soft Matter Science 001
best_comment: This class is great! By no means a gem, but still relatively light course load. The lectures are super engaging and the guest speakers are so interesting. There's also so many opportunities if you're genuinely super interested in this topic. If you have basic knowledge of physics, biology, and chemistry this'll be an easy enough A. I know my humanities friends struggled a bit more in this class. The labs and psets make up a substantial amount of time, but they aren't so hard you have to go to office hours. The exams are surprisingly hard and the final project is somewhat time exhaustive if you are productive during section. Overall, this is a great course and a good way to fulfill the requirement.
worse_comment: This is a fun class but it is considerably more work than many other GENEDs seem to be. The professors will also interrupt the guest lecturers sometimes, which is frustrating and rude. This class is also tough because the science itself is oversimplified, which at times is hard to difficult to justify as a science major.
best_gem_comment: This class is great! By no means a gem, but still relatively light course load. The lectures are super engaging and the guest speakers are so interesting. There's also so many opportunities if you're genuinely super interested in this topic. If you have basic knowledge of physics, biology, and chemistry this'll be an easy enough A. I know my humanities friends struggled a bit more in this class. The labs and psets make up a substantial amount of time, but they aren't so hard you have to go to office hours. best_comment: This was overall a good course, and a great way to fulfill the relevant gened requirements, even if it's not as "gemmy" as other classes. Lectures were fairly interesting, and it was cool how Profs Flad and Ur (who are clearly both experts in the field) used examples from their own research. Section was by far the highlight –– you get to do fun experiments (making pottery, making stone tools, etc.) to get some hands–on experience with the archaeological ideas that were discussed in lecture. The TFs were also great. The workload wasn't too bad; reading quizzes make sure you actually do the reading, but it was rarely more than ~30–45 minutes worth per lecture. The weekly assignments (a 500–1000 word reflection on section) were a bit hit–or–miss in terms of topic but not the end of the world in the grand scheme of things. Overall, I'm quite glad that I took this course, and would recommend it strongly to anyone who is interested in learning more about archaeology and/or needs another gened. I think that this class does a great job achieving the goals of the gened system, as it caused me to engage with an interesting subject that I had no prior exposure to and that has important ramifications for society. A few caveats: • The course does not communicate expectations very well. The syllabus refers to nebulous "section assignments," without really specifying that this includes a not–insignificant writing assignment every week. If you're going to assign weekly work, make it clear in the syllabus so that people know what sort of workload to expect. Additionally, the expectations for the final project were extremely unclear. The assignment page was multiple pages long, with a very complicated rubric. It shouldn't require that much effort just to decipher what we're being asked to write. A clearer assignment (along with examples of what a successful project looks like) would go a long way.  • There is an extremely strong ideological bent, particularly in Prof. Ur's lectures. While I'm not going to pretend to be surprised that a professor at Harvard is liberal, at times the evangelism was so strong that the class could have been a skit made by Tucker Carlson making fun of what he thinks Harvard is like. During many of the "debates" it was clear that there was one right side and one wrong side, and that any perspectives other than the party line would not have been tolerated. I imagine that this doesn't bother most people, but if you're someone who gets bothered by one–sided preaching you might not like that aspect of the class.   • The professors did these annoying "breakouts" during lecture, where a question would be asked and people would have to discuss with their neighbors. After the 2020–21 year, I didn't think anything could be more annoying and awkward than zoom breakout rooms, but the in–person analogue was even worse. I would strongly encourage the professors to change this for next year.
worse_comment: Section assignments feel like busywork and often require prior preparation. The quizzes often don't test true understanding of the readings but rather remembering small, insignificant details. Also greatly disliked how professors forced students into breakout groups all the time during lecture and did cold–calling.
best_gem_comment: Great GenEd that you will actually learn things in without excessive workload. The final project is also pretty fun if you actually are interested in your topic and apply yourself. As long as you do well on the quizzes (super easy if you do the readings) and go to class/ section, this is a gem.

gened: Histories, Societies, Individuals; Science and Technology in Society

best_comment: GENED 1114 not only focuses on learning how to paint / developing new painting skills, but also on learning how to read paintings. It has completely changed the way I view other artists' work! We also are given a lot of creative freedom in what we choose to paint within broad themes for each assignment, and our final project essentially allows us to create what our heart desires. Be aware that this is a great time commitment (as is a given with any art course), but definitely take this class! You will learn so much, the teaching staff is really nice, and this class is a lot of fun.
worse_comment: Very interesting and you will learn how to paint. The class is a lot of actual work, however. Its not hard, but if you have a busy semester it will become frustrating how much time you have to spend doing things .
subject: General Education

best_comment: This course provides a good overview of the most important concepts related to globalization and is very much relevant to current events. Lectures are great –– enlightening debates between the professors, super interesting guests. Memos were a good exercise in thinking about an issue from the perspective of a certain stakeholder, not just in thinking about an issue from the perspective of what is the most economically efficient solution –– a unique class in this regard. The second simulation (US–China) was great; the first was okay. Section was not very useful. Overall, a good class that exposes you to a variety of viewpoints on interesting issues like trade, climate change, etc.
worse_comment: It's very difficult for a GENED. The lectures are very long and boring. Material is somewhat interesting though.
best_gem_comment: This is a great course to help understand current global political/economic phenomena. Professors Summers and Lawrence are very engaging during lectures and their network of guests is unmatched, with diverse viewpoints and backgrounds from world leaders, renowned economists, executives, etc.  The readings are very interesting as well and the simulations allow you to learn a lot and consider different viewpoints. Content from the asynchronous lectures is essential for midterm/final, so keep up with these. Even if you aren't much into econ I'd take this class for the Gened, it isn't a gem per se (grading is tough) but you won't be bored and the assignments are engaging.
subject: General Education
gened: Ethics and Civics; Histories, Societies, Individuals

course_title: Power to the People: Black Power, Radical Feminism, and Gay Liberation 001
best_comment: this course unexpectedly has A LOT of reading, with you sometimes having to read whole books for section. not many people actually do all (if any) of the readings. the readings are unrelated to the lectures, which are kind of unrelated to section, which is kind of unrelated to the final project. the class is not that cohesive, but professor Bronski and the course staff are super experienced and great to talk to! the class is pretty easy but I'd recommend doing some of the readings to get something out of it! and make sure to start your midterm early and stay caught up on the discussion posts because those can pile up pretty quick. overall, a pretty easy class that is not very rewarding if u don't put effort into it.
worse_comment: Do not take this class if you're looking for engaging lectures. The lectures were mind–bogglingly boring with no argumentation style. The professor simply just read off historical figures and events without trying to make a point.
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Power to the People: Black Power, Radical Feminism, and Gay Liberation

best_comment: This is an excellent Gen Ed that will equip you with an understanding of loss, both how it is portrayed (writing, music, art) and how others make meaning out of it. There is no guarantee that taking this class will make grieving or death easier, but there is no better place to come face to face with this difficult subject because of how thoughtfully it is treated. Professor Coleman is a phenomenal lecturer who cares about each of her students, greatly valuing their participation and feedback. Particularly if you are interested in the classics (Greek/Roman history), you will be pleasantly surprised with the influence that these subjects have across the weeks. There is a fair amount of work involved, but the assignments are meaningful and reinforce skills that are useful in any setting.
worse_comment: Don't take this. God. Unless you're a white person who's only ever lost maybe a pet. You'll cry on the walk back to your dorm about how horrible it is. It is a horrific class. It should not exist.
best_gem_comment: This class is excellent for building emotional intelligence and empathy. It will help you build skills that are extremely important for the real world and interacting with others. In terms of workload, it is an absolute gem!!! Super light workload!
subject: General Education

best_comment: Borders is a decent class. The professor's lectures can be very dry at times but the content itself is pretty interesting. This class is not a breeze but is still extremely manageable. The assignment prompts weren't always clear and many students did complain about that, the prof had to send many emails for clarity.  Honestly the highlight was the section component. Elizabeth was an amazing TF and really cared about her students. She was knowledgeable, fun, and really knew how to get a meaningful conversation going. If you are lucky enough to get her as a TF you are set. I would encourage you to take this class but just know that it still requires a decent amount of effort, but you can get away with not doing all the readings.
worse_comment: This course was a pedagogical catastrophe. I write this not out of spite but out of sadness and concern, disappointment at the gap between what this course promised to be and what it was. And I write this as someone who cares deeply about education, immigration, and history: If this course is not changed dramatically, it will produce poor historians, writers, and activists.A list of major problems with this course:1)	Ethics: Although this is supposed to be an ethics and civics gened, there were no ethical frameworks used or any meaningful ethics teaching. Every unit would go a little something like this: We would read about a border that contributed to some violence, the professor would imply heavily that borders = violence = bad, this would be reiterated in section discussion, and then we’d move on. This used truisms – borders exclude people! – to avoid meaningful ethical discussions: Is exclusion inherently violent or immoral? What are the relationships between violence and immorality? Can we generate axioms or a standardized set of ethical considerations when evaluating a particular border? I came into this course with experience in immigration protest and a strong belief in the need to abolish or at least heavily curtail borders. I thought I’d be asked to engage with other beliefs in order to test, bolster, and better communicate my own. In fact, the opposite happened. The course’s very obvious but tacit anti–borders orientation leaves its students utterly unprepared to have substantive, difficult conversations with people who believe in borders because the class never in good faith entertained those beliefs, and the ethical reasoning behind them. 2)	History: This course jumped around in both space and time in a way that was disorienting and created shallow coverage.  We spent much of the time on Europe – World War I and the Cold War – and yet had almost zero historical context for those units. (This was related to siloed, out of context assignments, explained further below.) Without an ethical framework affording cohesion, the course needed historical momentum and narrative. Instead, it felt like we were randomly picking borders with next to no historical awareness – the plebiscites, for example – and the only unifying thread was Eurocentrism. I understand the impulse to start and end in the United States, but if this course wants to be global, it should be willing to spend more time afield – the Koreas, Africa post–colonization, etc.!3)	Assignments: The assignments were poorly constructed. The midterm in particular asked students to make an argument from six lines in an excel column. It was framed as a map exercise, but the map was essentially irrelevant; all the data came from those six lines. I got a near perfect score simply by reiterating the lecture on plebiscites, because there was zero other historical material from the class, and we weren’t allowed to even try to understand the historical context using outside material. The assignment implied the way to succeed was 1) restate exactly what the professor says; and 2) imply causation from correlation in the numbers. These are the opposite of the lessons students – especially young historians – should be learning. Similarly, with the final project: This isn’t 2015 anymore; podcasts are no longer new and creative. The course needs to either commit to having a creative final project that lets people draw on their creative skillsets, or have a final paper/exam. This in–between is frustrating – it’s as much or more work than a paper, but not truly creative enough to let students think outside the box. 4)	Technology: Almost half of the lectures were waylaid by technological failures that sucked up class time and impeded learning. Things like setting up subtitles on a video, using Google Earth, etc. would neutralize entire class activities and knock out 10–15 minutes of class time. Yes, technology can be finnicky, but not a single other professor I’ve had at Harvard has struggled to this extent, especially after the Zoom year, which afforded most teachers a basic level of technological competence. There are basic technological skills all instructors should have mastered by now.5)	Fraught lectures: Sensitive, politically complex discussions should be led by experts: We should not be learning about issues as fraught as Israel–Palestine from someone unequipped to facilitate deep conversations. This unit alone was shockingly mishandled. First, we spent an entire class watching a documentary with no context – a documentary that was flagrantly propagandistic, playing machine gun and bomb noises whenever Jewish sources spoke. After the documentary, we had time for exactly two questions: One student in the class asked “how the Jews got their weapons,” to which the professor responded “I don’t know.” !!! Another student asked who made the movie, to which the professor also responded that she wasn’t sure. Beyond the obvious pedagogical neglect inherent in showing a movie without knowing its sourcing, it was devastating to hear absolutely zero response to a basic question about the conflict (phrased in a way that definitely demanded unpacking!) The next lecture featured some ex post facto attempts to clean up the mess, which seemed shoehorned in, given how much the class ran over. Anyways, the damage was done. I think the unit was indicative of a bigger flaw in the current gened system, which allows professors who are experts in other fields to each tenuously related subjects as pet projects. The professor told us she taught this class because she felt she had to after Trump era border separation. I’m sympathetic to this political starting point, but not the fact that it emboldened her to claim expertise she doesn’t have on regions and issues that matter a great deal to a lot of people. Perhaps a co–professor would go a long way. 6)	Resistance to feedback: Earlier in the course, I submitted versions of these complaints via the anonymous feedback form. At the start of the next class, the professor summarily entertained them and dismissed them, in a way that made clear the point of the form was not to modify the course at all, but to reactionarily defend its decisions. Similarly, in the last lecture, we were told to be nice in our Q guide reviews, lest we hinder the teaching careers of our TFs. Do you all not understand that this defeats the purpose of the Q guide? Not to mention how condescending and educationally bankrupt it is. Both the mid–semester feedback form and the Q–Guide recognize that students may have legitimate issues with the way a course is being taught. The correct response to this is not to either ignore that feedback or preemptively shape it. The correct response is to LISTEN to the students. 7)	Attention: Many lectures started with or included a plea for students to not be distracted. Yes, technology and the pandemic have had a deleterious effect on attention spans and attitudes toward learning. But there’s a reason why we were bored! The lectures lacked cohesion or a driving principle; they felt like a random dissemination of information with weak gestures towards analysis (see the ethics point.) Attention is earned. If more than half your class is either not showing up or doing other work during class, that should be some indication that the class needs to be doing more. In sum, please do not take this course – especially if you are a freshman. It will prepare you poorly for later history courses, ethics courses, and courses that require writing. Upperclassmen – take this course only if you need a gem.
best_gem_comment: Readings are fair, and topic is super interesting. The lectures are very hard to keep up with (not because of content, but the way they're structured/taught). Assignments are fair and fun. Wouldn't call it a gem, but still in the easier side of things.

course_title: Mental Health and Mental Illness Through Literature and the Arts 001
best_comment: This class was amazing. As someone who is passionate about mental health and illness, I learned so much from the readings and discussions and the people in this class. It is a class with a decent amount of reading, but it is so worth it and manageable.  I also appreciated how in classes where I could not complete the reading, I did not feel too behind because we discussed it in lecture. As long as I familiarized myself with the text by the midterm, I was ok. Section was also really rewarding, and I did not feel pressured to speak merely for participation because I genuinely wanted to talk and engage with the great ideas and experiences mentioned. I also think the capstone project was reasonable and for me, rewarding. Like anything this class is what you want to make out of it and if you want to make the best out of it, it will be extremely worth it.
worse_comment: This course has a moderate/chill workload, but it is overwhelmingly boring and has a weird structure. I cannot really tell you the big picture/broad overarching themes of this course. I feel like the plot was not clear and never became clear; the course material focused on mental illness representations across the globe and was reading–heavy but the discussion was never centered around the arts as a whole. We only read memoirs and looked at paintings once or twice during a presentation from the Harvard Art Museums. Beyond that, the course was just a regurgitation of "those who are mentally ill struggle" and "mental health stigma is bad" every week. Professor is receptive to feedback; we expressed that the readings were too much and she trimmed it down. However, when we said the course was not engaging, she decided to throw more busy work at us with polls and random useless response questions on Canvas. This was a drag and did not add anything special to the class. By not engaging, we meant that the course material she discussed at length was boring. Once again, just repetition. No unique focus on art styles or psychology or social constructions of stigma/bias. Just surface level engagement discussing the very nuanced topic of mental health/illness. The grading breakdown is generous and you can definitely pass but it will feel like a drag sometimes due to the busy work. Harsh or lenient grading depends on your TF.  Teaching staff was useless, no offense. Did not particularly enjoy section with my TF Lizzie. Overall the class was decent but not change–your–life worthy.
best_gem_comment: This class is a great Gen–Ed. Wouldn't qualify it as a gem especially because of the midterm, which requires you to actually have done pretty much all the readings up until that point in the semester. However, I feel like I got a lot out of this class – so I would recommend taking it. The final project is very open–ended, so you'd get the chance to explore pretty much any topic related to mental health!

best_comment: I enjoyed this class and felt like I got a lot out of it, but I would warn future students that at its core it is a class about race philosophy and general racial theory, which to me it was not marketed as. I was expecting to talk more about real–world applications and this class (while great) was not that. It often felt to me detached from the structural problems I was expecting to discuss because of the purely theoretical nature of its readings. But it is a perfectly fine class for people who are expecting and eager to get philosophical, and if you like theory I would recommend!A big part of the class/section is formatted towards the understanding of argument formats in specific readings and situations and how to replicate them/make a good argument yourself, which is very helpful but again only really from a philosophy perspective.Professor Shelby is a great guy and clearly cares a lot about the material; some of the readings are pretty arduous and he makes them easy to understand.The TFs are amazing and so helpful in the same manner; use them! :)
worse_comment: I'm not sure that any Ethics & Civics course at Harvard would be particularly good, but this one certainly wasn't. I do like Professor Shelby though, and I would say to choose a class for this requirement that is taught by a poc/non–white person. It is so important to have someone who understands the issues facing minorities leading these courses. I think my experience in this class would have been even worse if the course head was a detached, clueless white man.

course_title: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Aztec Empire, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX 001
best_comment: Is the class a gem? In most regards, yes. There are copious amounts of reading but you do not have to do them, at least not in depth. There are only two assignments, a take home midterm and a final, which are supposed to be 6–7 pages but realistically are 20 pages (albeit a relatively easy 20 pages to write, defining terms and 2 short essays). Lectures are interesting — very unorganized, at times impossible to follow, but the professors are certainly passionate, many lectures feeling like sermons. Great, its a gem, but do you walk away with anything? Maybe. I was very lucky to have Leonardo as my section leader who organized the often times scrambled readings and lectures into coherent lessons. I learned interesting stories about Aztec times and am grateful for a deeper understanding of Mexico’s cultural past, from the colonial days to revolution to present day Mexico, I have gained an understanding of the forces that have shaped today’s Mexico. I’ve walked away with a few interesting anthropological concepts that I doubt I will use in the future but I am grateful to have understood. In short, lecture did very little, the readings ocassionally helped (granted I only skimmed), and section was interesting and informative. Writing the final and the midterm forced me to draw connections and while I at times felt like I was making things up, I think was a valuable exercise (although wayyy too long). Do not take this class if you want a great interesting class — it is not that. If you are looking for a gem, take it. The workload is light and you will walk away having learned a handful of things.
worse_comment: This class is a very easy Gen Ed, workload is very light and your grade rides on around a 40% mid–term and 50% final.  However, these are take–home where you just have to write two short essays and some short answers. You get a week to do them, and the TFs usually grade nicely. As long as you hand in something that makes sense, you can probably leave this class with at least an A–.  (They even have extra credit projects that you can do.) Also, there are a bunch of weekly readings, but I stopped doing them midway into the semester because it wasn't really necessary. You can get by by skimming them considering that we didn't have any assignments on them. Also, lecture is fine, and it's great when Dr. Carrasco is the one lecturing, but if not then it's just a way to kill time.  They take attendance which is a bit annoying. Main problem with this class is that it can definitely be BORING. This might just depend on section, but mine was incredibly dry and I hated having to walk there each morning just to sit for over an hour and not get much done. It made me uninterested in the material for sure, which is why I wouldn't call this class a gem. Otherwise, if you're just trying to have a lighter workload, then this class is for you.

There are only two assignments, a take home midterm and a final, which are supposed to be 6–7 pages but realistically are 20 pages (albeit a relatively easy 20 pages to write, defining terms and 2 short essays). subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Ancient Empire, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX

subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Moctezuma’s Mexico Then and Now: Ancient Empire, Race Mixture, and Finding LatinX

course_title: Pluralism: Case Studies in American Diversity 001
best_comment: This is probably one of the more relaxed but engaging ethics and civics GenEd classes. The weekly workload is fairly light. The background readings are interesting and informative. However, if you are swamped for one week and don't have time, you will survive without them. The two papers are fun. Write a case study! (it isn't as long and is more fun) The case study method is a cool way of tangibly learning about religion in America. The classes themselves felt a little circular at times cause it was an echo chamber of agreement. However, I loved my section. Speak up in your section and challenge one another! it is honestly the only way to really get a lot out of this class. Elam is also fantastic if he is TFing again.
best_gem_comment: This is a really underrated class! The case studies are really topical and fun to read, and the focus on Asian religions is not something you typically see in many other courses. The discussion–based nature of the course also keeps class interesting. The weekly workload is very light—just readings and one short discussion post. Students take turns leading section, which makes each one unique and exciting. The midterm short paper and final case study are also very manageable and give you the option to write about whatever interests you. The Ethics + Civics distinction can sometimes be daunting, but this class is really accessible and inclusive to students from all backgrounds. Definitely take this gem of a class!
subject: General Education
course_title_2023: Pluralism: Case Studies in American Diversity

course_title: Life and Death in the Anthropocene 001
best_comment: Really fun GENED. Decent amount of reading, but you don't have to do it all.  Very good if you're into climate change, and Prof. Oreskes is a pretty fantastic lecturer. Super interesting takes on big subjects, her lectures gave me great perspective on this material.

Such a great way to fulfill your Science and Tech Gened!!! First and foremost the course material is super interesting and timely. You get to explore vaccines from so many different angles and really understand why they have become such an important tool for public health. They bring in SUCH cool guest speakers pretty much every class for the second half of the semester, and you get to hear a variety of perspectives from real experts in the field. Highly recommend going to lecture because of how genuinely interesting I found it, but the other great thing about this course is that you can totally succeed without ever attending lecture. You have to write a one page response paper each week (with relatively simple prompts, never took me over 45 min), and as long as you quote from 2 of the readings you'll get full credit. Aside from the final project, that's really the only work you ever have in the class – pretty gemmy if you ask me.
worse_comment: I had taken the course with certain expectations –– relatively low workload, engaging guest lectures, etc., but that was definitely not my experience in the course. It ended up being a lot more work than expected and they only made it harder (by establishing more guidelines on the weekly response papers). It's very likely that they are going to enforce an attendance policy, and the class being at 9AM will kill you. I also felt that the podcast being the final project was something that wasn't my style. If you're looking for a gem, this ain't it.
best_gem_comment: Take! This! Course! It is a true GEM.  The final project is worked on throughout this semester so it isn't too overwhelming at the end and there's only one paper a week (+ two drops allowed). Also, I don't think she'll be TFing this course next year but Sara was hands down the best section leader that I've had at my time at Harvard. She made all the information super applicable and memorized everyone's name in the class and kept everyone engaged. An amazing yet easy course that I would 100% recommend.

You get to explore vaccines from so many different angles and really understand why they have become such an important tool for public health. best_comment: The best GENED Harvard has to offer and undoubtedly the best class I have taken here. The course was intellectually stimulating. The discussions in both lecture and section were fascinating, Prof. Sandel knows how to ask the right questions and find the core of the issue very quickly and focus the discussion on the most interesting points. He has a special talent in finding the controversial pain points and evoking a real desire in people to participate, I haven't seen this form of instruction in any of my other classes. The guest speakers were exceptional. The readings were not too long and super relevant. There was the perfect combination of philosophical discussions and practical debates on applications. We discussed issues that were relevant in the public debate like affirmative action. Really really recommend this class.Spend time on the essays and meet with section leader to discuss before because it really helps formulate a strong argument.
worse_comment: It gets kind of repetitive and boring at times
best_gem_comment: This is certainly a gem if you want it to be.
subject: General Education

course_title: The English Language Today, Yesterday, and Tomorrow 001
best_comment: This class has an interesting topic, but I would only recommend it if they fix the course structure. The teaching staff often were not on the same page about things, which made it that much worse and even more confusing for the students. However, Professor Donoghue is a super nice and interesting person, and also so so SO understanding of personal things going on in your life. He is genuinely such a kind and caring professor, I don't think I could've finished this semester without him. He is also super passionate about the topic, so it was really fun getting to see him "geek out" over Olde English. He was also able to get a lot of really fun and interesting guest speakers to come speak to the class, which made the class super engaging.
worse_comment: I really like Prof Donoghue but I unfortunately would not recommend this class. The organisation is poor – firstly there is no syllabus and so it's very difficult to know what is expected of you throughout the semester. The weekly exercises are tedious (and incredibly time consuming) and unrelated to what is taught in lecture. Lecture is interesting but very dense and the slides are scant so it is almost impossible to leave a lecture feeling like you know what is going on.

best_comment: Take this class! It helped me learn much more about certain topics and it helped me find ways to express them! It teaches you a lot about how technology and convenience have been viewed throughout the years as well as makes you think about the current state of the world and our relationship with technology and convenience. If you like thinking about things like the meaning of life, I feel like you could truly enjoy this course, because it takes one specific stance (in terms of the meaning of life) and then looks at the world critically from that perspective. Very fun course with amazing readings, and I think that anyone who does the readings and pays attention in lectures would enjoy it a lot!
worse_comment: This course is thought–provoking and provocative as a whole. It explores contemporary themes. Take the readings seriously. You will get a lot from this course.
best_gem_comment: I could not recommend this course enough. The professor was amazing, engaging and relaxing. The readings were interesting and not very challenging. A true gem of a course. The course granted be a more well rounded outlook on technology and generally how I plan to live my life – I find myself thinking of the lessons taught in this course on a semi–regular basis in my everyday life – and have altered decisions according to it.

best_comment: Swedish was the only class I would be happy to wake up at 9am for almost every day. Agnes is the sweetest person who tries her best to make the class as stress–free as possible. She's super reasonable and easy to talk to about anything. The pace of the class is perfect, but it's easy to fall behind if you don't study well enough for each chapter– so just make sure you keep yourself on track.
subject: Swedish

course_title: Global Oral Health: Healthy Teeth, Healthy Societies 001
best_comment: If you love global health, oral health, or are interested in medicine, this class is for you. Professor Seymour teaches the class with a lot of reflection and application which will help you have a non–traditional learning experience. There is no memorization to this course. If you immerse yourself in conversations, readings, etc. you will really enjoy this class! It builds a very good community too!
worse_comment: This is one of, if not the best course I've taken at Harvard. Dr. Seymour and Alyssa are phenomenal, the content is easy to digest, and it is a low stress course that emphasizes more on you retaining and learning the information than on memorization and stressful test taking. Please take this class if you're even considering it. Could not recommend more.
subject: Global Health & Health Policy
course_title_2023: Global Oral Health: Healthy Teeth, Healthy Societies

best_comment: This was my favorite class this semester. I think Professor Wang does an amazing job with providing engaging and interesting lectures. The readings may seem like a lot at first, but they are actually really interesting and great foundational knowledge for those thinking about concentrating in government. If you are deciding whether or not you want to concentrate in government, or you are looking for a class to fulfill the comparative politics requirement, this class is a great choice. There are mainly quizzes instead of assignments, but after the first one you get what they're looking for, so the class is also pretty low stress. I would recommend taking this class to anyone interested in social sciences.
worse_comment: This class is interesting if you enjoy government, but it is not a good introductory class. The sections were difficult, there were a lot of reading, and we didn’t get explanations or practice before our final paper or before tests.
subject: Government

best_comment: this is a solid intro course, but there are probably better classes out there if you have a deep interest in government. if you watch the videos, this class is super easy, but the format of having to watch videos/get quizzed on videos/then have lecture repeating all the info in the videos doesn't make much sense.
worse_comment: The class is not too hard. Yes, there is a quiz in every class, but they should be easily completed if you watch the videos. It is a little scary to think that 50% of the grade is decided within the final week of school. But, the midterm was not super hard.
subject: Government

course_title: Data Science for the Social Sciences 001
best_comment: This course was excellent. As a freshman, I had taken an environmental engineering course that taught R quite poorly. Hence, as a senior this year, I had strong worries and reservations about this class. But, Professor Blackwell and the course staff not only made this class beginner–friendly, in that you truly (as advertised) did not need significant statistics or coding background, but they also made it one of the best–taught classes I've taken here. Professor Blackwell is a very funny and engaging lecturer, with a memorable sense of humor. Psets are drawn from contemporary and interesting political science research, which is a neat way to apply the concepts we learn in class to timely real–world problems. The help available through Ed, Slack, and ample OH was tremendous––there was always an opportunity to get assistance if you needed it. The exams were very reasonable, and the autograder feature was awesome––it really drove home the value of continual attempts, analysis, and improvement in coding. The final project was also a neat way to further apply all the skills from this semester. Really enjoyed this class, and I definitely feel like I not only am more comfortable with R, but also appreciate it so much more. Professor Blackwell + team have really turned this class around, and I absolutely feel more empowered to utilize R in the future.
worse_comment: This is a very hard course if you don't buy in and pay attention from day 1.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Data Science for the Social Sciences

best_comment: Take this because you work super close with Professor Sweeney who is SUCH a cool and interesting professor.
worse_comment: Unfortunately, this class was my least favorite out of the three technology science requirements. I felt this class was rather disorganized. In fact, we did not follow the syllabus beyond the first two weeks, resulting in us only having one assignment before the final paper. Class usually followed the similar flow: starting late, presenting where students were in the research process, then individual time with the TFs. There is nothing more stressful than knowing one final paper is worth essentially 100% of your grade. I also felt that the data acquisition process for multiple students, including myself, took way too long, which resulted in many students throwing together a project last minute the final two weeks of the semester.
subject: Government

best_comment: the gemmiest gem ive ever taken. honestly to the point where i wish i'd taken something else. im definitely being uptight, but im personally super interested in the subject of this course, and i just found it pretty lackluster and disappointing. part of that was definitely because it took time to find a commissioner, but we barely did any policy research and the class was generally pretty disorganized. prof is sweet and funny, but super flaky with meetings.

course_title: The Governance and International Politics of World Regions 001
best_comment: If you're interested in IR and political theory, you will love this course. Some experience with political theory can be helpful, but is not required. I went into the course having never taken a government course at Harvard before, although I did enroll in another government course concurrently this semester (which I found helpful). While I had to spend a bit of additional time researching unfamiliar terms and concepts, I found the material accessible and extremely interesting, and I learned a lot from my classmates. Overall wonderful and informative course. Also a great opportunity to do independent research on a region that interests you.

I don't know about other seminar courses, but I enjoyed this one. Readings: A bit much, but useful. Later on, when people do presentations, you can do these more optionally, but I'd do them or at least skim them for the experimental design and abstract, as it'll teach you how you might add to the work in your final project. Also, we actually CRITICIZE the readings, which is super huge. Not many courses actually have us read a scientific paper and go: 'wait the experiment is super silly'.Assignments: Super manageable. Presentation and paper along with it do not need to be super long, and the research question and presentation are good milestones so you don't end up waiting till the last second.Project: Professor Hiscox is awesome, and the way the course is designed, you'll find that the part you do a presentation for ends up teaching you about the literature in that field, which then lets you really get into it to figure out your research design.Professor: Awesome, super approachable, has depth of knowledge in field, including practical, is willing to help and accessible and checks in!Class: Very cool, basically a 2 hour discussion. You don't need to be online all the time, as there's enough people to let it kinda flow.
worse_comment: an incredible class to take esp. since there's so much pressure to go into consulting, finance, etc. this class discusses the potential + detriment private companies can have.
subject: Government

best_comment: I would strongly recommend taking this class for an overview of African history and politics. This course provides a depth of knowledge on many different facets of national identity. The central motif of African solutions to African politics was evident in the structure of course materials and discussions. Though a heavy reading load, the course assignments are quite balanced and Dr. Rhodes is very engaged in class contributions and through out–of–class support. This is a great course to orient yourself to the broader context of politics and relationships on the African continent, and the structure is quite conducive to practicing self–study and individualized research and exploration.
subject: Government

course_title: The Politics and Ethics of Health Care 001
best_comment: Take this course. The best gov class I've taken at Harvard hands down. Gabe has had time to refine the course and it really shows. The readings complement discussion well, and are very thoughtfully picked out to reflect current trends as well. You also have enough freedom to pursue the questions you're interested in, but still get to know the basics about ethics / healthcare policy that will supplement your exploration of those questions. Great, great course.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: The Politics and Ethics of Health Care

course_title: Politics of Religion in Liberal Democracies: America and the European Union 001
best_comment: Prof Soroka is clearly passionate about teaching this class, and that's pretty infectious: it's really easy to become involved in the class discussions/debates and to feel passionately about the (incredibly important!) themes discussed. Totally worth taking the class, you'll learn a lot! I ended up having many discussions about class concepts with other students / family members, and it was always really interesting to bring up with different groups of people.

Halen is an amazing professor who truly wants to get to know her students and make sure they are thriving. The assignments aren't too bad, with emphasis on weekly reading responses and a project and paper. Highly recommend this course!
worse_comment: I don't think you'll learn too much in this course, but it is an absolute gem—so there are pros and cons! The professor is very kind, though, and understanding of the chaos of being a student.
subject: Government

course_title: Democracy in Practice in the Global South 001
best_comment: Definitely take this course. Julie is amazing and you'll learn a lot about research design in political science. The readings are amazing and she sends a reading guidance with them which makes it easy to read them. She also doesn't really care if you read the entire thing all the time and focuses on reading effectively and actually just getting the most important things from a reading. The final project is super flexible and you can basically do it on whatever you want within the topic. Great course overall and would really recommend. Even if you're not a gov concentrator tbh, if you're interested in democracy in the global south, take the course.

I recommend this class. Though the readings are heavy some of the weeks, overall it is a class in which you will learn a lot, and Is pretty chill. The research project is long though so keep that in mind.

If you have any interest in American politics, you should definitely take this class! Professor Skocpol is incredibly knowledgeable so you learn something new every single week from her. She brings such an important, unique perspective. Each week builds upon the previous week so you want to stay on top of your readings to make sure you're getting the most out of the class. The readings are heavy, but they are all super useful and interesting that you should try to read as much as possible. The more prepared I was for lecture, the more fun I had participating in discussions and the more knowledge I got out of lecture. Use the final research paper as an opportunity to explore a niche interest of yours.
best_gem_comment: This class isn’t easy and definitely requires thoughtful consideration of the material outside of class, but it’s so rewarding, especially the individual research component. Prof. Skocpol is also an utter gem and truly a joy to talk to both during class and outside.

course_title: Law and Politics in Multicultural Democracies 001
best_comment: I would highly recommend anyone who is on the fence about this class to take it. It was my first government class and I will definitely be taking more. I really enjoyed Dr. Liviatan's discussions and loved the readings. TAKE THIS CLASS.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Law and Politics in Multicultural Democracies

best_comment: Discussions in class were always a lot of fun and interesting. Dr. Rhodes facilitates good discussions and creates a really welcoming atmosphere in the class. While it is listed as a Gov class, it definitely feels more like a Sociology/Anthropology class, so be sure that that's something you enjoy. The papers are pretty light, which is nice during the semester, but if you're looking to write a senior thesis, a different seminar might be more helpful for that specifically.
subject: Government

best_comment: If you are interested in the UN, its history/structure, and how its different agencies/bodies have addressed different historical challenges, I would really recommend this class! I found the discussions every week on varied aspects of the UN to be very informative and helpful, and as someone who wants to work in the UN, this was very helpful. Professor Mikulaschek did a great job facilitating discussion and choosing interesting readings, and you will get as much out of this class as you put in.
subject: Government

best_comment: This class is a great way to get into data science for anyone who hasn't taken data science classes before. I had zero experience going into the course, but I now feel confident in my ability to create clear, compelling maps with ArcGIS software.
subject: Government

best_comment: This class was wonderful and I definitely recommend taking it!! Professor Hummel is a great lecturer and explains things so well, and the difficulty of the course is very reasonable. The assignments are also reasonable and ask you to apply concepts from class to the real world, which is honestly quite enjoyable. There isn't any complicated math or calculations for the sake of calculations – this course instead focuses on building intuition and understanding about these models. I definitely feel like I have a better understanding of how a lot of political systems work thanks to this course!
subject: Government

best_comment: "Remote Sensing" should probably be the real title of this class. The content is very specific – it covers basic ArcGIS and Google Earth Engine skills for manipulating raster data, focusing on images collected by satellites. If you are interested in spatial data / GIS, but not interested in those exact topics, I would recommend taking one of Jill's other classes on ArcGIS instead of this one. That being said, Jill is a helpful instructor who gives interesting lectures, and the class is relatively relaxed. So if you are new to ArcGIS and want to learn about remoting sensing as well, I would recommend taking this class!
worse_comment: Try to make a big effort not to fall behind. The lack of an attendance requirement + no late penalty can be dangerous as far as getting off track.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a truly fantastic course. Professor Nelson explains fascinating sources in a very coherent and compelling manner. This is more so an introduction to a certain way of thinking about all of political philosophy, than it is a didactic explanation of what conservatism means. Very highly recommend taking this course to anyone remotely interested in political philosophy.
worse_comment: This class is one in which you will be lectured with no visual aids. The readings are old philosophers. The concepts are interesting, but if you get a bad TF it will ruin your entire experience

best_comment: Harvard is greatly indebted to Mansfield for his unwavering commitment to knowledge and learning. While I’m at ideological odds with him on many things, this only meant I had a great deal to learn from him. His lectures — which imparted his deep knowledge of Plato, Hobbes, and Tocqueville — were wonderful to listen to and learn from. Having Sarah as a TF only made the experience better as she is incredibly knowledgeable and enthusiastic about the content. She takes engagement with the texts very seriously, which makes working through them a rewarding experience.
worse_comment: Prof Mansfield is a legend but a bit of a dry lecturer. Definitely must–read books, and section was more helpful and illuminating. Grading was harsh with no concrete feedback, which was very frustrating. But learned a lot about the theory behind democracy and equality/inequality.
best_gem_comment: This class is an informative and digestable way to learn some of the political theory typically taught in Social Studies 10a! I recommend if you are interested in political theory and the functioning of democracy but it's not a Gov dept gem. Sarah is really good at explaining things and it was cool to have taken a class with the legend Harvey C. Mansfield!

best_comment: Professor Tuck is retiring at the end of this year, so you'll have a different instructor if you take the class in the future. Much of my experience in the class was shaped by his unique character and expertise, so I don't know what your iteration of the course will look like! That said, I really enjoyed the subject matter and the emphasis Professor Tuck placed on reading complete texts; I think this does allow students to feel more confident in their knowledge of each thinker's works. If you're interested in classics or political theory, Gov 1060 provides a great foundation.
subject: Government

course_title: Protest Movements from Chartism to BLM 001
best_comment: take it Professor Ekiert is amazing and pushes you to dig deeper and gives great feedback
worse_comment: I assumed there would be more discussion about the protest movements, but we just had readings and presentations. Also, the final assignment of the class is a research proposal, however, the instructor is very unclear on proposal instructions and he is not helpful in teaching one how to write it, thus the assignment was hard to complete.

best_comment: Lecture is a recap of the readings, but it's worth trying to do because every assignment is heavily reliant on the readings and applying the specific theories. Professor Hummel is very nice and a good lecturer. The poll everywhere is a good tool for participation. Group assignments are very easy, but it hugely depends on who you is in your group and what country it is. DO NOT PICK A COUNTRY THAT IS SUPER COMPLICATED. I would call this a gem. Practically zero work besides the essays. Midterm was also ridiculous being 75 minutes.
worse_comment: This is a relatively easy but important course that will teach you how dictators stay in power, which is very relevant to today's political climate and the threat of failing democracy. If you haven't taken social science courses before, this course is very accessible and will introduce you to a wide range of methodological approaches.
best_gem_comment: Great way to knock off a gov requirement – straightforward, manageable, and direct. Not a total gem because there is work, but it's not difficult.
subject: Government

best_comment: GOV 1290 is an intermediate–level course in the gov department that really dives deep into theories and cases for democratization and authoritarianism. Overall, I don't regret taking this course, but I feel like there were a few issues with it. You will be given a lot of reading each week (up to 200 pages), but you don't really have to do all of it (which is about true for any reading–intensive course). Lecture is really interesting because of Prof. Levitsky (who's probably the best gov prof. at Harvard), but go really deep into specific cases and histories. If you really are into comparative gov't and theories, then this course and its content is for you. Else, it might be a bit of a bore to dive into kind of obscure theories and case histories and can take up a bit of work to fully appreciate. You also only have about 7 assignments total in the class (5 memos, 1 midterm paper, and a final), so each one is weighted quite a bit even if they might not seem that rigorous –– the grading is not transparent at all (memos for example are grading on a check minus, check, or check plus scale –– but they never say how that translates to numeric or letter grades). Overall, Levitsky is awesome, but this course is not for everyone (and may not be for the eagle–eyed freshman like myself).

take this class! It is a very easy way to explore gov, especially if you are more of a STEM person. As for Gov concentrators, this class is a nice break from heavy reading and writing classes. The workload is minimal and the content is interesting. Noah is the best TF ever and is very helpful and understanding. There is only one paper for this class, where you analyze your own rep in Congress for a final paper. There's 6 psets throughout the semester that have light coding and are very interesting. The psets are also graded very generously. Fantastic course.
worse_comment: You should take the course if you have a basic understanding and experience with r. If not, don't take the class. Noah, the TF, is very accessible and understanding if you get to know him. The lectures are not engaging, and most of the time, I was lost. Other than that, if you don't have any other choice... take the class. You'll still learn some things.

best_comment: Take this class if you have R experience and interested in learning how professional election analysts make forecasts! Professor Enos and the course staff are incredibly invested in students success and dedicate a lot of time to supporting you throughout a very challenging process. Forecasting elections is really really hard and it is definitely not for someone who may get discouraged easily but if you are interested in the subject matter there is definitely a great pay off. In addition, the class developed real camaraderie as we tried to figure out best forecasting methods and we definitely bonded as a class. You will love the people and learn a lot if you are willing to take the challenge!
worse_comment: If you're someone interested in learning about how Americans behave politically with respect to elections, or if you're simply someone who wants to really hone their data science skills, take this course. It's not an easy course but I think it's a really fair course because the difficulty lies with the actual topic of the course (predicting elections) and not extra busywork that you might find in some other courses.

course_title: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class! Professor Sweeney will help you view technology from a new perspective, and you’ll be able to identify technology–society clashes in the products we use every day. As innovation grows increasingly prominent around us, this is an outlook that everyone can really benefit from.I think that students will particularly enjoy the course if they have an interest in technology or entrepreneurship (but note that this isn’t a class on entrepreneurship/startups), and especially if they are interested in how technology often clashes with society's best interests. That being said, the subject is interesting enough that I think anyone and everyone can really approach and enjoy Gov 1433. The course is also not demanding work–wise, and the final paper can be fun if you pick a fascinating topic!Lastly, Professor Sweeney is a huge asset to the course. The insight and stories she brings from her own experience in this field make lectures engaging, and she is wonderful to talk to in office hours or after class!
worse_comment: This class is a disaster. Everything from assignments to grading is very disorganized, and there is only ONE teaching staff besides the professor available continuously for the class of around 40 students. Professor Sweeney is definitely experienced and knowledgeable in this field, but every lecture felt like a speaker event, and I learned nothing substantial. Also, due to her busy schedule, The professor was not available most of the time. Assignments were particularly bad since the class didn't post the grading rubric for most of the assignments, including the final project. In addition, the class didn't have a section, and I received absolutely zero feedback on my assignments. Don't take this course unless you want to. You will not learn anything applicable and will waste one class slot.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: Tech Science: From Democracy to Technocracy and Back

best_comment: I would highly recommend this course, especially to anyone interested in national security or war studies. Even anyone just slightly interested in the topic should take the class because Prof. Rosen is great! I think this course accomplishes a lot in teaching material and skills as the debate component of the course is great public speaking experience. The first half covers foundational material and it is important to be engaged in the readings and lectures here. In the second half, I would recommend being as engaged for all debates but you can get by without too much work on the weeks that you don't debate you will just have to do a little more by the time the finals comes around. I also thought the final exam was actually very effective at tying the course together.
worse_comment: This is an interesting class at times, but it is also extremely broad. Be prepared to do a lot of readings that can be not super intuitive at times. If you're a good debater, you will do better for sure. AVOID CROSS–EX as your role if possible; this is the worst role in the debate since you will not really be able to show off your argumentative capabilities.

best_comment: Phenomenal class. Christoph is a great, entertaining lecturer. If you're curious about international issues / enjoyed other IR classes like GOV 1790, would highly recommend taking this class. Some IR background is very helpful + will make you get more out of the class. However, exams are pretty taxing (6 hours long!), so be sure to prepare for those. Ruofan is also a great TF, and section was great as well.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is an incredibly engaging course which, while not without its challenges, is definitely one where you get out what you put in. While learning some economic frameworks and history is critical for weekly preparation, a lot of the course centers around the reading and critical engagement with political economy literature, pushing all to not only learn the material but to leave able to participate in debates in the field –– understanding the strengths and weaknesses of various models and how all the pieces fit together. This is the type of course where week–to–week assignments are lighter, but you really need to stay on top of the reading for exams and papers –– plus, the stronger your background in the topic for a given class day, the more you'll get out of the discussion! I wish I had been able to put a little more time in than I did, but would definitely recommend.
subject: Government

best_comment: This course is an excellent introduction to Central Asia in a geopolitical context. Prof. Nargis is very chill, friendly, and approachable; she is always willing to help, and is very receptive to student feedback. The readings and other course materials were also pretty engaging, but sometimes lectures were characterized more by dull chronological rehashings of historical facts, rather than analytical insights into diplomatic strategy or foreign policy. And while Prof. Nargis is a generous and fair grader, prepare well for the midterm;  she can still grade harshly. As long as you go to class, turn in assignments on time, and show that you are trying your best, you will be fine (I hope).
subject: Government

best_comment: This course is a great one, but BEWARE. It is NOT a gem and it is NOT easy. You have to put in a lot (a LOT) of work to get in the A range, and even then, putting in a lot of work will only take you so far. Kertzer is an amazing lecturer and is extremely knowledgeable. The teaching staff is great. Section was also great (for me). The exams and paper were somewhat painful, but not horrible. This class covers a LOT of content, and you sometimes have to take strides on your own time to connect the dots from one topic to the next. This course is very pro–America (obviously), but it might be something you want to keep in mind.The exams in this course are entirely writing–based. Anything Kertzer says and anything in the readings is fair game – and I mean it! Lots of definition–style questions (fill in the blanks), short–answer questions (paragraphs), and essays. The short–answer questions are graded very harshly (from my experience). You have to write in the way they want! If you're a mind–reader, this shouldn't be too difficult for you. For us lowly folk, it can be hard to know what to say. Giving the correct answer isn't enough. That will only get you ~1/2 the points. The essay questions are usually pretty broad and not too hard to do well on. With that said, it can be really hard to score in the top range (say 16–18/18 possible points). The readings for class are LONG and PLENTIFUL. I spent hours and hours trying to understand the readings. If you get behind, it can be very difficult to catch up. You have to put in a lot of effort to memorize the readings. It was sometimes annoying that the reading I spent a lot of time studying wouldn't even show up on the exam. But you can't leave one out – if you do, you know that will be the one that shows up. The reading responses due each week on slack were horribly annoying, I won't lie.The guest speakers for this class were amazing. Kertzer is also amazing. Attending lecture is usually a positive experience, although attendance isn't always required as far as an attendance grade. With that said, there is a LOT of government vocabulary you have to learn and be able to use. For that reason, I only recommend this course for people who are serious about pursuing a gov concentration. I thought that was me at the beginning of the year, but I've now settled into the English path. I put my entire heart and soul into my policy paper to get an A. Although it wasn't perfect, I probably spent around 50 hours on the paper over the course of a month (more like 2.5 weeks because I slacked off at first). I recommend writing about something you are truly interested in. If this means you propose a new prompt, then so be it. You will be spending a LOT of time with this paper – make sure you care about it. When all was said and done, I was very proud of my paper and was able to display it to my friends and family; however, this was not without strenuous effort and grief. I didn't see the sun for 3 days leading up to the paper submission deadline.Above all, try to make friends – with the teaching staff and with other classmates. It made the work much more bearable. I really enjoyed working with my friends leading up to exams and will miss it next semester. Good luck with Gov 1790!
worse_comment: Neoliberal as hell but not that hard, and you can challenge that in ur paper
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. It will teach you how to think critically about foreign policy issues happening now and in history. This class will help you develop informed opinions about major American foreign policy topics like counterterrorism, nuclear weapons, emerging technology, the rise of China, the role of international institutions, the role of the media and public opinion, but even more importantly, it will show you that foreign policy is so much more complex and nuanced than the oversimplifications that we see in the media. Take this class to be a more informed person, a more critical thinker, and to simply learn so much about the international system. It changed my life!!!! Made me sure that I wanted to be a GOV concentrator. Kertzer is an absolute GEM of a professor, and he is so effective, empathetic, and engaging in his lectures. He makes every lecture extremely relevant and even makes efforts to have lunch with all of us. I am so lucky to have taken this class with such a kind, knowledgeable, GENIUS professor!

course_title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course. It is certainly challenging; the professors expect not only your writing but also your national security thinking to be operating at a high level, and anecdotally, many graduate students and mid–career folks also found it challenging. It's certainly not your average undergraduate class, and you're expected to come up with ideas and solutions that are more comprehensive and thought–through than most college classes. However, it's also an incredible opportunity to take what you've learned in more theoretical academic settings and/or extracurricular and professional experiences and apply it to practical problems under accomplished professionals. Professors Allison, Sanger, and Reveron have a wealth of experience that they share with you, and they supplement their own knowledge with a ton of incredible guests. I came away from the class with a better foundation for professional writing and clear thinking along with career inspiration that I know I'll take with me far into the future.

course_title: Central Challenges of American National Security, Strategy, and the Press 001
best_comment: This is an excellent course. It is certainly challenging; the professors expect not only your writing but also your national security thinking to be operating at a high level, and anecdotally, many graduate students and mid–career folks also found it challenging. It's certainly not your average undergraduate class, and you're expected to come up with ideas and solutions that are more comprehensive and thought–through than most college classes. I came away from the class with a better foundation for professional writing and clear thinking along with career inspiration that I know I'll take with me far into the future.
