I came away from the class with a better foundation for professional writing and clear thinking along with career inspiration that I know I'll take with me far into the future.

This isn't really an introductory course and you will need to work hard with other people and go to office hours if you are going to be successful in this course. It requires a lot logistically and you need to make sure that you're organized from the jump to figure out all of the different deadlines and assignments throughout the week. It's not that easy and it will probably start to make sense near the end, but it really requires you to be very comfortable with coding and moderately comfortable with statistics and math if you want to understand most of it. There's a fair amount of your time that will feel wasted by this class. The teaching staff is really kind and wants you to succeed, so it's worth it to take if only because you'll get to know wonderful people who will be good advisors and mentors later on.
worse_comment: This course teaches you to do meaningful statistical data analysis using the R programming language through entertaining lectures, but course requirements can be uncomfortably exhausting and rigid if you have any other commitments. If you don't attend Harvard and are just looking for a graduate elective to broaden your knowledge, it might be better to first search for a similar course within your own school.

best_comment: Take the course! Prof. Imai is incredibly brilliant, supportive, and intelligent. The course covers many important topics that have a range of applications across industries. The class is also very useful for those interested in pursuing careers in policy.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a great course to take as an Applied Math in Gov concentrator. It's fascinating work, and I really left the class feeling like I could tackle interesting and complex problems.
subject: Government

best_comment: Cherish it if you get a place in this class and really put in the effort to learn and devote yourself to the readings / discussions – they are all intentional and it is the least you owe to yourself, your classmates, Professor Sandel, and all those who were did not get the chance to have a seat in such a class taught by a legendary professor
subject: Government

best_comment: A wonderful seminar all around. Eric Beerbohm is a marvelous teacher and mentor throughout the seminar, and the weekly conversations were enjoyable, informative, and transformative. Reading is a tad heavy at times, though Eric recognizes the burden and makes sure to ease up over the following weeks. Assignments were very straightforward as well. Overall, highly encourage everyone to enroll in the seminar!

course_title: The Political Philosophy of Jonathan Swift 001
best_comment: Thank you for a wonderful semester! This was a wonderful capstone course in political theory. What a fun chance to consider important questions through the lense of Gullivers Travels!
worse_comment: This class is unlikely to be offered again because of Mansfield's retirement. That said, the subject was pretty interesting, though very niche. I was a bit disappointed this class involved no student discussion as it might've appeared on paper; it was just Mansfield talking through his Swiftian musings, some plausible and others much less so, to a seminar–sized audience. As someone with very limited political philosophy background, I didn't take away that much from this class, but for someone with more prior experience, this could be a fulfilling deep–dive.

best_comment: If you are interested in government and institutions, regardless of what subfield, this is a great course to take

course_title: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar 001
best_comment: This was a great class and one of my favorites I took this semester. The professors were very attentive, knowledgeable, and committed to the course and students. They facilitated great class discussions. The course is an interesting and fast introductory survey of the main important topics, theories, and readings in political science. There were a ton of readings but most of them were useful to understanding the theories and being able to participate in discussion. The weekly response papers were helpful to digesting the large amounts of information in the readings and preparing for class discussion. The final paper was a lot of work but a great exercise in doing an analytical literature review on a topic related to political science of our choosing. Highly recommend this course for PhD students interested in an immersive introductory political science course.
worse_comment: Honestly, don't take this class. It was really demoralizing and useless.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar

course_title: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar 001
best_comment: This was a great class and one of my favorites I took this semester. The professors were very attentive, knowledgeable, and committed to the course and students. They facilitated great class discussions. The course is an interesting and fast introductory survey of the main important topics, theories, and readings in political science. worse_comment: Honestly, don't take this class. It was really demoralizing and useless.
subject: Government
course_title_2023: American Government and Politics: Field Seminar

best_comment: You should appreciate a course granting you so much flexibility.
Would recommend! Any work you do to take notes during the term will really pay off for the final, so make an effort to take actual notes rather than just underlining or highlighting in the text.
subject: Government

best_comment: Would recommend! Any work you do to take notes during the term will really pay off for the final, so make an effort to take actual notes rather than just underlining or highlighting in the text.
subject: Government

course_title: International Politics in the Post-Soviet Space 001
best_comment: Professor Colton is clearly the biggest strength of this course. He is super knowledgeable, kind, adaptable and a great mentor to have. The class is also well formed – a good mix of students, with different backgrounds and opinions. It’s a very discussion–heavy class, which I find to be the best way to develop one’s knowledge on the subject. Be prepared to start the final paper early, ask for feedback in October regarding your topic and start sketching a plan. It is rather overwhelming if you try to do it in a week or so.

I highly recommend this class––it will make your life much easier as a teacher and give you the tools you need to ensure that both you and your students have a better and more productive experience in the class.
subject: Government

best_comment: This is a fantastic course taught by one of the best professors in this university. Highly recommend taking a course with Prof. Brown at some point in college, but this is only a course for people who are truly interested in doing a lot of research and want to improve the writing skills. This course is a lot of work, but it is worth it!

course_title: Capitalism, Crime, and Punishment in American History 01
best_comment: This course is fantastic and Aaron is the best professor. It's the most interesting course I've taken at Harvard, challenging in the best way. The content is amazing and class discussions are a great way to digest them. The cumulative research paper is a great way to explore any topic of your choosing that interests you in depth. I'm not a history concentrator, and you're interested in anything vaguely related to capitalism, law, history, or crime, you will get a ton out of this class.
subject: History
course_title_2023: Capitalism, Crime, and Punishment in American History

course_title: Quad Lab: Histories of Technology, Society, and Everyday Life at Harvard 01
best_comment: Quad Lab was INCREDIBLE! Everyone was automatically bought–in, yet Ian fostered such a beautiful community where everyone supported each other. I am friends with the people in this class! I liked the discussions and how we got to go all–in on the archives and meet with the archivists. Discussions were fun because everyone brought in their own Quad experiences. Really fun final project and the final presentations were so cool. Ian is awesome and very supportive and generates so much enthusiasm for the material. Since this is the first time teaching it, they were pretty disorganized with deadlines and assignments, but were super flexible as a result. If you're a history concentrator, there might be some repetition (you do go into the how–to–use–the–archives stuff so that everyone's on the same page and there were some repeat readings from previous classes). Hopefully in the future they straighten that out. What you put in is what you get out, and even though I took this as a gem, I got so much more out of the class than I expected. TAKE THIS whether you want it to be a gem or you love (or hate) the Quad or want to take a class with Ian in Cabot dhall!
best_gem_comment: Quad Lab was INCREDIBLE! Everyone was automatically bought–in, yet Ian fostered such a beautiful community where everyone supported each other. TAKE THIS whether you want it to be a gem or you love (or hate) the Quad or want to take a class with Ian in Cabot dhall!

best_comment: This is an incredible course taught by someone who deeply cares about their students' knowledge and well–being. Professor Chalhoub has a lot of experience working as a historian and helps break down difficult concepts in understandable ways, while also making class very interactive and enjoyable. The texts chosen for the class are difficult and sometimes dense, but I encourage you to stick with them as they will leave a lasting impression on you––especially if you are a history concentrator. If there is any particular historian you have always wanted to study more in–depth, this is also a great way to do so. Professor Chalhoub is an incredible support and someone very approachable who will make your time in this class very memorable.

Jumping ahead of all technological possibilities, Professor Gordon and Walter Benjamin, working in careful conjunction, will in a snap of a finger transport you to Paris for free every week. This is a class in which you will get a chance to dive deep into the recesses of European literature and philosophy and temporarily see the French Second Empire resurrected and examined so many years after its fall. It is a seminar that will never fail to give you beautiful and stimulating readings followed by conversations that will then help pierce the surface of the many delightful, allusive texts. Truly, truly a marvelous, wonderful experience, at the crossroads of so many sources of adventure!

Take this class! A paper every week might seem a little daunting, but the weekly assignments are completion–based: the low stakes and open–ended prompts are a great way to push your writing forward. Professor Seow and Professor Rothschild are both fantastic, as are the rest of the teaching staff. The class environment is really friendly and the discussions are engaging and productive. I came into this class as a science concentrator, with little to no background in history, but I still felt like my perspective was valued in the class. Regardless of your background, if you're passionate about climate and want to get better at writing about it, this is the class to take.

Take this class! A paper every week might seem a little daunting, but the weekly assignments are completion–based: the low stakes and open–ended prompts are a great way to push your writing forward. Professor Seow and Professor Rothschild are both fantastic, as are the rest of the teaching staff. The class environment is really friendly and the discussions are engaging and productive. I came into this class as a science concentrator, with little to no background in history, but I still felt like my perspective was valued in the class. Regardless of your background, if you're passionate about climate and want to get better at writing about it, this is the class to take.

Take this class!! Professor Deloria is a wealth of knowledge, and his passion for the subject is infectious! It's also so rewarding to learn about the history of Native people from the lands you go to school at, and the things you learn about Harvard's history will change the way you think about and interact with the institution. I really loved this course! The only thing I disliked was the quantity of reading, which was pretty overwhelming in the beginning and middle of the course. However, I loved everything else! I especially loved the instructors' efforts to get speakers to come in and enhance our learning. I also loved how we were encouraged to use all the resources Harvard had to offer to enhance our research.

Take this class!! Professor Deloria is a wealth of knowledge, and his passion for the subject is infectious! It's also so rewarding to learn about the history of Native people from the lands you go to school at, and the things you learn about Harvard's history will change the way you think about and interact with the institution. I really loved this course! The only thing I disliked was the quantity of reading, which was pretty overwhelming in the beginning and middle of the course. However, I loved everything else! I especially loved the instructors' efforts to get speakers to come in and enhance our learning. I also loved how we were encouraged to use all the resources Harvard had to offer to enhance our research.

course_title: The Origins of the Cold War: The Yalta Conference (1945) 01
best_comment: This is a truly fantastic course. I really enjoyed it. A few things to note for the apprehensive prospective student: yes, the readings are a lot. No, they are not boring (I loved doing all of them!) and are quite balanced. Yes, the research will take up your time. But it's something you're interested in, so it should be fun! You will learn a ton about World War II and the post–war order, and you will get to learn from Prof. Plokhii which itself is a very special experience given his depth of expertise. Another note: the course is called "the origins of the Cold War," but there isn't too much Cold War–study going on. It's mostly WWII focused,  but your papers can focus on the early Cold War. All in all, take the course! I had a great experience, it definitely is one of my favorite courses thus far and might be my FAVORITE course
worse_comment: I would tell them to take this course if they're interested in Cold War relations, and if they want to get some practice with writing 15–20 paged papers.
subject: History
course_title_2023: The Origins of the Cold War: The Yalta Conference (1945)

best_comment: This class is required if you (primarily) concentrate in history so you don't really have much of a choice, but even if you're just an allied concentrator in history, this class is still great because (a) it counts for credit, and your thesis is a LOT more work than you think and (b) Carla and Kenneth (and I'm sure whoever replaces Kenneth once he graduates) are great resources for writing your thesis.
subject: History

course_title: Native American and Indigenous Studies: An Introduction 001
best_comment: Take this course!!! You could not find a better teaching staff – Prof. Deloria is truly incredible, warm, brilliant, kind, supportive, and knowledgeable. Anthony is an excellent TF, and he is also very encouraging and all–around great. The course assignments are fun and fairly chill. The lectures are incredibly engaging. Take it!!

course_title: Native American and Indigenous Studies: An Introduction 001
best_comment: Take this course!!! You could not find a better teaching staff – Prof. Deloria is truly incredible, warm, brilliant, kind, supportive, and knowledgeable. Anthony is an excellent TF, and he is also very encouraging and all–around great. The course assignments are fun and fairly chill. The lectures are incredibly engaging. Take it!!

course_title: Japan in Asia and the World 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in Japan or history, this is a course for you! The professors are extremely knowledgeable and fantastic teachers, and are great at generating passion for their respective historical fields. It is a fantastic way to learn about Japanese history in such a condensed and fun format. Would strongly recommend regardless of concentration or background

course_title: Japan in Asia and the World 001
best_comment: If you have any interest in Japan or history, this is a course for you! The professors are extremely knowledgeable and fantastic teachers, and are great at generating passion for their respective historical fields. It is a fantastic way to learn about Japanese history in such a condensed and fun format. Would strongly recommend regardless of concentration or background

Absolute no–brainer class. Super interesting and important material to understand world history. I wish it had spent a bit more time on things like WWII, but it's a great survey. Jasanoff is an engaging lecturer. The readings are interesting if you want to do them and to have engaging discussions in section. The essays do not relate to lectures that much, but you should go to lecture so you get the relevant background info.  Essays are not a cake–walk to do well in but if you are thoughtful and go to OH you will be fine. I think this is a perfect, interesting, not too challenging course. I wouldn't call it a gem just because you have to do some work to get an A, but it should not be too bad.
worse_comment: The lectures were very disorganized. The instructor would jump from topic to topic in a non–chronological order. She would also offer her own political opinions on a lot of things. I took this class because I wanted to get an objective sense of what the British Empire was like. Instead, I had to listen to 75 minutes twice a week of how absolutely terrible the British Empire was. The instructor should consider possible opposing views and include them in the course. Where these were included, the instructor undermined these views and offered biased opinions. I am quite disappointed that the content of this class had to succumb to a very liberal point of view by the instructor. This class may perhaps be the only class I've taken at Harvard where the instructor openly ridiculed moderate and conservative views. For those who are thinking of taking it: you will be listening to a very one–sided liberal agenda, and what is worse is that the instructor will be doing it on purpose.
best_gem_comment: Absolute no–brainer class. Super interesting and important material to understand world history. I wish it had spent a bit more time on things like WWII, but it's a great survey. Jasanoff is an engaging lecturer. The readings are interesting if you want to do them and to have engaging discussions in section. The essays do not relate to lectures that much, but you should go to lecture so you get the relevant background info.  Essays are not a cake–walk to do well in but if you are thoughtful and go to OH you will be fine. I think this is a perfect, interesting, not too challenging course. I wouldn't call it a gem just because you have to do some work to get an A, but it should not be too bad.
subject: History

best_comment: The professor reflected a personal connection to history which was embued in his lectures. Every session was important and passionate, and my ability to understand such vast and complex issues in such a short and comprehensive semester is surely attributed to his mastery.
worse_comment: Don't take this course. It's not engaging, mostly because it feels as though the professor doesn't care about teaching it. Bose gives me the impression of being one of those professors who cares much more about their own research than teaching students. The lectures were not engaging, as Bose isn't the best lecturer. Unlike other history classes, it didn't feel like the professor really had a purpose with the way he was presenting the information. There didn't seem to be much pedagogical thought put into it. The vast majority of the readings are written by Bose. There are literally zero primary source readings. Strangely, it felt like you needed prior knowledge to understand this course.  It's just not a great class, so don't waste your time by taking it.

best_comment: If you have the chance to take this class or any class from Professor Scott Ury, take it!

course_title: The American Century?: A History of the United States since World War II 001
best_comment: Take this class!! It's great because it gives you an in–depth review of post–1945 America with great material. Professor and TF staff are great and super passionate about the course. Super engaging class!
best_gem_comment: This class was definitely *not bad*, but I would think critically about if you really want to take it. If you have already taken AP US History or have a general understanding of US History, then this really will not further your knowledge more than a few Wikipedia articles. Professor Bekemeyer is undoubtedly an excellent lecturer––he almost reminds me of John Green when he's speaking, and definitely highlighted key laws and case studies in class. However, the readings, while very interesting (most were from books published for a general audience), felt disconnected and had too many pages assigned, so many people in section didn't do them, and honestly they did not really contribute much for the exams or writing assignments. Additionally, the grading is rougher than you'd expect for this class––each essay and exam is weighted heavily, and there are no small assignments to get feedback on or try to improve your grade, which makes these assignments incredibly important. On top of this, no rubrics were provided, and the only grading guideline was "it will be graded holistically." While the class did lack in actual substance (unless maybe you knew very little about modern US history), it could have made up for in primary source analysis or historical reasoning, but it really didn't, especially because there were two essays. Besides the lack of clarity for grading, there was no *major* issue with this class; I think it lacked in overall substance and meaning, and is neither a chill history gem or an engaging, fascinating course.
subject: History
course_title_2023: The American Century?: A History of the United States since World War II

best_comment: This is a really great class that does a deep delve into Ukrainian history obviously, so if you're interested in the pre–amble for the Russo–Ukrainian war or just Ukrainian studies in general it's a great background course. It also explores a ton of other things though that you can think about more broadly– nationality and culture, imperialism and colonialism, European studies beyond what you'd learn in an American high school (i.e. France, England, and WWII). It's super interesting and the professor is very sweet and always delighted to answer questions.
worse_comment: Very difficult, do not recommend unless you already have a good understanding of Ukrainian history.
subject: History

best_comment: Definitely take this course. The material is fascinating and the lectures are incredibly well put together and very engaging. The course gave a far more nuanced understanding of the collapse of the USSR and the evolution of modern eastern Europe. Not only was it incredibly enjoyable, I feel that I have become much more informed when reading and thinking about many important current events. I definitely recommend this course.
worse_comment: Make sure to actually do the readings before lecture. At least look at them. If you don't, there's a very good chance you'll be lost and confused during lecture.

best_comment: Pretty relaxed course. Great professor, good discussions.
worse_comment: Be prepared to read and discuss difficult material, but do so with the understanding that this is the history of an entire people and their descendants.

course_title: The United States and World Order since 1900 001
best_comment: This course is perfect if you have an interest in history, but do not want to take a super intense course. While this course is a good amount of work, you are not typically overwhelmed by it. The teaching staff is very well coordinated with one another and they provide helpful insight and resources to allow you to succeed. If you are dedicated to showing up to lecture, you should do well and enjoy this class.
best_gem_comment: Definitely take this class! It's a gem

best_comment: This is a fantastic class ! Going into the class, I thought I already had a strong understanding of China (I have taken govt classes on China before), but Prof Ghosh showed me another way of looking at China. The history discipline also goes much deeper and wider than govt/other social science classes on China and is really comprehensive. I thought I had a good grasp on China but I found myself learning about names and events that are super critical to China but I was surprised that I had never even heard about in my China govt classes. If you want to learn about China, you must take this class!James is the best TF and is so caring and enthusiastic and wonderful. Everyone loved him.The readings tend a little long so make sure to dedicate time for this class. The class is not too difficult – very fair as long as you put in the work! I think the best way to do well in this class is truly just do all the readings and pay attention to all the lectures. You'll be set as long as you're a consistently good student.
worse_comment: The lectures in this course require attendance unless you are sick because you can only access the recording if the professor gives you access to the recording. Additionally while the slides are posted, they contain almost no lecture content and no other lecture materials are posted. Furthermore, the lectures are not on the readings so the readings do not cover lecture material you missed. Therefore, if you didn't take notes on something or remember it, it is very hard to recover that information in this class.
best_gem_comment: This course is awesome!!! I came in not having any background in Chinese history, and this course gave me a comprehensive understanding of modern Chinese history as we understand it today. Also James Evans (the TF) is a gem on this campus, super chill, funny, and kind, definitely one of the best TFs I have ever had at Harvard.

course_title: The History of Sub-Saharan Africa to 1860 001
best_comment: This is a truly wonderful class. I came into it knowing relatively little about –– especially premodern –– African history, and am leaving it feeling like I both have learned a lot, and that I can appreciate just how much more there is beyond the course materials to learn. In that sense, it's an incredibly successful survey course; wish there were more African hist offerings at Harvard. Prof. Akyeampong is a passionate and truly wonderful lecturer, whose anecdotes and clear interest in the subject will make you care deeply about the class and look forward to lectures. And Grace's endless kindness, generosity with time, and willingness to engage students on tangential threads both is really helpful when preparing for the essay, and makes section a wonderful time. Going to miss them both next semester. As for workload and all: the readings are considerable, but outside the core lecture and section texts the point is more to understand arguments than to remember dates/names/etc. The exams require some prep, but esp. if you take reading notes it's very manageable, and they'll give you advance notice of the question categories. Just be sure to do some wrist stretches beforehand.

course_title: A Critical Introduction to the Study of the Middle East 001
best_comment: Enjoy.
subject: History
course_title_2023: A Critical Introduction to the Study of the Middle East

best_comment: I would highly recommend this class. Professor Jasanoff is incredible; she facilitated some of the best class discussions I've experienced, the design of the class is extremely thoughtful, and the feedback I received from both the professor and my peers was very helpful. I loved the class!
subject: History

best_comment: This class is the most rewarding class I have every taken at Harvard. It gives you an opportunity to directly see the impact of your work in real time, which is an experience that will stay with me long after I graduate. The class is challenging, but it is in such a warm and welcoming environment that makes it feel easy. I highly recommend this class to anyone interested,

Would encourage brushing up on basic Python before this course—definitely helpful if you're looking to delve into something analysis or programming–intensive! Great course—really allows you to dig deep into an area of interest. There's such a wide range of projects from student to student, which I found to be very exciting.

– take this class if you know what you would like to write about for final paper already in the first week or two – this will probably be the hardest course of your semester – don’t expect to be able to do weekly assignments in 1 or 2 days: start working on it right after your class – make sure to establish connections with your fellow classmates as they will be your primary reviewers and feedback givers– go to office hours to ensure you understand what is asked of you and check in about the class expectations
I strongly recommend this class. Figure out a method early on to read (not skim) a book a week.
worse_comment: If you are at all interested in the Cold War at a deeper level, take this class

course_title: Readings in Modern Chinese History: Proseminar 001
best_comment: Great class – Prof Ghosh is a very able facilitator of discussion, and the syllabus is really well–designed. Prof Ghosh gives written feedback on every Canvas discussion post, which is great, and also shows in how he picks up on what people in the class are most interested in with every week's readings. Covers major disciplinary approaches in the field, assigning a couple classics but mostly recent works.
Don't feel pressured to read everything
subject: History

course_title: Colloquium on Teaching and Professional Practices 001
best_comment: Although people might mope about having to take extra required courses alongside teaching, I think it's very helpful to have some kind of structured way of sharing experiences with the entire cohort. So I definitely recommend showing up!
subject: History
course_title_2023: Colloquium on Teaching and Professional Practices

best_comment: Take this class!!! The material itself covered in the course is fantastic and homework readings may not even feel like work because they're so interesting. There's also a great balance of films covered in the syllabus too which is a nice way to enjoy something different after reading a book. We didn't have weekly responses in this class even though they were listed on the syllabus, which was helpful in taking away some stress and focus more on discussion. Don't be scared off by the essays, which really aren't bad, especially if you pick a topic that interests you, and they build up gradually to the culminating essay so you can focus on specific skills in each one.  As a first–year, I was worried that the essays would be difficult since I haven't taken Expos yet, but they were the ideal amount of challenge for me to grow as a writer, and I feel MUCH more confident in tackling essays after this class. Professor White is so helpful and supportive and provides really encouraging, detailed constructive feedback that gives you specific things to work on, which makes it less overwhelming. He is also available for office hours even outside the scheduled office hours times, and I'd recommend attending them because they're really beneficial for figuring out how to get on the right track for a paper. This class was definitely my favorite of the semester and has me considering a Hist and Lit concentration, so I can't rave about it enough. For me, it was the perfect mix of informative, challenging, and fun, and I'm really going to miss it.

course_title: The Reinvention of New York City 001
best_comment: super chill, interesting course!!

course_title: Sound and Color: Music, Race, and US Cultural Politics 001
best_comment: Hands down my favorite class that I've taken here at Harvard. I learned soo much from this course and genuinely enjoyed every minute of it. It allowed me to think about music and entertainment in entirely new ways and the assignments are actually fun! There's always a creative option. I will say that a lot of the success of the class is contingent on whether the people in your section are engaged, and I would say I feel very lucky in that regard. It was one of the few sections I've been in where almost everyone is eagerly participating because they have so much to say.

I would highly recommend this class to future students, especially those interested in diaspora and migrations! Vikrant is an amazing professor whose discerning and insightful commentary sparks rich discussions. I also really appreciate how Vikrant works with you to find resonance between the course materials and your personal interests – he was incredibly supportive of my interest in the intersection of migrations and the environment.
subject: History & Literature

best_comment: If you want a welcoming but highly academic space to engage with the most important issues facing Asian Americans today, this is the class for you! This class provided an extremely relevant and engaging survey of Asian America in popular culture — not just how Asian Americans are represented, but what that representation means for identity more broadly. Be prepared to read some dense academic texts, but they are very well curated and you can see what Prof. Huang wants you to take from each one. In addition, haven't taken a class that was as organized and well–run as this one — Prof. Huang is fantastic at keeping the discussions on track so we could all get the most out of them, and expectations for assignments were laid out very clearly well in advance and all the class materials were all provided before the semester even began. I can't recommend this class enough!

course_title: Race and Empire in the Americas 001
best_comment: This was an amazing class. The readings were amazing. The professor did amazing in leading discussion to allow us to deeply engage with the texts. The readings were absolutely amazing; I learned so much.
subject: History & Literature
course_title_2023: Race and Empire in the Americas

best_comment: I would strongly recommend any student take a Hist–Lit 90 course. They are very small and over really interesting, niche subjects. The people in your course are likely to have some connection to the topic at hand which makes the discussion even more interesting. The readings were all fascinating and I feel I really improved as a writer. Cannot recommend enough.

I really enjoyed this class because of the course content and classroom community! It was definitely a challenge, but probably one of the best classes I have ever taken (but I am just a first–year). If you are worried about your college–level writing skills or that you are not a match, speak with Dr. Ridgway for guidance. They are such an amazing person and I am so honored to have been their student this past semester. This class is so rewarding and I cannot express in words how amazing it has been and how much I loved it.
subject: History & Literature

course_title: Tasting Place: Food and Culture in America 001
best_comment: The class does a good job exploring the subject matter and looking at food through a historical/cultural lens; be prepared for a mix of readings/sources, and take the class if you're already passionate about food.
worse_comment: This class was a lot more stress than it was worth.

best_comment: Take this class! The readings are fantastic and super fun. You'll learn so much about this niche topic. Plus  Adhy is a very good lecturer and does a good job facilitating discussion in the course.

course_title: Con Artist Nation: Scams, Schemes, and American Dreams 001
best_comment: This course is fascinating! Every week we learned about a new type of scam in American history, which greatly improved my understanding of the culture at the time. While the reading can be long at the beginning of the semester, most of it is very engaging. Halfway through, we switched to watching movies each week (along with secondary source readings), which decreased the workload. Discussion was interesting, and Angela is a fabulous teacher. Make sure you go to her office hours and get to know her! Overall, I would highly recommend this course to anyone interested in this topic.

This class is amazing! The readings were very interesting and insightful, and I feel that I truly gained so much from our in class discussions. If you have any interest in public health or medicine, please take this course. I truly believe it will make you a more compassionate and understanding individual.

course_title: A Luta Continua: Legacies of Portuguese Empire 001
best_comment: I would not recommend this course unless you really love this subject, do not take as an explanatory if the current design fo the class is maintained

course_title: British Soft Power from Shakespeare to Dua Lipa 001
best_comment: Take this class! The topic is so fun and interesting, and Laura is an amazing instructor. The in–class discussions are really engaging and definitely improve your analytical thinking and writing. Outside of the three essays, the only workload in the class is the readings, which are completely manageable and really entertaining (including watching Downton Abbey and Dunkirk and listening to music). A super fun and interesting class!!
Alpert is a wonderful professor, and she will support you. She goes out of her way to help her students. The content itself is unique and will give you knew perspectives.

You should definitely take this course! It gives knowledge on a topic most people don't know about and it is so interesting. The assignments are doable as long as you put in the work and check in with your TF at the office hours beforehand. The professors are lovely and are very passionate about their topics. They are also experts in their field as they manage the Aga Khan program, so they're really dedicated to make Islamic architecture more accessible to people.

You should definitely take this course! It gives knowledge on a topic most people don't know about and it is so interesting. The assignments are doable as long as you put in the work and check in with your TF at the office hours beforehand. The professors are lovely and are very passionate about their topics. They are also experts in their field as they manage the Aga Khan program, so they're really dedicated to make Islamic architecture more accessible to people.
Professor Pereda is the best lecturer I have ever had at Harvard. Super engaging, useful, and interesting! An amazing class!

course_title: Modern Art and Its Colonial Matrix 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! This was an amazing introduction to modern art, and Prof. Gough is one of the best lecturers at this school.  This class completely changed my perspective on some of the most famous artists in history by putting them in the context of colonialism. There are also several museum field trips where you basically get a private tour of the MFA by a leading world expert on modern art (prof. Gough). The readings and workload are all very manageable and fair, and there is significant creative freedom to study the aspects of modern art most interesting to you.
worse_comment: This class can tackle complicated, problematic histories and students should be prepared for that.

best_comment: I looked forward to coming to this class every week. Isabel McWilliams was a wonderful, reliable TF. It's like HUM 20 but even more intimate and personal!!This course had such wonderful breadth (as promised)!! The response paper prompts challenged us to engage with the weekly readings/material but allowed us to explore our personal interests. Our time at the art museum was very special and kept us on our toes/kept things from losing any energy on a Wednesday afternoon. We got to meet amazing professors and get a comprehensive taste of the HAA department. The TF was definitely a strength of the course –– accessible, energetic, encouraging, and willing to share her own interests and expertise!
worse_comment: Ultimately, this is a required class if you're an HAA concentrator, so if you're not a huge history of art person you will probably not like this class. This course varies on a week to week basis because of the guest lecturers, and it really depends if you're interested in the guest lecturer's work that affects if you like this course.  Personally, I found the majority of guest lecturers very boring –– though some really piqued my interest –– so again it's more of a personal thing. Assignments are not hard at all –– the class is just a bit dull and a requirement you have to take.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: I would tell them it's a great class! If you like museums, you'll like the class, and even if you don't, you probably will! There are a lot of interesting readings and class discussions, and the class is very manageable. The museum trips during class were really fun and a way to appreciate all that Harvard has to offer.
worse_comment: Readings and discussions can be difficult simply because the topics we're dealing with are very complex.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: I found this course to way more engaging than the sophomore seminar, since this one is completely centered around architecture. At times, it feels like we are not qualified to be talking about these materials since we've only done 2 readings on a concept and have had no technical training –– so it feels like we are making stuff up –– but I think the course gave me a greater appreciation for architecture and design theory and helped me get better at talking about it. Very easy.
subject: History of Art & Architecture

best_comment: The HAA department does a great job helping seniors in the thesis process. If you are in the department definitely write a thesis
subject: History of Art & Architecture

course_title: Architecture in the Early Modern Mediterranean World: A Cross-Cultural Perspective 001
best_comment: This course is great, especially if you're interested in architecture particularly within the Mediterranean regions. This course is also very individualized which I enjoyed, so you can make your focus of research and study very much what you want and get to listen to some lectures from this fantastic professor. Some of the longer lectures can get a bit dry if you aren't engaged in the topic, but as someone that does not specifically study Mediterranean architecture (though an HAA student), I very much enjoyed this class and professor and would take it  again!
Take take take this course! You won't regret it. Christina is enthusiastic and the course is very engaging and interesting.

Although a lot of people may take this course for its light workload, the material is genuinely really interesting. The class does suffer a bit from a general lack of enthusiasm and effort put forth by its students, and lecture can be a bit dry and repetitive, but if you are interested in learning about Harvard Square's past and future, I recommend this class! Also I would note that the weekly blog posts are pretty involved, and can take anywhere between 1–4 hours to complete.
worse_comment: If you need to fulfill a requirement go for it, but not the best run class.  Would regularly go over the already 2 hour long slot and there’s no feedback on assignments unless you explicitly ask for it
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2023: Harvard Square: Social-History of Cambridge, MA

best_comment: Take this class! It is a really special class that covers both artists from vastly different points in history, and Professor Wang is extremely knowledgeable. There aren't that many assignments, but it is really helpful to do the readings to engage more during class. This class was also amazing because we got to visit the Art Study Center in HAM and actually view all of the artworks in person every week. You really get to just look at, experience, and just enjoy art. I now feel like I can interpret these kinds of paintings much better in their mental and emotional narrative, which will change the way I think about art (especially Chinese art) when I go to museums. I have a newfound appreciation for landscape painting as a whole.

course_title: Threads: Histories and Theories of Clothing and Fashion 01
best_comment: I highly recommend this course if you are interested in fashion or history. While I didn’t have a strong background in either, the course was an excellent gateway. Every lecture was interesting and I felt like the Professor was always eager to answer our questions or promote discussion. The section is honestly the best part of the course. Getting to view garments in museums or doing hands on fabric dyeing added so much to the experience.
best_gem_comment: This course is definitely a gem of Harvard. The students who take it are so engaged and knowledgeable about fashion across time, and so the class discussions are always lively and participatory (no silent, awkward classroom vibes). Professor McCormick and Carolyn, our TF, also poured so much of their hearts into making the class experience flow super smoothly, and really encouraged us to think across weeks in the course, so it definitely is one to take if you would like to engage in synthesis–level thinking. The course staff were also super reachable outside of class and receptive to student ideas. This is also a really accessible introduction to HAA –– I had never taken an HAA course before taking this course. Take this course if you have any interest in fashion, embodiment, and body.

best_comment: It's very informative and engaging if you are interested in African history or Architecture in any way

course_title: The Diagram Paradigm: Diagrams in Medieval Art and Beyond 001
best_comment: I would tell them to be as proactive as possible about finding a research topic, because the great joy of the course is to have Prof. Hamburger advising the paper.  His conception of the diagrammatic is capacious and imaginative, and this comes out most clearly in research–focused conversations with him about how to build the project into something unique. The sooner they can do that, the happier they will be!
Professor Wang will make you a better scholar. He does not give you all of the answers straight away. Instead, he provides you with the tools you need to draw your own conclusions.

course_title: Methods and Theory of Art History 001
best_comment: I would encourage them not to be shy in class. I found that the professors were really looking for honest engagement with the material, including questions about things we found difficult, and that they appreciated hearing our opinions.
subject: History of Art & Architecture
course_title_2023: Methods and Theory of Art History

best_comment: This is a required course for HistSci concentrators, so you can't avoid it. But I will say that this course made me reconsider being a HistSci concentrator; if it weren't required, I would not recommend it to any student. Not because it is hard (it wasn't, especially if you start brainstorming topics and working on your paper early), but because there are so many better structured and organized courses that would teach you the same skills (and more) in writing an extensive paper. There is value in putting together your final 25–page research project, especially if you take the time to create something you are proud of. I think I'll look back on my paper fondly for a long time! That being said, there is so little concrete support from the class itself to put together this paper; the only thing I felt like this class gave me was the actual reason to write the paper.Plenary is not beneficial. It is unclear what the attendance policy is, but if it is/was optional, I would say you could never attend plenary and still produce the exact same finished product! The utility of section is highly HIGHLY dependent on your TF, and I would recommend that you switch TF's/sections at the beginning of the semester if you get the sense that your TF is not going to give you useful feedback on your intermediate assignment if that is what you want.Like I said, this is a required course, so nothing I say will change your mind on whether to take this course. But I hope a History of Science faculty or staff member reads this and realizes that some aspects of this course's structure and contents need to change. I have spoken with several concentrators who have said that this course actively made them decide not to write a senior thesis, which is a loss for the department. I also say all of these things as a student who has never actively disliked a class in my time at Harvard. This class was just not it.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: Pretty chill on assignments but plenary often felt like a waste of time although the course staff is very kind. They are definitely there to support you and make sure you do well.
subject: History of Science

best_comment: HS99 is a very well–organized course that gives students structured deadlines/opportunities for feedback and is a great way to ensure that we get to interact with other thesis writers in the department. It was a great course that had the necessary structure for me to make great progress on my thesis.
worse_comment: Whatever you do, work on your thesis every day. Even if it's just a little, work on it every day. I cannot emphasize this enough. Anyway, doing a thesis is difficult work, but Erik gives a lot of good insight into how to do historical research, and the whole group sessions are centered around overcoming obstacles in thesis writing. You got this!
subject: History of Science

best_comment: If you are considering whether or not to write a thesis, I strongly recommend. The process is challenging but very rewarding and you will be very happy that you did. Find a topic that interests you and as you read more you will keep finding aspects of the topic that interest you. You will learn so many important life skills through the process.
subject: History of Science

course_title: Knowing the World: An Introduction to the History of Science 001
best_comment: Overall this a wonderful class and I would highly recommend it if you have any interest in the material. It strikes a good balance between teaching lots and being very easy. Professor Csiszar gets very excited about theories of history and old demonstrations of science in a very cute way. He also makes lectures fascinating and often quite fun.The readings were good, especially the primary sources. Sometimes the secondary sources were a slog, but there aren’t as many of them and I'm not even sure you needed to read them always. Section isn’t great, but I think that’s true for a lot of intro classes/geneds in this style. This class is super light. There are maybe 2 hours of reading per week the majority of weeks, and then there are three short essays. The midterm and the final are super chill. If you’ve been doing the work and study for an hour or two you’ll do well.
worse_comment: Take this class, but prepare to be bored for at least a quarter of it. The information is really good to know, but actually learning it can be a pain.
subject: History of Science
course_title_2023: Knowing the World: An Introduction to the History of Science

best_comment: This course is unlike any other course you will take at Harvard. You will learn about the complex multi–species relationship between humans and non–human animals. The course expectations are that you come to class each week having done the readings to discuss in small groups. The assignments are very manageable and interesting. Professor Browne is an excellent teacher and very passionate about everything she does.  She brings delicious snacks each week when we take a break half–way through class.  She is always kind and willing to answer any questions.

course_title: A History of Medicine Through Patient Voices 001
best_comment: Apply to take this course! As a senior this was one of my favorite classes I have ever taken at Harvard. Michelle is an incredible professor who is always available for you to talk to, gives incredible feedback on weekly assignments within a day, and makes sure that everyone in the class gets an equal opportunity to share their thoughts. You can really tell Michelle cares for all of her students and wants everyone to succeed! The sources in the class are all super interesting; there is a good balance between articles, books, movies, and podcasts. Coming out of this class will allow you to see medicine from a completely new lens and feel much more prepared for a future job in anything medicine related!

course_title: Diagnostic Technologies in Medicine: From the Stethoscope to Artificial Intelligence 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! (Especially if you're considering pursuing medicine / medical policy / etc!!!!) Course material is so so interesting and if I decide to go into medicine, I'll definitely put some of what I learned into practice. It's a great reflection on the medical system and historical trends; this was my first Histsci course at Harvard so I didn't need any special background in that area, but I really loved the course. Michelle is also lovely as a person, mentor, and professor –– she works hard to create a truly welcoming and inclusive environment in the course, and also to make sure everyone has a voice in discussions. There's a lot of flexibility in assignments and course work, which allowed me to put a lot of effort into this course without feeling stressed out. This was one of my favorite classes this semester and I'm so glad I took it!

TAKE THIS CLASS!!! Professor Abi–Rached was the highlight of this course. In addition to giving fascinating lectures, Professor Abi–Rached was extremely skillful at facilitating discussions and keeping students engaged throughout the weekly two–hour sessions. Also, I was very impressed by how large of an effort she made to get to know her students; she encouraged all of us to sign up for her office hour sessions, and if a student hadn't made it to her office hours yet, I noticed that she would go up to that student before class began to re–encourage them to sign up. She really made me feel like she was invested in our personal interests and academic goals! Beyond the professor, this course's materials were extremely interesting and guidelines for assignments and other class expectations were very clear. This class's community was also exceptional; I felt l knew most of my classmates pretty well by the end of the semester, and Professor Abi–Rached and Adri did a fantastic job maintaining a positive and supportive class environment.
worse_comment: It is a very enriching class with engaging materials. However, they can be very triggering and traumatic. Understanding and analyzing these works will require a lot of work, but you are forced to become a critical thinker who interrogates sources.

best_comment: This course provided me with an incredibly transformative experience. Professor Abi–Rached's passion for the material was truly infectious and inspiring. Each week's readings answered previous questions I had regarding the relationships of war and medicine but then prompted me to ask even more. The course materials and presentations (both by Professor Abi–Rached and by students) were always very engaging, and I never failed to leave class without having at least one moment of sitting in awe. The midterm and final papers (10 pages and 20 pages respectively!) both seemed daunting at first, but I found them to be so rewarding; I would even say that my final paper for this class has been my favorite so far in college. You will learn so much not only about the complex intersections of war and medicine, but also the dependency of medicine and society. I recommend all interested individuals to take this class, even if (nd perhaps, especially if) you are not a History and Science major!
worse_comment: If this course is capped, then definitely take it. I loved the course. My only problem with it was that it was so large (and still held as a seminar) that it felt impersonal, yet we were having very difficult and important discussions. Otherwise, take this course if you want to work on a semester long research project at the intersection of health, migration, war, and more.

best_comment: Take this class! A paper every week might seem a little daunting, but the weekly assignments are completion–based: the low stakes and open–ended prompts are a great way to push your writing forward. Professor Seow and Professor Rothschild are both fantastic, as are the rest of the teaching staff. The class environment is really friendly and the discussions are engaging and productive. I came into this class as a science concentrator, with little to no background in history, but I still felt like my perspective was valued in the class. Regardless of your background, if you're passionate about climate and want to get better at writing about it, this is the class to take.

Take this class! A paper every week might seem a little daunting, but the weekly assignments are completion–based: the low stakes and open–ended prompts are a great way to push your writing forward. Professor Seow and Professor Rothschild are both fantastic, as are the rest of the teaching staff. The class environment is really friendly and the discussions are engaging and productive. I came into this class as a science concentrator, with little to no background in history, but I still felt like my perspective was valued in the class. Regardless of your background, if you're passionate about climate and want to get better at writing about it, this is the class to take.

course_title: An American Way of War: Technology and Warfare 001
best_comment: Fantastic class!! Professor is so smart and funny and kind. Great TF. Really fascinating lectures and readings. I learned so much

course_title: Podcasting the History of Science: Creating Research-Based Audio Stories 001
best_comment: This is generally an interesting class, but class discussions can go on a bit long. Also, because they're whole group discussions and we don't really spend time getting to know each other, they can be hard to participate in if you're a quieter person. If you're interested in the topic I would recommend it (and it is an easy class), but it wasn't always the most enjoyable.
worse_comment: Especially if you need a break from extremely rigorous classes, this is the course for you.

best_comment: Pretty good course. The reading responses were doable and the readings themselves very interesting. The book review assignment was a bit boring if you weren't interested in science/military involvement, but the final paper was really fun. Erik was clearly passionate about the subject matter, but our discussion could get a little bit dry / quiet at times. I think this might have been an artifact of this being the first time the class was offered though –– I'm confident that it will be even better in future years. The class was also pretty early, so I think folks were still waking up.
worse_comment: It is a good class but a lot of readings, and difficult if you do not have a strong background in history of science. Mostly geared towards upperclass students.

best_comment: Professor Seow is amazing and kind, and the class is a fascinating look into the history of work, as it weaves in and out of the history of science. The discussion posts can seem like a lot, but they're actually a really great way to engage with the reading before class, and Prof Seow asks helpful questions to guide your responses. Some of the books we read are ones that I will continue to reference in other classes, and even for the rest of my life.

Absolutely take this class!! If the title speaks to your foremost interests, you will be in good company.  I give this class a glowing review for the rich discussions, thoughtful in–class mini–debates, top–notch readings, and amazing class environment. Professor Jones is not only incredibly knowledgable but also approachable and kind. One of my favorite classes at Harvard.

course_title: Food, Science, and the Invention of Global Hunger 001
best_comment: Harvard offers very few classes on subjects like this, and this course is extremely well done. Soto Laveaga is a fantastic professor. The readings, while heavy, are very engaging and you will learn a ton! Highly recommend for undergrads looking for a small, intellectual, and engaging class experience.

course_title: Freud and His Legacies: Readings in the History of Psychoanalysis 001
best_comment: This is an incredibly unique course and  one of the best I have taken at Harvard. While knowing the psychoanalytic canon is helpful in many fields, from English to clinical psychology and beyond, a course on its  comprehensive history is rare. The reading is not light, but if you have an interest in the material, it is easy to get absorbed and it stops feeling like work. Active participation is expected, and the environment is extremely encouraging, but this means that you do need to do the readings carefully.  Additionally, Professor Lunbeck is quite a famous historian of psychoanalysis and has an encyclopedic knowledge and virtuosic understanding of some of the more difficult material. She also has strong footing in sociological theory and incorporates it skillfully into the syllabus; social studies concentrators seemed to gravitate toward this course to great avail.  I really recommend this course to anyone in any field who is interested in psychoanalysis, as a variety of perspectives is actively encouraged (everyone from college juniors to post–docs, in fields from medicine to philosophy to architecture) and this variety made for one of the absolute best experiences I have had at this school.

This will be the best class you ever take at Harvard. There is no other course that allows for as much critical engagement and reflection with what it means to live in a world so prominently shaping by and shaping of science and technology — without descending into techno–fetishism nor abandoning S&T all together. If you've ever felt at the intersection of questions or interests that include S&T, how we govern emerging technologies, the future of democracy, the state of truth, the state of knowledge, quantification, constitutionalism/citizenship and/or individuality and collectivity, this class will be what helps you make sense of these as inextricably linked dimensions of questions of past, present, and future. Science, Power and Politics is so tremendous because it's not just about "studying" science/technology, power, and politics — it's about boldly interrogating and aspirationally envisioning the types of worlds being articulated as ones worth living in, what might be at stake in that, and what we should do about it. There are very few classes at Harvard the strike at the heart of the human condition, and this is far and away the best academic and personal experience one could ask for in this regard (among many others). Sheila Jasanoff is a professor unlike any other at Harvard, and her brilliance, generosity, wit, and kindness can not be overstated in how legendary and incredible this stalwart of a class has been and continues to be over the years she has taught it. Take it! It may be intense, unlike anything you've done before at Harvard, or a lot of work — but these are take it "because" reasons, not "in spite of" ones. Your time at Harvard should not be an intellectual nor personal wasteland, and it's SPP and classes like it that turn a wasteland into a flourishing garden, trees of knowledge and all.

course_title: Historiography of the History of Science 001
best_comment: Helpful to get started in history of science; also worthwhile and rewarding to engage with the texts
subject: History of Science
course_title_2023: Historiography of the History of Science

course_title: Historiography of the History of Science 001
best_comment: Helpful to get started in history of science; also worthwhile and rewarding to engage with the texts
subject: History of Science
course_title_2023: Historiography of the History of Science

best_comment: This is a helpful course to supplement your work on your thesis. There are helpful presentations on sections of the thesis and is a great way to get feedback form someone other than just your thesis advisor.
worse_comment: Julie is amazing and wonderful but the HEB department as a whole provides very little thesis guidance. Get in a lab early or you will have a bad time.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Great class and not too difficult. It can be really interesting if you make sure that you actually engage with the material, but will be very boring if you do not. I would suggest taking it if you have interest in the topic, but not if you don't. If you are interested definitely take it and it will be so much easier for you because you enjoy it! Also, ideally you would do the readings and pay attention in class but I think for the most part you can do one or the other depending on which you prefer.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: The Human Face: How evolution, growth, and behavior has shaped the way we look 001
best_comment: This is a laid–back, excellent HEB elective. Dr. Lawrence is wonderful and gives very engaging presentations. She is readily available to talk outside of class, which I highly recommend doing because she gives great feedback and has interesting insights about the material.
worse_comment: This class was very laid back, and only has 3 short writing assignments and a final paper. You have weekly practicals but they are not graded (more completion based and she wants to see you experimenting with using the new software). However, a lot of students had tech difficulties using the software, and it made the second hour of class a bit longer than it needed to be (sitting around unsure of what to do at times). This was fine though because the class only met once a week for 2 hours.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: The Human Face: How evolution, growth, and behavior has shaped the way we look

course_title: Wearable sensors: measuring activity, health, and performance 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It is awesome. It is low stress but you actually learn a lot and you get to program a lot of really cool things.  You also get to know your class really well and the sets are not very hard when you work through them together. Ali is awesome and its so fun!
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: Wearable sensors: measuring activity, health, and performance

course_title: Clinical Comparative Medicine: Evolutionary Perspectives on Mental and Physical Health 001
best_comment: If you are interested in evolution, disease and/or animals, this is the course for you! This class was really enjoyable, because it teaches a mindset, rather than making you memorize facts. It was really interesting to learn about how/why diseases in humans may have been preserved throughout evolution/why they may have been adaptive in other species. Would also highly highly recommend Amar, one of the TFs/section leaders! He was amazing, and this class was easily the best section experience I have had at Harvard. Instead of rehashing lecture information, he always brought us new and interesting examples from the literature that pertained to lecture without repeating it. Overall very enjoyable class, and would recommend!

This class was amazing! Martin and Joyce are so knowledgeable and passionate about what they do, and I loved that this class took the form of a small lecture in a classroom.  There are 8 quizzes throughout the semester which can sometimes be tricky, but course content was so interesting and engaging! Would highly recommend.
worse_comment: I don't recommend this course. The organization and communication was very poor — even communication between the two professors seemed quite bad. The professors go through the slides way too fast for students to write them down. The quizzes were graded harshly and asked for specific details I didn't remember. The professors were not engaging lecturers. We ventured into weird topics at times and drew some comparisons between non–human primates and humans that seemed a little problematic.
best_gem_comment: study for the quizzes. they are only 10 mins and worth 50% of grade. i thought the quizzes were relatively unfairly graded but you can ask for points back if necessary. the rubric for projects was last minute and not always clear but those were graded fairly easy. i think the content is really interesting esp for HEB concentrators but this isn’t a gem
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: This class was amazing! Martin and Joyce are so knowledgeable and passionate about what they do, and I loved that this class took the form of a small lecture in a classroom.  There are 8 quizzes throughout the semester which can sometimes be tricky, but course content was so interesting and engaging! Would highly recommend.
worse_comment: I don't recommend this course. The organization and communication was very poor — even communication between the two professors seemed quite bad. The professors go through the slides way too fast for students to write them down. The quizzes were graded harshly and asked for specific details I didn't remember. The professors were not engaging lecturers. We ventured into weird topics at times and drew some comparisons between non–human primates and humans that seemed a little problematic.
best_gem_comment: study for the quizzes. they are only 10 mins and worth 50% of grade. i thought the quizzes were relatively unfairly graded but you can ask for points back if necessary. the rubric for projects was last minute and not always clear but those were graded fairly easy. i think the content is really interesting esp for HEB concentrators but this isn’t a gem
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Take this course!! Seriously the best class I’ve ever taken.  Erin is incredible and so knowledgeable about the field.  The class is extremely interesting and engaging (even the readings!) and you get to work with dogs! The workload is very manageable and Erin truly wants everyone to succeed.  I learned so much about dogs and animal behavior.  If you want a truly fun class or are at all interested in animal behavior testing and research (or just really like dogs) I highly recommend.
best_gem_comment: Genuinely, this class was great! An absolute gem. Erin and Sophie are so supportive and I have learned so much in this class. Not too much work but when there is work, it is so interesting so it's really not that overwhelming.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: Professional Writing for Human Evolutionary Biologists 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Bridget is beyond amazing, and you will actually improve your writing. This class gives you the chance to take a step back and become a better writer without the pressure of long assignments or sharp due dates. It really encourages working on something YOU are interested it, and then helps you make that the best you can.
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Human Evolutionary Biologists

course_title: The Arrogant Ape: Rethinking our Relationships to Others 001
best_comment: This is a great class to take if you are interested in studying the relationship between humans and the environment but have no background in STEM. Dr. Webb is a great teacher who is passionate about the subject, which helps make every class dynamic and engaging. Her syllabus provides enough context and background on the topics we discuss in class that I never felt behind, even though I am not an HEB concentrator.  The topics we discussed in class and read about were incredibly interesting and novel to me. This class completely changed my view on how humans ought to relate to the natural world, and I'd absolutely recommend anyone even remotely interested in the course description to enroll.

Take this class only if you are ready to put a lot of work into it. A lot of graduate students take this course and if you don't feel very experienced in biology classes and research yet (which as a sophomore, I did feel like it) be prepared for a difficult class. But the course did teach me a lot, and I recommend taking it if you are interested in doing research in the future. The final project might be one of the most difficult things that I have ever done in college, as I had no idea how to do my own research. The professor is very nice and helpful, and the topics are very interesting, and if you work on the class hard enough, you will not do bad on the exams as it doesn't ask you anything you haven't learned. Just study very hard if you want to take this class!
subject: Human Evolutionary Biology

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Valeria Luiselli 001
best_comment: Each week, this class has: 1) 75–minute lecture; 2) 60–minute writing lab; 3) 75–minute seminar. It is very manageable. Writing lab is chill (at least for my TF). In past years, you did not have to read all the books to do well, but I guess too many people did this because this year we have an exam where we need to identify passages lol. But even then, I really recommend reading all the books. Even from the ones you do not enjoy so much, there is something to learn. There is so much variety in the texts, you are bound to like at least one if you love reading at all, and the professors — some of the leading experts on the genres and authors in the WORLD (crazy) — are very accessible, friendly, and passionate. I would say main reason to do this class would be for the inspiring lectures. Second reason is if you want to time and an excuse to read a lot of interesting books. Hum 10 is a class that fosters a deep love for learning, a love for understanding humanity, a love for art. You need to love reading & love analyzing texts on your own. I am also a non–humanities major, and I would say it is one of my favorite courses this semester.Which is not to say that this course does not have its drawbacks. You need to really work to find community here, because the seminars meeting only once a week frankly feels a little insufficient (though I do recognize that these professors and TFs are probably taking time that doesn't necessarily exist in of their already busy schedules to teach teenagers). There are group events meant to foster community but lots of them are very "quirky" and happen at hours of the day where lots of people aren't free. Though I was surprised to find that most of the students were those stereotypical pretentious humanities types – yeah, they definitely existed, but most of the people were very sweet and fun to talk to.
worse_comment: I recommend this course but definitely take a long time thinking about these responses and if you’d prefer taking Expos20 before making a decision. Hum10 has incredible lectures, book selections, and teaching staff but the reality is you will start feeling annoyed and upset about the course if you do not read the books and receive a harsh writing lab TF.
subject: Humanities
course_title_2023: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Derek Walcott

Though I was surprised to find that most of the students were those stereotypical pretentious humanities types – yeah, they definitely existed, but most of the people were very sweet and fun to talk to.
worse_comment: I recommend this course but definitely take a long time thinking about these responses and if you’d prefer taking Expos20 before making a decision. Hum10 has incredible lectures, book selections, and teaching staff but the reality is you will start feeling annoyed and upset about the course if you do not read the books and receive a harsh writing lab TF.
subject: Humanities
course_title_2023: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Derek Walcott

course_title: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Valeria Luiselli 001
best_comment: Each week, this class has: 1) 75–minute lecture; 2) 60–minute writing lab; 3) 75–minute seminar. It is very manageable. Writing lab is chill (at least for my TF). In past years, you did not have to read all the books to do well, but I guess too many people did this because this year we have an exam where we need to identify passages lol. But even then, I really recommend reading all the books. Even from the ones you do not enjoy so much, there is something to learn. There is so much variety in the texts, you are bound to like at least one if you love reading at all, and the professors — some of the leading experts on the genres and authors in the WORLD (crazy) — are very accessible, friendly, and passionate. I would say main reason to do this class would be for the inspiring lectures. Second reason is if you want to time and an excuse to read a lot of interesting books. Hum 10 is a class that fosters a deep love for learning, a love for understanding humanity, a love for art. You need to love reading & love analyzing texts on your own. I am also a non–humanities major, and I would say it is one of my favorite courses this semester.Which is not to say that this course does not have its drawbacks. You need to really work to find community here, because the seminars meeting only once a week frankly feels a little insufficient (though I do recognize that these professors and TFs are probably taking time that doesn't necessarily exist in of their already busy schedules to teach teenagers). Though I was surprised to find that most of the students were those stereotypical pretentious humanities types – yeah, they definitely existed, but most of the people were very sweet and fun to talk to.
worse_comment: I recommend this course but definitely take a long time thinking about these responses and if you’d prefer taking Expos20 before making a decision.
