subject: Humanities
course_title_2023: A Humanities Colloquium: From Homer to Derek Walcott

course_title: A Colloquium in the Visual Arts 001
best_comment: Definitely one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard. I would strongly, strongly recommend it!! The biggest strength of this class is looking lab and section. I looked forward to these discussions every week. I felt like all my fellow classmates were on a level playing field and we all felt comfortable sharing our "uninformed" thoughts about art and learning from one another. We had engaged, robust discussions every week with almost zero dead time during our meetings. Each section is led by a professor which is a really cool opportunity that doesn't exist in other lecture classes. I found Professor Koerner to be an incredible section leader, giving us his expertise and perspective when necessary but also asking the right questions to get us engaged and participating. My TF, Joseph, was also a great resource in both looking lab and office hours. This class isn't a traditional art history survey course in a dark room with slides, moving chronologically through time periods. It took more of a thematic approach, allowing each professor to teach on an artwork in their specialty. I feel like I got a thorough introduction to art history and gained the ability to talk about art in an informed/smart way. I would wholeheartedly recommend this class!!
best_gem_comment: Hum 20 was amazing! It's a fantastically designed intro class; no matter your experience, you'll leave this class with the tools to really engage with a piece of art, which you can use for the rest of your life. The lectures are hit or miss, but the good ones were some of my favorite lectures of college. Take it with friends and shoot the s*** talking about art, it's great for conversation. Not exactly a gem, since the weekly discussion papers can sneak up on you, but it's worth it to force you to actually have something to say about every unit.

course_title_2023: A Colloquium in the Visual Arts

best_comment: Take this course if you can – this is an extremely rare and rewarding opportunity, and represents the best of what Harvard has to offer academically. Each week you will engage with a different medium, and you will be taught by an amazing professor of that field. The preparation required outside of class is similar to other courses, but unlike a gened it is critical that you actually do it, since you will get so much out of the discussions and the opportunity to hear from these professors. Approach every topic with open–mindedness and enthusiasm, even and especially the ones you think you have little interest in/prior exposure to – there are no wrong answers here, and this course is an incredible intellectual sandbox to engage with interesting content and ideas, surrounded by some of the brightest and most engaged classmates you will find in any discussion–based class. As for the writing assignments, while they are only 500 words do not be deceived into thinking they are easy or should be taken lightly – while they may not require as much time as longer papers, they require a similar if not higher level of engagement and effort to write well.
subject: Humanities

subject: Humanities

best_comment: This was my favorite course this semester by a long shot.  There are a few things that played into this being such a great course.  First off, Andrew Bottoms is a fantastic teacher.  He is kind, funny, informative, and never makes you feel bad for making mistakes.  With ASL being new to most students in the class,  Andrew fostered a positive culture around taking risks and having fun.  This course is not a major time suck at all.  Homework never took more than 3 hours in a week other than preparing our final presentation.  Tests are all reasonable, and if you pay attention in class and review a bit you'll find success.  I never found myself stressed  over this class.  I will say that Andrew can be slow to give feedback on videos or emails, so just know that going into the course.  In person, however, Andrew loves getting to know students and helping them dive deeper into ASL.
worse_comment: I think everyone should take ASL! Many assume that the language is similar to ASL when it's very different. This class has taught me a lot about the Deaf community and has redefined what I think language is because ASL has broken my barriers to communication. Language is not just verbal; it includes body movement and facial expressions.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: ASL 3 is going to be more difficult than ASL 1 or 2, but it's still an amazing class. Anbo is an amazing and caring professor and I highly suggest this class to anyone with an interest in pursuing greater competency of ASL past the first 2 classes offered at Harvard.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: Your experience in this class will depend on the TF's you get, but I had an amazing experience. I loved mine and the small classroom environment is very nice! Really relaxing and fun course
subject: Linguistics

course_title: The Science of Language: An Introduction 001
best_comment: This class was interesting and I feel better off for having taken it, but I have my reservations. Prof. Sag–Parvardeh was really great and kind, and the entire teaching staff was really supportive. The psets were easy, short, and infrequent (too easy in my opinion) and this class was definitely a gem. This class achieved its goal in covering a broad range of introductory linguistics topics. However, this course definitely had its problems. The pacing of this class seemed really off. Lectures were attendance mandatory but they crawled by so slowly. The content that we covered in 2–3 classes (2.5–3 hrs) was covered just as easily in a 1–hr section. In fact, section felt like the most important part of the class. Additionally, there were often questions that arose during section or from psets that garnered confusion among the majority of students and never actually had a clear answer.
best_gem_comment: This class was interesting and I feel better off for having taken it, but I have my reservations. subject: Linguistics
course_title_2023: The Science of Language: An Introduction

best_comment: Professor is very sweet and knowledgeable about the course material, but the lectures often felt like he was just reading from a textbook. Section was very helpful in clearing up questions. Psets were completion–based which was super clutch, as the second half of the psets were quite hard. Interesting content and good class overall
worse_comment: do NOT take if you're not a concentrator. honestly this class was not great. i should have known when literally half the class turned out to be auditors

best_comment: IT'S TERRIFIC!!!!The problems were a blast to work through. They had so many neat nuances and challenged me in the healthiest way possible. Professor Chierchia is an absolute gem –– dynamic, caring, approachable, self–aware, patient, and warm.  And yes, the homework is tough at times, but there are SO many resources at one's disposal: office hours, class notes (with solutions), section notes (with solutions), etc. Also, the TF and the professor give highly useful feedback on the homework.Both the professor and the TF are VERY knowledgeable. Getting to ask them questions was always a delight.This class is also super conceptually rich; you'll get to engage in some very cool debates!Though all that aside, Professor Chierchia is one of the most special people I've met at Harvard; simply getting to know him makes the course so valuable to take.

best_comment: This course was honestly super fun. I really liked getting to delve deeper into Syntax, and I genuinely had a great time in class even though two hours of Syntax doesn't sound fun at first. If you're not really into Syntax you'll probably find the content a bit dull, but if you like Linguistics at all, you'll love this class. The course is super easy to keep up with, and the content isn't too hard to understand.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: If you like phonetics or phonology and want to see if one or both is truly for you, this is the class to take. The two–hour–long lectures, very difficult assignments, and 3,000–word final paper will be a delight if you really do love phonetics and phonology. If it turns out phonetics and phonology aren’t for you,  you’ll think, “I’m so glad I took this class, but I’ve had my fill now.” I fall into the latter category and can say that either way, you’ll win. So grateful I got to take this class and to learn from Professor Franich and can say it was definitely worth taking.With that, under Professor Franich (a phonetician), the course is pretty phonetics heavy. We had two clear–cut phonetics assignments, one articulatory phonology assignment (which really just felt like a phonetics assignment), two Optimality Theory assignments, one rules–based phonology assignment, and one perceptual phonology assignment. You’ll use fairly specialized software for the entirety of the last two assignments (which you should DEFINITELY start early so that you can debug, find participants, etc. as needed). TaDa is very cool, and it’s always great to pick up some new technical skills. I didn’t realize just how rich of a discipline phonetics was, and I’m glad Professor Franich opened my eyes to that.I liked the format of the homework. It’s usually two or three really hard questions that require substantial amounts of time and thought to answer. It was great to think through problems on such a deep level! I had a lot of fun working through them. And yes, they can be a lot to tackle, but Professor Franich is VERY helpful and patient over email and in office hours. So really, you’ll get to spend your semester tackling conceptually rich problems that required thorough, flexible, creative, and critical thinking. This class will make you a much stronger problem solver and thinker. Also, Professor Franich knows a TON about experimental design, laboratory work, field work, etc. and can discuss them with you in very accessible terms. And she has so much wisdom and experience to share re: the design of constraints, conventions around writing in linguistics, etc. (She’s also a phonologist!) Definitely go to her office hours, talk with her after class, etc. The final squib was the hardest paper I’ve written since the spring of ‘21. But that made finishing it that much more empowering and encouraging.Professor Franich would have us get up at the board and draw tableau, write rules, etc., which I loved. In summary, LING 115 is the hardest linguistics class I’ve taken, and I’m glad I took it because it’s fun and interactive and made me a better problem solver!Fellow undergraduates: DO NOT take graduate–level classes lightly. Only take one at a time. The final squibs are a beast — and one alone will be doable but a lot to manage when you have other finals to worry about. Treat this class as one of your tough ones when building your schedule.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: take this course if you’re interested! definitely have some background, but this course was really nice!
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: It would be nice to choose this course in your G2 year if you are a PhD student in Linguistics.
subject: Linguistics

best_comment: This class was my favorite this semester. We have amazing course instructors who help us stay engaged and also have a great time in class! We also all learned great skills that will help us to succeed in our future college experiences.
worse_comment: Reach out to the team or your peers when you feel stuck

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 000
best_comment: This isn't like a regular math class where you're lectured about how to solve a problem, you have to solve the problems themselves on a board, but there's a ton of support available for you in class, at the MQC, and in office hours so you'll never feel lost.
worse_comment: Be prepared for some psets that waste your time and some insane quizzes
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 000
best_comment: This isn't like a regular math class where you're lectured about how to solve a problem, you have to solve the problems themselves on a board, but there's a ton of support available for you in class, at the MQC, and in office hours so you'll never feel lost.

subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 001
best_comment: Students should expect to need help for much of the course material. I usually had to attend office hours or MQC but the help I received made understanding the material much easier.
worse_comment: I recommend this course as a starting point for those who do not feel confident in their calculus skills.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 012
best_comment: This course gives a thorough introduction to functions and calculus, so if you are going into college unsure of whether or not you have mastered the basic calculus skills, I think this class is the perfect fit. It introduces you to college–level math but it is not overly challenging or work heavy like Math 1a. If you do struggle in the course, MQC and office hours are really helpful to get through PSETs or review for assessments. It is also nice because there is a final project instead of a final assessment, so it is more indicative of what you actually learned from the course. I would definitely recommend this course because it makes you more confident in your math abilities without causing unnecessary stress.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 020
best_comment: Very good class! The TF's and CA's are so incredibly helpful! The psets are very fair for what is covered in class, and the practice quizzes are very similar to the quizzes/exams. Excellent class and very well taught.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 021
best_comment: I would say that this class does move at a slower pace at first if you do have some level of calculus background, however, it is a great review and is truly helpful in a lot of ways. So give it time and it will progressively pick up over time
worse_comment: I switched from 1a into math Ma. No one who switched from 1a to Ma has regretted it!
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 022
best_comment: TAKE MATH MA. I can't stress this enough. Ok unless you are a math genius and it seems boring to you. I took calculus up to integrals in high school and feel like I still learned a lot. You might want to take 1a or 1b to prove that you can take a higher math course, or to have the course requirements done early. Whatever reason it may be, if you want a solid foundation in math, low stress and supported class take this one. Sure, there are many assignments but that gives you a constant, sustainable working amount instead of the ups and downs and stressors that come with a lot of other math courses. You can always move up and get more intense, but especially as a freshman when you are figuring things out, this is the perfect class to start with. You wont regret it ! a lot of my 1a friends feel this class would have also been great for them. Also i met some of my best friends in this class ;)
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 030
best_comment: Very well–structured, enjoyable, and a good amount of challenging. There's three p–sets and quiz almost every week but it's super manageable. P–sets might take an hour or two at most, and the quizzes are very similar to p–sets and what we learn in class. This class was fun and very applicable to real life. Really made me consider a math concentration.
worse_comment: Work hard to review on quizzes and don't put the class on the back burner! You get what you put into the class.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I 040
best_comment: Take this class! It goes by slow so you can take in more information at a time but has an incredible department that are super willing to help!
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Functions and Calculus I

course_title: Quantitative Analysis for Economics and the Social Sciences I 001
best_comment: LOVE LOVE LOVE THIS CLASS!! I was a bit hesitant between this and MATH MA but this course was definitely the course for me!! I will preface this by saying if you do want to do a math heavy concentration, this might not be the course for you. However, if you love thinking about math beyond equations and in an applied way, if you want a course head/lecturer that LOVES his course and the topic, and if you want amazingly supporting TFs, TAKE MATH QA!! Its definitely one of my favorite classes that I took this year. The topics and lectures were super interesting the workload wasn’t anything too crazy. Also, Brendan is super supportive with both your goals in and out of the class!!

This course is time–consuming, but it’s extremely doable, especially if you have previous calc experience. Good class to fulfill QRD requirement and gain basic calc experience. Just expect to spend a good bit of time on the psets. Definitely take advantage of office hours and MQC.
worse_comment: You need to have taken calc before. The course will be very stressful and confusing if not.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course is  very good if you are considering diving straight into learning about precalculus. You don't need any prior experience with differentiation and integration to excel in this class as you will learn how to understand each of them in details as you go through the course. It has 3 Psets a week and plenty of opportunities for you to check your reasoning before each of them is due. It is also very exciting to be able to use Math to analyze real world situation from their data sets, propose possible solutions to identified problems and just have fun while behaving like data scientists.
worse_comment: This class will teach you calculus but will also take all your time and damage your mental health.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is an intro calc class, but if you're going in expecting a high–school type of formal teaching, you won't get it. The structure of the class (in my experience) is that they pass out a worksheet with the day's lesson and the teacher tells you to start on it with a group of people. If you don't know the concept period, you're stuck unless another member of the group has taken calc before. You can ask questions, but in my section the teacher usually just told students to think about it more (???). There's no note taking in a formal math notebook unless you want to make more work for yourself; you just jot down whatever you need in the margins of the worksheet usually. Honestly, you might be at a disadvantage if you have zero calc background since they don't really teach, just give you worksheet problems to do. I also had to switch out of a different teacher's class (same math class just different time slot and teacher) because his voice was hard to understand and he just didn't clarify students' questions. The course CAs are good mostly, so just pray that you get nice ones. For homework, you pretty much have to go the the math question center (MQC) if you want to get full points on PSets because there will be just little subtleties in the question directions that if you don't get, you'll be marked off for. Hannah subbed for my class period once, and from that one class I wished I was in her section since she explained things more clearly, but ask around and see who liked their teacher the most. The tests are a lot like the practice exams, so that's fine.
worse_comment: this is the worst class. ever. i hadn't taken calc before doing this class, because why would one take calc before taking calc right? i was wrong. people who had taken calc before had no clue what was going on in class, and i was none the wiser.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Take 1A!!! Much better than MA/QA if you are willing to learn. 1 semester is very nice. I highly recommend it as the grading scale is super generous. Multiple attempts for tests.
worse_comment: If you were into math at one point in your life but have grown to dread it and are unsure about continuing math and this is your level, take this class. Be aware of the 3 psets a week when considering your full course load but do not let that by itself steer you away from this class. The work load is fair and never over bearing.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Take this course because it’s the best opportunity to get a strong grip in your basic calculus. I wish I didn’t take it because the topic of integration only came in the last two weeks, so if you already took calculus and know how to differentiate, I would rather take math1b and learn the integration part with Khan Academy. That said, the Math1A Staff is REALLY prepared and they’ll try their best to make you succeed in class.  Prepare for 3 psets a week. Take it with Hannah if you can, couldn’t love her way of teaching more
worse_comment: Class is terribly structured, though it is usually a requirement for most students. So if you must take it, be prepared to do some independent learning.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is very easy if you have an AB Calculus AB background. I had this coming in and it made a huge difference, especially with how I approached section. The class teaches very basic calculus concepts in a very overcomplicated way and because of this, it is easy to get lost even if you already have prior knowledge of the course. I had friends that did not know any calculus and they definitely struggled a little bit more. 3 PSETs a week gets old, but most of them are pretty good in reaffirming concepts. Make sure to do the practice assessments before every exam because it gives a good indication of exam difficulty.
worse_comment: You probably have to take this course for some sort of requirement, so the following points may not actually influence your decision to take it or not. However...1. The PSets are rough. They aren't too long at all, but they are due every Monday, Wednesday and Friday. You always have math you could be doing and that is sort of horrific. Additionally, many of the PSets I was unable to complete by myself: I will never get back the hours I spent from 7:30pm–10:00pm in the MQC for so many nights this semester, feeling miserable. Some of the CA's are great, others are really moody, not super helpful and talk to like you are sort of dumb. 2. The projects are not that related to course material at all. I wish they were: it would make the class better, however, they are not. No one in any of my groups did any work and I ended up doing a lot of it. 3. The way the sections are structured can be pretty bad. The first half of the semester, there was no demonstration or lecture at the beginning of class to show you how to do what you were supposed to be doing. You were expected to stumble through a worksheet with a group of fellow students (many of which had completely different learning styles than I did) and "figure it out." This was miserable. This got a lot better after the midterm survey went out because they began to incorporate some form of lecture at the beginning of class: but be forewarned. 4. Your experience in this class will greatly differ depending on who your CA's and TF are.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class will not be a cakewalk no matter how good at math you are. It's not because the math is hard, but instead because it's repetitive. The psets can be a lot and the occasional one would take over 5 hours to complete. That said, you will learn the math and learn it well. The key is making use of the extra resources page and the videos they provide, which are super helpful for the entire course. Also, make sure your section leader is good. All due respect to my boy Cliff, but he was not the most effective instructor for me. If that's the case, don't be afraid to see if you can switch sections. Amadeus is incredible and does a great job teaching, you'll be set if he's your professor. If you're diligent and don't fall behind on the material, you'll be well prepared for the midterms and the final. Also, don't sleep on the Psets, for us our pset average was worth more than the two midterms combined.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course is a lot of work, so be prepared! In fall 2022, there were 3 PSETS a week (33 total). But, if you start the PSETS early (i.e., right after class) and go to office hours, you can learn so much math and do well. The teaching in this course is FANTASTIC! I had Amadeus, and he taught us everything in class, without anyone ever having to use the textbook. Additionally, unlike other classes that are graded on a curve, where the top X percent gets a certain grade, this course is structured so that it rewards understanding. If you work hard and learn the material, you will do very well, regardless of how others are doing. If you are on the fence about which math class to take Freshman fall, math 1B is definitely up there for the most work, but the grading is much better than some of the classes that require less work (i.e., Math 21A, 22, or 25).If you come in with a weaker math background, the course may feel undoable at the start, but KEEP WITH IT! You will eventually get to the other side and be so glad you stuck with it.
worse_comment: This class is extremely difficult but no impossible. Being premed, I took this alongside LS1a, and doing both at the same time is TOUGH. If you do, do two geneds or a gened and freshman seminar with it. Otherwise, you will be in the *trenches* at all times. The psets are long, but they got shorter after we left comments about it in the midyear evaluation. The trick to this class is getting the pset done on the day it is assigned, so you can go to MQC that night when no one else is there. MQC on the night a pset is due is super crowded and the TFs have less time to spend with each student.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is definitely a time commitment with three psets a week, but if you stay on top of your work—start working on it the day it gets assigned—and make a good pset group, you'll be fine. The content is paced pretty well and there is a lot of a support with MQC.
worse_comment: There is not much background that can help in this course.  Many people –– including me –– took this as an "easy" class, since we thought it would be a repeat of AP Calculus BC for our math requirements.  I took math up to AP Calculus BC previously, scoring 5s and the highest grades possible in all of those classes; however, Math 1b was still somewhat difficult for me.  The material is taught very differently, and requires you to rethink/relearn everything you've learned before.  Additionally, it is a lot of work.  The psets take hours of your time; this class was the biggest time sink of all my classes this semester, and it was a poor choice for freshman year 1st semester.  If you need to spend time in your freshman year adjusting to the new environment, don't take Math 1b.Overall, the format of the class is somewhat disappointing.  There were no lectures; just "experiment with these problems and find the answer".  The CAs and MQC saved us.  I do wish they did more teaching in this class.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: The course has been greatly improved in the last few years. The more manageable PSETs and QRDs weren't terribly difficult and did a great job at preparing you for the exams. You will get out of this class what you put into it, so go to class and try the worksheet/board work, when studying for exams, really take the time to review the PSETs as a lot of what you do there translates directly. Overall the class has been one of my favorite math classes at Harvard.
worse_comment: Start psets early and go to office hours. It’s manageable if you can organize your time to compare your answers with other people and ask questions if you get stuck.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Multi gets a bad rap, and despite what many others might say, I think this course was great. I get that for some it might not be easy (especially when this is your first time taking the course), and sometimes Professor Wood seems too smart for you, but I do think it's set up really great. From the hands–on and intuitive approach to learning, to the reassessments it is designed for you to do well, and at the very least understand what's going on inherently. Professor Wood is a great guy, super nice, super smart and generally accessible. If you go to his OH or ask him questions during class, he can be very helpful. I genuinely believe he wants to help students out, which is always a great quality in a professor. In all, I would recommend for social studies people as I think Professor Wood will continue to refine the course to make it better and I personally think it's a better alternative to 21a if you can.
worse_comment: Don't take it if you don't have to. The material is not extremely challenging, there is just an humongous lack of actual teaching and those who had already taken multivariable calc in the past did much better, because we never actually learned a lesson in class.  Looking at the worksheet solutions was more efficient then wasting an hour and 15 in class and walking out confused.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Modeling and Differential Equations for the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: The two broad sentiments behind Math 19a is that you love it or you don't. I personally really loved the class. Material: A large emphasis is on ecological modeling,  but if you're into medicine or biochemistry, the topics will also flow throughout the course. There are also concepts that come from human anatomy (either in papers like epidermal wounds, leukemia modeling, cardiac electrophysiology) that are introduced through a mathematical lens and changed my way of viewing processes like heartbeats, healing, and medication.Lecture: Honestly it is so useful when it comes to reviewing the steps you need to approach in solving a problem set question. Go to every class and write down everything Wes puts on the board, even if it takes a minute to understand. It might click as you work through problems.Problem sets: They're only once a week, which is so much better than Math 21a and 21b. If you're between this class and Math 22a or 22b, I'd select 19a if you don't have experience with proofs. Also office hours were helpful because the TFs are patient and will guide you as you approach questions. Show up even if you barely started.Exams: It's nice that there are only two. It's scary that they cover so much content. One thing that caught me off guard is that your understanding of the readings is also asked. It's nothing tricky or too specific. If you take notes while Todd presents the key points in the article and later review his lecture slides (which contain more notes on Canvas) then you'll be ready. As for the math portion, make sure you know the rationale behind what certain topics are and not just the steps, because some questions will not be so simple as to just memorize the steps and write them down.Final Project: Start early!! Your proposal is due sometime in mid–October. If you're learning about a certain concept in LS1a, LPS A, or another life sciences adjacent class, pick your favorite and find some math behind it. This way, it feels more interesting as you learn more and study for your other class. As long as you begin graphing models (at least one graph) before Thanksgiving break and continue before/throughout reading period, you'll be fine.Always reach out to Wes! He's a great person to talk to and genuinely is rooting for everyone's success. If his office hours don't work for you, reach out for an appointment! He will be more than happy to do so.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Modeling and Differential Equations for the Life Sciences

best_comment: This course is a perfect step up from high school level calculus. It is challenging at times while also being entirely manageable and is a great first step into higher level math. Janet Chen has paced this course wonderfully and depending on your prof, you will have a great time. (Roderic is the best!) On the occasions that I was stuck on a problem set, MQC was a great help, and it was reassuring to know that the problems I was stuck on were also difficult for a multitude of other people. The support is really wonderful all throughout the course. Overall, it was a really really good course to take coming right into college.
worse_comment: Go to office hours the same day because topics are hard.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course is a perfect step up from high school level calculus. It is challenging at times while also being entirely manageable and is a great first step into higher level math. Janet Chen has paced this course wonderfully and depending on your prof, you will have a great time. (Roderic is the best!) On the occasions that I was stuck on a problem set, MQC was a great help, and it was reassuring to know that the problems I was stuck on were also difficult for a multitude of other people. The support is really wonderful all throughout the course. Overall, it was a really really good course to take coming right into college.
worse_comment: Go to office hours the same day because topics are hard.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course is manageable and enjoyable if you make sure to stay on top of your work. There are 3 problem sets a week and class 4 days a week – which is a big commitment! But if you can create a schedule for yourself, you will learn the content and succeed. It is a good idea to do the textbook readings before class because class is mostly focused on completing a worksheet and not on instruction. I also highly recommend completing practice exams –– they are generally harder than the real exams, but are great practice. Start preparing for the exams well in advance because each covers a good bit of content. Also, go to office hours! Especially with Janet Chen, who is a fantastic instructor and really patient when explaining the concepts. Make sure to work with other students too (and credit them when you do)–– Math21a is a huge class so it is a great chance to collaborate and learn from your peers. Do not feel intimidated by this class if you don't have the strongest grasp of BC Calculus. As long as you have a relatively solid grasp of integrals and are willing to review some as you go, you should be fine. Personally, I did not fully learn parametric equations, polar coordinates, and infinite sequences and series in BC Calculus due to COVID. I was worried this would lead me to fall behind in Math21a, but it was not an issue. Finally, if you don't have to take this course for a concentration, make sure you are actually enthusiastic about the topics because this class will take up a good bit of time!
worse_comment: Problems sets are long and time consuming, especially if you have never taken multi variable calculus before.  Doable but must be willing to put in a LOT of effort into the course.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: It's thoroughly fine. Like, it's intro math, nobody is signing up to get their minds blown or their passions satiated. It is fast–paced and builds cumulatively, so make sure you are staying on top of stuff! And don't be surprised if the practice tests are harder than the actual exams. Make friends, PSET together, and you will be fine :)
worse_comment: It is not bad at all if you liked and did well in the previous math classes. It is hard to keep track of all the different integral theorems and types, but it is more of a memory problem than a math one. It is also hard to avoid careless mistakes, but it is possible if you are organized. For most people, that will be easily fixed. Also, I feel that the general feeling after exams were that those were not too bad aft all.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class was really hard and drove me crazy at times, but it was also pretty rewarding to see myself improve over time. Don't be a perfectionist on the Psets because they will take you forever. Definitely would recommend office hours and MQC as well as working with other students – super super helpful. I also really like that this was taught in sections!
worse_comment: This class is A LOT. They changed the curriculum so now problem sets are 3x a week which is not fun. No longer opportunities to re–test objectives. To do well, you must keep up with material and always be following along. Would not recommend unless required.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This math course is probably one of the better–structured and better–organized math courses you will find at Harvard. The course materials are ample: from worksheets and solutions to online readings to extra practice and practice exams, you'll be well covered. The practice exams prepare you very well for the exam, and the course study schedules are reasonable and meant to help you succeed. There are also plenty of opportunities to get the help that you need. MQC is highly collaborative and a great place to get PSET help, but it is very very crowded and not necessarily an enjoyable experience. Office hours give much better one–on–one help. There aren't really bad office hours to go to either... everyone is super helpful and good at explaining the material. Feedback is very thorough even for exams, so you'll always know exactly what you did wrong! Have a group of friends that do the PSET around the same time as you and don't be afraid to ask for help. This is one of those courses where as long as you put in the work, you will see good results. There is a lot of work – 3 PSETs a week is no joke, but nothing is unmanageable or even unreasonable. You also have the opportunity to learn extra late days... use them!!
worse_comment: If you don't have a strong math background you will struggle in this course. There is a lot of content and a lot to take into account when solving a lot of these problems, and it's hard to take into account things you are learning for the first time/don't already have intuition for. However there are some good TFs who are willing to sit down with you and make sure you really conceptually understand the material. Just dedicate the time.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: The TFs for this course are amazing! The 3 class, 3 pset, 1 workshop a week structure can be taxing at times, but you definitely get good at what you learn/practice and the length of the psets are not too bad. Math 21A does a great job of being flexible with students (lots of support, many office hours, many practice materials, shorter psets before exams, etc). I loved the community and people I met in section or checking pset answers with. Whether you have taken multi before or not, most people come out with really well developed multivariable calculus skills. The exams are always close to what you expect (they want you to succeed) and the course is organized. If you want to get a good foundation in multi AND understand it well, this is a fun course to take. Just make sure you're mentally ready for the workload and commitment.
worse_comment: I would tell future students to, if they choose to take this course, make sure that this is your most difficult course. This course requires time. The material is not difficult necessarily, there are just so many ways to approach each problem that practice and solid foundations are necessary. Do not take this course at the same time as Organic Chemistry. Do not do it. I repeat. Do not do it. You do not want to be struggling to figure out which class to pour your time into. Going to MQC and working on problem sets 3 times a week will take away from time that you may need to put into other classes. Make sure that you have the time for this class and that you can dedicate yourself to this class.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is awesome! It was so fun to take and I definitely recommend it to everyone. As someone who was never passionate or fascinated with math, this class changed my perception of the whole field. Although it has a daunting 3 psets a week, they are short and manageable and help you learn a lot and the teaching staff is fantastic. It is one of the more chill math classes and was my favorite class this semester as a premed student who isn't a math person. If you take this class, I would definitely recommend finding a good group of people to work on psets with and study for exams (3 hour practice tests for the final are brutal without a pal). MQC is a really underutilized resource because the CAs are super helpful and willing to sit down with you for however long you need. Also, start studying for exams early!!!
worse_comment: This course is designed so that if you do all the problem sets and understand the problems, as well as the problems you go over in class on the worksheet, you will learn the material. I highly recommend taking all the practice test and giving space between them so that you have time to digest what you made mistakes on.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: If you must take a math class at Harvard, take this one!! 100% choose it over Math1b or anything lower. You must be familiar with taking derivatives and integrals for this course (but not the extremely complex versions) and everything else will be taught to you! This is easily the best–taught math class I have ever been in. For context, I took this freshman fall. I had placed into the math classes a level above math 1b (math 18/19, 21, 22, etc), but I was strongly considering redoing math 1b thinking that I needed a stronger foundation in math no matter which field I decided (econ/stem concentrator). I am so glad that I chose to take math 21a instead of 1b. Talking to friends in 1b, it is a notoriously hard class that almost nobody enjoys. Math 21a is also a difficult course, but in contrast to 1b, I think that it is more manageable and (from people I have talked to who took both classes) better structured. If math is not your strength, taking 21a also gives you the advantage of taking one high–level class and being done with math for good, since it fulfills many concentration requirements for honors track or a high–level math course above 1b. Take this class if you have to take a math course. It will be work, but it's a very rewarding and fulfilling course.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class requires a few hours more than the other classes you are enrolled in, especially if you are a bit rusty in your calculus knowledge. Be prepared to attend MQC to get help on PSET questions, I recommend attending the day it is assigned as there are fewer people those days and you can receive more help one–on–one. Regardless, the class was very fun, especially being able to visualize a lot of things in 3d.
worse_comment: Do NOT take this course if you think it’s going to be easier than math 1b it’s a trick. The course is hard and the problem set grading is a gamble in the dark.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Strong recommend –– I put this course off to junior year but really should've taken it freshman year. The progression of this course is logical and satisfying: everything you learn builds on the previous material, and it's very well paced such that you get a chance to get comfortable with material but don't dwell on anything too long before moving onto something new. The flipped format of this course works really well too: you get to learn things for yourself in a cooperative environment w supportive teachers and TFs. Every class you learn something cool. A lot of psets but they're short and sweet. If you were intimidated or turned off by Math 1b or HS calc (as I was), def give this course a shot!
worse_comment: This class is great in my opinion! I am on the dumber end of most Harvard students and I thought it wasn't too difficult! The material builds on itself and isn't easy by any means, but it all makes sense conceptually and it's very doable overall. Don't miss any classes, you'll feel far behind if so. I missed one class and I was really behind. But if you attend every class and turn in everything, you'll have no issue.There are 3 psets a week currently, so be warned of that. Also there is a required workshop every week which is pretty much a waste of time. You'll like this class if you like flipped–classroom format. No exam makeups besides the first one. You only get 3 pset drops and a handful of late days even though there are 35 psets.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I initially took this course because I had a poor background in understanding matrixes and felt very uncomfortable using them.  This course helped me to become VERY comfortable in using matrixes now!  Assignments are generally 3–5 questions long depending on the rigor of the material.  GO TO THE MCQ to double–check your answers are correct and also to ensure you get a good understanding of the material.  Create a PSET group chat to help.  Assignments took me about 1.5 hours to finish, not including MCQ, and there's three PSETS per week.  Grading is nice: several of your lowest PSETS are dropped at the end of the year, and more weight is given to your best Midterm I/Midterm II/Final exam.  The TFs are generally great and want to help you.  The class offers practice quizzes over the course of the year to prepare for midterms.  Generally, I prefer to review the quizzes right before the exam because they are at times harder than exam material and will make me feel confident going into the exams.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Oh, Linear. This class is indeed intense; conceptually, as the topics are abstract and the math is nothing like calculus, and time–wise, as the three–pset–per–week grind is constant, unending, and will require care and dedication. This class was like learning a language, or cultivating a plant requiring lots of daily attention. It's your child for the semester. Good time management skills are crucial to prevent late nights, but you will probably still have some late nights, and it does take a village––GO TO MQC!! Discussing questions with the CAs is extremely helpful because it helps iron out nuances, and that's very important.The class takes a nice practical focus and is both computationally and conceptually oriented, so if you come into it mentally prepared for the grind and prepared to give it love, you will certainly do well. It **is definitely doable if you just give it the time it requires**, it's not the type of class that leaves you still lost if you're starting the psets the day they're released, and blocking out time to really digest the material and review and study in addition to doing the psets. I can imagine that if a person did this, they'd be just fine. Especially with how there are in fact a lot of supports for your grade, it's actually very flexible and supportive. If you bomb your first midterm because you thought doing the psets was enough to understand the concepts and didn't study much, (AKA you need to study outside of class), there is a grade–weighting option. Don't get to a pset until very late at night because of life happenings and/or other work, after MQC has closed? You can drop it, six of them in fact. But a word of caution: DON'T fall behind early. DON'T use these pset drops early. Don't lean heavily on these supports, otherwise you will pay for it later and throughout the course because the material builds on itself!!!! This is NOT a class you can cram for, it's about building skills and knowledgeable intuition and *thoughtful* muscle memory.  And did I mention the material builds on itself? It's like a nesting doll with three or four layers and you need each, in the right order! The first portion of the course will feel pretty doable––there are some nuances, and it's not bad. But if I can provide any one piece of advice from my experience, it's that you really, really need to have a strong understanding of the concepts that comprise all the material leading up to the first midterm (and doing well on the first midterm will save you a lot of anxiety). This will make the rest of the course go infinitely smoother, and not leave you with a sense that you're on a ship and there are a million holes leaking water everywhere that you have to keep patching up (speaking from experience here). Build the hull the right way the first time.If you do these things, you will do well! Yes, it's fast–paced. Yes, the course really can't come second to others and be left behind or you will be left behind. But if you do this, you'll learn about an absolutely amazing realm of math that has just AWESOME implications for the world. It's genuinely incredibly powerful, with fascinating nuances and fascinating applications, including to differential equations (which was really cool to see through an explicit lens). You'll learn so, so much, and it's a very profound sense of satisfaction to have looking back.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Before taking this class I heard it was difficult, so I was preparing for the worst. However, it is NOT THAT BAD! The 21 series is great, and you have SO MANY support resources. But, even with just the class worksheets, PSet's are doable alone. The only thing that sucks is 3 PSets per week, but as long as you stay on top of them it is fine. Multiple choice on exams are really difficult, so I would recommend practicing those a bunch. THE BEST WAY TO STUDY FOR EXAMS IS TO DO THE PRACTICE EXAMS!
worse_comment: Would not take this course if it's not a requirement. The course is overwhelming and unnecessarily stressful, and the three problem sets per week are superfluous. The only way to be successful is to spend hours in office hours, which are mainly held at night.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra I 001
best_comment: TAKE IT!!!! This class by far was my favorite class this semester. I am a freshman most likely concentrating in applied math cs and I felt like going into this year I got very little guidance on what to take. There are so many options! I took this class somewhat on a whim and I think it was the best choice by far. Here are my thoughts:18/19 seem like a lot of fun but they are very specific to their subject areas. In addition, not that many people are in them. Take it you are very passionate about those areas but not otherwise. 21 seems fun and a lot of people do it. That said, it’s a lot of computation and busy work since there are no proofs and 3 psets a week. They have to work on a pset pretty much every night (so it’s the same if not more of a time commitment than 22) but it’s a lot less rewarding (more plug and chug). You will also end up having to take an additional class (120 i think) to learn proofs anyway. I literally don’t know a single person who did applied math 22 it doesn’t seem to be very popular. 25 seems incredible but it’s A LOT of work. There is a reason there are 200 people who take 22 but only 40 who take 25. Most of my friends who tried out both classes in the beginning of the year dropped down to 22. It seems like the teacher is amazing and you get an incredible grasp of math on both a granular and broad level but it is going to be very hard and very time consuming. Only do it if you are really serious about pursuing math. In that case it will be very rewarding. Now for the reasons 22 is amazing!! First off, based on the comments on this page you have probably already heard that Dusty is amazing. He makes an effort to know everyone’s name. He is a very passionate lecturer. And he seems to overall really care for his student’s individually (which is really hard to find in other intro lecture classes). For example, he encourages you to email him or meet with him with any questions. If people do badly on an exam he offers corrections. There were even times during really stressful weeks where he offered pset extensions to the whole class. In addition, the community is great. Because it’s a pset class you will have to find people to work with which encourages you to make friends (and with 200 people there are a lot of opportunities to do so!). Somehow, when people discuss the class they assume that you know everyone in it (and that is pretty much true). GO TO OFFICE HOURS! Psets take a while by yourself but are easier and more fun with friends. In addition it’s a great way to meet people and find people to sit with. I would sometimes go to office hours by myself and just ask if anyone was working on a specific problem and join them. This is actually how I have found some of my best friends (even out of the class). Finally, the material is really fun. Proofs allow you to be creative and you walk away with a final project that you can be really proud of. The class overall is obviously challenging but as someone who hasn’t done linear or multi before I felt that it was doable!
worse_comment: take this class!!!!! i came in with no linear algebra or proof–based experience and the beginning is definitely tough, but dusty makes everything worth it. i sent the most mentally unhealthy stress email to him in the beginning of the term freaking out over our first midterm and he emailed back immediately and set up a meeting for the next day. we talked through studying strategies, he put my in contact with one of the course assistants who gave me one–on–one help (going over material again, answering my endless questions about stuff i didn't understand, helping me start pset problems, helping with exam corrections, etc. [THANK YOU CATHERINE YOU ARE A LIFESAVER]) and dusty also always chatted with me before class when i was just hanging out in the building. he is absolutely incredible. btw, if u don't learn well with textbooks, there are other ways to supplement lectures! i felt kinda guilty when i stopped reading the textbook but it genuinely wasn't working for me (and that is okay!!!). i liked three blue one brown videos (great visuals) and professor dave explains videos (he goes through topics quite slowly and does computational examples), and i'm fairly certain both youtubers are quite accurate. in conclusion, if u take this class – you got this!!! have fun! <3
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Vector Calculus and Linear Algebra I

course_title: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis I 001
best_comment: Math 25a is a project that you put a lot of work into, but if done correctly (which does not mean good grades, but active participation and interest in the class), is very rewarding. You are left with very important and fundamental proofs done in class or in problem sets or reviewed in the textbook. It is also strongly recommended to LaTeX your psets, which is very helpful when reviewing the psets for the midterms or the final exam, but also takes a lot of time (in my experience, about 5–6 per week). The class is VERY well put together and structured. All the problems have a meaning behind and will probably be useful at some later time in the course (go to Wes's office hours to learn the "meaning" of each problem).  The reading, unlike other classes, are straightforward and helpful. The lecture notes are too! I strongly recommend not skipping lecture, even though it's a 3 times per week 9am class, since not all lecture videos are uploaded, and by actively participating you learn a lot easier. Also, it is pretty easy to get left behind if you don't attend lectures. One thing that I did not like were the solutions to the psets, which were not quite useful, because they were skipping a lot of steps, and not giving proper explanations. Another thing I really liked was Wes's openness. He was very supportive after the first midterm, and did not release the mean of the exam, which was emotionally helpful for the students's sake. He really emphasized self growth, which I have rarely seen in teachers. I strongly recommend going to his office hours if possible. They are not that useful for solving the pset problems, but for understanding class material, and its usefulness in other areas (Wes is an applied mathematician and gives many examples for applicability of linear algebra).  Also, you get to build a connection with a wonderful faculty member. After the final exam, he said that whether we choose to take 25b or not (which is also his class), he is our supporter, and our adviser throughout our undergraduate experience. He said to reach out whenever we need anything math related. So, to sum up, Math 25a is a hard class, very thoroughly done linear algebra, but which proves to be helpful a lot of areas such as physics, and it is very well structured so that you get through the difficult material easier.
worse_comment: Take this class if you are fed up with rote calculations in math. The vast majority of our problems are proofs. Read the textbook and do the practice problems in the textbook if you feel that you are not understanding concepts too well.  Wes is a great lecturer. Exams and tests are graded leniently, but be aware that the course has no curve.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Theoretical Linear Algebra and Real Analysis I

course_title: Studies in Algebra and Group Theory 001
best_comment: Overall I had a very positive experience with Math 55a. I believe most of the people in the class would tell you this is by far their favorite class (naturally) as a consequence of us spend the most time on this course and with other students solving the problems. I made an absolutely amazing group of friends through this class, who are not only passionate about math but also very study–focused, kind, collaborative, and hard working. If you want to get your college experience started off on the right foot by making a group of supportive, hard–working, and curious friends, this is THE way to go. Moreover, if you could handle it, finishing this course gives you the unshakable confidence you can handle whatever challenge and class that comes in the future at Harvard as this is probably the most intensive math experience you could get here. That is not to say one would necessarily become cocky; my classmates constantly dazzle me with their brilliance and curiosity and I also needed to seek out computational problems to fill in the holes in the applied side of things. We had an exposure of a wide range of higher level mathematics, and I felt my brain constantly expanding and challenged during this course as if I caught a glimpse of something sublime, an experience that is hard to replicate in the other freshman math courses. However, we barely did any computational problems or applications, and Math 25a taught more applications of linear algebra than Math 55a (though it is relatively easy to self study these applications, one could just ask 25a friends for their notes). If you are deciding between Math 25a and Math 55a like I was in the beginning of the year, I highly recommend sitting into both classes in the first week of class, and by the end of the second week you most definitely would know which class fits you better. Ideally, I recommend students who have taken/self studied a course on abstract algebra and a course on linear algebra to take this course. Personally I did not have any abstract algebra background coming in and I felt very behind than some other students in the first few weeks of class. However, I also have a few friends who came in with only calculus and linear algebra knowledge. Competition math experience might be slightly helpful but definitely not necessary, I personally was not a USAMO qualifier (though many classmates are) and I was able to handle the class just fine; I think the psets mostly test the understanding of complex material, perhaps 2 or 3 questions out of 10 questions require extensive problem solving. By virtue of putting some of the brightest kids into one classroom there were some getting used to in the beginning of the year. I remember the first two weeks or so the class was not necessarily the most welcoming as classmates wanted to prove themselves, but very quickly the classroom environment became mature and welcoming, very much a big family. So don't be intimidated by other students in the beginning, breathe.I wish someone told me what to do in the summer before freshman year to prepare for Math 55a, so here: there are roughly four 'units' – introduction to abstract algebra, linear algebra, harder group theory stuff, then ending with representation theory that ties linear algebra and group theory together. The first and third unit heavily relied on Artin's Algebra, the second unit basically covered the entire Linear Algebra Done Right book by Axler, and the last unit was based on the first 40 pages of Representation Theory written by Professor Harris himself. We ran through Artin chapter 2 in the beginning of the year then we just speed ran Axler, if possible I recommend reading through the first 5 chapters of Axler and Artin chapter 2.Coming in I was also curious what other Math 55a students took alongside this course in the fall. From my experience it seems that many students took Stat 110, a decent amount took CS 50 (a handful took CS 121 or CS 61), and many chose to have at least one Gen Ed or freshman seminar.On the question of balance: Taking Math 55a  does in many ways throw one into a grind culture. I did cut down my involvement in clubs and sometimes I could not check out opportunities I would liked to see if I did not have a pset due in two days. Looking back, I think one needs to constantly remind oneself to put quality social interactions above the problem sets. We were told there were only 5 late days for the semester but in reality the CAs are very lenient and you pretty much can take as many late days as you wish. I wish I learnt about this earlier so I could be less stressed and focused on always turning in the psets on time every Wednesday and be more present around my friends and intentionally spend more time socializing early on in the semester. The midterm was relatively easy and mostly meant as a check on if you know what is going on. The final was very difficult and I recommend starting it as early as possible during reading period. However, most of the grade depends on the problem sets and if you did well on the midterm do not worry too much about the final. My biggest advice for studying: I find reading the relevant lecture notes/textbook sections before lecture then come to lecture to ask questions then do problem sets to review the most helpful, or else having lecture be one's first introduction to some abstract material could be hard to understand. As for pset groups, I recommend trying to work with different people in the beginning of the year,;there is no shame in asking if other want to pset together as most people are willing to experiment, people start to form semi–fixed groups around week 4, though I continued to try pset with different people to make close friendships and that is totally possible as well.  Moreover, Tuesday nights and Wednesday nights at the math lounge you can always find people who are willing to work together.The CA's pset feedbacks were not the most helpful as they are always 5 weeks behind on grading the problem sets. But some sections/office hours are helpful and I highly recommend checking out as many of them out as possible in the beginning of the year to see which CAs you find the most helpful/vibe with.Overall, Math 55a is an amazing course!!! I highly recommend at least coming to a few lectures to check it out. Best of luck with Harvard and everything that comes with it!
worse_comment: The class is fun, but it's a lot of work and can be overwhelming if you fall behind on problem sets or don't have anybody to turn to when you're stuck on a problem.
best_gem_comment: This class was my favorite course by far semester and we had a very good group of talented, interested students and an absolute gem of a professor. Professor Harris did the best possible job anyone could do given the amount of time and the amount of content and I came out of the semester thinking "dang, we go through all of that!"The CAs are also super kind and willing to help whenever. Would totally recommend this class for anyone interested in the math concentration!
