best_comment: This was a great tutorial! Taeuk is very good at explaining things and providing helpful intuition and commentary on how to think about algebraic geometry and stacks. The lectures were fun, and Taeuk was very accessible and eager to help clear up the many points of confusion I had while learning this material. Highly recommend taking anything he's teaching!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: McMullen was great and made lectures really engaging. The CA's were also great and super helpful. This was a great introduction to proof based math, and I feel way more confident for upper level math and cs courses now. I definitely recommend if McMullen is teaching this course again (I heard who ever teaches this class affects how good the class is). The only bad thing about this course is that we never got a single break from psets. We had one due every single week, even the week of our midterm. I will also say, though, shout out to the Math 101 community because this was my first stem class that actually felt social. Hopefully future iterations will be like that too.
worse_comment: If you have no background with proofs then take this course.
subject: Mathematics

course_title: Analysis of Function Spaces, Measure and Integration 001
best_comment: I would recommend this class, but only for math concentrators and only because the material is important if you're interested in math. When you do take the class, be warned that it's not great. The lectures are pretty dry. Each lecture just feels like a list of theorems with little motivation. And the proofs of the theorems in lecture are the kind of proof that doesn't follow a natural train of thought that you could think of yourself, instead seeming like someone just magically figured out that it works. Thankfully, the homeworks, while sometimes difficult, aren't too bad, so if you put in effort then you should do fine. There were many complaints about this class, which you'll probably see in the other comments, and they're all fair complaints. But there were some bright sides as well. Although most of the material is dry, the basic underlying concepts of measure theory and Lebesgue integration are very interesting. Also, Prof Yau was very lenient. He only assigned 8 homeworks, and whenever a homework was too long or a particular problem was too difficult, we asked the CAs to ask him to shorten the homework, extend the deadline, or remove the problem, and he always listened. He could have explained some things better and been more engaging, but ultimately I think the material itself is just pretty dry, so I don't blame him in particular for the class being dry.
worse_comment: This is my third semester at Harvard, and this is easily the worst class I've taken here. The professor did a poor job explaining the material, and I felt that I learned very little due to the poor quality of instruction. It didn't help that the organization was super unclear, so we were moving back and forth between different topics. Course logistics were super disorganized too, and it was routine for us to renegotiate problem set deadlines and the problems of the problem sets. The midterm and finals were not cumulative and were focused on what we did in class just the week and a half before. If you're a math concentrator you'll probably take this class because it is the only rigorous undergrad analysis class offered here, which is a real shame. But just go in with low expectations, and you'll probably have to learn analysis on your own if you ever want to understand it.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Analysis of Function Spaces, Measure and Integration

best_comment: Usually it's a pretty small class, which is nice for community and for sharing the experience. It's really an experience.
worse_comment: It is kind of difficult to stay on top of content in this course, and I am conflicted about the flipped classroom method. Learning is based on studying different kinds of problems and proofs, so it is helpful to organize content in your own way to develop understanding.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: I enjoyed this class a lot and would highly recommend it.I came into this without much experience in abstract math and found this course to be a great introduction. We covered linear algebra with a lot of rigor and I really liked the linear map–based approach in contrast to a matrix–centric approach. I definitely learned a lot! Math 121 covers roughly the same material as Math 25, but meets twice a week instead of three times; it works at the same level of rigor, but goes through material a little faster to fit everything in. I found the pace to be quite manageable. Ana is a really wonderful teacher – I've heard nothing but good things about her teaching, and I think that is true. She is incredibly organized and clear in her lectures. When introducing a new topic, she will often gauge the class's familiarity with some basic concepts, and she checks in with the class after the more convoluted proofs, making sure everyone is on the same page. The material is well motivated, rarely feeling arbitrary, which I really appreciated.The workload of this class was doable, but problem sets did take a fair bit of time to complete. There were a few particularly tricky questions scattered throughout the course, but this is Ana's first time teaching it, so I imagine such things are to be expected. While they were a lot of work, I really did learn a lot from them. One's first foray into abstract math can be difficult, and while the lectures were always understandable, I definitely did not feel solid on the psets at the beginning. I think this is to be expected, it is quite a transition. But learning how to make good use of office hours, and how to collaborate effectively with peers, is an incredibly important skill to learn, and office hours in particular helped me find my footing. So go to office hours, they were incredibly helpful! There are no answer keys for the problem sets, but CAs were always happy to answer any questions I had.The exams were generally reasonable, although I felt a little short for time when I took the midterms. Her grading was quite fair though. I do have to say though, I was not a huge fan of the grade breakdown for this course – the midterms and the final make up a combined 65% of your grade. Somewhat unfortunate. But oh well.I will say, if you are thinking about taking this course, check who is teaching it. It can change drastically depending on the Professor – I understand it was quite different last year. But if Ana is teaching it, I'd definitely recommend it! I learned a ton and found it to be a very good course.
worse_comment: This class is difficult for sure – having no answer key for the psets makes it very challenging to do, especially when the TFs sometimes also have no idea what's going on. Still, there's only one pset per week, and the class goes over material at a manageable pace.

course_title: Algebra I: Theory of Groups and Vector Spaces 001
best_comment: This class was a solid introduction to abstract math and it covered groups and rings. But it mostly focused on the fundamental notions and ideas and did not offer too much depth into group theory or ring theory. It exposed us to a good amount of abstract algebra. I can say that the course content is good, the lecture notes taken were amazing, but the psets were a bit grindy at times. They can require a lot of casework and proof by exhaustion. Also, a lot of times, the concepts we learned weren't motivated very well, so it felt a bit irrelevant and boring. However, it all makes sense at the end.I think Myrto is a pretty good lecturer, and most of the time lectures were pretty clear and approachable. I personally enjoyed group theory more than ring theory, but I found stuff related to number theory quite interesting at the end. I can say that this course is slightly slow if you previously took math 25 (or similar level of math). For me that was good, because it was an easy course. So, if you're looking for a nice math course to take, I would say you learn a good amount of material in the course but it is not overly challenging, and does not consume all your free time.
worse_comment: I think this is a tough course only because it condenses too much material. I think in–person examination is a terrible idea at this level since the point shouldn't be to  evaluate how quickly one can do math under such stressful conditions (like a 3 hour exam). The PSETS are challenging and will take up a lot of time.
subject: Mathematics
course_title_2023: Algebra I: Theory of Groups and Vector Spaces

best_comment: Many people describe topology to be very “abstract” and “difficult”––although I do believe that many of the things that I learned this semester were one of the most difficult objects to comprehend in my math career, I think professor DeMarco in Math 131 did a really, really nice job making these topological concepts very intuitive and almost natural. I took this class after having taken Math 25a/b, which roughly covers material from Math 121 (Linear Algebra) and Math 112 (Real Analysis). Since this course teaches topology from the very definition of a topology and builds from there, I think the only hard prerequisite is a proof–writing course, like Math 22a+/100–level math course. But I HIGHLY RECOMMEND having taken real analysis––having a level of background dealing with the topology of R^n will allow you to appreciate the course a lot more, since you will be generalizing these concepts to a lot of wacky spaces (for instance, what does it mean for a function to be continuous between two topological spaces which aren’t necessarily metric spaces?). I also think it’s difficult to realize the significance of topology without having seen it in action in real analysis. As for the group theory prerequisite (Math 122), I’m unable to speak much about it since I have not taken a group theory class yet. Hefty group theory is only used only in the last quarter of the course, so I think it’s the softest prerequisite. That being said, I feel that my understanding of the later topics in algebraic topology are a little superficial, so having a background in group theory will definitely help you appreciate topology at a deeper level.The class is very well taught, and professor DeMarco provides extremely intuitive descriptions for topological concepts––which I would’ve not understood just by reading the textbook. Unlike previous math courses that I’ve taken, there is a very significant portion of the class where professor DeMarco explains topics using drawings, instead of writing out a long proof on the black board. Professor DeMarco really emphasizes the understanding of the subject, which is great for a subject like topology that is difficult to comprehend, but she does expect us to read the textbook outside of class so that we get acquainted with the language and the formalism that is used in the proofs. Some proofs in class might be a little abbreviated, or even skipped, so it’s important to refer to the textbook for details. The topics you learn in this class are extremely useful and general––and will appear everywhere in math, especially if taking analysis/topology courses in the future. I highly recommend taking 131 with professor DeMarco to fulfill your Geometry/Topology requirement, not only because it’s the most foundational topology course, but because professor DeMarco teaches you to think like a topologist, and will equip you with a very strong understanding of topology.
worse_comment: This class is very difficult.  Be prepared to spend a lot of time every week puzzling over the problems, and do not get too far behind on the material at any given time.  The end of the course also picks up like crazy.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This is the best math class I have taken at Harvard so far. Puskar is a great instructor who really cares about whether you understand the material or not, letting you ask questions during class and giving very nuanced insights into how results should be viewed as well as the strategy to derive them. If you're considering taking this class or 132, I would recommend this class because I didn't take 132 (which is sometimes looked at as a pre–req or at least is helpful to know) but I found that I was able to understand all the material here without that class, so if you want to take a class in the 130s I highly recommend this class. I would also recommend going to office hours because they are super helpful for getting to know the instructors and to also get help on the problem sets.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course is certainly not easy content–wise – good course to take if you're like me, and forgot to take CS20. Will prepare you for proofs, and hopefully graph theory and whatnot for 124 in the spring. Taken concurrently with CS61 and 2 GenEds, and my courseload is manageable, if a bit easy. I'd 100% recommend taking this course if you're interested in a unique experience and don't care about the grade. Paul is an awesome teacher, with lots of funny stories, and he's a super kind dude. If Janna is still TF'ing, 1000% take this course, it will change your life and make you realize how awesome TFs can be. Also, don't worry about the grades. if you just do your PSETs and programming assignments, it will be impossible for you to get below a B in the class.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This course was difficult but rewarding! The material was really well chosen, and if you're interested in algebraic combinatorics, this course would be interesting for you. It was not the best–organized class I've taken, but Cesar tends to be available for questions and is a really great lecturer.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Do not take this course unless you're reasonably certain you want to do grad school in math. It is very, very hard, but also very rewarding if you put in the effort.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Math 221 is a very accessible graduate–level course for advanced undergraduates to take. It will be essential to have a strong background in algebra before the course, and I personally recommend (while not totally necessary) taking Math 123 to ensure a strong background in Galois theory. This is a great introduction to a foundational subject as well as some advanced topics, and Salim makes the subject very easy to digest with his skilled lectures. If you are interested in taking a graduate–level course in mathematics, I strongly recommend Math 221!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Don't be fooled by the fact that you don't require a lot of prerequisites for this class. If you have never seen any of the material here before, much of it will fly over your head like it flew over mine. Dr. Ye is a really nice person and fun to talk to 1 on 1, but his lecturing leaves much to be desired. He speeds through most of the beginning material to leave more time for the later topics on principal bundles and connections, which is quite a bad idea since by the time we reach said topics, we understand so little of what is going on earlier that there is a lot of difficulty understanding the later topics. The last two classes felt like absolute pop science to me, as he started dishing out many ideas from algebraic topology in addition to many modern theorems from differential geometry. I had no idea what I was supposed to get out of those classes except to "see" what the Yang–Mills equation was about. Furthermore, the textbook (Taubes) is really bad, and if you don't understand the material during lecture, don't even try to consult the textbook because it will definitely confuse you even more. Since he follows Taubes, trying to use another textbook (say Lee or Tu) proves to be quite challenging as well since the structure of the textbook is very different from the course material. Overall, an interesting class if you already know a bunch of differential geometry, but if you don't know jack like I did, be prepared to work very hard to gain very little.
worse_comment: I really do not recommend this course as it is taught now. The lectures are extremely dry and boring. Fan also never did any example problems, so it was very hard to translate the high–level ideas into homework problems. Something in–between would have been really appreciated. Fan also provided no intuition for the concepts that were introduced, so it was not helpful at all to go to lecture. I came in very excited about learning differential geometry and I exited the course extremely disillusioned. The math department needs to start taking teaching seriously. Many classes in the department are so poorly taught compared to any other department.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: This class is hard, but it's quite rewarding. Learning (co)homology is really important, and it's fun to see the topological fruit that comes from lots of algebraic labor. The material is difficult but not overwhelmingly so, and Andy is a great lecturer and makes everything easy to follow.
worse_comment: the course introduces concepts in algebraic topology which are absolutely essential for a working mathematician... why this is so is not demonstrated very well, and much of the material (definitions, theorems, techniques etc) feels unmotivated by broader questions or connections with other fields
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: A very tough class (probably the most difficult psets I've ever had) but incredibly rewarding (and Dori and Alice don't make it harder than it has to be). Compelling and enlightening lectures, terrific feedback, outstanding instructor support. If you have the background and the time, I'd recommend in the strongest possible terms.
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Amazing class, definitely worth taking!
subject: Mathematics

best_comment: Yeah so this class is hard but it's worth the effort. Did not realize how important micro local geometry was to so many fields, but this opens the door to the frontiers of many fields. Ben is really smart and goes fast, so keep that in mind.

course_title: Topics in Algebraic Geometry - Kodaira dimension and families of varieties 1
best_comment: Professor Popa is a great lecturer, everyone can learn a lot out of his class. I strongly recommend his class.
Great lectures, even better office hours. You'll learn how to live a good lifestyle with motives.

course_title: Tools and ideas in low-dimensional topology 1
best_comment: Prof. Kronheimer is an excellent lecturer and the course topics are very interesting. Definitely recommend if you want to get the lay of the land in this field.

course_title: Embedded Teaching Practicum (for Graduate Teaching Fellows) 001
best_comment: Unfortunately I think this may be the last iteration but I think while it could use some improvement in direct relevance it had a good intention behind the message it was trying to communicate.

Some instructors might not be able to give you useful feedback if they do something entirely different in their labs.

best_comment: I would say that this class is useful to people who might not have much experience in putting together a research proposal. That being said, I would also mention that the feedback will not be equally useful from section–to–section. Some instructors might not be able to give you useful feedback if they do something entirely different in their labs.
worse_comment: Expect to get most of your PQE proposal done, but without much help from the sections.

best_comment: Joe, John, and all the TFs work really hard to make sure everyone is comfortable with both the course material and their transitions into graduate school more broadly. This is apparent from day 1 and makes for a very fun (and unintimidating!) learning environment. I am more of a cell bio person myself (sorry Joe!), but the faculty and fellows were so helpful and personable and always kept the class interesting.
subject: Biolog Chem & Molecular Pharm

best_comment: This class is amazing as someone who is passionate about medicine, either pre–med or from a research standpoint. As an undergraduate, I definitely was out of my depth several times in a class geared more towards graduate students, but the course does a good job of bridging gaps in knowledge as long as you're passionate about the subject material and willing to be diligent with reading the papers.

best_comment: This course tries to achieve a difficult task of being both a foundational knowledge course while also being a research survey course, and it ends up feeling like it does a half–baked job at both. If you are interested in learning about a broad range of topics in bioinformatics but without going into much depth on any particular topic, this could be a good course to take.
worse_comment: This class is challenging  due to its lack of structure and the various assumptions of knowledge made by the different faculty members. I would not recommend this class.
subject: Biomedical Informatics

course_title: Teaching 100: The Theory and Science of Teaching 001
best_comment: This is a great course to take if you are interested in pedagogy. You get to read many pieces of primary literature on education studies and see the data of the studies behind various pedagogical practices. Tari is an excellent instructor who presents the material in an easy–to–digest manner while simultaneously promoting lots of active discussion among the class. Tari made the classroom environment very welcoming which helped students feel comfortable speaking up.
subject: Cell Biology
course_title_2023: Teaching 100: The Theory and Science of Teaching

best_comment: This is a very challenging class, but pushing through to the end feels very rewarding. I would also make sure they understand that you cannot be expected to know every single concept in absolute detail for the course, and perform well in all of them. That's a part of being in the science field, and adapting that mindset will really help you get through the class, even if you do not start out well.
worse_comment: sections are essential and working on practice problems is essential

course_title: Tumor Microenvironment and Immuno-Oncology: A Systems Biology Approach 001
best_comment: This is a great class for anyone who hasn't taken a cancer biology class yet. Professor Jain does a great job with bringing leading researchers from Harvard and MIT to talk about their research and how it applies to solid tumors. The course is very flexible, where the assignments are not actually graded but are simply there to help students manage their time to write and complete the project. The final project itself is challenging and takes a lot of time (roughly 2–4 hours/week on average, with the last couple of weeks or so being more like 6–8 hours/week) and requires you to take meaningful time to think through the scientific problems you want to solve. However, the project is fulfilling and can be taken in any direction that the student wishes. I felt like I learned a lot in this class and am glad I took it despite the heavier than average workload.
worse_comment: If you are looking for a more physiological and cellular perspective on cancer, this is a great and broad introduction to just that. It is accessible to many students and gives you the tools to speak and write about cancer.

course_title: Principles of Human Disease: Physiology and Pathology 001
best_comment: This is one of the best classes I've ever taken at Harvard. You just go over to Longwood and tbh ur just vibing the whole time. The science and lecturers are super exciting, and this is the ONLY class where I haven't absolutely hated the flipped format.

best_comment: I think it is best to focus on what you can learn from the lectures, and just try not to let the assignments and assessments bother you too much. The lectures are really great, and even with a strong immunology background, you will certainly learn immunology, which is why you are there.
worse_comment: I would be hesitant to tell non–immunology students to take this course, and it's required for immunology students.

best_comment: While there are no assessments via homework or quizzes, this course requires active participation in discussions each day and thereby a thorough reading of all the assigned papers and figures prior to the class. Unless you already have a background in immunology, this may be time–consuming and challenging.
worse_comment: I think you should definitely take this course if you're interested in cancer immunology, cancer, or immunology. Particularly, it might be helpful for first–year graduate students trying to get their toes wet with actively and critically reading literature.
subject: Immunology

best_comment: Although this course is an annoying requirement at times, I also think it can be a good opportunity to reflect more deeply about pros and cons of academia and hear from a wider variety of students their perspectives on the topic. By G6 fall we should already be doing this, but I feel many of the discussions set up by the course were not topics I would've thought as carefully about nor got as many different opinions on otherwise. Discussions were usually fun and at times legit helpful. This experience probably varies quite a lot depending on what group leader you end up with, but I'd advise trying to take the course seriously going into the semester and be optimistic about the value of the discussion sections. More concretely, I'd highly recommend Jeff Moffitt's section if you can. We regularly dove into much more interesting topics than the scripted course material.
worse_comment: Graduate before it is required you take this nonsense again.

course_title: Mechanisms of Bacterial Pathogenesis and Host Immune Response 001
best_comment: This class is perfect for those interested in the fields of microbiology and how bacteria can cause disease. It does have a lot of scientific reading, and you will definitely become better at reading scientific papers from it, but it is very approachable and interesting.

best_comment: I think future students should try to embody the excitement of the professor even if they don't necessarily feel excited about the content. It makes it much easier to engage, discuss, and ask questions when you are enthusiastic about the topic. I would also say that everything builds off everything, so it is important not to get behind otherwise it'll be much more difficult to understand lectures in the future.

course_title: Authority and Invention: Medieval Art and Architecture 001
best_comment: If you are interested in architecture, religion, or medieval history you should take this course. The professor has a great pedagogy that involves some level of memorization, which is easy if you do a little bit each week, and not cram the day before the exam. But once you have the memorization down you will really begin to understand how to look at a building. Aside from that you gain a great knowledge of what influences architecture and what its meaning is, the interplay with history, theology, and other factors. Truly an excellent course, and it counts for history concentration credit.
worse_comment: I truly believe the content makes for a very promising and robust course, but it is in deeply unsuitable hands. Professor Smith does not make a welcoming environment for students; in fact it is more hostile and unsafe than anything else, as she is genuinely rude and unreasonably curt in her written feedback and is quick to shut down opinions in discussions that might not align with her own. She shows clear favorites among the class and looks down mockingly and resentfully at the students who struggle a bit more with the material, never offering to actually help in any way. Finally, she cannot tell the difference between her Asian students and I honestly felt so bad watching her read a Chinese student’s name on the board and then look around for the nearest Asian person instead of even trying to get to know her students. This professor singlehandedly genuinely made studying architecture incredibly unpleasant for me.

best_comment: This course attracts a significant number of very conservative Christian undergraduates. They are generally nice but I didn't always have the best experiences with some of them outside of class, including being told that I was "morally debased" at a party by one classmate while another nodded along. This greatly diminished my experience in class and negatively affected my ability to learn in lectures and sections. Professor Donahue and Max, the TF, are opposed to such views and are excellent and compassionate teachers. That said, future students should know this class seems to attract students that hold views the larger Harvard community finds abhorrent. This was my favorite course until the party incident. I end the semester with it being my least favorite class in my four years at Harvard. Nonetheless, if you have thick skin I highly recommend taking this course. The course material and teachers are excellent and I've grown greatly from this course. I hope what happened to me does not happen to you and that you strongly consider taking this course while considering my reservations. If you believe you wouldn't be able to learn in a fabulous class that also attracts bigots, I recommend not taking this course. That would be a loss though, as the underlying course is excellent.
subject: Medieval Studies

best_comment: This is one of my favorite classes I've ever taken at Harvard! Dr. Etcoff is a leader in her field but she's super humble and down to earth. She seems to genuinely enjoy facilitating student discussions and can speak on a wide variety of topics. If you have any interest at all in neuroscience, art, architecture, fashion, medicine or just hope to gain a more emotionally informed life perspective you'll definitely enjoy this class.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem — fascinating topics, wonderful instructor. Coming to class every Thursday brightened up my whole week. If you have the opportunity to take this course, please enroll!
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: The Role of Music in Health and Education 1
best_comment: This course is super fun and really fascinating! The seminar formatting makes it a lot easier to get to know one another in the class, and discussions are always really interesting to listen to and participate in. Regarding workload, there are two relatively informal presentations and a final paper, in addition to short weekly discussions, so it's definitely very manageable. All of the guest speakers (and the teaching staff) are truly wonderful as well! If you have any interest in music, science, and/or healthcare, I'd definitely recommend this course :)
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior
course_title_2023: The Role of Music in Health and Education

course_title: Psychopaths and Psychopathy: Psychological, Neuroscientific, Legal, and Policy Issues 1
best_comment: This class was great. The topic is a really interesting one, and you get room to explore whatever aspects of psychopathy you find interesting as well as become interested in new aspects (biological, social, behavioral, legal, etc).  The class is also extremely non–stressful––the work each week is reading 2–3 papers and writing a one paragraph discussion post, and then there is a short case study of a psychopath and a final paper on any topic. It's really more about the class discussions than any assessments/grades. The class discussions are usually on interesting topics, and the professor is amazing and hilarious.
best_gem_comment: This course is so interesting. I liked how well the topic connects with the philosophy of responsibility and real–life situations. It definitely is a gem, and I could not recommend it enough! The assignments are really fun too!
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior
course_title_2023: Psychopaths and Psychopathy: Psychological, Neuroscientific, Legal, and Policy Issues

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!! It's literally so good!! You connect with the students and professor on such a deep level in this setting. The papers are fascinating, the material is accessible, and by the end of the class, you'll be convinced that meditation is the answer to so many problems. We got to start class with a short meditation, then informally discuss the readings + add in our own philosophies on things. I'm not very neuro–experienced, but I had a great time steering the conversation to more philosophical places instead or just learning from others. And the only big assignment is a paper at the end.Michael is unbelievably amazing. Everyone in our class loved him. He and the TFs did everything in their power to construct the most beautiful, accepting, and flexible space for all of us.As a South Asian, I think this course was done really well in terms of treating South Asian culture properly. Nothing felt patronizing, offensive, exoticizing, etc. It was honestly such a beautiful opportunity for me to finally get to learn about something so near and dear to my culture in a proper academic setting. We need more classes like this.This class will be your favorite class of the week, and you'll be sad it only meets once a week because waiting for the next class period is no fun.Workload is super reasonable! It's really what you make of it–– you can get by with skimming the papers, but if you have the capacity in your schedule to read them a bit thoroughly, really engage on the discussion boards, etc., you'll find this stuff so much more fascinating.Again, just please take this class, ESPECIALLY if Michael is the one teaching it again. I think Dr. Lazar isn't as laid back, so apply what I've said there^^ to if *Michael* is teaching the class.
subject: Mind, Brain & Behavior

course_title: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology 001
best_comment: LS1A is a lot and moves quickly. It is VERY important to stay on top of your work, and if you do, you can succeed. For context, I came in mainly having done research and science competitions in high school and also did well in the class so that is the perspective from which I'm providing advice. The first half of the class is chemistry so it is a lot more chemistry than the name implies. Also, there is an emphasis on applying the material as opposed to memorizing it. Also, it's a requirement so here's an objective review on what you can do to succeed in the course.There are a lot of moving parts to this course, so you need to stay on top of it.Problem Sets – Only piece of advice is to go do Psets in Sien's office hours or SSN. You can finish the entire thing and probably get 100% on all of the psets. Just go to Sien's office hours or SSN and start and finish. There is no need to sit by yourself and struggle over your upset with these resources. Office Hours – Go to Sien and Rebecca's office hours. They care so much about making sure you actually know the material and your wellbeing. Going to their office hours once will help clarify everything (I mean it) that you are confused about. On weeks you have lab assignments, you can often knock out the lab assignment and Pset before the weekend.Learning Pods – Read the textbook and stay ON TOP OF IT (taking notes) throughout the entire semester. I think this was the biggest differentiator between people who did relatively well and people who were stressing every time the finals rolled around. Learning pod videos are essentially a duplicate of the textbook material and so is lecture so you don't really need to pay attention. Lectures are meant to be supplementary (not where you learn the material) and just skip through the learning pod videos to the quiz unless you are confused by something in the textbook. Then it's nice to go back and watch the videos, but ONLY IF YOU ARE CONFUSED. Otherwise, it's a waste of time.Lectures – Lectures are often repeats of the textbook/learning pods but sometimes its nice to pay attention when they give out Pset help. Otherwise, do something more productive during lecture.PIEs – You have to learn how to take PIEs. Each question is trying to test you on a certain topic and if you can figure it out you'll be able to do it (aka do not overthink the problems). They are lowkey stressful because they are biweekly and they can be a lot when you have two of them sandwiched with a midterm. Do the practice PIE questions and take good notes because they are open notes. Also, in the grand scheme of things, each PIE is not worth that much (2%) and you do get a drop. Make sure you are careful and take it with a calm mind.Midterms – Midterms are very fair. There aren't any curveball questions and it feels like a longer PIE. The best studying you can do is to make a good cheat sheet by reviewing the labs, problem sets, section handouts, and your notes (they don't give practice midterms which is weird). Be aware though that they are pretty brutal with partial credit. It's also good to make your midterm cheat sheets online so that for future midterms your life is much easier. Final – They give you a practice final and I thought it was similar to the midterms in terms of fairness and what they expect you to know. Many questions are similar to the practice final.Section – If you read the textbook, then section might not be the most helpful but it's helpful to have a section leader who is good with grading because they are the ones who grade all of your assignments. Additionally, the handouts are useful because they often provide concise summaries. The most important thing with this course is to not drown in the details and section handouts help distill the core information and the broader patterns that LS1A wants you to know. It's super important to develop a sense of what these broader patterns that they are testing you on are.A dark side of LS1A is that they curve and sometimes this can mean down. In the past when there were no midterms and only open note PIEs, the cutoff for an A was between a 95 and 97 depending on who you ask. I don't know how midterms will factor into this (overall the midterm grades helped even out the distribution and I think will help the curve) but if you want a good grade, just follow the above advice and you'll be able to get an A. Just figure out how the course works and you will do well. Overall, I do think it is a good intro to bio and chem, it's just a lot
worse_comment: This class was very hard. I took AP Biology and Honors Chemistry in high school but was not prepared for the material we learned in this class. I also took time–consuming classes alongside it (a gem gen–ed Race and Justice,  Math 22a, CS50) so I never had enough time to fully learn all of the information so if you have a lighter course load than this class may be easier for you, though most of my friends did not like this class. I feel like lectures were not helpful and I had to heavily depend on section to learn the material. Watch the learning pods and take notes from them if you have time. PIEs killed me in terms of time limit, you  have 40 minutes and as someone who takes a bit longer to process questions it was really hard to complete the quiz as thoroughly as I wanted to. Also the graders are harsh with the points and sometimes take off a lot of points for small mistakes. I honestly wish I took LPS–A instead even though I am a premed with AP science background because this class made me hate science and will not be good for my gpa.

subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2023: An Integrated Introduction to the Life Sciences: Chemistry, Molecular Biology, and Cell Biology

best_comment: This class is a great experience. You learn a lot from a large variety of topics, some of which I had some background on before coming to college (cell cycle, genetics) and some of which I had never heard of (stat mech), but all of which we learned interesting new ways of thinking about. I was worried that I would not have enough math experience coming in, as I had only done up to AP calculus (while many I talked to had taken multi or linear algebra), but this was not the case. While almost every unit has a math based approach, most of the math is well weaved into the other topics, and I did not need more than my knowledge of integrals/derivatives from BC calc (they sometimes use more complicated stuff in lectures so that we can know where their values came from, but you typically don't need to know how to replicate them for assignments). Prior experience with Python or a similar coding language is helpful, but not necessary as they will review everything you need to know and there will inevitably be someone in your class who knows how to code and can help you. I was also worried because I did not have any research experience coming in, but this wasn't a big problem either. Most people in the class have lab experience, which made me feel inexperienced, but they talked us through everything we needed to know in lab, so it wasn't a big deal. In terms of the bio/chem/physics content, it is mostly bio, and you should be fine if you did well in high school AP bio/chem. The PSETs are difficult and you should start them early in the week and go to CA office hours, but they are not so long that you physically cannot finish them in the day or two before (it will just be a terrible experience), and there is only 1 a week (as opposed to the 4 a week you'd have between Math21a and LS1a). Organize study groups early in the year to make friends and stay on top of your work. LS50 is not the guaranteed bonding experience some of the Qreports make it out to be, but if you put in some effort to go to study sessions and talk to people in the class, you'll definitely meet some good friends.  The midterms (our year at least) are easier than the PSETs, so if you do well on them and the practice exam, you are probably well prepared. If you are worried about workload and settling into, you could take a GenEd and a Freshman Seminar (like I did) with LS50, but honestly, it was not as much work as I thought it would be and I wish I'd taken a harder 3rd class.  The professors, TFs, and CAs were all amazing our year (Andrew Murray was on sabbatical, so I can't say for him, but Michael, Emma, Ben, and Kara were fantastic). They all have regular office hours (though most fell in times I couldn't attend, so I suppose I can't speak to their quality) and give engaging lectures with helpful slides (well.... Michael's can be a bit hard to follow, but you the classes are recorded so you can just rewatch parts). The CAs and TFs also office hours/PSET sessions which are very helpfulI can't say much about the labs since they change every year, but getting to do original research for the first time was very cool (even if I don't want to look at another ant for the rest of my life), but three straight hours every tuesday on top of an hour of LS50 and potentially an hour of another class is A LOT, but it was doable once we got through the initial lecture based lab sessions. If you are in a lab section right after class, make sure to eat some lunch. The cafe on the first floor of Northwest has some decent food and accepts Board Plus.  LS50 will NOT take over your life. It will be a heavy time commitment, and you will have to study a lot, but it does not have to consume your every waking moment. I had plenty of time to join clubs, make friends, and relax (except maybe in the day or two right before a midterm). I highly recommend this class because your first semester can feel strange and overwhelming, and it's grounding to have a regular class that meets every weekday and is a similar size to high school classes. Overall, this class is not easy, but I don't think it is much harder than taking LS1a and a math course, and instead of two large, generic classes, you get a more unique and personal experience from the small class size and original research.
best_gem_comment: If you have any intention of wanting to pursue research in the life sciences, this course is for you! Don't let the reputation of the course scare you – if you really love biology and you're ok with calculus (you don't have to love math – I didn't), the course is enough fun that it will feel like less work than it actually is. Now, that doesn't mean that you should overload your schedule – this course takes TIME – a lot of it – but it's a course that I was glad that I took not just at the end, but at every moment throughout the course, including at my toughest moments. The community that LS50 builds is incredible and the fun that you will have doing psets together and just hanging out will be some of the best fun of your first semester. Also, the lab, in my opinion, is the gem of the course – you get to do original research on incredibly interesting topics (for us, it was ant evolutionary biology!) in a very chill environment, which is such a rare opportunity for first–year undergrads. My main suggestion would be to go to ALL of the office hours – for all of the lecturers, all of the TFs, and all of the CA drop–in hours. Not only will it make everything so much easier, but the relationships that you build with the course staff in this tiny class are incredible and they're really great and nice people to get to know.

The CAs and TFs also office hours/PSET sessions which are very helpfulI can't say much about the labs since they change every year, but getting to do original research for the first time was very cool (even if I don't want to look at another ant for the rest of my life), but three straight hours every tuesday on top of an hour of LS50 and potentially an hour of another class is A LOT, but it was doable once we got through the initial lecture based lab sessions. If you are in a lab section right after class, make sure to eat some lunch. The cafe on the first floor of Northwest has some decent food and accepts Board Plus.  LS50 will NOT take over your life. It will be a heavy time commitment, and you will have to study a lot, but it does not have to consume your every waking moment. I had plenty of time to join clubs, make friends, and relax (except maybe in the day or two right before a midterm). I highly recommend this class because your first semester can feel strange and overwhelming, and it's grounding to have a regular class that meets every weekday and is a similar size to high school classes. Overall, this class is not easy, but I don't think it is much harder than taking LS1a and a math course, and instead of two large, generic classes, you get a more unique and personal experience from the small class size and original research.
best_gem_comment: If you have any intention of wanting to pursue research in the life sciences, this course is for you! Don't let the reputation of the course scare you – if you really love biology and you're ok with calculus (you don't have to love math – I didn't), the course is enough fun that it will feel like less work than it actually is. Now, that doesn't mean that you should overload your schedule – this course takes TIME – a lot of it – but it's a course that I was glad that I took not just at the end, but at every moment throughout the course, including at my toughest moments. The community that LS50 builds is incredible and the fun that you will have doing psets together and just hanging out will be some of the best fun of your first semester. Also, the lab, in my opinion, is the gem of the course – you get to do original research on incredibly interesting topics (for us, it was ant evolutionary biology!) in a very chill environment, which is such a rare opportunity for first–year undergrads. My main suggestion would be to go to ALL of the office hours – for all of the lecturers, all of the TFs, and all of the CA drop–in hours. Not only will it make everything so much easier, but the relationships that you build with the course staff in this tiny class are incredible and they're really great and nice people to get to know.
subject: Life Sciences

best_comment: This class is a great experience. You learn a lot from a large variety of topics, some of which I had some background on before coming to college (cell cycle, genetics) and some of which I had never heard of (stat mech), but all of which we learned interesting new ways of thinking about. I was worried that I would not have enough math experience coming in, as I had only done up to AP calculus (while many I talked to had taken multi or linear algebra), but this was not the case. While almost every unit has a math based approach, most of the math is well weaved into the other topics, and I did not need more than my knowledge of integrals/derivatives from BC calc (they sometimes use more complicated stuff in lectures so that we can know where their values came from, but you typically don't need to know how to replicate them for assignments). Prior experience with Python or a similar coding language is helpful, but not necessary as they will review everything you need to know and there will inevitably be someone in your class who knows how to code and can help you. I was also worried because I did not have any research experience coming in, but this wasn't a big problem either. Most people in the class have lab experience, which made me feel inexperienced, but they talked us through everything we needed to know in lab, so it wasn't a big deal. In terms of the bio/chem/physics content, it is mostly bio, and you should be fine if you did well in high school AP bio/chem. The PSETs are difficult and you should start them early in the week and go to CA office hours, but they are not so long that you physically cannot finish them in the day or two before (it will just be a terrible experience), and there is only 1 a week (as opposed to the 4 a week you'd have between Math21a and LS1a). Organize study groups early in the year to make friends and stay on top of your work. LS50 is not the guaranteed bonding experience some of the Qreports make it out to be, but if you put in some effort to go to study sessions and talk to people in the class, you'll definitely meet some good friends.  The midterms (our year at least) are easier than the PSETs, so if you do well on them and the practice exam, you are probably well prepared. If you are worried about workload and settling into, you could take a GenEd and a Freshman Seminar (like I did) with LS50, but honestly, it was not as much work as I thought it would be and I wish I'd taken a harder 3rd class.  The professors, TFs, and CAs were all amazing our year (Andrew Murray was on sabbatical, so I can't say for him, but Michael, Emma, Ben, and Kara were fantastic). They all have regular office hours (though most fell in times I couldn't attend, so I suppose I can't speak to their quality) and give engaging lectures with helpful slides (well.... Michael's can be a bit hard to follow, but you the classes are recorded so you can just rewatch parts). The CAs and TFs also office hours/PSET sessions which are very helpfulI can't say much about the labs since they change every year, but getting to do original research for the first time was very cool (even if I don't want to look at another ant for the rest of my life), but three straight hours every tuesday on top of an hour of LS50 and potentially an hour of another class is A LOT, but it was doable once we got through the initial lecture based lab sessions. If you are in a lab section right after class, make sure to eat some lunch. The cafe on the first floor of Northwest has some decent food and accepts Board Plus.  LS50 will NOT take over your life. It will be a heavy time commitment, and you will have to study a lot, but it does not have to consume your every waking moment. I had plenty of time to join clubs, make friends, and relax (except maybe in the day or two right before a midterm). I highly recommend this class because your first semester can feel strange and overwhelming, and it's grounding to have a regular class that meets every weekday and is a similar size to high school classes. Overall, this class is not easy, but I don't think it is much harder than taking LS1a and a math course, and instead of two large, generic classes, you get a more unique and personal experience from the small class size and original research.
best_gem_comment: If you have any intention of wanting to pursue research in the life sciences, this course is for you! Don't let the reputation of the course scare you – if you really love biology and you're ok with calculus (you don't have to love math – I didn't), the course is enough fun that it will feel like less work than it actually is. Now, that doesn't mean that you should overload your schedule – this course takes TIME – a lot of it – but it's a course that I was glad that I took not just at the end, but at every moment throughout the course, including at my toughest moments. The community that LS50 builds is incredible and the fun that you will have doing psets together and just hanging out will be some of the best fun of your first semester. Also, the lab, in my opinion, is the gem of the course – you get to do original research on incredibly interesting topics (for us, it was ant evolutionary biology!) in a very chill environment, which is such a rare opportunity for first–year undergrads. My main suggestion would be to go to ALL of the office hours – for all of the lecturers, all of the TFs, and all of the CA drop–in hours. Not only will it make everything so much easier, but the relationships that you build with the course staff in this tiny class are incredible and they're really great and nice people to get to know.
subject: Life Sciences

course_title: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences 001
best_comment: If you still need to complete your semester of research requirement for something like neuroscience, I would highly recommend this course ! You will work closely with a project leader and 2–3 (sometimes a bit more) members of your group to complete a research project for the semester. All of the topics are really interesting, so don't worry about getting one that you're not initially crazy about (that was my case, and I ended up loving it!). The lectures by project leaders and presentations by all the different research teams was truly a highlight of this course. All students were able to learn about each other's research and able to learn from the project leaders, who are themselves leaders in their own research. I really appreciated the collaborative nature of the course. All in all, I highly recommend taking this course ! Especially if you don't yet have much research under your belt.
worse_comment: Your experience in this course can be really hit or miss depending on which project you get. My project was deceptively straightforward and low stress before it began to amp up severely and became very stressful and confusing. You should be prepared to be on top of your project assignment. Overall though, would recommend. Not too bad if you're on top of it.
subject: Life Sciences
course_title_2023: Experimental Research in the Life Sciences

best_comment: Take this class! Although the lab component may be a bit time consuming, the actual course content is super interesting if you're at all interested in molecular biology. The lab component is also super helpful for bringing down the barriers that some people may feel towards science, so please please please give this course a shot, and don't be discouraged by the difficulty up front! The course staff is great. Dominic and Audrey are absolute gems that should be protected at all costs. They are both insanely knowledgeable, and truly amazing people to sit and chat with, so take advantage of them as resources if you take the course. Which you should.
worse_comment: Be wary. I've come in with certain expectations, but it was MUCH worse. It was mainly due to confusing lectures from Vlad Denic, but also because the course as a whole felt unstructured for the student. The assessments are bad –– "usually the first midterm is the worst and the rest are better," they say, but it was actually horrible for the first two exams and made a lot of people feel like crap. It's also really hard to study for them because the course content is so broad and theoretical, that we don't know of "practical" applications for exam questions. Just be prepared to go to Office Hours and hope you have a good lab group.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Take this class! Although the lab component may be a bit time consuming, the actual course content is super interesting if you're at all interested in molecular biology. subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Take this class! It's as gemmy of a true biology course as you can find. The exams are fair and frequent enough that no single exam makes or breaks your grade. The course staff are definitely very knowledgeable in their own fields, and Professor Viel is amazing. He has a very dry sense of humor that makes lectures fun to attend. There is a flipped classroom element that can be kind of annoying to keep up with because it can feel like busywork, but you actually have to do it. I personally needed to watch the videos thoroughly and take notes on them to be successful, but I know many others who were fine just watching on 2x speed to complete the required quiz. The material we cover is integral to MCAT studying as well. I wish I'd taken this a bit later, so I could lighten a harder semester and be closer to my MCAT date, but overall I'm so glad I took this class and would absolutely recommend to any MCB/CPB concentrator or pre–med.
best_gem_comment: This is a great class if you need to cover the biochem premed requirement! I am taking chem 20 and chem 27 instead of one of the usual sequences and this is such a gem to fulfill the biochem class. There's not a ton of work– tests every other week on about 3 lectures worth of material and PSETs other week. The section is helpful so I would definitely go. The tests also aren't bad and focus on big picture ideas instead of insane details.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This course is awesome! The teaching staff is very knowledgeable, supportive, and interesting, and the course topics are equally as interesting. Take this course if you are considering studying psychology or neuroscience, I think it's a great introductory class that will give you a sense of whether those fields are for you. The class is also hybrid, and that's been helpful for me on a busy schedule. The course is forgiving and has a strong infrastructure, so it's not too stressful a class at all!
worse_comment: If you do not need to take this course, don’t unless you enjoy being forced to teach yourself the material. It was a waste of time.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Amazing course!
worse_comment: Start the paper early! You don't want to work hard all semester and then turn in a paper that isn't your best work.

course_title_2023: Research for Credit in Molecular and Cellular Biology

best_comment: Have clear communication with PI and MCB, lean on other thesising friends, and overall enjoy learning cool things YOU discover!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Have clear communication with PI and MCB, lean on other thesising friends, and overall enjoy learning cool things YOU discover!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This is really hard course. Work together. Support each other. Find help ASAP. This class will eat up so much of your time. The sooner you find your support group, the better it will be for your mental health. And don't blame the professor. It is not the professor's fault. They care about you. It's how the course is structured and the material being taught. People have complained about this course for YEARS. Literal years. And nothing has changed. Don't expect it to change. Hate the class, not the prof.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This is an amazing class and it's suitable for students with a variety of backgrounds. I'd recommend this course if you are interested in biology, cs, math, statistics, or any combination of those fields. Sean is an amazing professor. His lectures were pretty good in my opinion. The problem sets can be challenging at times, but nothing too difficult to handle. I will say that some background in statistics and cs will go a long way in this course. However, don't feel discouraged if you don't have that background. It's still possible to do well. I also really appreciated the fact that our entire grade depended on the psets. I still felt like I got a lot out of the course, even without exams. Overall, mcb112 is an excellent course and I highly recommend it!
worse_comment: Do not take this class if you have weak python and math skills or have not taken calculus and probability. This course is very heavily laden with math and programming.

course_title: Neurobiology of Perception and Decision Making 001
best_comment: If you are looking for a way to fulfill your advanced neuro requirement, take this course. Such a straightforward, easy workload that is so fair. The content is also really interesting. It can sometimes be hard to listen to Nao because he isn't the most engaging speaker, but meet with him one–on–one to get to know just cool he is. The TF saved all of us this semester.

I highly recommend this course! Professor Losick is an incredible educator and is extremely passionate about this material! Professor Losick presents a personal side to the study of the history of molecular biology that you will not find anywhere else. This is one of the courses at Harvard that every student should take! Whether you study science, history, or truly any field, you will find this course extremely enjoyable and interesting. Our society depends on a number of different developments that have come from the field of molecular biology.  Professor Losick will guide you on a tour through the ages to study these incredible discoveries and learn about and meet some of the incredible scientists who made biology what it is today. For the final project, you will have the opportunity to research a scientist who made an impact in molecular biology. Professor Losick also helps students find scientists and stories that will be meaningful to them. For example, in my final project, I studied an Italian scientist of whom I had never heard prior to the course, but who epitomized resilience and was personally meaningful to me. Throughout the course and for the final project, Professor Losick is incredibly helpful outside of class and his office hours are always an enjoyable time where you will learn a great deal and get advice from one of the world's foremost scientists. I cannot recommend this course enough!
best_gem_comment: This is one of the best courses I've taken at Harvard! Rich is incredibly knowledgable, inspiring, and kind. Taking this course reaffirmed my desire to pursue a career in research. The course was easy, but I took so much away from the class. The best gem you can take!
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This is a great class! Maxim is a talented lecturer and thoughtful professor, and the material he put together is very interesting. I would recommend it to undergraduates as well as grad students. The required background is not extensive (basic undergrad Physics and Biology), but if you put in the work it will be a very rewarding class. The weekly journal clubs take some time, but are completion graded and will improve your presentation skills.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: This course is overall so great! Shiv is an amazing professor and spends the last ten minutes of each class theatrically reciting poems he wrote about the day's lecture (AND he has them fully memorized!). It is so clear that Shiv loves teaching and truly cares about his students–– he is such a special professor.  The material is so fascinating but the course organization is poor. Definitely READ THE TEXTBOOK! I spent the two days before the final reading about 700 of the textbook and it really helped tie all the concepts together. I don't recommend doing this, however. Instead, keep pace with the course and read one to two chapters each week––it will really help you understand the lecture material and get more out of the class. The midterm exam was not too bad; however, it was only one long question so if you got one part wrong, you lost a significant amount of points. The final was really hard, honestly, and touched on concepts we didn't learn in section or lecture. Study well in advance and know as much as you can for this.
worse_comment: be aware of psets, it is hard to gauge what they are actually looking for you to answer. read the textboo and take notes, make study guides every week to consolidate information. don't want until October for midterm to study.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: I would highly recommend that you take Prof. Bellono's course. Really great structure. A wonderful opportunity to learn about the diversity and complexities of ion channels, which serve such fundamental biological functions, without undue stress to think or do a certain way when it comes to assignments. Exceptionally kind and understanding course staff. Assignments are structured to keep you engaged throughout the semester with a few larger assignments that open up the opportunity for you to pursue specific areas that pique your interest. Exciting guest speakers interspersed throughout the course. If you have the chance, I think you would enjoy this course.
worse_comment: Overall a solid course, but is not super well structured
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

course_title: Cellular Biology, Neurobiology and Developmental Biology 001
best_comment: This class, although may seem super annoying and not worth your time, is actually so useful. I came in really confident about my presenting abilities. I know I am a great presenter. However, this class was still super useful and helped me further improve my public speaking abilities. There are so many ways to present well. So many different styles. Pay attention and figure out what you like and want to incorporate into your style.
subject: Molecular & Cellular Biology

best_comment: Definitey join HRO! Although it can be a bit of a time commitment, the community is awesome and music making level is very high!
subject: Music

best_comment: Collegium is one of the warmest, most welcoming communities that I've found on campus, and it doesn't hurt that they're one of the most musically talented. If you like good music, friends, and performances, it's wonderful.
subject: Music

best_comment: If you are in the Glee Club and have space in your schedule there is no reason not to take Music 15! There is already a big time commitment with rehearsals and trips, so I'd say getting credit for it makes a lot of sense. The Harvard Glee Club has the best community among the Choirs, for sure. It does feel like a family, with traditions and huge support. Really, I've had immense financial support for tails, and get to travel to sing for free. Andrew, our conductor, is also the type of person I know cares a lot about the singers, and if ever needed to talk to hum, I know he will be around the corner. So, if you like music and are open to learning more about it with other cool people, join and take Music 15!!!
worse_comment: Do problem 2ä only.
subject: Music

best_comment: Look at who is conducting when deciding. If it's still Meg and Liz on staff, then definitely do it – even if you haven't sung before! If it's Andy and some new people, I would shop it but think about how you learn music best and your background. RCS is a great community though – probably the best of the three HarChor choirs
subject: Music

best_comment: I would recommend this class to anyone who is looking to major in music. At first, it does appear to be pretty easy, however I can assure you that it does get more difficult, and one strong point of the class is its ability to cater to different ability levels. All of the teaching staff are really friendly, approachable, and helpful, and the workload isn’t too big. The final exam was surprisingly simple – it really is a low–stress class.
worse_comment: It's exactly what you expect. Difficult but necessary for most music stuff.
subject: Music

best_comment: HRO remains one of my favorite parts of Harvard.  When I arrived on campus my freshman year, filled with anxiety and raging imposter syndrome, HRO was the first home I found.  I knew I wanted to join, so I auditioned and joined.  When we went on retreat that first Labor Day weekend, I suddenly felt at home.  I loved getting to know everyone in the orchestra, and sitting in the orchestra is one of the few places at Harvard where I feel I truly have a way to give back to this university that gives me so much.  A year and a half later, HRO has only grown more important to me.  Many of my favorite memories so far at Harvard have been made through HRO; unforgettable concerts, fun rehearsal memories, and wonderful times with friends at HRO social functions outside of rehearsals.  Many of my closest friends have been made through HRO.  It's the most important community to me at Harvard and the extracurricular to which I am most devoted.
worse_comment: HRO already rehearses quite a bit (7.5 hrs/wk) and taking this course binds you (by grades) to attendance, which is sometimes inconvenient.
subject: Music

best_comment: The pieces we work on can be difficult, but there are so many people willing to help you, and the concerts are always so rewarding
subject: Music

best_comment: Great course if you are in jazz band – doesn't add a ton of work to your plate and is a good way to learn more about what you are playing within the ensemble.
subject: Music

best_comment: This class was so lovely! But, you should be very interested in music or vocal music if you want to take this class.
subject: Music

best_comment: Take this class!! I had a wonderful time in this course and strongly encourage anyone remotely interested in music to take it. The course is not stressful and really allows you to focus on learning the analytical principles through readings, class examples, and homework assignments without the stress of exams. Professor Duguay is very knowledgeable and loves to talk to students during the class break or over email; it is very clear that she enjoys teaching and discussing music. The class has a pretty set workload with readings and a homework assignment every week which I found manageable even when taking harder courses (like organic chemistry) at the same time. Section is sometimes helpful, sometimes not so helpful, but only an hour long so not too much of a hassle. The grading scheme for the class is very fair and the rubrics for homework assignments and the final project are very clear. It's certainly easy to be successful in this course and get a lot out of in terms of learning about how to look at music through various different lenses. Professor Duguay is also very open to students analyzing music in other genres outside of strictly pop so it's easy to be interested in the course material and see how it applies to music you already listen to. I had a great time in the class as a stem concentrator so I highly recommend this course to anyone that wants to take it!
This class is very fun– definitely take it if you want to experiment with your abilities as a composer.
worse_comment: In its current form, this class doesn't do anything for your musical development nor creativity.

best_comment: This is the first time this course is offered. It is very interesting and simply lacks structure. You'll go out of your comfort zone doing new full–body exercises and meditations. It's extremely chill, and Li is very kind. However, it's a long class, and there's a section.
worse_comment: I wouldn't recommend the Fall 2022 version of this course with Li, as its quite disorganized and is pedagogically all over the map. We didn't learn much about performance, composing, or collaboration, to the degree where I began to question if the course title was a mislabel.

best_comment: Good class to learn more about Brahms. There was no midterm, and the final was a great performance of chamber music by Brahms that we had worked on throughout the semester. The actual playing of Brahms was the highlight of the class, as we got to actually apply and think about how to use the knowledge and understanding that we had just read about and discussed. Readings were sometimes overly complicated and convoluted, but the general points they got across were important. Fed is very knowledgeable and extremely passionate about anything he decides to teach, which can lead to sometimes disorganized class sessions but informative and very interesting nonetheless. Someone with incredible insight if you are willing to spend the time to try to access it.

This is one of the most amazing courses that Harvard has to offer. The fantastic blend of musicology and practice of playing makes it a very well–rounded course from which you can gain a lot, not to mention the mind–blowing fact that you get to learn a period instrument from an amazing professional player for free! I cannot recommend this course highly enough, and it is easily one of the best courses I have ever taken at Harvard. If are ever unsure about whether you should take this course: you should.
subject: Music

course_title: Music Makers of Asian America LEC
best_comment: Great class!!! Work is minimal but very enjoyable and engaging. You have the freedom to make each assignment your own. The artist visits are so special and rewarding — you get to meet and speak to some incredible and renowned musicians in a very intimate setting.
subject: Music

best_comment: “Our goal in this class is to have fun and enjoy the process of making music together, as equals, and grow. Everything else is just logistics.”This is what was said to us on day 1. And it was an incredible semester.I've made friends who are some of the kindest, most perceptive, caring, curious, and interesting people I know. We thought about music. We learned about the music and in working towards a common goal, learned about each other, and I understood myself better.The larger world may be chaotic, but it has never looked so beautiful as it does in that moment when you’re together and creating something larger than your individual selves.The Parker Quartet is so cool. I don't know how they're able to sculpt such brilliant music. This was a great experience.
subject: Music

best_comment: “Our goal in this class is to have fun and enjoy the process of making music together, as equals, and grow. Everything else is just logistics.”This is what was said to us on day 1.
