best_comment: “Our goal in this class is to have fun and enjoy the process of making music together, as equals, and grow. Everything else is just logistics.”This is what was said to us on day 1. And it was an incredible semester.I've made friends who are some of the kindest, most perceptive, caring, curious, and interesting people I know. We thought about music. We learned about the music and in working towards a common goal, learned about each other, and I understood myself better.The larger world may be chaotic, but it has never looked so beautiful as it does in that moment when you’re together and creating something larger than your individual selves.The Parker Quartet is so cool. I don't know how they're able to sculpt such brilliant music. This was a great experience.
subject: Music

best_comment: “Our goal in this class is to have fun and enjoy the process of making music together, as equals, and grow. Everything else is just logistics.”This is what was said to us on day 1. And it was an incredible semester.I've made friends who are some of the kindest, most perceptive, caring, curious, and interesting people I know. We thought about music. We learned about the music and in working towards a common goal, learned about each other, and I understood myself better.The larger world may be chaotic, but it has never looked so beautiful as it does in that moment when you’re together and creating something larger than your individual selves.The Parker Quartet is so cool. I don't know how they're able to sculpt such brilliant music. This was a great experience.
subject: Music

best_comment: This class is a great problem–solving course where you have an opportunity to learn about both the history of music and politics and how to openly discuss your thoughts and feelings with your classmates.
subject: Music

best_comment: Worth taking!
subject: Music

best_comment: You can choose to learn a lot from this class if you wish, but there aren't many enforcement mechanisms for learning that material, other than eight reading responses and a final take–home essay/exam that, for some reason, accounts for 70% of your grade. But the material is great, the lectures and readings are fascinating, and the teaching staff are great at what they do. Overall, this course was a net positive for me, but I can see why others might not have had the best experience with it.

course_title: Hebrew Bible Studies: Past and Future Trajectories 001
best_comment: If you're at all interested in how modern biblical scholarship began and has progressed, this class is a must. Prof. Rhyder is extremely knowledgeable, and very skilled at presenting complex material in an accessible way. She's also very nice – but she definitely expects your best, and this class will demand it. Expect to be doing a lot of reading. If you're taking this class, presumably that's what you want to be doing anyway – just be aware that this will be a heavy part of your courseload for the semester.

Homework in this course is frequent but manageable, and is really meant to help you make Arabic a part of your daily life. Lessons are engaging, and Richard is very receptive to questions–––he makes sure no one is left behind. My Arabic progressed far more in one semester than I had anticipated it would. It is also helpful that this is a small class, so you have a community of speakers who are at the same level that you are–––this helps with the language–learning process. For example, I would frequently exchange Arabic greetings with my classmates whenever I saw them outside of class. If there is one thing that I would say that this class falters in, it is that it has made me a far better writer than speaker. However, that is partially due to the nature of being in an intro–level class–––it is difficult to have high–level conversations without first understanding grammatical rules, which are learned through writing.
It's hard but arabic is really lovely! the teacher is passionate about the language, and just taking it introduces you to a lot of interesting cultural events on campus.
worse_comment: This class is extremely demanding and you need to be aware of that before signing up. Nevertheless, the professors will guide you through and assist you as much as you need. You just need to be able to have sometime each day for the workload and often many assignments that awaits

best_comment: Take the class! It's a great introduction and Arabic isn't as scary as it seems. When you come out of the first semester you'll be shocked by how much you've learned.

This is an incredibly taught course! I walked into class not knowing how to say hello in the class and I have learned sooo much in such a short amount of time. You will definitely get more out of this course  based on how much time you dedicate outside of class when doing your assignments and learning vocabulary before the class. I loved going to class even though it was a 9am because it was the most exciting hour I had during the day. My classmates were so positive and full of joy and you are all growing together as a small family. I will say this class was the one that I dedicated the most time to because there are no breaks when it comes to learning a language so I would definetly make sure you can handle the work load because I know I struggled at times with my four other classes that also demanded a lot of attention. So try to balance out your schedule so you can get as much out of the course as you can. ALSO, DANA AND KEVIN ARE THE ABSOLUTE BEST TFs EVER!!!!! They are soooo supportive and really really care about you and how you are doing in and out of the course, I am so grateful for having met them and my classmates! I really loved taking this class!

Take this class!!! This was my first Arabic class at Harvard and it was a fantastic experience. Amr is amazing and makes the class very welcoming and a comfortable learning space. This was my favorite class of my first semester and I highly recommend it to anyone interested in learning Arabic! Hada as–saf mumtaaz!!!

Take this class. Ustaadh Muhammad Habib is so amazing, and so so kind. I miss him already. We used Al–Kitaab, and read amazing short stories from the Sahlawayhi series, watched several funny Arabic films in class, and discussed a lot about Arabic culture. I learned so much in this class and I wish I could take it again. If you're thinking about intermediate Arabic, take this class.

This class is A LOT OF WORK but you learn A LOT OF ARABIC. You must know walking in that the nightly homework, biweekly tests, and biweekly essays make this class very demanding––your week may revolve around it like mine did. That being said, its excellently designed, Madi is an amazing teacher, and you learn a lot. But it is very very difficult and requires a high level of buy–in. You have to really love the language and be committed to learning it because again this is a tough class that will ask a lot of you. That being said, you get a lot out of it. Be ready to spend 10–15+ hours a week learning vocab, writing essays, studying grammar, in office hours, etc. but know you'll come out better, the department really cares about you, and the small–class environment cultivates a fun community.
subject: Arabic

best_comment: I would really encourage them to dispel with the notion that Arabic is a hard language. I would tell them that the class actually becomes so much more enjoyable and fulfilling for you once you try to stay on top of the work and always come prepared to class. The feeling of understanding more and more of what the teacher is saying and the feeling of being able to speak with more and more fluency is unmatched. Please, don't make the mistake I made at the beginning of my language studies and just treat this as an "extra class" where you don't need to put in that much work –– you will become miserable. I strongly encourage you to approach each assignment not as an assignment, but as a genuine chance for you to engage with the language more and become more proficient in it.  In summary, PLEASE –– for your own mental health but also for your own enjoyment –– try to stay on top of your work and try to approach this class with a positive mindset.
worse_comment: You will learn a lot in this class, but you will also have to work hard to get to that level learning throughout.
subject: Arabic

best_comment: The class is a far amount of work, but ensures you come away with a robust, useable knowledge of the subject. Prof Nasser is a great teacher and incredibly fun to learn from. The small class size means classes are made up of frequent discussion and commentary, which Prof Nasser directs well. If you want to learn a lot about Quran in a short time, this is the class for you

course_title: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture I 001
best_comment: Ustaaz Nader SLAPS, take this class if you want to be in a fun joke–filled environment while actually learning Arabic and getting more fluid in your discussions! As an upper–level course, this class is not about language drills or vocab memorization, it's about fluidity and organic understandings of material. Ustaaz Nader is great at connecting with his students and helping them understand concepts in a way that's enjoyable, approachable, and very often brings in hilarious pop culture references. If you're on the edge about feeling "prepared" enough for the class, I'd urge you to take it — it will most likely be a pretty small class, and Ustaaz goes to great lengths to make sure content and discussion is understandable for everyone. Take this class if you want to keep up with Arabic in a more organic way with a teacher who really knows what he's doing!
subject: Arabic
course_title_2023: Advanced Modern Arabic Bridge: Language, Literature, and Culture I

course_title: Arabic Five: The Arabic Short Story Between Art and Politics 001
best_comment: Professor Habib is immensely kind, well–informed, and an amazing resource! The class does get a little tiring with the same structure week after week, but overall, it does keep you active with your Arabic skills!
subject: Arabic
course_title_2023: Arabic Five: The Arabic Short Story Between Art and Politics

best_comment: This is one of the best ways to improve your classical Arabic past "Upper–level" and Prof. El–Rouayheb is extremely good at accommodating different students' goals.
subject: Arabic

best_comment: Take take take this course! You won't regret it. Christina is enthusiastic and the course is very engaging and interesting.

course_title: Philosophy and Law: Readings in Maimonides’ Mishneh Torah 001
best_comment: Professor Kimche is an incredible teacher! The material was fascinating and every single class discussion was extremely informative and enlightening. Professor Kimche masterfully weaves in a great deal of information about the various aspects of Maimonides' writings and life with topics spanning philosophy, metaphysics, medicine, and history. Throughout the course, students grapple with a balanced, curated set of primary and secondary sources that make class discussions particularly exhilarating. I highly recommend Professor Kimche's class to all students at Harvard who are interested in precisely the type of cutting–edge in–depth multidisciplinary study upon which Harvard University prides itself!

course_title: Introduction to Islamic Philosophy and Theology: The Modern Period (19th and 20th centuries) 001
best_comment: Take the class. Great Prof and TF

Great class with Professor Asani, he's so kind and knowledgeable. Definitely a bit of work including listening to lectures outside of class, doing readings, and going to section, but overall manageable. Definitely worth engaging with the material and going to office hours with Asani. Overall a solid pick if you're interested and know nothing at all.

PROFESSOR ASANI IS A LEGEND!!! Take this class if you are remotely even interested in the subject. The class is very chill and you get to learn a lot by discussing various topics. Professor Asani even has a mid–way break with snacks and tea!!!!

course_title: The Cairo Genizot and their Literature 001
best_comment: A great deal of fun and an intellectual challenge.

Irit is an amazing professor and you should do anything you can to take this class with her! There is a lot of course work and time in the classroom, but it feels intentional and is all for the purpose of helping you learn the language. This isn't an easy pass at getting your language out of the way, but is fun and meaningful and anyone interested in learning Hebrew and appreciating the historical roots of modern Hebrew should take this class.
worse_comment: Irit makes this class. Given that I'm not sure she will be back, I don't think I have much to say.
subject: Modern Hebrew

best_comment: Osnat runs an amazing course. She really understands what students want and need to do to learn. We talk (in Hebrew) about current events and politics and Osnat is always willing to change her itinerary to match what we want to do. This semester, student's wanted to focus a lot more on conversation and we spoke all the time in class. Definitely take this course if you want to progress in Hebrew and have a good time. The class feels like a family we are all good friends.
subject: Modern Hebrew

course_title: Shi’a Islam and Politics in the Middle East 001
best_comment: Definitely worth it. And worth it to do the reading! If you are interested in Shi'sim, Iran, or geopolitics of the region, prof Sagha is the guy to ask
subject: Modern Middle East
course_title_2023: Shi’a Islam and Politics in the Middle East

best_comment: This class is a great opportunity to understand history in a practical, locally focused sense. If you are focused in the type of history that focuses on tracing different ideas over time through a single place (as opposed to tracing one idea across time and place), this is a great course!

course_title: Dynamics of Transformation in the Modern Middle East 001
best_comment: Dr. Shahin is an incredible teacher, and his enthusiasm for the topic made it easy to get excited about the various subject matters.

course_title: The History of the Book: Using Harvard's Greatest Treasures to Study the Material Text 001
best_comment: Take this class!! If you're looking for a unique Harvard educational experience, it does not get any better. You get to touch and engage with really rare and fascinating materials (obviously the Gutenberg Bible, but also stuff like Shakespeare's first folio, ancient scrolls, Renaissance scientific books, etc.), and learn to see them with new eyes. The class itself is laid back but if you engage with the materials and take advantage of your time in the rare books library, you'll get a really meaningful experience out of it. Also, our class really bonded and even hung out outside of class, which I think goes to show how Professor Stern does a great job of building community.
subject: Near Eastern Civilizations
course_title_2023: The History of the Book: Using Harvard's Greatest Treasures to Study the Material Text

best_comment: Persian is a wonderful language and this course is perfect for you if you want to study modern Iranian affairs.
subject: Persian

best_comment: This a great way to learn Turkish.
subject: Turkish

best_comment: Intermediate Turkish is an excellent, if difficult, course. You will learn more Turkish than you thought possible in a semester, and all in a friendly and compassionate atmosphere. Make sure to review grammar concepts consistently over the semester; they all build on each other and you don't want to get behind!
subject: Turkish

best_comment: This is a great introduction to the history and politics of Yiddish. All of the course materials are very engaging and this is a wonderful chance to push and deepen your knowledge of Yiddish.

I would really recommend this class if you need to fill a requirement! It's pretty interesting and not too difficult if you haven't done STEM in a while. I was scared to take this because I haven't studied neuroscience/biology since high school, but I felt really confident in the material. It did definitely help that I had taken Psy 1 though and took other psychology classes in high school so I knew a bit about neurons before going into this. Still though, I think they really transitioned you well into this course! Obviously, this could really depend on your TF though, so just be advised. I had Ya'el and she was AMAZING, so would definitely recommend you take this class and try to get her. This class does have a few more weekly assignments than what you may usually expect (watching like 2.5 hrs of lectures online every week, but you could just put it on 1.5 times speed to get it down to like a bit over an hour per week, a weekly PSET, along with an online quiz), so be ready for that. The quizzes are honestly easy and they are online + open notes, so you'll be fine. The PSETs can be a bit confusing, but I realized you can just go over them with your TF for like 5 mins after section and they'll be a breeze then. There is a midterm and final exam, along with 2 online tests, but the online ones are open note and the exams in class weren't too difficult in my opinion. Having a bunch of assignments in the end did help me feel more confident in my grade, so don't worry too much about it. There are also like 2 group projects, but they'll be fine, especially if your TF is an easy grader. Overall recommend, though do try getting Ya'el as a TF because she's probably the only reason I really had a good time with this class. (I heard Kevin was also amazing from multiple friends and whenever I interacted with him he seemed super nice, so either of the two!!)
worse_comment: The material for this class is extremely interesting, but it is poorly taught. The lectures are prerecorded COVID lectures AND you must watch in person quest lectures during that T/TH time spot so if you have the discipline to do the course as stated in the syllabus it is actually a 4 lecture course plus section. The material is disconnected and confusing, and it is very much a "remember this because it is what it is" course. I have taken math 21b and organic chemistry, and although those two classes were difficult, I felt that I could understand those classes and the WHY behind the material. I felt so lost in mcb/neuro 80 and the only things you can do is reread the facts and memorize the disconnected material. I think the course as a whole is not difficult, but I had a hard time holding a decent grade. I feel that this course is especially bad for students who have a hard time learning from online zoom lectures and memorizing disconnected facts.
best_gem_comment: I would recommend anyone who is on the fence to please take neuo80. It is a gem in a sense that you will learn so much but you will not be extremely stressed out about grades. The grade distribution in the course is amazing. Every aspect is weighed enough so that you have to be consistent in order to do well in the course and your grade is not just reliant on a few test grades. The psets are actually fun and manageable, the course staff are accessible and ready to help or answer questions. It is a great introduction to the department.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: The Neurobiology of Sleep and its Role in Mental Health 001
best_comment: Great class, the professors are fantastic and super encouraging. Recommend!!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate
course_title_2023: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep

course_title: The Neurobiology of Sleep and its Role in Mental Health 001
best_comment: Great class, the professors are fantastic and super encouraging. Recommend!!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate
course_title_2023: Sleep Talk: Unraveling the Mystery of Sleep

best_comment: Take this class! Dr. Jordan is an amazing professor. The course is manageable time wise and the assignments are great at furthering your understanding of the concepts and research surrounding substance use. If you are at all interested in pharmacology and/or SUDs, you will really enjoy this class. Dr. Jordan is very knowledgeable and puts in the effort to make the class accessible to everyone by breaking down difficult concepts and even refreshing the basics so you can leave with a strong understanding of the science discussed each week!
best_gem_comment: take this class! a GEM for sure
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate

course_title: Sculpting Activity: How Inhibition Shapes the Brain in Health and Disease 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS IF YOU CAN!! If you have ANY interest in neuroscience, specifically inhibition in the brain but really any interest in how different disorders or mental illnesses may manifest in the brain, I highly recommend the course. Saad is SUPER engaging and really facilitates discussion. If you are feeling behind or not on the same page, he really fosters an environment where you feel really comfortable in asking questions and clarifying your thoughts. The papers build on one another in a really interesting way, and the assignments are really relaxed/you have plenty of tie to do them. I really cannot recommend this class enough it is GREAT!
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate
course_title_2023: Sculpting Activity: How Inhibition Shapes the Brain in Health and Disease

best_comment: I wish I had more time for this class, because it was go great. That being said, you can also take this if you have a packed course load–– you'll just get out a bit less. I was taking this completely for fun as a CS concentrator, and I'd wholeheartedly recommend it as an easier course that's still extremely interesting (instead of taking a gem).  The lectures are recorded and amazingly clear and interesting, and the homework does not require OH and is very straightforward and interesting. There is no busy work that isn't interesting. The course structure is a good balance between learning and application.
best_gem_comment: I wish I had more time for this class, because it was go great. That being said, you can also take this if you have a packed course load–– you'll just get out a bit less. I was taking this completely for fun as a CS concentrator, and I'd wholeheartedly recommend it as an easier course that's still extremely interesting (instead of taking a gem).  The lectures are recorded and amazingly clear and interesting, and the homework does not require OH and is very straightforward and interesting. There is no busy work that isn't interesting. The course structure is a good balance between learning and application.

course_title: The Brain: Development, Plasticity and Disease 001
best_comment: This class is a great neuro elective if you're interested in exactly how plasticity and development works on a genetic, molecular level. The readings for each class are low pressure and you usually don't need to know every detail but just the general goal of the paper. Go to office hours if you need help and Prof Kunes is happy to answer questions and he was a super nice teacher and even brought food in every morning for the class. Papers get put together easily if you have a good idea, so think of one early and clear it with Prof Kunes. Problem sets can be detailed, but answers are easy to find if you take notes on the readings and look through slides. Impossible to get a bad grade in this course if you pay even 50% attention in class. I enjoyed it – highly recommend.
subject: Neuroscience - Undergraduate
course_title_2023: The Brain: Development, Plasticity and Disease

course_title: Neurobiology of Perception and Decision Making 001
best_comment: The courseload is not bad. Class feels very unnecessary.

DONT SKIP LECTURES ND GO TO OFFICE HOURS! There is a lot of content in this course. And I mean a lot. Some of it may galvanize your passion for medicine and some of it may bore you into oblivion but nonethless, all of it is important. Because of this, I highly suggest attending lectures (and trust me, you will be tempted not to) but forming helathy habits around this class will be the most likely way you'll suceed. BUT if you have already devloped a system of missing lectures and performing well, then whatever floats your boat I guess. I just found that in missing lectures, I struggled to catch up later on. As for office hours, these are golden. The female teaching staff is godly. Every fem–presenting/woman in LS2 knows their stuff and can break down concepts in the simplest way–which makes for easy and lasting learning. Shout out to Jo, Cary, Claudia, and Katie for single handedly teaching me the cardiovascular system, male and female reproductive systems and processes, and where almost every dissected animal part was located before practicals. You guys rock! You gave me confidence to succeed in this course, walked me through step–by–step on things even when i was embarrassed for not knowing the answers, and never made me feel like I didn't belong. Now in the off chance that these lovely persons are no longer teaching by the time you (whoever might be reading this comment) sees this, I guess the 3 head lecturers are pretty cool too or whatever. Each professor has their own teaching style (Prof. Lauder likes drawings and fish, prof Biewener likes detailed lecture slides, and prof Lieberman like running, conceptual images, and less detailed slides). Pick their brains, ask questions that force them to say "thats a great question, I don't know the answer to that" and then work with them to find the answer–it'll help in your learning journey tremendously. Don't be a pretentious fool who thinks they know everything, anyone and everyone has something to learn from this class! P.S. it is more than possible to start studying for a practical the night before and still perform relatively well but it is NOT possible to start studying for an exam the night before and pull off the same stunt. Please, please, study for these exams at least 1 week– 4 days in advance (I know college is hard so we can be a bit realistic, start at least 3 days in advance if you're reallyyy good at cramming) and once again, go to office hours!
worse_comment: The course is AMAZING but you have to dedicate the time to learning the material. Since there ae no PSETs it can be difficult to stay up to date with material so you will have to take the initiative to learn on a weekly basis. This is not a class you can cram for.
subject: Life Sciences

worse_comment: The course is AMAZING but you have to dedicate the time to learning the material. Since there ae no PSETs it can be difficult to stay up to date with material so you will have to take the initiative to learn on a weekly basis. This is not a class you can cram for.
subject: Life Sciences

best_comment: DONT SKIP LECTURES ND GO TO OFFICE HOURS! There is a lot of content in this course. And I mean a lot. Some of it may galvanize your passion for medicine and some of it may bore you into oblivion but nonethless, all of it is important. Because of this, I highly suggest attending lectures (and trust me, you will be tempted not to) but forming helathy habits around this class will be the most likely way you'll suceed. BUT if you have already devloped a system of missing lectures and performing well, then whatever floats your boat I guess. I just found that in missing lectures, I struggled to catch up later on. As for office hours, these are golden. The female teaching staff is godly. Every fem–presenting/woman in LS2 knows their stuff and can break down concepts in the simplest way–which makes for easy and lasting learning. Shout out to Jo, Cary, Claudia, and Katie for single handedly teaching me the cardiovascular system, male and female reproductive systems and processes, and where almost every dissected animal part was located before practicals. You guys rock! You gave me confidence to succeed in this course, walked me through step–by–step on things even when i was embarrassed for not knowing the answers, and never made me feel like I didn't belong. Now in the off chance that these lovely persons are no longer teaching by the time you (whoever might be reading this comment) sees this, I guess the 3 head lecturers are pretty cool too or whatever. Each professor has their own teaching style (Prof. Lauder likes drawings and fish, prof Biewener likes detailed lecture slides, and prof Lieberman like running, conceptual images, and less detailed slides). Pick their brains, ask questions that force them to say "thats a great question, I don't know the answer to that" and then work with them to find the answer–it'll help in your learning journey tremendously. Don't be a pretentious fool who thinks they know everything, anyone and everyone has something to learn from this class! P.S. it is more than possible to start studying for a practical the night before and still perform relatively well but it is NOT possible to start studying for an exam the night before and pull off the same stunt. Please, please, study for these exams at least 1 week– 4 days in advance (I know college is hard so we can be a bit realistic, start at least 3 days in advance if you're reallyyy good at cramming) and once again, go to office hours!
worse_comment: The course is AMAZING but you have to dedicate the time to learning the material. Since there ae no PSETs it can be difficult to stay up to date with material so you will have to take the initiative to learn on a weekly basis. This is not a class you can cram for.
subject: Life Sciences

best_comment: This is a great class – I genuinely really enjoyed learning the material as a non–bio/science major and it really gave me a sense of wonder about the evolution of life! Also a good way to fill reqs. All 4 professors are good lecturers and passionate about the subject. The field trip is really fun and was one of my favorite parts of the semester. The quiz–and–pset format is very doable as long as you review lecture slides before the quiz, and it's great to not have a final. Working with a real non–class–affiliated professor on the grant proposal is also fun and gives a good sense of what science research might be like at Harvard if you're a first year or sophomore who doesn't know.
worse_comment: it's convenient that this class has no exams, but the quizzes (an alternative to exams) are terribly designed. they are true/false and short, meaning that it is easy to get them wrong, but they are also horrible reflections of what we learned in class –– they are more about tricking students about random minutia that have nothing to do with major lecture concepts and themes, and there were so many times where i spent upwards of five hours studying for a quiz just to fail it or get a C. so be wary of those quizzes if you want to take this class.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: This is a great class – I genuinely really enjoyed learning the material as a non–bio/science major and it really gave me a sense of wonder about the evolution of life! subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course! You'll need to know what's going on so not exactly a class you can slack off in, BUT there are a lot of resources for you to do well! I highly recommend going to office hours because that's where I really got to understand the topics. The take–home tests were great and felt pretty low–stakes, which was super nice. The fact that the problem sets were graded off neatness was super nice, too, because then you didn't feel so much pressure to get every single thing right, and the emphasis was more on learning the material!!
worse_comment: The lectures aren't really helpful. You'll learn a lot from the work you do to do the PSets, midterm, and final. The podcast isn't too bad, but really didn't seem that relevant to the rest of the course despite being a fun project.
best_gem_comment: This class is a GEM but very enjoyable. Lectures are straightforward, expectations for the exams (which are all take home for multiple days) are very clear, and the professors really care about the students and the course content. The only downside is the section since it's pretty disorganized, but the pros far outweigh the cons.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I really enjoyed this course! You'll need to know what's going on so not exactly a class you can slack off in, BUT there are a lot of resources for you to do well! I highly recommend going to office hours because that's where I really got to understand the topics. The take–home tests were great and felt pretty low–stakes, which was super nice. The fact that the problem sets were graded off neatness was super nice, too, because then you didn't feel so much pressure to get every single thing right, and the emphasis was more on learning the material!!

subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: Best course ever!  Even though evolution seems like a topic that all biology students know about, learning more about it and the way it works is seriously a must for all biology students and I cannot think of a better way of learning about it. Professor Berry is so engaging, the readings are very interesting, the section is awesome, and you end up learning a lot and gaining a new perspective. Even though it can be a lot of work around midterms, it is worth it! My favorite course at Harvard so far!
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I cannot stress enough how good this class is. This is coming from someone who wants to study and do research in ecology, but if you are at all interested in ecology this class is the best way to get experience actually doing ecology, along with learning all about it. At times it can get kind of math heavy, but  you don't really need any special prior math knowledge (although 1b or 21a would definitely help) as most of the class is conceptual, and the whole teaching staff is always prepared to help you out with the parts that do get more math–y. Andrew and Ben are some of my favorite professors that I have had during my whole time at Harvard, so if you get the chance to take a class with either of them, definitely do it!!!My best advice is to go to a bunch of office hours with each of the professors and the TFs because it will make going through the psets and field trip reports a lot more manageable. Also – go on all of the field trips if you have the chance!!! They are DEFINITELY WORTH IT!!! Going on the field trips and doing the reports I think was the most rewarding part of this class because you actually get to do real ecology and practice putting together a scientific paper.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I cannot stress enough how good this class is. This is coming from someone who wants to study and do research in ecology, but if you are at all interested in ecology this class is the best way to get experience actually doing ecology, along with learning all about it. At times it can get kind of math heavy, but  you don't really need any special prior math knowledge (although 1b or 21a would definitely help) as most of the class is conceptual, and the whole teaching staff is always prepared to help you out with the parts that do get more math–y. Andrew and Ben are some of my favorite professors that I have had during my whole time at Harvard, so if you get the chance to take a class with either of them, definitely do it!!!My best advice is to go to a bunch of office hours with each of the professors and the TFs because it will make going through the psets and field trip reports a lot more manageable. Also – go on all of the field trips if you have the chance!!! They are DEFINITELY WORTH IT!!! Going on the field trips and doing the reports I think was the most rewarding part of this class because you actually get to do real ecology and practice putting together a scientific paper.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: This is an amazing class and you should take it! Dr Pierce offers a biodiversity and vertebrate morphology perspective, while Dr Srivastava teaches how the organs develop during embryonic development. They are both excellent lecturers. The lab activities on Thursdays are really fun and hands–on, involving dissections and interesting experiments. One of my favorite things we got to do was spawn sea urchins. The Professors and TFs are enthusiastic about biology and share this interest with students and through their teaching styles.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Very interesting and very little work . No psets, only post–labs and some short reading responses. Structure is one lecture and one lab per week, both 75 min. Cannot recommend enough. Great way to avoid other scary pre–med bio courses.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: This is an amazing class and you should take it! Dr Pierce offers a biodiversity and vertebrate morphology perspective, while Dr Srivastava teaches how the organs develop during embryonic development. They are both excellent lecturers. The lab activities on Thursdays are really fun and hands–on, involving dissections and interesting experiments. One of my favorite things we got to do was spawn sea urchins. The Professors and TFs are enthusiastic about biology and share this interest with students and through their teaching styles.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Very interesting and very little work . No psets, only post–labs and some short reading responses. Structure is one lecture and one lab per week, both 75 min. Cannot recommend enough. Great way to avoid other scary pre–med bio courses.
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol

best_comment: I absolutely loved this course. The teaching staff was truly fantastic, and Prof. Davis is perhaps one of the most down–to–earth professors I've ever had the pleasure of learning from. The course material is fascinating, too, and highly relevant to many modern issues we face (invasive species, sustainability/output in agriculture, regulating medicinal plants, etc). If you are at all interested in the intersection between plants and humans, I could not recommend this class more. You also have the opportunity to develop your scientific writing technique, which is a skill far too often forgotten or de–emphasized in other science classes. The final project is a lot of fun (especially if you plan ahead), and the teaching staff is extremely helpful both in and outside of class.
This is a good class! I love the teaching staff and they really try to help us. Lectures are entertaining, and the guest lecturers are very interesting.
worse_comment: This class is really interesting, but it is also quite difficult.

course_title: The Mouse in Science and Society 001
best_comment: I really wanted to take a science class, but was looking for one that was less general/introductory, instead diving into a more specific subject. This was a great fit for that purpose! Dr. Pritchett–Corning was super engaging and communicative throughout the course and was really supportive of every student. I learned so much new information about mice, as well as how to read and analyze scientific papers. Overall, I really enjoyed this course and looked forward to it every week.
best_gem_comment: Wonderful class. Definetly a gem, and the professor is great as well! So much to learn here
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2023: The Mouse in Science and Society

best_comment: This is a cool class if you love biology and love to learn about random facts. You also learn to think about fetus–mother conflicts, life history strategies, trade–offs animals make, other conflicts, etc. Professor is very knowledgeable and it's interesting to take a deep dive into pregnancy. However, if you don't like biology or this topic, your're not going to enjoy this course.
This is a great discussion–based class that likely won't be too challenging grade–wise, but be sure you have strong interest in speciation and/or biology at large
worse_comment: cool class, covers quite a lot of ground re: species concepts, but the lack of structure can make it difficult to pin down what exactly you learned.

best_comment: Really fantastic class. A must–take if you have an interest in diving into a fascinating niche of population genetics. John is both incredibly knowledgeable and super kind, always encouraging questions and letting people in the class learn from each other. That being said, you'll get out more of this class if you a.) have some prior statistics (i.e. STAT 110) background and b.) prior experience in population genetics plus a desire to put time into this class. But a real favorite of mine this semester.
worse_comment: I would recommend future students to take pictures of the equations John puts up on the board, as he will ask questions on the problem sets which are directly related to these concepts

course_title: Comparative Genomics: Phylogenetic Approaches to Linking Genomes and Phenotypes 001
best_comment: This class is really stimulating, but you don't have to fully understand every concept to do well. Some of the topics were pretty heady or mathy, and it was tough to understand all of what was going on. Reading (and re–reading) some of the papers helped, but honestly, it helps to accept that you don't have to know every detail, just the greater themes, and reasons. For your final project, it is really helpful to pick a method that you did actually fully grasp since you have to use it and justify it. Also, don't be afraid to be wrong, ask "stupid" questions, or challenge some of the things you hear. This class was pretty two–way and it seemed like Scott was genuinely interested in what we thought about various methods in comparative genomics, and their strengths and limitations.

course_title: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology 001
best_comment: This is a really chill and fun course!
subject: Organismic & Evolutionary Biol
course_title_2023: Topics in Organismic and Evolutionary Biology

best_comment: Definitely take this class!! Philosophy is a transformative discipline & you might leave the class with a greater appreciation for the field even if you're not a philosopher concentrator. The teaching staff is fabulous at making tough concepts digestible + are very generous with their support infrastructure (offering abundant OH slots, being flexible with deadlines/grading, etc.). They teach with the understanding that most students are just getting into philosophy/may not have much exposure to college writing at all. You can truly tell that Professor Nickel + the TFs care about the students (they responded immediately, for instance, to constructive midterm feedback). I left the class with a strong foundation in various contentious philosophical debates and overall found the course fun, rewarding, and accommodating.
worse_comment: I think this course is an excellent introduction to philosophy. However, I would recommend that you have a base level of understanding regarding philosophical papers and how to construct papers. The professor goes through material exceptionally quickly and does not delve much into how to structure these papers, even though they are most of your grade. So while the professor may say you can take this class without ever taking a previous philosophy class, this did not match up with my or my peers' experiences. This was very stressful for some students, as one student even cried during one of the sections due to a lack of understanding. For instance, before coming into this class, I enjoyed philosophy immensely,  but now I associate it with confusion and lack of understanding due to how fast the lecturer went over the material and how there was little to no focus on structuring papers. These papers are very distinct from other academic papers, so I suggest there be a bit more focus on this, especially since the averages were extremely low for the first few papers.

best_comment: Professor Doyle is very smart and interested in the material, but he is an abysmal lecturer.  If you plan to take this class I recommend getting started on the essay's early and coming to office hours. You should probably only take this class if you have an interest in philosophy and are prepared to do a fair bit of reading each week about it.
worse_comment: Would not recommend

best_comment: This is one of the best classes I've taken at Harvard. It incorporates a range of materials, from philosophical texts to present–day news articles and Twitter threads. Also, there is a great amount of diversity in the identities of the authors we read (given the stereotype of philosophy being only dead white men). Prof. Siegel is an amazing professor –– she is obviously an expert on these topics, but she explains concepts in an understandable and engaging way in class. The readings were sometimes long, but they were always thought–provoking. I didn't have any philosophy experience, but I was sincerely interested in the subject matter, and the class was an experience that I will keep with me for a long time.

This is a solid class. Definitely take it if you want a chill lecture class and think you'd enjoy the readings. But it was definitely overhyped to me. After taking it, I have to assume that all the people who thought it was a profound, life–changing experience probably just hadn't gotten to take a comparably–solid literature class yet. It is a good class!!! Just not unmissable. So if you're unsure how to use that last elective slot, apply to that AFVS workshop you're eyeing instead, do whatever readings from this class that you actually wanted to read on your own, and get a friend in the class to send you the lecture recordings.Pros: Engaging, ted–talk–y lectures. A professor and teaching staff with a lot of enthusiasm who are eager to talk about the material with you during office hours. (Prof. Kelly's office hours are well attended and it feels not at all awkward to show up to listen even if you don't have questions! I was really impressed by how much time he was willing to spend talking with us and how much he seemed to care about teaching, and if you're a freshman considering Philosophy it seems like he'd be great to know in the department and great to have as a mentor.) No need to stress about your grade (lots of extra credit opportunities). Some great readings. SUCH good films––watch them even if you don't take the class. Would be great to take Freshman year.Cons: A lot of gesturing to the significance of texts in your daily lives without gaining a very deep or clear understanding of what the texts are actually saying. Section is fun but not very enlightening. It sometimes felt like Prof. Kelly misinterpreted student objections to simplify things more quickly (a relief in lecture sometimes if it was a tangent, but otherwise a con). De Beauvoir and Fanon felt like they were only glossed at the end (not in time to write about them for either paper). You have to write about The Brothers Karamazov for the second paper. Reading The Brothers Karamazov. Still reading The Brothers Karamazov weeks later. The Brothers Karamazov.
worse_comment: I loved Phil 34! It was one of those classes that actually made me think deeply about my life and things I care about, and it has given me genuinely new perspectives.Workload is entirely manageable, but I'd emphasize staying on top of it and trying to think seriously about the readings. The class can be not so fun if you're behind. It can be very fun if you are on top of it with some friends to banter about the various positions with!
best_gem_comment: Phil 34 is an amazing class, taught by a kind, genuine, smart professor who is such a gem at Harvard. Prof Kelly designed the course in such a way that I have no doubt it will change your worldview as well.

course_title: Introduction to the Power and Limits of Logic 001
best_comment: generally a good intro to logic. Prof Richard really cares about students and doesn't want to scare you away from the field. it can be a bit disorganized at times, but if you're a self–starter and go to office hours, the course is manageable. Richard is a funny guy too – was always a pleasure to be in class with him.
worse_comment: The professor is very odd. On the first day, he hid behind the desk out of embarrassment. While he is overall a nice person, I cannot recommend this course if you really want to engage in the material in class.

best_comment: You will be challenged by both the readings and the papers, but if you put in the work you don't need to worry about your grade because your TF will help you improve upon your writing and thought (anyone can do philosophy!). The readings are not that long, but take a ton of time because they are incredibly dense. The first paper you write you also get a chance to rewrite, which is helpful to understand how you might improve upon any paper.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Hopefully Ryan teaches this exact course again. It's a really excellent course that covers a broad range of philosophical topics through genuinely engaging and interesting media. I also cannot stress enough how much Ryan's feedback improved my writing.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: I'm a second–semester senior and this was one of my favorite courses I'd ever taken. Plato is so interesting, eloquent, and fun to read. They're all dialogues, like little plays or conversations, which makes it so much more approachable than I'd ever thought philosophy could be! Obviously you can't take everything at face value because these people genuinely believed in Apollo and reincarnation and stuff, but so many underlying themes are so interesting and some are applicable to life now. Professor Doyle is absolutely amazing! So knowledgeable, passionate, and thoughtful. I always went to his office hours and each time made me think about things in a different way.
worse_comment: DONT TAKE THIS!! Absolute comedy but you're the victim. You will learn nothing. The organization of the class was non existent. Not an exaggeration the professor didn't return assignments until Mid December and did not create a section in the class until November.  The professor had a fairly bad handle on Plato, which to his credit he did acknowledge. You will learn nothing and will be tortured in the process. Stay away from Doyle at all costs.

best_comment: If you want to learn some Chinese philosophy, this is a great class! Seth is a super enthusiastic instructor who makes so many great connections between different thinkers, both just Asian as well as between Eastern and Western thinkers. You only have two papers to write: one application paper and one analysis paper. If you put in the work, you'll get an A, and you'll learn a lot.
best_gem_comment: This class is super interesting and I think is a bit of a unknown GEM. No prior experience required, the professor is amazing and workload is totally manageable. It may even change the way you live your life.
subject: Philosophy

course_title: Beyond Dualism: Descartes and His Critics 001
best_comment: This is an absolutely excellent course on early modern philosophy! Prof. Simmons is a fantastic professor who has a phenomenal ability of presenting the material in a very clear and understandable way, and makes you really enjoy working through it (even during those times when you are just completely confused about what is going on in the readings). The course environment was also excellent and, despite not being always easy, it is certainly a course that is worth taking and investing time into.

ABSOLUTELY TAKE THIS CLASS. Kelly is amazing. One of the best lecturers ever. This class is, of course, very niche, but it somehow feels feels radically important for our every day existence. This combination is very special. Made me fall in love with philosophy. Even if you aren't a concentrator, it teaches you how to think critically about some of the most important questions of our day, namely "what is it to be?". Plus, you touch on all sorts of other relevant and engaging topics, including art and technology.

I really enjoyed this class. I would highly recommend taking it (with one caveat; see below). The material improves your ability to make well–reasoned inferences in real life, and it's also an interesting puzzle by itself. The material is presented in a very intuitive and easy to follow way (although it moves quickly, so you have to make sure you're paying attention), and abstract logical concepts were almost always explained using concrete examples, which helped a lot. I thought Prof Goldfarb was a great teacher, though apparently he won't be teaching Phil 140 anymore.I would say that this class requires some appreciation for pure math and some skill with mathematical reasoning. If you are only interested in philosophy and not math, then maybe you should think twice about taking this class.
worse_comment: I highly recommend against taking this class unless you are a pure math concentrator. Otherwise, you will find yourself very lost amongst useless lectures and difficult–to–understand textbook chapters.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: This is a great course! Dr. Robertson is one of the most engaging and passionate faculty members I've met at Harvard, and the readings and lectures discuss interesting philosophical theories that you won't see in most other philosophy classes. I don't know if Dr. Robertson selects for this or if the course content naturally draws certain types of people, but the people in the class were students with a variety of different concentrations and backgrounds, all of whom seemed to be primarily interested in thinking (both academically and personally) about how to be better people (Dr. Robertson is also exceptionally kind). In my experience, it is unfortunately rare to encounter such a positive and warm environment in Harvard so, even if you have no academic reason to take the course, I recommend this class as a way of meeting some incredibly kind people and think about how you can grow as a person.
worse_comment: This class is not specifically about virtue ethics. It is about virtue theory, and covers three broad topics: virtue/vice theory (analyzing virtue/vice terms and their meaning with no context), virtue ethics, and virtue epistemology (basically the analog to virtue ethics in questions of knowledge). However, while these are the broad topics discussed, it does not feel like that. It feels like an overview course in which every week you read a different selection, and readings are not related too closely. If you are looking for a broader theory about virtue or vice, this course will present you many such theories, but will not help to decide how or which to pick. You will gain familiarity with many new ideas, and you'll probably end up feeling more disoriented than you started. That can be a good thing. Just keep in mind it'll be the start, not the end, of your journey into this topic.

best_comment: This class is definitely worth taking if you want to have a lot of interesting and fun discussions about cybersecurity and privacy. I would recommend it to anybody from the Phil department who is interested in computer science and anyone from CS with an interest in philosophy.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: Before this class, I knew nothing about Bernard Williams. After taking it, I am incredibly grateful to have been introduced to him. His thoughts on ethics are so different from what I learned in my intro to ethics class, and I find them incredibly compelling. He is now one of my favorite philosophers and writers. I have never taken a class in which I felt so passionately about the readings. I was unable to finish all of them, and I am committed to complete them during winter break (I have never done that before). It is a testament to how great the readings are that this was my favorite class, even though the seminar component was lacking. In a way, I do feel that I would have gotten almost as much out of the class as I did even if I had been unable to attend the seminar discussions and only had to read and write essays. Nonetheless, I'm sure the class will improve, and if just for the readings it is 100% worth taking.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: This was my first philosophy class (as a senior). I enjoyed it and would recommend! I took it pass/fail but it does feel like the course load is reasonable even if graded. Handouts and lectures are super clear, and Selim is great at engaging a class to ask questions during lecture. Ezra was also a great TF and gave a lot of helpful feedback on papers. I will say that the topic of metaethics itself can feel repetitive at some point; it's a lot of very specific arguments around similar topics.
worse_comment: This class is difficult– I know Prof Berker says it, but it’s the kind of class where by the midpoint you’ll be reading words without comprehending much. I would have taken at least one upper level philosophy class before this, in an analytic style (Heidegger or history of philosophy will not be the best prep) – philosophy of language would probably be best because it’s very closely tied to metaethics. There’s also a lot of work in this class – three essays, first one has a rewrite, and there’s a three hour final exam where the questions aren’t easy. The grading is also firm. Prof Berker is a fantastic lecturer as any of his groupies will tell you, but just know what you’re getting into.

best_comment: I knew after going through the syllabus that this would be a course with topics that I'm very interested in. If you're also interested in these topics, this is a great course to take. Definitely carefully read all the readings and choose a topic that you're very interested in for the final paper. Office hours are also very helpful.

Enjoyed the course greatly. Some incredibly interesting material with very impressive profs. Quality of discussion in class can vary (presumably depends on who you happen to get on the course). Prof. Sen is certainly no longer at the peak of his powers but still has something to contribute. Nice to be able to pick whatever you want for the term paper, with support from the profs if you ask for it.
subject: Philosophy

best_comment: It's got quite a leaning toward political philosophy, I do like how we present finished work, which feels like it allows for more helpful feedback on one's writing (not just one's ideas) than if we were giving talks and such.

best_comment: I think there were many strengths of this course. To start, I appreciated the intentionality in the course. In terms of the content, I am grateful for the connections that the course makes between physics and medicine/biology to highlight how a course that may not be the direct focus of students' studies can be relevant and important to what they are interested in. I thought the course staff did a great job in choosing problems that were relevant to our interests and helped us to better understand the world around us. Secondly, I think the way they presented information was very intentional and important. I think it was helpful to learn about some of the material taught in class before that class began and then to have an opportunity to review that content at the start of class and build on what we learned through practice problems and the opportunity to ask questions in class. I found the teaching staff (the lecturers and the TFs/CAs) to be particularly incredible. I found Anna and Greg to be especially caring, thoughtful, and kind and the other members of the teaching staff to be supportive as well. I am very grateful for the enthusiasm and engagement that Anna and Greg brought to the classroom and how much they cared about our wellbeing. I learned a lot during this class and felt excited about the material and very much supportive throughout the semester. I also thought that the lab was great in being able to introduce other content related to what we learned in class that was important to use in physics and relevant to concepts from other disciplines. I very much appreciated the opportunity to learn about and practice using the scientific process and experimenting. This class was a great physics class to take, especially if you are premed, and the teaching staff is awesome. Also, the demos in this class are amazing!
worse_comment: MCAT physics but very difficult for no reason.
subject: Physical Sciences

course_title: Electromagnetism and Quantum Physics from an Analytic, Numerical and Experimental Perspective 001
best_comment: People have mixed opinions about this class, but I genuinely recommend it!! Prof Yelin is very enthusiastic and the course is an excellent overview to a lot of different topics. I really appreciate the coding aspect, even though the assignments were not always clear — I had barely coded, and never in Python, before taking 12a, and I have learned so so much. The labs were not always relevant to lecture but were extremely fun; the teaching staff overall is very engaging and ready to help. Take this class if you’re doing engineering, looking for a more applied version of 15b, want to get better at Python, or don’t like exams; don’t take it if you want a theoretically rigorous understanding of the content.
worse_comment: It was extremely hard if not impossible to keep up with this class without the background knowledge and understanding of vectors, 3D fields, cross products, etc. Yelin moreover, does not have great handwriting and never explains the different variables she writes down, so it was extremely hard to keep up in class and teach myself things when I can't even understand what she is writing down (very quickly) on the board. For example, she would draw an upside down triangle and I could not tell whether it was an accidently upside down drawn delta sign or weird V because she never introduced it as a "gradient" sign in class–– she just started to use it without explanation or context. It was only weeks later when I learned what a gradient in Math when I finally realized what she was writing about. It is shocking that Math21a is not a requirement for this class. You cannot pass this class if you don't have a solid understand of the material covered already or not being at office hours every day
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: This is an amazing course and I cannot recommend it highly enough. However, I do recommend you take it during a semester when you aren't as busy. I took this as my fifth class during a very busy semester and it was not my best idea. Especially toward the end of the course (last 4–6 weeks), the assignments get bigger/harder (at least for me, not necessarily for everyone), and I was so stressed about being able to get things done and semi–functioning by their due dates. However, the course staff is super flexible, understanding, kind, and supportive. When you inevitably run into issues trying to get something to work or figure out how to do something, you should definitely turn to Google, YouTube, and other peoples' projects and websites first. Then, definitely talk to/message the TFs or Nathan, who are so helpful. It's also very useful to chat with them about your plans for projects so they can give you their recommendations and expertise. Finally, be sure to start your documentation early: ideally, you'd do it as you go. Creating thorough documentation is vital for succeeding in the course (and also just generally useful).
subject: Physical Sciences

best_comment: This is an extremely rewarding class.  The demonstrations during lecture are often really exciting and cool––it's worth going to lecture just to see them.  David Morin is a super enthusiastic teacher who makes the material interesting and fun; he also has great limericks.  Psets are time consuming but office hours can be really helpful; plus it is very worth it to work through the psets thoroughly because exams match them very closely.  If you put in the time in this class, you will learn a lot and do well––Morin is a forgiving grader.
worse_comment: This class is very difficult for those who have no experience with calculus–based physics in the past. It goes through a large amount of material with extreme depth, and does so in a short period of time. This class will challenge anyone, but especially those without a background in difficult physics.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is pretty hard, especially if you haven't taken E&M before. Professor Dvorkin is an amazing, kind, and enthusiastic professor, but beware that her lectures often move really fast and don't explain a lot of the fundamental concepts. Definitely make sure you that you are keeping up with the content early on, because everything builds off each other. Psets can be challenging but are usually fair and aren't too painful if you start them early and go to office hours (which I recommend doing!!) Sections are amazing and the TFs are so helpful and funny –– definitely get to know your TFs because mine were great and made the class so much more entertaining. This class is pretty challenging and thorough with its content, but completely doable. The grading is very reasonable and the course head and TFs all want you to succeed!
worse_comment: This class is a fairly typical science class at Harvard. If you're taking it, I assume you need it for a concentration. It's not bad but definitely not the best stem class I've taken here. Cora is super nice (go to her office hours!) but sometimes the lecture material felt rushed. We finished the course material early, so she definitely could have slowed it down. Also,  section experience really depended on which TF you got. One TF was supposedly great, but the section I went to (with Diya) was awful. It was disorganized, she hadn't done the problems in advance, and couldn't answer student questions. So I definitely found section to be a waste of time.
best_gem_comment: If Professor Dvorkin is teaching this class, TAKE IT!!! With Professor Dvorkin this class truly is a gem. I have never felt more engaged during lectures, and you can feel Dvorkin's excitement for the material exuding throughout the lecture hall as she teaches. Her pace is generally manageable, but at times when she goes fast, she stops to take questions so students can keep up. Physics 15b is probably the hardest of the 15 series, but Professor Dvorkin truly wants to see her students succeed. I've honestly never seen a more dedicated professor who would take direct feedback from her students– if you found something particularly challenging, she would talk to you about it and work with you on how she could better support you. One example I remember is a group of students who came up to her asking if there could be an additional bonus/fun/not physics question on the final similar to those on problem sets to decrease stress, and she immediately agreed and began brainstorming ideas with students. Physics 15b could have been a bad experience because of how hard the class material is, but with Professor Dvorkin, the class has become one of my favorites.
subject: Physics

best_comment: 15c taught by Professor Mitrano is an interesting and rewarding course. It's certainly more difficult than previous iterations of the course, but it is worth it. I appreciated and truly understood the course content in way that I haven't in most of my other courses. Lectures are great; Professor Mitrano is a very effective lecturer who is engaging and organized. Section was great; our TF was kind and fun and section material often helped a lot with the problem sets. The problem sets were also great; they were difficult but interesting, and they required application of concepts in an interesting way.  The lab component of this class was terrible, so for 3 hours per week, we were miserable (lab was unnecessarily long and slow, and we spent a lot of time just sitting around staring into space). The class in general was also rather inflexible regarding getting sick. For example, if you got COVID, and you told the lab professor that you had to miss it, he would simply not reply and it would affect your participation grade.  Otherwise, this class was great.
worse_comment: This class is just really annoying. Sometimes it's not even worth trying to understand, just ask for help immediately.

subject: Physics

best_comment: Overall: Physics 16 was by far the most definitive and transformative course I took this semester. It is (per the title) a course in mechanics and special relativity, and it rightfully lacks the title of “introductory.” Physics 16 takes concepts you have seen before in, say, AP and not only expands on its generality in the form of solving for general equations of motion but also pushes you to truly appreciate the deeper intuition and mathematical rigor behind these concepts. Further, it takes you beyond your beloved F=ma and reveals the entirely different formalisms of physics (think “approaches to physical problem solving”) that are Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics. This line from last year’s Q Guide continues to hold: “This class is not about learning physics. It's about learning how to think about physics.” Above all, 16 was where I met the most talented, creative, and enthusiastic peers. Never before have I felt so connected (trauma bonded) to so many people who share my passion for physics. Professor: Professor Yao (“Norm”) does a brilliant job of keeping lectures exciting and bringing the class together. I am proud to have been a part of Professor Yao’s first year teaching at Harvard. With the relatively small class size, you are blessed with close connections with the world’s youngest tenured professor and with the brightest physics students of your age. Thursday lunches after class and after a long night of pseting were the best. At the expense of the physics department budget, I say: please keep up the class culture! Norm appreciates your community–building :)Textbook: Norm’s approach to much of the content differs from Morin. Nonetheless, Morin provides an excellent supplement to the material from a slightly different perspective that greatly facilitates solidity of understanding. Especially important for material that you have not seen before. David Morin’s Introduction to Classical MechanicsTopics covered: See My.Harvard. With the restructuring of the class, the topics for next year will be more accurate there.  Course structure notes: Weekly lectures Tuesday and Thursday. Psets due Thursdsay in class. Physics nights on Wednesday. Sections (subject to change) weekly to supplement lectures. Don’t procrastinate.
worse_comment: This is not an easy class. The concepts are difficult, but the sheer amount of time required to complete problem sets is what really makes this class hard. That said, I now feel like I deeply understand weird properties of the universe ranging from the conservation of energy to the precession of a top to the redshift of light from distant galaxies.I think this class would be extremely difficult without plenty of previous experience with classical mechanics and calculus.
subject: Physics
