subject: Physics

best_comment: I have never in my life taken an introductory STEM course like this. It was an absolutely amazing experience. Professor Barandes is an incredibly welcoming and understanding person, and has several unparalleled qualities about him, including that he is able to remember so much information and relevant stories that are carefully conveyed and intelligently woven into his lectures.  He is unbelievably knowledgeable, and he will stay for literally an hour or two afterwards and answer questions, and explain new topics to you. He really cares. Furthermore, it speaks for itself that that he was able to consolidate and really encapsulate the essence of almost every major realm of physics leading up to (and including, which was really cool!!) the development of quantum mechanics in an accessible but thorough and un–simplified way. By covering in broad sweeps all of the important realms of physics from throughout its past, this class was in a lot of ways a history of physics, and felt like a 31–course intellectual meal. Every lecture provided something new and exciting. Now, I took 15a before this course, but as someone with a passion for learning and a curiosity about a lot of disciplines in science, I felt that I wanted a class that showed me what physics 'is about'. And physics 19 sure delivered. This was unlike any other introductory STEM class I've taken; this helped me solidify my choice to study physics.  I feel this class should be required alongside physics 15a, they're really each of a very different breed, and this class is just fantastic. For the physics student, 15a teaches you how to think about and solve classical mechanics and special relativity problems well. This is important. Physics 19 sends you on an intellectual rollercoaster and makes you question and think about the philosophical experience of understanding the inner workings of the universe. This is important for a deeper reason. It gets you excited about studying physics; I had my intellectual and physics boundaries pushed in so many different directions, leaving me feeling like I gained a tender awareness of what physics 'is about', the soul of it, this ever–growing tapestry of knowledge, as seen through so many other historical figures who gave their lives to its development and all it can now account for in Nature. And again: it's accessible! You don't actually need to have taken a physics course before this! Having an interest in physics is all that is necessary, and being interested in deep questions is a plus––Barandes' specialty is physics and philosophy, and this combines both.
worse_comment: I wouldn't recommend this class unless you're really into physics and math. As an engineer, lectures got really hard really fast and it was tough to catch up. Additionally, PSets took up a lot of my time and seemed to be really repetitive and a bit excessive in terms of workload. I think I thought this class would be a lot more theoretical and involve writing and stuff like that, but it's literally just a lot a lot of math.
best_gem_comment: If you are reading this, I assume you have some level of interest in physics. If you have any interest in physics, please take this course. Therefore, if you are reading this, please take this course. Physics 19 is an absolute gem of a class, and I promise you will not regret taking it. Professor Barandes is genuinely one of the kindest and wisest teachers I've ever had, and if you do take this course, I encourage you to block out some time to stay after class and simply talk with him. He is incredibly knowledgable and somehow manages to make very complicated and high–level topics understandable for a beginning physics student, or really anybody interested in the topic. Another thing that I think is important to mention is that although this class is many things, it is certainly not a slog at any point. It is fast paced and can definitely be hard to understand sometimes, but Professor Barandes somehow manages to keep everything interesting, and it leaves you wanting to learn more. This class is a gem, and I highly, highly, ..., highly recommend you take it.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take this class! It's super fun and manageable. Even if you have a little python knowledge already, the applications to solving ODE are super useful and it's a great way to learn about using python to solve real problems.  The teaching staff are great and lectures are interesting. It was held in Allston with mandatory attendance, which could be frustrating sometimes, but if you don't miss the bus it's not an issue at all .
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take this class! It's super fun and manageable. Even if you have a little python knowledge already, the applications to solving ODE are super useful and it's a great way to learn about using python to solve real problems.  The teaching staff are great and lectures are interesting. It was held in Allston with mandatory attendance, which could be frustrating sometimes, but if you don't miss the bus it's not an issue at all .
subject: Physics

best_comment: This is an awesome course! I felt like I learned so much about so many different fields in physics. The workload is incredibly reasonable—you just need to prepare a presentation for one of the speakers and write a final paper, both of which turned out to be quite enjoyable ways to learn a lot about a certain topic. You gain exposure to a wide array of physics sub–topics, so if you're interested in pursuing physics research and want to find a good topic (or even if you're not going into physics and just want to know about what's going on in the field), this is a perfect class for you!
subject: Physics

best_comment: I would highly recommend taking this class! Especially if Louis is teaching it. The material is very interesting if you're interested in mathematical physics. It's taught at a pace that is somewhat fast but still reasonable. You'll see each concept many times (in the textbook, in lecture, in section, on homework) which gives you plenty of opportunities to learn the material and not fall behind. Louis is a fantastic teacher! He explains the material well, and you can tell that he cares about you and your learning, which is great for helping you stay motivated throughout the class. He gives very fair homeworks and tests, and he has a great sense of humor.
worse_comment: If Louis is teaching, take the class! He tries to give a real intuition for quantum mechanics, and not just a framework for doing the math or solving problems. This intuition is something most students don't get until grad–level quantum, but Louis build his whole course around it. Take it with Louis!!
subject: Physics

best_comment: This course is definitely a step up from 143a with Louis, but the material is more interesting and the course is more rewarding. The lectures are pretty hard to follow, but the lecture notes are super helpful. The material sometimes seems pretty tedious, but you get to some pretty cool results and learn a lot of quantum mechanics that starts being applicable to research you might be doing. You also understand the 143a material way better after taking 143b.
worse_comment: Professor Randall is not the best lecturer, and it takes engagement in the class to understand what is going on. However, the lecture notes are well–formatted, and the assignments are good, so the material can be learned with some effort. Just be warned that confusion in lecture might occur frequently.
subject: Physics

best_comment: This class is a really great introduction to particle physics! It's a topic I had always been interested in, so I am super glad I took this course because I had such an enjoyable time! The course is really focused on maximizing what you can take away from it and having fun as opposed to grades or really rigorous assignments, so the relief from that pressure gives you more confidence in diving deep into the challenging concepts of the course. Girma was a fun professor since he was so excited about the material, and Alexis was a fantastic TF who was really devoted to helping you understand the material and led useful sections. The course assignments were all very fair. Overall a really fun class that I absolutely recommend if you're looking for a low–key, yet productive introduction to particle physics!
subject: Physics

best_comment: This was a great class, and I'd definitely recommend it.First, I found the content of this course to be incredibly interesting. The focus is not really on solving problems per se but understanding classical mechanics as a whole. Professor Jaffe develops the material in a very rigorous way, and I really gained a lot of appreciation for physics more broadly. This was a chance to push classical mechanics to its limits. I think the course is well organized, with an emphasis on symmetries a common thread throughout. The last couple weeks we branched out and talked briefly on a number of different topics and closed the course in a transitionary way between classical mechanics and quantum mechanics. As far as the lectures go, I found them to be quite good. It is very clear that Professor Jaffe is incredibly knowledgeable on this subject, and truly enjoys teaching. He will smile with glee as he derives an elegant result ('the matrix is Hermitian!'), and he starts every class by asking for questions – he wants the class to be engaged. He tries not to start without answering at least one question, which may be a tad awkward when nobody has any to offer, but it really is a great chance to make sure you're actively engaging with the material, and so if you take the class, come with questions! Quite honestly, I think this is a practice that should be done in every class.Professor Jaffe wrote very extensive and rigorous lecture notes, that take the place of a textbook for this course. He reworks them every year (!), and it is clear he cares a lot about having a good set of notes. In the process of rewriting them, some typos do get through, but he often finds them quite quickly and is fast to resolve them. While at times a typo can be a little frustrating, for better or for worse they do serve as good checks, to make sure you really understand that material and aren't just skimming through it on a surface level.  That notwithstanding, the notes are quite thorough and in–depth – a very useful resource indeed! His notes often go into more depth than in lecture (doing all derivations explicitly, etc.), or approach the problem in a different way, providing multiple approaches on a particular issue which can be quite useful. There was a topic or two for which I felt I'd benefit from additional outside reading, and David Tong's lecture notes have come highly recommended as a supplement to Prof. Jaffe's. But in general, I found his notes to be quite good, and the exercise of reading through them carefully (including derivations) to check my understanding was quite helpful. Also, I like Professor Jaffe. He is quite approachable, and always happy to talk. He's very nice, passionate, and an incredible physicist. Go to his office hours!Section was great, Ahmed was very thoughtful in what he went over, and it was a great opportunity to solidify ideas from lecture etc. And Ahmed was just very nice and helpful throughout the course, a great TF!Problem sets were not weekly, but every few weeks or so. Keep that in mind when looking at the hours/week. I personally liked this arrangement; physics nights were a great chance to knock out a good chunk of the pset. They were generally reasonable, although some of the derivations got quite tedious. Doable, but at times a lot of algebra/calculus, not necessarily the most fun. The cancellation was very satisfying when it worked out, but it often took some 'bashing.' Tests were not too bad, although at times I felt a little unsure of what to study. Professor Jaffe was quite clear on the topics that would be on the test, but we went into such depth in class that it was hard to know what extent of the material we needed to be comfortable with. I have to say, I think the grade breakdown was very fair, and I am quite fond of it. Tests were weighted enough that one did genuinely care about them and study hard, but at the same time weighted lightly enough that one was not unduly stressed. I think Professor Jaffe really has found a very good balance in the grade breakdown. I also am a fan of the final projects. I think it was a great opportunity to actually learn through doing, rather than focusing simply on regurgitating material. I know I learned a lot in my project and solidified a lot of ideas from the course by really applying them rigorously.Now, to talk about prerequisites. It's good to have some background with abstract linear algebra, but most things can be picked up along the way if needed. Also, basic vector calculus etc. As far as physics experience goes, I think it would be good to be at least familiar with Lagrangians, although not absolutely necessary. A lot of people were not exposed to them before and seem to have done well, yet I personally found it very helpful to have had some experience with them. More broadly, it's good to have had some classical mechanics background before this course, though not absolutely necessary. While the course may be doable without, I think one gets a lot more out of 151 with some such background than one would otherwise.I'm very glad I took this course and would recommend it! You'll come out of this having fallen in love with the Hamiltonian :)
subject: Physics

best_comment: Definitely take the class. Will let you play around and do some really cool experiments you wouldn't have the chance to otherwise. The student faculty ratio is great and you will receive help and supervision from very knowledgeable people. Your writing will improve a lot from the paper criticisms. Your ability to break down complex topics quickly without clear guidance also improves tremendously.
subject: Physics

subject: Physics

best_comment: The lectures are pretty good in general. Prof. Mundy is an experimentalist so she might not be super familiar with some detail but she gave pretty good intuition. Overall, some of the students found the course pretty slow. Some interesting topics like phonons and superconductivity are not introduced in detail. But for most student, I believe the pace is alright. I would recommend it as an intro to the field of condensed matter physics.
worse_comment: Do the problem sets on your own. Then ask questions in OH when you get stuck.

best_comment: Definitely take the class. Will let you play around and do some really cool experiments you wouldn't have the chance to otherwise. best_comment: You cannot rely on lectures for your learning of the course material, but Professor Vafa is really nice and don't be afraid to ask for clarification or ask questions.
worse_comment: Don't expect a satisfactory teaching of (time–dep and time–indep) perturbation theory.
subject: Physics

best_comment: The course is great! You can learn a lot about quantum field theory in this course. The assignments are very helpful to better understand the materials. Some familiarity with undergrad–level complex analysis and working with indices for tensors would be helpful. With Professor Yin, we also had the opportunity to do a final project to explore something interesting related to what we've learned in the course and it was a great way to learn how to approach a theoretical physics topic and very helpful for future work whether you will do theoretical physics or not because you would learn how to think deeply on a scientific issue and question yourself and keep pushing yourself to learn more.
worse_comment: Xi is probably the best lecturer I've had in the physics department. The course staff are accessible and the problem sets are well constructed. Workload is high but not unreasonable. Overall, a fantastic course.
subject: Physics

best_comment: Take this class if you are intrigued by the subject. It does involve a lot of work but you also learn a lot. The concepts covered in the course are quite diverse and have wide applicability, so definitely worth taking it, even if you are not from an immediate physics background or pursuing a physics degree. Depending on person teaching this course, you might be recommended to register for only this course in a term, particularly if you are grad student involved in research as the work load can be quite intensive. However, definitely worth the effort.
worse_comment: Don't let the midterm grading discourage you. Vinny has high expectations. Choose your group members who have similar research interests
subject: Physics

best_comment: Prof. Falkovich's version of Physics 268aR has a great lecture note and wonderful material. However, I found the lectures quite confusing oftentimes, although I had a good preparation in terms of physics prerequisite before taking this class. Since the TF in our year was amazing, I recommend this class as you will learn some interesting contents in information theory and how it is related to physics. However, you might not learn a lot directly from the lecture but more from the TF or the lecture note.
worse_comment: To understand the physics behind this course, you need to be completely fluent in statistical mechanics. However, to understand the information theory, you need almost no background.

course_title: Topics in the Physics of Quantum Information 001
best_comment: This class teaches you a broad and pretty detailed overview of quantum technologies. It is a great class if you want to improve your paper reading skills, presentation skills, and learn more about some quantum technologies you might never otherwise work with. This class has a considerable amount of work, and it definitely requires a bit more background than an intro to QI course such as Phys 160. Prof. Lukin's effort in listening to everyone's presentation closely is also admirable.
worse_comment: difficult to do course alone. many students know each other already from working in one of the qc groups.

course_title: Inference, Information Theory, Learning and Statistical Mechanics 001
best_comment: This class has an excellent promise of teaching about solving inverse problems with statistical tools. That is definitely a very deep and useful topic. But the materials could use some more polish. The initial 1/3 is excellent, the middle 1/3 starts to feel weak, and the final 1/3 covering unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning is not well–organized. As we paced through a range of interesting topics, we barely had the time to even properly scratch the surface. As a result, please think twice the reason that you want to take this course: if you want to learn some tools and interconnected concepts, great, this course could do it, but if you want to develop a rigorous and cohesive understanding of machine learning and its connection to information theory of physics, I'd probably suggest taking a difference course from CS, Stats, or even applied maths department.
This class was very well–taught and gave me a lot of new knowledge about string theory as well as the methods used in theoretical physics research.
subject: Physics

course_title: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids 001
best_comment: Great class, and you don't need any knowledge of solid state beforehand. The problem sets being every 10–14 days was great, and Subir's lectures are nice and clear (although sometimes a bit slow). Workload was light compared to some other physics classes I've taken.
worse_comment: Establish a wide net of problem set partners. Didn’t realize everyone in the class was doing this until too late.
subject: Physics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Quantum Theory of Solids

best_comment: Great class if you're interested at all in low–dimensional physics. Problem sets are biweekly which is super nice too!

course_title: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers 001
best_comment: If you're hoping to learn specific writing techniques (e.g. grammar, syntax, flow), then this probably isn't the class for you. However, if you are hoping to learn about overarching principles of scientific writing—such as how to make a timeline for writing a journal publication, how to make clear figures, and how to determine authorship—then this class covers all that and more. Suzanne and Dan really care about this class and put in so much effort to make it an enriching experience for everyone, and it's a great class to develop confidence in your overall writing abilities.
subject: Physics
course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title_2023: Professional Writing for Scientists and Engineers

course_title: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences I 001
best_comment: This is a course required for PHS PhD students, though students can elect to waive out of the coursework and just sit for the exams. I would encourage everyone to take the full course rather than just the exams. While this means you will have to complete problem sets, they are extremely helpful for the exams and also help you to get a deeper understanding of the course concepts and ultimately the concepts underlying modeling that you will do in your research. The problem sets are not that much work either in comparison to other courses, such as the Epi sequence. The exams themselves are fair – they can be long, but you are well–prepared to do well on them if you spend time with the course material. In addition, you will get great exposure to a truly wonderful teaching team. Never have I experienced such a group of professors and TFs so strongly dedicated to teaching.
subject: Population Health Sciences
course_title_2023: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences I

subject: Population Health Sciences
course_title_2023: Quantitative Research Methods in Population Health Sciences I

best_comment: Interesting class. I will say it covers a lot of the content you need to know for the MCAT for all the premeds out there, so I think it's good to take while studying for the MCAT because the content overlaps well. The midterms are alright. Definitely study for them, make sure you look back at the lecture slides and know the experiments, and definitely read the textbook. They ask about some pretty obscure details from the chapters sometimes, and I know they say rereading isn't a good way to study, but honestly rereading/skimming through the chapters and additional readings a couple days before the midterms actually worked out really well for me as I was more likely to remember small details from the textbook that they would ask about on exams. The exam questions are pretty fair. However, a lot of the questions are simply there to test whether you actually did the readings rather than testing your understanding of psychology, so make sure you actually read through the entire reading/chapter, even though some of the information might not seem important/relevant, because they might ask about a small detail that you'll want to recognize as the right answer on the test. A little annoying, I know, but hopefully they'll change that up. Midterms aren't too bad overall though, and an A is definitely possible if you just put some work in. Overall a pretty interesting and not super awful class.
worse_comment: PSY1 is a fun course as a whole but the exams are extremely difficult. The professor emphasizes the importance of reading the textbook but many students often found it useless as none of the content from the book showed up on the exam. The test format is also unfair, with 25 multiple choice questions each worth 3 points, and 5 written responses worth 5 points each. It's extremely difficult to get an A on any exam. I would recommend studying early for these exams and possibly finding a study group for this class. My biggest regret is not taking this class pass/fail. Only take this course letter graded if needed for concentration/pre–med requirements.
subject: Psychology

subject: Psychology

best_comment: Content: I found the material super compelling (at least in the first 8 weeks). Much of the material we covered seems to be the subject of active research,  so the material is not as beautifully packaged as it would be in an undergrad CS or pure biology class where the results are pretty old and at least well established. I found this to be a really cool thing. The profs and TAs are in the midst of the experiments which end up on the slides. As someone with no psych background nor any related long term goals, I found this very fun. Sections were great and the recordings basically contain the exam solutions. Workload: There was a short assignment (20 min including reading) where you proposed a question for the author of a current research paper which cumulatively less than 10% of the grade. The bulk of the workload is a few hours of studying for each of the three tests (including a final). One cannot do well without studying (i.e. memorizing the lecture material). There is also a short writing assignment. I found the tests useful and necessary for my internalizing the material.
worse_comment: I felt that there were a lot of final assignments that made this course more stressful towards the end. I think there should have been more resources/guidance on the final paper.
subject: Psychology
