best_comment: Go to lectures!!! It will prove to be super helpful, and the content of the lecture is also super interesting too. Dr Shingleton incorporates many examples from her clinical experience which help us understand the concepts better. I would say this is my favorite course this semester. Take this class if you are interested in psychopathology or just want to learn a bit about psychology in general –– it definitely is super interesting and fun. I would say the class doesn't require any prerequisite knowledge on the subject. Tests are fair and not too difficult, and the memoirs are actually interesting to read.
worse_comment: Take it if you are looking to learn general knowledge about mental health, but no deep exploration and analysis. Section for this course is not necessary.
best_gem_comment: I learned so much in this class and it was also so easy. It was really mind opening and I loved that we watched videos of people experiencing different psychopathological issues so we could learn to empathize with them. One thing that was maybe not so great was that some of the people in my section would laugh at and make fun of certain disorders but I think that's more to do with the kind of people who take this class than the teachers (it's considered a GEM  so a lot of people take it without genuine interest in and respect for the topic). Overall, an amazing class and so interesting with an amazing professor and amazing course staff, but I think some sensitivity training in section would be amazing.

best_comment: Excellent class! I only wish it wasn't so early. Ellen seems a bit too optimistic at times, but she grows on you and makes you think of life a bit brighter. The TFs are wonderful and the class itself is very engaging and fun. Definitely recommend to take it!
worse_comment: take this class if you want a gem but just know prof. langer says some controversial things sometimes
best_gem_comment: This class is extremely beneficial for general life mindset and perspective. I would consider it a GEM that actually gives you useful information for life.
subject: Psychology

course_title: The Science and Psychology of Music 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! Mayron is the absolute best, he is so passionate about this course and what he teaches and truly wants his students to learn and enjoy the course. Work load is super manageable and the assignments are super interesting which makes them fun to do.  I learned so much throughout the course and was excited to go to class everyday. 1000000% recommend
worse_comment: Don't take this course if you want to be challenged in every aspect of your academic experience.
best_gem_comment: THIS COURSE IS A GEM!!! MAYRON AND THE ENTIRE TEACHING TEAM IS AMAZING! You get to learn so much about music and psychology all while having fun! The assignments are really manageable, and this is really one of those courses where you get out what you put into the course. Highly recommend overall!
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: The Science and Psychology of Music

best_comment: I think everyone should take this course! This changed the trajectory of my concentration and my post–college goals. I thoroughly enjoyed every lecture, reading, and assignment. It was hands–down the best class I've taken at Harvard.
This is a great class, and one of my favorites in the psychology department. The material is interesting, and the workload is pretty light. Dr. Levari is a great lecturer, too!
worse_comment: This is a good basic course, but is not very engaging. The material can be a bit dry and not straightforward but overall digestible.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: I would not call it the best class that I have taken at Harvard, but it is definitely a great course! I would for sure take it again just to talk to Dr. Lukas because he is exceptionally insightful and engaging. His great public speaking skills and sense of humor definitely compensated for the extremely busy slides with tons of info on them (they should be restructured). I would say that to enjoy the course, you constantly need to remind yourself of the bigger picture of why we are studying each of the drug classes. Otherwise, it feels like training for pharmacists since you need to know the different names of drugs and their biomolecular functions.
worse_comment: Keep up with the lectures so you're familiar with the material. Study hard for the midterm and harder for the final because it has open response. Study the quizzes for the tests.
best_gem_comment: This class is great. Very low stress, the quizzes are not very difficult if you just read through the lecture slides right before. Midterm was very fair and I did much better than anticipated, and I only studied the day before. The debate was easy even though i despise public speaking. You can make up like up to 6 quizzes or something so even if you miss/bomb some it's totally chill. Section was super chill, if Diana is still a TF you should try to get her, she rocks! Material is super interesting, even to someone who is not particularly interested in clinical stuff. Also just generally relevant/good to know info for navigating life. Professor Lukas is super enthusiastic and makes lectures enjoyable and interesting. If you're looking for a psych/neuro gem that is not only low workload/stress but also interesting, definitely take this!!! Loved it, highly recommend.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Brain Damage as a Window into the Mind: Cognitive Neuropsychology 001
best_comment: Great course, professor caramazza is great, very knowledgeable about all of the subjects he teaches. He is also enthusiastic and funny which always makes a class more interesting. Encourages everyone to come to office hours and ask questions whenever they have them, which is very helpful
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Brain Damage as a Window into the Mind: Cognitive Neuropsychology

course_title: Essentials of fMRI for Cognitive Neuroscientists 001
best_comment: Amazing course! Highly recommend. fMRI was made comprehendible even if you have no previous knowledge of the technique! I had no background of fMRI and I now feel like I know so much and could design many types of studies. This is definitely a methods focused class, so do not expect to learn about findings using fMRI, rather how fMRI works and how to design the studies themselves. Super useful if you are planning to do fMRI research in the future. Weekly quizzes are for you to test your knowledge on the week's material. Lots of the assignments in this class are mostly for you to test your knowledge and they are intended for you to learn rather than the be tested on. You will work through an fMRI paper and analyze its design in class, and you will also be able to apply concepts you learn in class on BrainVoyager software and have the chance to work with real brain data! You will also get to explore topics on your own when you do your presentation, which is focused on a teaching the technique to another person. Great class overall!
worse_comment: This class is relatively easy week to week, but I had to cram for the exam since there weren't many good check ins throughout the semester.

course_title: Debugging the Brain: Computational Approaches to Mental Dysfunction 001
best_comment: Really great course! We had a diverse group of students including psychiatrist in training which made conversations very interesting. If you are interested a new way of looking at mental disorders take this course. Readings can be challenging, but Sam is able and happy to answer any questions.

course_title: Neuroscience Fiction: An Introduction to Cutting Edge Neuroscience through the Lens of Film and Tele 001
best_comment: I would highly highly highly recommend that you take this class, if you have the fortune to do so. Wonderful professor who is so kind and caring and truly cares that you learn and have a chance to reflect on current advancements in neuroscience. An exceptional selection of movie clips that will get your mind going at the beginning of each class. Thoughtful and really really fun discussions about not just the movies but also neuroscience papers that use cutting–edge techniques. You really get to go deep into few papers, which I truly appreciated. All told, take it if you can. One of the few classes which I can recommend without reservation.

course_title: Power and Society in Romantic Relationships 001
best_comment: This class is great!! You do the readings, come to class, and have discussions about it. Got to talk about so many different aspects of love, romance, and attraction.
This was a great class. Fiery is such a great professor and held great conversations during seminar. He was really good at breaking down important concepts through conceptual exercises.
worse_comment: This course is a phenomenal exploration of how different aspects of culture and socialization operate and can change between environments. I would highly encourage you take this course and spend time with the material to both criticize what it is arguing and look at what the implications are of what it is trying to say.
best_gem_comment: Take this class it's a gem and so so interesting.

best_comment: This was one of my favourite psych classes. The professor is amazing. She is super enthusiastic and loves teaching. She keeps classes fun and keeps you engaged. She is very personable. Class for is very manageable and it is easy to get an A if you show up and complete the assignments. Would recommend to anyone

course_title: Controlling the Uncontrollable? Emotion Regulation and Well-Being 001
best_comment: This is a great class if you want to learn about emotion regulation. Jess is an excellent professor, and nearly all of my critiques of the class are critiques of the research literature itself.Out of all my classes, Jess is the professor who cares about my learning the most. It's not even close. She's given so much detailed feedback and structured the assignments in a way where I actually put in the work to get things out of the class. If you don't want to do the readings for a class, don't take it. The weekly readings are fairly reasonable and can get done in 30–60 minutes, so it's really not a big deal.The class itself is 2 hours and usually split equally between lecture about the weekly emotion regulation topics and discussion led by other students in the class. There are no phones/computers allowed and the discussions can be pretty fun, but sometimes because the class is so long it can drag. It's very nice that it only meets once a week, though.Emotion regulation research is very early. Some of the studies we reviewed are not nearly as rigorous or interesting as I'd hoped, and it felt that a majority of the field's findings converged on a few emotion regulation strategies (e.g.,, reappraisal, suppression, etc.). Moreover, the curriculum could've focused more on how to apply these findings – how can you *actually* improve emotion regulation in yourself or others? How can you spot good/bad emotion regulation behaviors? TLDR: definitely take the class if you like the topic, Jess is great

This class is truly incredible. Professor Singh is one of the most brilliant young professors at Harvard and this class is really the first of its kind in the field of technology and how it effects our mental health. Shifali's expertise in the area helps you recognize the size and scope of the issue at hand and gives everyone in the class a chance to learn more and weigh in on their stance. The smaller class setup provides for an engaged community who you'll find you really get to know pretty well by the end of the semester. The assignments are not too strenuous and are actually quite fun and thought–provoking. A no–brainer of a class to take if you're interested in getting an in–depth look of how technology impacts our mental health–– for better and for worse.
worse_comment: I think that this class is an important one to take. As we move into a world that is continuously more reliant on technology, it's important that we, as the next generation, learn how to build it in a sustainable way. Understanding how exactly technology interfaces with our mental health can equip us to make a difference to the current global crisis.
best_gem_comment: THIS CLASS IS A MASSIVE GEM! I LOVED IT, AND I LEARNED SO MUCH FROM DR. SINGH! SHE REALLY IS THE BEST!! Take this class!! You learn about all the ways mental health and the digital era interact with each other through a clinical lens. You will also gain so much insight on mental health issues through readings and class assignments. THIS IS A MUST FOR YOUR COLLEGE EXPERIENCE! So much of it can also be applied and used in your daily life beyond college!
subject: Psychology

course_title: Broken Brains: Mechanisms and Markers of Mental Illness 001
best_comment: This class is a gem in the way that it is very enjoyable and you will easily get a good grade since the professor wants you to succeed. The course is truly structured to make it so that you do not have too much on your plate at once so that you are actually learning the course content. I'd definitely recommend this class to anyone particularly interested in research on reward processing, psychopathology, neuroimaging (especially fMRI/dMRI), and just generally understanding different types of psychology research.
best_gem_comment: This class is a gem in the way that it is very enjoyable and you will easily get a good grade since the professor wants you to succeed. The course is truly structured to make it so that you do not have too much on your plate at once so that you are actually learning the course content. I'd definitely recommend this class to anyone particularly interested in research on reward processing, psychopathology, neuroimaging (especially fMRI/dMRI), and just generally understanding different types of psychology research.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Broken Brains: Mechanisms and Markers of Mental Illness

course_title: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences 001
best_comment: This class is super easy, but you'll still come away from it with a practical understanding of how to use statistical tests in psychology research. I really appreciated how the course was structured – the flipped classroom and weekly quizzes helped me learn and were very manageable, even though they may seem annoying on paper. Grace cares so much about the class and works hard to make the learning experience as best for students as possible (ex: all exams were open–book with no time limit, and there were many extra credit opportunities). She truly wants everyone to succeed. Take this class for an easy QRD with a kind and caring professor!
worse_comment: Very very easy course but frustrating at times because going to class is useless since no teaching happens then.
best_gem_comment: This is quite a gem, but also super interesting and useful if you have no background in statistics. As someone who has never taken a stats class before, I would 100% recommend to anyone trying to break in the field or even gain a deeper understanding of reading psychological reports. Outstanding professor, teaching staff, and course as a whole!
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics for the Behavioral Sciences

best_comment: Mina is a great professor! I honestly liked how the class was set up because I didn't really think much about my grade as much as making a coherent, comprehensive study. I will say that the assignments not having deadlines made it hard for me to keep track of things because assignments with deadlines are usually listed on the right side of the Canvas main page. However, the course staff was super lenient with deadlines and really did their best to make it as least stressful as possible for the students—that was extremely appreciated on our end.
worse_comment: Prepare to spend a lot of time learning the material required for the later assignments on your own. You will need a lot of time for trial and error on the final project.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: It may be useful for students to take an R focused course prior to learn the platform and then enroll in this course to learn how to apply the knowledge/use of R in statistical contexts. This course is most helpful if you want to learn how to apply R to data analyses you want to work on for your research, but is really the most helpful when you already know R (e.g., it is not a course focused on training you in R although it provides some information in this regard). I would recommend that students who enter this course choose this because they want to learn applied statistics approaches that happen to involve analyzing data in R, rather than to choose this course as a starting point for learning R for the first time. (However, this comment is given with the caveat that I came into the course already knowing R, but  from my own prior experiences entering similar courses without R training and from what I have heard from those who haven't had prior R training before enrolling in this course, I can imagine that for me it would have been very difficult and incredibly time–consuming involving substantives amount of time (beyond the average/recommended) to put in to finish problem sets compared to peers who do know). That all being said, this course can be a helpful tool for students ready to engage in independent research to gain the tools to conduct the appropriate data analyses for their work consistent with current statistical and reporting standards for research publication.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: I would tell future students to ask faculty specifically what they are looking for in a successful vs non successful response paper. I would also tell them to write about what truly interests them as it can be a great opportunity to brainstorm real ideas.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: I would tell future students to ask faculty specifically what they are looking for in a successful vs non successful response paper. I would also tell them to write about what truly interests them as it can be a great opportunity to brainstorm real ideas.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: Highly recommend. One of the best classes I've taken. Patrick has made a really excellent course that focuses on practical applications of a broad array of psychometric methods (factor analysis, structural equation modeling, network analysis, item response theory) with no math background required and just some introductory–intermediate statistics required, but still briefly provides theoretical/mathematical aspects for those interested. He provides a lot of code to get started, and it's all the code you need to do the exams which are straightforward. He's available for office hours and collaborations and encourages discussion. He's also really an expert on the topic, having written an excellent textbook himself, and has a lot of insight on different additional methods to try out.
worse_comment: Psychology PhD students: take this class! Don't think you need psychometrics for your research? You're wrong! You absolutely do! If not for primary results, AT LEAST for cultivating a more complete understanding of your data in your early stages of analysis.

best_comment: I would highly recommend joining this lab and taking the course. A lot of opportunities for undergraduates to engage with an active lab and develop research ideas into publishable projects.
subject: Psychology

course_title: Laboratory for Clinical and Developmental Research 001
best_comment: Take it! The Nock lab is such a nice and supportive group of people. And you'll be exposed to some really cool work.
subject: Psychology
course_title_2023: Laboratory for Clinical and Developmental Research

best_comment: This course is very dependent on who you are paired with, I would assume, but Nicole was amazing and it was so great to learn from her and develop a relationship with her. I worked as a confederate in the Behavioral Lab at HBS which was such a cool experience. That was the bulk of my work. I also helped with some work on Excel. I really liked how different this experience was from my other classes – it was much more experiential obviously and paired well with classes like PSY 1900 and 1901.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: This lab is such a special community, and you’ll get to meet individuals with a range of different interests who are all united by their curiosity about the individual mind and how it interacts with society. I am grateful for all of the friendships and mentor relationships I have built here. One piece of advice is don’t be afraid to ask questions about psychological or statistical concepts you might not know — I was for a while, but usually, most of the undergrads are in the same boat. Even if it is something that feels elementary to a social psych lab, everyone is very understanding and happy to explain a concept.
Langer is the best. She creates an equal working environment where everyone is encouraged to share their ideas instead of be judged and graded for them.
subject: Psychology

best_comment: It's a great course and you will get out of it what you put in.

It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.

It's a difficult but rewarding class/experience. Interacting with these experts of the field was a pleasure and even if it might not be polished yet, as it is a new class, it's worth your time and effort.

course_title: Topics in Regional Studies East Asia: Proseminar 1
best_comment: Great opportunity to be exposed to other disciplines.
worse_comment: It can be frustrated sometimes when you have to read papers you can barely understand.
subject: Regional Studies - East Asia
course_title_2023: Topics in Regional Studies East Asia: Proseminar

course_title: Who Needs God? Rethinking God in Light of Hindu and Christian Theologies 01
best_comment: Great class overall. Beware of the writing assignments, though. You might think you have a certain degree of freedom in choosing your topics because, frankly, the Professor’s expectation to stick to only course readings/themes is not really ever specified. Don’t end up like me and have a final project that you threw your heart and three straight days of no sleep into get absolutely trashed by an oddly distrustful Clooney.

TAKE THIS CLASS, its so intersectional in so many different topics (evolutionary biology, feminism, anthropology, african/AA studies, and of course religion). As a conference course, there's a very good mix of short lectures for background context on the readings, and seminar–style discussion.  The class itself attracts the most interesting people with different religious focuses different relationships with motherhood, providing a super warm class environment, very inviting of different perspectives. Very interesting and wide–spanning topics in the course across weeks (the syllabus gives a great preview)! Professor Patton and our TF Jessica were amazing, and really care about their students, and about dignifying motherhood.

I would recommend this class to anyone interested in Christian evangelicalism. I took it as an undergrad, so it was more difficult coursework than I am used to, but the professor and teaching fellows were so accommodating and helpful with any questions or issues we had. Very reading heavy (the readings were always excellent though), but light on assignments – just a couple of papers and discussion posts. One thing I loved about the class was how responsive the professor was to feedback. She truly did care about students and wanted to make sure everyone was succeeding in the class. Fascinating class, amazing lectures, amazing teachers – strongly recommend.

This is an incredibly well–put–together and interesting class and I would highly recommend it with one reservation. The difficulty level of the course is a bit high. It's nothing ridiculous but I would highly recommend taking the course pass/fail if you are unfamiliar with the topic and do not want to devote a lot of time to the subject matter. When taken pass/fail, the course is a bit more relaxed and you can focus more on the content of the readings and the discussions without worrying as much about your grade or completing tons of assignments. One of the most interesting and unique courses I've taken at Harvard!
subject: Religion

best_comment: This is an amazing class! Although challenging at times, the topics and discussions held in class are extremely important and meaningful. You don't need any background in Canadian history to take this class! The assignments are very reasonable and Pamela is a great professor. We had many great guest lecturers and we even got to go on a few outings. This class does have a lot of readings in the first half of the semester but you can manage your time you should be fine. Please please please take one of Pamela's classes if you get the chance!
subject: Religion

course_title: Issues in the Study of Native American Religion 01
best_comment: Difficult topics and readings, and really excellent visiting lecturers. If you're interested in learning about the religious dimension to contemporary issues that Native American communities face, I would highly recommend this course.
worse_comment: I personally would tell Native students to be very cautious when taking this course, and I am not sure I would recommend it for Natives. I felt uncomfortable most of the time and left almost every class angry or frustrated with what other students in the class had said. This class was definitely interesting but was also one of the most ignorant spaces I have encountered at this school thus far.
subject: Religion
course_title_2023: Issues in the Study of Native American Religion

best_comment: Great class with Professor Asani, he's so kind and knowledgeable. Definitely a bit of work including listening to lectures outside of class, doing readings, and going to section, but overall manageable. Definitely worth engaging with the material and going to office hours with Asani. Overall a solid pick if you're interested and know nothing at all.

PROFESSOR ASANI IS A LEGEND!!! Take this class if you are remotely even interested in the subject. The class is very chill and you get to learn a lot by discussing various topics. Professor Asani even has a mid–way break with snacks and tea!!!!

course_title: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World 003
best_comment: The class is a very welcoming and wholesome environment, and Emily was a really encouraging TF who would readily provide feedback and answer the questions that we have. The course material isn't too difficult, and the course isn't the hardest; I would recommend it if you struggle with confidence speaking or writing in French.
subject: French
course_title_2023: Upper level French : Current Events and Media in the Francophone World

course_title: Advanced French II: Écrivons droit(s)/ Writing Right(s): Justice, Equity, Rights, and Writing 001
best_comment: Would highly recommend this class and Dr. Turman! This is the first French course I have taken at Harvard in person (took 2 on zoom), and it was very enjoyable. Class time has a very relaxed feel, mostly focusing on conversation with other students about various aspects of writing or pieces that we were reading. I definitely improved my speaking and listening skills because of this. The most stressful aspects of the course were vocabulary quizzes which were very short and easy (just know the words) and in–class essays. However, Dr. Turman is very fair in grading in–class essays, and they are a smaller part of your grade than the final product. Additionally, it was very helpful to have a template with feedback when you go to write the second draft! In short, would highly recommend! I learned a lot from this class without being too stressed about it.
subject: French
course_title_2023: Advanced French II: Justice, Equity, Rights, and Language

course_title: Exploring French Language in North America through Text, Image, and Culture 001
best_comment: This is the very best french course I took at Harvard to fulfill my citation. It is incredibly interesting, and the topic is not something easily found in french courses (at Harvard or elsewhere). Grading is not harsh at all, and the essays throughout the semester all help you formulate your final paper so the workload is not horrible at all ! The community in this course was great, and Dr. Brisson was an amazing professor, always sweet and helpful and responsive to the needs of the class. One of my favorite memories is one day where class was hosted outdoors because it was a beautiful day ! You will definitely not regret taking this class.
subject: French
course_title_2023: Exploring French Language in North America through Text, Image, and Culture

course_title: Genres of Self: French Autobiographical Writing 001
best_comment: This class is truly amazing! The course readings, assignments and the final project all breeze by in such a pleasant manner because Matthew never makes it feel daunting or pressuring! The class discussions are awesome because every student catches different elements that stand out to them, and then, as a class, we dissect and explore those literary devices/methods together. This was a great class for learning more academic French through readings of classic and novel autobiographies (and different styles of writing autobiographies), and for exploring our own motivations if we choose to write one of our own! Definitely recommend:)

course_title: Growing Pains: Le roman d'apprentissage, l'apprentissage du roman 001
best_comment: French 128 is undoubtedly the best French class I've ever taken and will forever be one of my favorite classes at Harvard. Professor Kim not only helped us to improve our French reading, writing, and speaking skills but also taught us how to reflect critically on our society and how it has shaped us. Each class offered a rare and much appreciated opportunity to slow down and unpack my identity as well as purpose in life. I am also so grateful for the really welcoming and safe environment Professor Kim was able to create that allowed everyone in the class to quickly open up and learn from one another to the fullest. Please take this class!!

course_title: A La Francaise: French Feminisms Today 001
best_comment: Professor Jardine is incredible! She is a passionate, engaged professor who truly wants the best for her students.

course_title: Advanced Italian I: Italian Through Cinema: Oral Expression and Performance 001
best_comment: While a lot of work, this class is very rewarding and a lot of fun. I loved the films we watched and our class discussions were always so insightful and engaging. The Italian classes at Harvard are so well structured and it is always my favorite class on my schedule :) would recommend to anyone
subject: Italian
course_title_2023: Advanced Italian I: Italian Through Cinema: Oral Expression and Performance

best_comment: Take this course! The Professor is, and I say this without exaggeration, one of the brightest minds not only at Harvard, but out there. He is someone who will inspire you through the humanities and his way of seeing the world to look at life differently and to ponder upon the questions that truly merit thought. I am a senior now and will truly miss the chances of being able to sit and hear his thoughts, to be with him has been one of the greatest privileges of my time here.

It's a wonderful class with a great professor. The seminars can be long but the readings are quite manageable (make sure to clarify the page requirements for weekly readings!) and always informative. You will learn about fascism, Italian fascist history, Italian history, and more random tidbits from the fields of history, art, architecture, poetry... It is mostly graduate students so if you are an undergraduate do keep that in mind, but the professor is so receptive to undergraduates and flexible with the specifics on their requirements if need be that the experience was a real pleasure.

course_title: Intermediate Portuguese I: Justice, Equity and Rights in the Lusophone world 001
best_comment: Cris is an incredible professor –– definitely the kind of professor you will remember fondly years after taking this course. She teaches with so much enthusiasm and passion that it is difficult not to fall in love with Portuguese. The social issues and speakers that make up this course make it an academically enriching experience, but Cris makes it an enjoyable course.
subject: Portuguese
course_title_2023: Intermediate Portuguese I: Justice, Equity and Rights in the Lusophone world

best_comment: Prof. Kim is one of the most generous and sharp readers that I have encountered throughout the Phd. She is a really fantastic professor and her course teaches crucial lessons for everyone who wants to follow an academic career.
subject: Romance Languages

course_title: Haiti, Cuba, Martinique: Plotting Resistance in Fiction and Film 001
best_comment: Take this class!!! Dr. Richman is the absolute best, and facilitates class discussions so well. The topics are so important, and assignments/discussion flow very well because they are quite flexible. Especially great if you are getting a secondary in French/Spanish and want to take this course for your secondary!

This class serves as a focused film survey course on the great, great films of the past. (a focus on French film and Italian film).  Prof. Conley is exceptionally well versed on the great films and how literature and psychoanalysis meet cinema.It's a course that is more loosely structured and lectures are not some kind of text–book like speech. Rather, lectures can serve as jumping off points for discussion or related discussions on adjacent films. Write down all of these adjacent films that Prof. Conley mentions throughout a lecture and study them in the library, you've just made the best version of a film survey course at Harvard. I recommend Prof. Conley's film courses to all students.

This is a relatively heavier time commitment during the semester so be sure you're ready for that! I spent ~4 hours on the weekly writing assignments, ~4–5 hours on the readings (which are long, dense, theoretical texts). Plus you have to create an activity for one week (extra time going in depth on the readings, ~1.5 hour meeting with the professors, creating and gathering materials with a partner) and write modest length final paper at 7–8 pages (written as a "companion piece" to another paper so you don't have to come up with a new idea). I think this time commitment was proportional to the rewards I reaped from this course––but I do think it's helpful to be informed about how much this class will demand from you on a weekly basis.
worse_comment: Only enroll if you like a highly demanding course based on self–learning. Professors don't explain readings. The assignments require a lot of time and effort that aren't worthy. Also, the game pedagogy could be hard and confusing.
subject: Romance Studies

best_comment: This is a relatively heavier time commitment during the semester so be sure you're ready for that! I spent ~4 hours on the weekly writing assignments, ~4–5 hours on the readings (which are long, dense, theoretical texts). Plus you have to create an activity for one week (extra time going in depth on the readings, ~1.5 hour meeting with the professors, creating and gathering materials with a partner) and write modest length final paper at 7–8 pages (written as a "companion piece" to another paper so you don't have to come up with a new idea). I think this time commitment was proportional to the rewards I reaped from this course––but I do think it's helpful to be informed about how much this class will demand from you on a weekly basis.
worse_comment: Only enroll if you like a highly demanding course based on self–learning. Professors don't explain readings. The assignments require a lot of time and effort that aren't worthy. Also, the game pedagogy could be hard and confusing.
subject: Romance Studies

best_comment: This class was probably my favorite class of the semester, although it didn't start out that way. In the first week, this course made me absolutely terrified. I came in with no prior Spanish knowledge, and the Spanish professors speak exclusively in Spanish (from day one)! Be prepared to be challenged linguistically, and remember that YOU decide how much you get out of this course. You can probably do fine (and maybe even get a better grade) if you stick to the simplest sentence structures, vocabulary, and grammar, but you will learn a lot more if you push yourself to use more complex structures and vocabulary, even if it means you might miss a few points on a test or interview. The work in this class is not overwhelming, but you should probably write down or at least make note of all of the due dates at the beginning of the course. They are not evenly spaced out, so you might find yourself having no work outside of class one week, but having work outside of class every day in another week. Also, if you aren't sure that Spanish is right for you, you might consider how much time you're willing to devote to learning the language (well). The Spanish department requires a 95+ to get an A for the GPA, but this is not the same for other languages (93 for an A is Harvard "norm," and those 2 points really can make it all the more challenging to get an A). Keep that in mind.Above all, the small class size (about 15 students) and amount of time spent (four days a week) has made this course feel like a family. Our instructor, Andrea, has been nothing short of fantastic. I really admire her for all the work she puts into this course (because she is also incredibly busy outside of this course!). I feel confident that I could communicate effectively in a Spanish–speaking country or community after just one short semester of Spanish. Be prepared to work hard, but remember that the end goal is simple: learning as much Spanish as you can in order to communicate with other Spanish speakers! Don't get too caught up in the homework or exams, and remember that this is a new language. You aren't meant to know everything from the beginning. I got really frustrated a few times this year, but something has really clicked in the past few weeks and everything has really started to make sense. This class has inspired me to pursue a Spanish citation, and I've also been able to find some really amazing Spanish music that is now always on repeat while I study or just listen to music for fun! ¡Buena suerte!
worse_comment: Be careful about the section attendance. The class punishes students really severely (half a letter grade) for each absence beyond 3.
subject: Spanish

best_comment: This class is definitely worth it if you plan to continue with Spanish in the future. It is very encouraging and the instructors are there for you to succeed not bring you down.
subject: Spanish

course_title: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures 001
best_comment: Get the Rojas y Curry "Gramatica Esencial" grammar review book that the course recommends (it's also at the Harvard library system if you get it before other students) and use that to study grammar. It's very well–structured and directly applies to the grammar that is barely reviewed in class but shows up on every exam. This is a fun course. You will be pushed to speak and understand spoken Spanish, as well as to read at a high level with a complicated vocabulary set and all grammar forms. You'll have to get better at reading and understanding based on context clues and vocabulary you know because there will be too much new vocab for you to look up every word you don't recognize. Reading "Cronica de una muerte anunciada" is the most intense portion of the course – the other readings aren't too too long and grading for writing pieces, exams, and conversations, is quite fair (maybe a little too easy :) That being said, there are pretty consistent assignments that will take time, most notably the writing compositions.The presentations are actually quite interesting, so look forward to the other students' presentations and a chance to share some cool research in Spanish!Johanna Liander's section is the best.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Upper-level Spanish: Four Countries and their Cultures

course_title: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World 003
best_comment: This course is awesome! Each of the movies we watched was very interesting and fostered great discussion. I learned a lot about Latin American cinema and history. The class is mostly discussion–based so I got a lot more confident in my Spanish speaking abilities and comprehension. I felt like there was a  strong sense of community built in the class among the section leader and the rest of the students which made it fun to come to class every day. The course had a manageable work load as well
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Advanced Spanish Language I: Viewing the Hispanic World

best_comment: Highly recommend! Class discussions are relevant and low–stress, the teaching pair is excellent and supportive. The community service element is the cornerstone of your experience, so make the most out of your assigned organization! The class gets you out of the Harvard language bubble and into the actual Spanish–speaking world –– which I personally think is the place where we should be speaking Spanish anyway. Assignments are mostly movie notes and short readings, and the essays are brief and centered around the work you're doing with your organization. Find something fun and meaningful for your final project, the second half of the semester is all about your work there.
worse_comment: if your skill level is higher than spanish 40 then this class can be very boring since a lot of the other students are at a lower leveli would still take it again though but just keep the in–class experience in mind because it is not just volunteering
subject: Spanish

course_title: The Ethics of Business in Latin America 002
best_comment: For context, I've taken Spanish throughout high school; Spanish 30, 40 at Harvard; and studied abroad for a summer in a Spanish–speaking country. That being said, my personal level of fluency enriched my participation in the course, but that was never a barrier to entry. Take this course if you're anything resembling a freshman who's pretty confident in their language ability. Super easy workload (3 hours a week tops) and exams are oral with a group. Discussions are very interesting, best course I've taken thus far.
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: The Ethics of Business in Latin America

course_title: The Ethics of Business in Latin America 003
best_comment: This class is great, I would highly recommend to anyone interested in Spanish, especially if you want to learn about the businesses across latinamerica and the way that history and world politics have influenced them. This course is super interesting and also a great way to get more confident and fluent with spanish. I improved my spanish speaking a ton. You have the chance to do research and present independently on a topic of your choice, as well as the chance to work in small groups on exams to learn from peers. The assignments and readings are manageable and Señora Gutiérrez is a great teacher and always willing to help out! You will bond with your classmates and learn a lot – highly recommend :)
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: The Ethics of Business in Latin America

course_title: Introduction to Contemporary Spanish Literature and Culture 001
best_comment: Take this class! You get to learn about contemporary Spanish history and literature at the same time. It's generally well–structured, and Prof. Vega–Durán's lectures are well–organized and clear. The compositions are of reasonable length and there aren't too many other outside assignments. You also do "tertulias" with 1–2 other students once a week and get to meet and tie up loose ends from class, which is helpful since you only meet once a week. The readings can be dense and hard to understand at times, since they are from the 19th/20th century. I had to look up a lot of words and sometimes, English translations. If you're not a native speaker, make sure you feel fairly confident in your reading skills and/or are willing to put in the work to understand the readings. For reference, I took Spanish 50 and 59 and found this just challenging enough. The professor is super nice and knowledgable as well. Highly recommend!

course_title: Words of Which History is Made: Translation Workshop on Modern Spain 001
best_comment: This is a great class to learn about translation! Daniel creates a really fun and dynamic environment, and the reading isn't too much so most of the work you do is only in the class itself. The structure of the class has you on your feet/working with groups for a lot of it which is fun, and it was cool to learn Spanish in a more technical format like that. This class also teaches you how to find other words/ways to express yourself in Spanish even if you don't have the exact words that you're thinking of. I would definitely recommend it!!!
worse_comment: it is not much reading, but hard work!
subject: Spanish
course_title_2023: Words of Which History is Made: Translation Workshop on Modern Spain

course_title: Spanish Film from Buñuel to Almodóvar 001
best_comment: I highly recommend this class. It's rare that I feel really good about a class after I've finished it, but I can say that after having turned in my final paper before I wrote this, I'm super grateful that I got a chance to take this class. It's a tough call between this class and Stories from the End of the World, but I think that this class might be might favorite that I've taken at Harvard (at the very least, this class and Stories are far ahead of my other classes in terms of favorites). I learned a ton in this class and felt like I was having fun doing it, Raquel does a great job in making the work not feel onerous and instead makes it feel like you're just talking about what you liked/thought was cool about a movie you watched for class. The movies she chose are also super good, so even if you don't take it, I'd recommend looking at the syllabus and watching some of them (my top recs are Mujeres al borde de un ataque de nervios, El orfanato, The Others, El espíritu de la colmena and El laberinto del fauno, but honestly all of them were good).

course_title: Decolonial Views, Decolonial Practices: Indigeneity and Protest in the Caribbean 001
best_comment: Take this class!! Not only will you learn more about Latin America but you'll look at different movements and topics that are very crucial and impactful to the people. The professor is very passionate about the course and I think through that enthusiasm it'll also encourage you to look at the materials carefully.

course_title: Queer Indigeneity: North and South Conversations 001
best_comment: This is a fabulous class!! The reading list is excellent and structured really well — each week naturally builds on prior content. JSC facilitates excellent discussions. I learned a lot — a genuine shift in how I see the world.

This class is really fun and absolutely worth it if you are remotely interested in learning more about Borges. The readings are super interesting and you really do take a deep dive into his literature with the world's leading scholar on the subject. Class can drag on at times and it's easy to get lost, but section is great at reeling you back in and going over everything we do in class. Try to participate and engage with the course material to get the most out of it. Would definitely recommend.

This is a get to know your peers, mentors and research topic better type of class. The assignments are thoughtful and not too difficult. The course organization is a bit , but it is an otherwise great intro to REECA.
subject: Russia, E Europe & Cntrl Asia

best_comment: Tatiana Kuzmic is incredible! The Slavic Department is incredibly lucky to have her. She's been my professor for three years now, and her class is genuinely a highlight of my semester!
subject: Bosnian, Croatian & Serbian

best_comment: The hardest part about this class is the sheer amount of work. The assignments, projects, and tests themselves were not that difficult, but they just kept on coming. That said, the teaching staff was on our side the entire time and helped navigate through it all. You will improve a lot in fluency, and if you're on the fence about continuing Russian past Elementary I'd definitely recommend sticking with it.
subject: Russian

course_title: Advanced Russian: Introduction to the Language of Social Sciences and the Media 001
best_comment: This course will force you to read significantly more Russian text than you would ever do otherwise, which is extremely beneficial. If you are interested in three hours of linguistics–related chatting per week, the class meetings are also beneficial. If you are looking to improve your reading skills in Russian, you are better off finding an accountability buddy and spending the three hours per week reading together.

course_title: Fourth-Year Russian: Russian and Post-Soviet Studies 001
best_comment: Amazing class, definitely a great way to continue the work from third year Russian in terms of grammar, speaking, and vocabulary, but more–so in terms of learning much more about the Russian speaking world, which is so much more diverse that we are lead to originally believe. Just beautiful.
Take this course! The readings are really interesting and provide a unique view into the beginnings of Communism in Russia!
subject: Russian

best_comment: If you're like me, and have been wanting to read War and Peace but just haven't gotten around to it, I couldn't recommend this class enough! Not only was it wonderful to finally get through this novel, but having a class setting in which we could engage with it in a more critical manner was also wonderful. I also thought the class moved at a really good pace, so there was never more reading assigned than I was reasonably able to get through. Prof. Buckler is also just a wonderful professor – she really encourages class discussion and makes sure everyone feels welcome and encouraged to participate, which made the class a very collaborative and welcoming space overall.

If you have ever been curious about Russian literature, this is a phenomenal course for both introducing you to another world of literature and deepening any existing interest for Russian culture and literature. Russia and its literature can be such a mystery, but there's something uniquely honest, soul–gripping, and of course, strange about it that's hard not to appreciate.  This class has a weekly theme in which the works we read or movies we watch revolve around. We would meet twice a week for small group (~8 students) discussions. I really enjoyed the focus on discussion where we, the students, could push the conversation to whatever subjects piqued our interests. It's an added bonus that the intimate nature of the class allowed us to get to know one another very well, and Professor Sandler is fantastic at facilitating discussion. She's like the tour guide that leads us through these different works and her expertise and openness to interpretation was always appreciated as it can be difficult to dissect "strange" texts. It was gratifying to see how our initial thoughts were developed throughout the discussion and by the end of each class, we came away with these profound insights. It's a big credit toward Professor Sandler and my awesome class that we could develop a diverse variety of interpretations, find the connections, and come away with an understanding that you just can't get when thinking alone. Additionally, the majority of the works we read were short stories and poems. You will definitely come away with at least a couple new authors you want to keep reading in the future! In terms of assignments, we had response/creative papers of varying lengths (anywhere from 2–5 pages usually) that were given every couple weeks in addition to a final paper.  To me, this system worked since the papers would help reinforce each couple weeks' worth of material.  They were also a nice opportunity to take a deeper dive into a works that particularly caught your attention.  Overall, I'm grateful to have taken this course and it was always a pleasure to go to discussion and get into the readings each week. Professor Sandler is brilliant, empathetic, and passionate about what she teaches, it's easy to see, and I think you could take any class with her and find it to be an immensely rewarding experience. Not to mention that she is so kind and supportive of all her students. In retrospect, I think exploring Russian literature through strange writers is perhaps the best way to get into it. You'll see what I mean if you take the class. Finally, Russia can often be misunderstood especially because of its rich and complex history. This class was integral in helping me navigate the biggest themes related to Russia, learning how to make sense of them, and ultimately, I gathered enough of an understanding to feel capable in continuing to explore Russia, strange writers, and Russian literature in the future. It's a great feeling. I'm thankful to have been able to take a class like this as it has added to my appreciation for a culture that I probably couldn't have made sense of on my own. Definitely would encourage those curious to take this course!

Have you ever been to an opera? Personally, I haven't, but after having taken Complit 153, I think I have an idea of what it must be like. In an opera, a singer comes on stage and performs some piece of music with tremendous passion, and although you have no idea what they were saying, you still nod to your friends, say it's good, and applaud because you appreciate the art of it. Similarly, in Complit 153, Professor Weir enters the lecture hall, talks in highly elevated diction for an hour and a half about some sophisticated–sounding topics, and although you have no idea what he's saying, you still try to jot down notes and nod to your friends because you appreciate the art of it. But what exactly is this art? It is the art of quoting from other scholars: When he explicates an interpretation, he makes sure to include as many sources of Nabokov scholarship as he can. He often always throws in a dash of Russian as well, just to add some interlingual insight. It is the art of improvisation: Arrive early enough and you will get a sneak peek of Complit 153 behind the scenes. Fifteen minutes to 6:45, Prof. Weir enters the premises. Five minutes to 6:45, Prof. Weir walks in and flips frantically through all 60 pages of his notes. At 6:45, Professor Weir begins his performance. It is the art of speed: Prof. Weir always has many more notes than he has minutes in class, but they don't call him the "master chef" for no reason. He always cooks up an incredible stew, expertly blending together scholarly ideas, usually relying on the last 10 minutes as a speedround to "popcorn" from person to person as they collectively crowdsource just about every insight to be had. It is the art of abstraction: His handwriting is illegible. But most importantly, it is the art of the simple: Behind the facade of the multilined model with thousands of different facets, there's always a really simple Nabokovian principle. Some of my favorites include: all art is flawed art, unless it's Pushkin's or Nabokov's; Freud is awful and any character who agrees with him is awful; nature (especially the butterfly) is beautiful; and of course the hermeneutics of perversion. Comparative Literature can be so wonderful. This was my first comparative literature class at Harvard, but after taking it, I became confused as to why people call comparative literature majors "losers," unless a loser is just someone who wrestles with a text long enough to extract an insight about the world.In all honesty, this class has topics that are really interesting, but they are often presented in a way that blurs the fine detail and focuses on the big themes instead. I am a fan of the post–lecture 1–hour class discussion where we consider the artistic and political aspects of the text and this part is usually pretty well–done, even though the conclusion will be something obvious (funny). Lectures themselves often move too quickly as a result of the large number of literary buzzwords that are not explained in much detail (and time taken up by the class discussion). It is unfortunate that there is no textbook because there is no way to explore the material presented in class and get a better understanding except by combing through the books Prof. Weir quotes from, which are usually behind a paywall. Essays are pretty good both as a learning tool and in terms of content (they usually remind me of something from popular culture like Queen's Gambit or Stanley Kubrick that we then compare with the novel), although I wish the page length on them was just a little more high. I feel uncomfortable when I take notes for an essay and I am able to fit my notes on only 3 lines (with the paper in landscape orientation). In–class pop quizzes seem unexpected at first, but they actually happen just about every week an essay is due, so it's hard to be unpleasantly surprised. The weekly workload varies wildly, since Professor Weir assigns either most of a 200–page novel in addition to a two hour movie or just a couple pages' worth of selected excerpts to reread. He put the weekly homework on the course page weeks before we had to do this and this was actually what we did, leading many to be very happy. As a result work is pretty predictable, so don't be too sad if you don't have time to get it all done one week, chances are you can catch up in the week following.If you want to take this class, make sure you know a bit about Nabokov, make sure you know your Russian early–20th–century politics and Russian idioms, and that's basically it. It's quite accessible really, once you actually find it in the course catalog.
worse_comment: Nabokov is brilliant but his perspective might startle you

course_title: Introduction to Russian and Soviet Film 1
best_comment: Daria is the best. Loved this class. Honestly, I was very skeptical about taking a silent Russian Film class, but it ended up being one of my favorite classes I've taken at Harvard! The movies were so fun and we spent every class doing a deep watch of some of our favorite scenes. Daria is super knowledgeable about all of the films and generated so much enthusiasm. I love her so much, please take this class! She's amazing!

It’s a very good course to expand your understanding of race and knowledge of Russia and Soviet Union. The class itself might be a bit chaotic because a lot of new materials by students are introduced and it might feel overwhelming but this way the class also teacher you to focus materials important to you

If you are interested in any social sciences, but haven't quite fallen in love with any department yet, take Social Studies 10A. I would not consider myself a political or social theorist at all, but I absolutely adored this class. Bonnie and Nicolas really did a good job in trying to make this year's curriculum more diverse and consider other important voices in this space. There's a lot of readings, and you won't do all of them, but definitely read enough so that you understand the important ideas and let lecture or tutorial fill in any gaps that you didn't cover. But, definitely dedicate some serious time to reading the texts. You'll thank yourself for it.
worse_comment: This class is not what I thought social studies would be like. The class has a very limited discussion of modern–day social science, and instead focuses solely on social theory. I often found that I was discouraged from bringing up and writing about current events throughout the course. Additionally, my tutorial leader created very stringent discussions and expectations that made it hard to express personal opinions in class. I know that this class is a prerequisite for social studies, but this may be the most blatantly difficult and unfair weeder class I have ever seen.
subject: Social Studies

course_title: Inequality and Social Mobility in America 001
best_comment: Anya is a fantastic professor & a great relationship to have in the Social Studies department (literally a Social Studies superstar). She is a bit of a tough grader but means well & wants to push us to get better. Definitely try and choose a research topic as fast as you can as the prospectus really sneaks up on you. Highly recommend making this tutorial your strong first choice!!

Nicole is the best person to take your junior tutorial with. Not only is she very passionate about the subject material, but she provides such helpful guidance in writing the research paper which is very valuable preparation for the senior thesis. The readings are also super interesting. I had no background in anthropology prior to this class, but we got to read really interesting pieces that are very narrative and a welcome departure from the Social Studies 10 canon. I can't recommend this section enough!
worse_comment: Take it if you're interested in Asia OR ethnographic research for your thesis. It's hard to compare against other tutorials (since I haven't taken them) but I can't imagine them better preparing you for your thesis than this one.

course_title: The Critical Theory of the Frankfurt School 001
best_comment: This is one of the better junior tutorials. The readings are –incredibly– difficult, but also some of the most interesting and eye–opening I have had the pleasure of studying. Charles is a really fantastic teacher, so there were days I came in having read 0 words of the assigned readings and still was able to learn and participate. This is because he provides a handout where he identifies short passages with key takeaways, so whenever the reading is too difficult or people don't have a lot to say, he'll just direct us to close read the key passages together. Every tutorial should be run this way, but I find other tutors in 10 and 98 have this complex about not "giving students the answers" which just makes it awkward and useless when no one has read or the reading was too hard. I find that the approach where there is always close reading to fall back on makes every minute of class actually worthwhile and actually incentivizes students to read more.  When we get to see how generative a discussion can be when we are unprepared, we are inspired by that to dig deeper for the next week. Another thing I loved about this course is that Charles cut out all the unnecessary assignments from the syllabus, so the only thing you really need to do throughout the semester is show up and think about your term paper. Could not recommend this course with more enthusiasm.
best_gem_comment: If you're at all interested in Critical Theory, TAKE THIS CLASS. CHARLES IS A M'FN GEM WHO WILL LISTEN TO ANY WACKY IDEAS THAT YOU HAVE AND EXPLAIN HOW IT CAN ALL FIT TOGETHER.DO IT.

best_comment: This class (or any future class that Tracey is teaching) is objectively very good! Tracey is the goat fr fr, she straight up does not miss. If you’re like me, then this class is going to go from very good to phenomenal. If you aren’t (totally fine!), it might go to good.This class is very theory heavy while still being grounded. There’s a lot of psychoanalysis, a lot of neoliberalism, some marx, a good amount of sociological theory, etc… Im very theory pilled, so I loved the readings, but if you aren’t, it might not be the class for you BUT at the same time Tracey helps orient theoretical discussions around the actual happenings of the world, which keeps things grounded and present. I don’t mean to make it sound all theory (it really isn’t!!!), but it’s definitely the most theoretical class I’ve had that still ostensibly about ethnographies and studying particular societal trends.The class is about entrepreneurialism in the loosest of senses. We read about entrepreneurialism in the first week, then we never really discussed it again (which I honestly didn’t mind one bit.) It’s really a class about identity formation under capitalism. And, as mentioned, it is also very theoretical, so ideally for people who like theory and like Freud, Foucault, Butler, etc… I will also say that though the more theoretical texts DO connect with the more ethnographic readings (which come mainly in the second half) the connections are not always explicitly drawn. My personal only real complaint is that in class presentations from other students were quite long. TLDR; Tracey is a great great teacher, if you like studying theory, psychoanalysis, identity formation, and capitalism as not just an economic system, it’ll probably be a GOAT class, if you don’t, probably still quite good, but know what you’re getting into.
subject: Social Studies

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!! Gili is one of the best instructors I have had in my life. She cares so much about this subject and the contributions of every student. She listens and appreciates everything each student says, and she is more than willing to meet with you about any question or concern. Many professors say this, but with Gili, you feel encouraged to meet not out of obligation but because you know it will benefit you. The structure of each class is really helpful because she outlines where you will go and what information you should take away from each part of the lesson. The readings are also super interesting, and lots of the history you discuss seems like stuff you should have been taught about in previous courses but never got the chance to learn. The assignments of this course are SUPER helpful when drafting your final paper. I love that we learned about historiographies and primary source analyses and could just use the assignments we had already written as sections of our final paper. This was also really helpful because we had already gotten feedback on parts of our final paper when we started drafting it. The type of people that this course attracts is also great, and I loved the energy of everyone I took it with. This was probably one of my favorite classes I have taken at Harvard, and I can't recommend it enough. Social Studies is a better place because Gili is in it, and this course is part of the reason why!

course_title: Rethinking the City: Modern Life in and Beyond Europe 001
best_comment: This was a fantastic course! The discussions were great, the materials were incredibly well–chosen, and Andrew is AWESOME! Our discussions were always really informative and engaging.

course_title: To Remake the World? Revolutionaries, Regimes, and Paradoxes of Power 001
best_comment: this tutorial is one of the best classes i've taken at harvard. it's a great balance of social theory and history, and the discussions will really make you think deeply about revolution, power, change. dr. whitham is a great and always willing to chat in office hours, and the course readings were very engaging. if you care about politics and activism, i can't recommend this tutorial more! it's rigorous, thought–provoking, and also just a really good time
subject: Social Studies
course_title_2023: To Remake the World? Revolutionaries, Regimes, and Paradoxes of Power

course_title: Qualitative Research Lab: Immigration, Citizenship, and Belonging 001
best_comment: Definitely a challenging and sometimes time–consuming, but rewarding class. Instructor is excellent and really instills a passion in the topic

If you're interesting in sociological canon, take this course! I took this since it was a requirement, but even as someone not necessarily interested in canon, this was really interesting! I definitely had an overall positive experience because of the professor, Dr. Dromi. I know someone who took this with someone else and they didn't have a good time. HOWEVER, if this is being taught by Dr. Dromi, take it!!! He's an amazing professor and such a nice person. The way he structured this course was amazing and I learned a lot without feeling too overwhelmed. This course is also really section–heavy, so I'd recommend trying to get someone who seems nice. My TF was Zehra and she's such a gem. She's genuinely so so kind and an overall interesting person. She really looks out for you and clarifies things really well. I also don't think she was a difficult grader (not super easy, but pretty medium leaning towards easier). I heard some not great things about Emma, so just be wary there. I also know someone who had John when the professor was not Dr. Dromi and he was apparently really not great + when some people I knew interacted with him this semester (he was the head TF), they had not great experiences as well. The workload is all right though there can be a lot of readings. More generally though, you just have to complete a certain number of weekly posts, make a group presentation for a book, and write the midterm + final papers. Overall, I would recommend this course!! Dr. Dromi makes it really worth it and as long as you like your TF in the end, it'll be a good time
worse_comment: participate! theory is boring if you don't engage with it and classes are boring if you don't engage with people
subject: Sociology

best_comment: I highly recommend this course for anyone interested in human rights, activism, or global politics. The professor is not only very knowledgeable but she is also very helpful and nice. I can tell she is eager to help all her students and make the course the best it can be. During lecture, she is able to explain hard topics or readings really well. Furthermore, she does a great job promoting discussion. The weekly assignments allow you to explore qualitative methods and the research process. The course really helped me learn how to answer my own research questions and I feel like it greatly prepared me for a senior thesis.

course_title: Junior Tutorial: Inequality in the United States 001
best_comment: This is an excellent class to take! You'll learn a great deal about how to effectively conduct qualitative research, and will have the opportunity to explore an issue of interest in a more detailed way than any of your other classes will likely give you the opportunity to. On top of that, Tom is a kind and encouraging instructor.

This is a survey class so we cover a lot of topics over the semester but, overall, the readings and discussions were great and there was something to learn from each week. Instructions and expectations for assignments are super detailed and clear so they are more manageable and easier to do. A great intro class for sociology and super engaging lectures (which also go over everything you read for homework so you get a good understanding of the material).
worse_comment: There are quizzes every class. This is a horrible introduction to sociology. Start off with a different sociology class and then take this when you are older and ready to endure more pain.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: This course was amazing! I was hesitant to enroll in it at first because it looked like a lot of work and I was not deeply interested in the topic of higher education; however, someone recommended it to me because Manja was the instructor, and I am SO glad I took it. Not only did it make me really interested in higher education (there are so many interesting topics, which I hadn't thought about before this course), but I also felt so supported by Manja. She met regularly with every student, helping us on every phase of our research, was SO encouraging, and really kind and flexible. This course was maybe the best organized course I have ever taken. Overwhelmingly, if you want to take a sociology class where you will look forward to coming to class and seeing your classmates and instructor, this is the course for you.

You will get out of this class what you put into it. The subject matter is obviously interesting, and Professor Ouimette is extremely kind and accessible. It is really engaging to learn from and with your classmates in this seminar, and to hear about Professor Ouimette's passion for the subject matter. However, the seminar sometimes veered into tangents, which could be disappointing when I was excited to have a seminar–style discussion.  When we did make time for discussion, though, the class was really engaging and allowed us to think about the various stakeholders involved in health and environmental policy as it relates to individual consumption patterns.

This class is super interesting and super reasonable. Only 20 pages of reading each week max. The prof is super genuine and cares about her students. The exams are super fair, no tricks. Also, the guest lecturers were amazing. I highly recommend this class.

course_title: Leadership, Social Change, and its Challenges: Boston as a Case Study 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. Chris, Ira, and Madison are such incredible scholars, and their love of the subject really comes through in the course. This is a great course to do a deep dive in the history of Boston, as well as get some practical experience in through the various field trips and projects. I've always looked forward to this class, and the coursework is very manageable. I really enjoyed doing the essays, especially since I had a lot of freedom to guide my own research and learn more about something that I wanted to learn. This is easily one of my favorite classes that I've taken so far, and I'm so glad that I found it.Chris is one of the best sociologists in the field, and I feel so sad that he's retiring this year because that means that future students won't get to learn from him. He's very kind and patient, and takes the time to help us truly internalize the course material.Ira is an amazing professor. He's from Boston and has a lot of practical experience when it comes to the topics we cover, so he offers a lot of knowledge that you wouldn't get otherwise. Moreover, he's the nicest person ever. I was going through a tough time this semester, and he would make sure to check in whenever he saw me, and would even email me sometimes to make sure I was doing okay. He clearly cares very deeply about his students and makes every effort to get to know us as human beings.Madison is an amazing TF. She would always be available and was very patience and accommodating. She would make sure to send us reminders to keep us on track with the coursework, and took the time to check in if she noticed anyone was missing an assignment.
subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: Leadership, Social Change, and its Challenges: Boston as a Case Study

course_title: Leadership, Social Change, and its Challenges: Boston as a Case Study 001
