subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: Leadership, Social Change, and its Challenges: Boston as a Case Study

best_comment: This is a great course, but you definitely get what you put in. The reading selections are very interesting, and the classes serve to outline the readings and how they connect to the theme. Thus, if you don't actually do the readings every week, you may as well not take the class (the readings take 30–75 minutes a week). The papers are a little tricky because you really have to produce a novel idea, but that's not inherently bad. The grading thus far has been slightly harsh in my opinion, especially since a majority of the class has never taken a sociology class before (of course haven't gotten my final grade back). Rachel Meyer (prof) is very passionate about the topic and her enthusiasm is infectious. She definitely is left–leaning and is not afraid to express it. She's less available outside of class than I'd like, but she made up for it by having Rachel Kim as her TF, who is probably my favorite TF of all time. If Rachel Kim is TFing the class, then it's a no–brainer to take, because Rachel's sections were so thoughtful and really made the class for me. If it's an average TF, this class is more of a toss–up, it depends how much you want to put into the class.
worse_comment: Without a sociology background this class can make your head spin at times. I often found that my interpretations of the readings did not align with the takeaways discussed in lecture, which makes following and contributing to in–class discussion difficult.
best_gem_comment: gem!! professor meyer knows how to keep her class engaged. workload is minimal: 3 units, weekly readings (that are honestly pretty short bc professor does her best to cut them down), 2 analytical questions for each unit (literally a question about a week's reading), and a paper for each unitsection was also super fun but still learned a lot!!this is coming from someone who took the class w/ no prior sociology knowledge at all! can get a lil confusing in lectures sometimes but nothing you can't pick up on

course_title: Pursuing Truth and Justice: Principles and Methods of Equity through Inquiry 001
best_comment: I'd tell future students to be prepared to get uncomfortable, especially if you've done prior research projects. You'll have to comfort a lot of your inner beliefs and experiences, but it will all be worth it!!
subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: Pursuing Truth and Justice through Action for Health Equity

course_title: Online Dating and the Transformation of Intimacy 001
best_comment: This is a very good course to take if you're interested in learning about the effects of online dating. Professor Narr is very accommodating and generates enthusiasm about the subject matter– as a STEM major, I really enjoyed this course and would recommend it to others as long as you're content with writing a 20–25 page research paper as the final.
worse_comment: This class is horrible. It is low effort because of the singular assignment (the final paper) but even that does not make having to work with Dr. Narr worth it. I would advise students not to take this class and the department to consider not bringing Dr. Narr back.
subject: Sociology
course_title_2023: Online Dating and the Transformation of Intimacy

course_title: Popular Culture and Contemporary Sociology Theory 001
best_comment: If you have the chance, you MUST take this course! Dr. Dromi is so so amazing and a great lecturer. You can tell he cares about his students along with the material! The course itself is also really interesting, you'll get to look at different forms of popular culture and see how it relates to sociological theory. Not only do you learn about really cool theories, but you get to look at media from a new perspective! We also got to watch a bunch of different things in class (like Black Mirror), which was super fun! I can't recommend this course enough honestly. It does have some work (you have a certain amount of weekly postings and quizzes you have to do, along with the midterm + final papers), but it's definitely manageable if you try. My TF was DA and he's super chill, though I think both TFs were actually pretty great. Anyway, TAKE THIS COURSE!!! Dr. Dromi is absolutely wonderful and the course is just so well structured + genuinely interesting :))

In this course, you will learn a lot of new terms used in the sociology field, so be prepared to add new definitions to words you already know. Also, this class is more about how human rights policy is conducted right now and less about how it can progress. Depending on what you want to gain from the course, that will change your approach to the assignments.

course_title: Crime, Punishment, and Policing in an Unequal America 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! the most worthwhile course I've taken here so far—it's truly a gem in the sense that you'll leave class everyday feeling like you engaged in the most intellectual discussion ever, because of the way everyone is so invested in making class time an eye–opening experience. I took this as an elective, and I'm so glad I didn't drop out of it, because it taught me how to defend any given argument and correspondingly how to critique an argument (even if it seems airtight). Chris and Adaner are the GOATS... really hope they can teach together again. truly a unique experience witnessing the blend of sociology and philosophy. I for sure gained a new appreciation for how theory and empirics can and ought to work together when tackling difficult and controversial issues. this was always the class I looked forward to the most this semester—it was an honor being in a room full of such inspired and thoughtful people. I'm not normally this awestruck by a class, but this is not your average class at all. I often found myself talking about the topics we discussed in class outside of class, which is pretty rare for me. all in all, I loved this course.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! the most worthwhile course I've taken here so far—it's truly a gem in the sense that you'll leave class everyday feeling like you engaged in the most intellectual discussion ever, because of the way everyone is so invested in making class time an eye–opening experience. I took this as an elective, and I'm so glad I didn't drop out of it, because it taught me how to defend any given argument and correspondingly how to critique an argument (even if it seems airtight). Chris and Adaner are the GOATS... really hope they can teach together again. truly a unique experience witnessing the blend of sociology and philosophy. I for sure gained a new appreciation for how theory and empirics can and ought to work together when tackling difficult and controversial issues. this was always the class I looked forward to the most this semester—it was an honor being in a room full of such inspired and thoughtful people. I'm not normally this awestruck by a class, but this is not your average class at all. I often found myself talking about the topics we discussed in class outside of class, which is pretty rare for me. all in all, I loved this course.

best_comment: This class is an amazing introduction to organizational studies and the field of sociology. and the concepts it teaches are immediately applicable from the first day of class to the last. Dr. Handsman is one of the most down–to–earth and passionate professors I have ever met at this university and taking their course has not only taught me a lot about organizations, but has also given me some peace of mind knowing that there are teaching staff that truly do care about my education and future success!

TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!  I loved the entire thing. The guest lecturers, the field work, the lessons, the teaching staff!!! Chef's kiss fr. Tom and the TFs were so so so so awesome. I cannot speak highly enough of them.  Tom is a genuine gem; you do not meet many people like him in life. He truly cares about what he is teaching and offers a course that will allow you to actually gain valuable first hand experience in the topics you are learning about. You will leave this class with an entirely different view of the United States, especially since it forces you to step out of your comfort zone. Because I know people are worried about grades: It is also pretty easy as long as you engage in the material and truly care about what you are learning. Perfect introduction to a sociology course; I would recommend the course to someone without any knowledge of the department.
worse_comment: I highly recommend students to take this class, especially if you've never taken a sociology class before. You'll learn so much about the pathways into poverty and systems that keep people in poverty. Moreover, you'll be taught by the most incredible/dedicated teaching team I've ever had at Harvard! Can't recommend enough.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!!!  I loved the entire thing. The guest lecturers, the field work, the lessons, the teaching staff!!! Chef's kiss fr. Tom and the TFs were so so so so awesome. I cannot speak highly enough of them.  Tom is a genuine gem; you do not meet many people like him in life. He truly cares about what he is teaching and offers a course that will allow you to actually gain valuable first hand experience in the topics you are learning about. You will leave this class with an entirely different view of the United States, especially since it forces you to step out of your comfort zone. Because I know people are worried about grades: It is also pretty easy as long as you engage in the material and truly care about what you are learning. Perfect introduction to a sociology course; I would recommend the course to someone without any knowledge of the department.
subject: Sociology

course_title: Advanced Research in Reproductive Health and Rights 001
best_comment: This course was amazing—Professor Viterna is an extremely brilliant Professor, and the students who enrolled were so passionate and so inspiring. The material we read was pertinent, interesting, oftentimes jarring, and extremely important to know. Our projects and frequent presentations were extremely informative to both craft and learn from, and the class speakers we had were amazing (Michele Goodwin, Kate Kelly). Learning about Professor Viterna's research in El Salvador was amazing, and the chance to meet with women she worked—who were unjustly imprisoned in El Salvador after miscarrying—with was absolutely invaluable. The class became so close–knit and we are hoping to still work together on the issues we discussed—it was truly a one of a kind, life–changing class.

Coming in with a basic and general coding intuition (whether in Python, R, Stata, etc.) is extremely helpful for this course.  This is a grad–level class, so of course it's challenging, but in the best way possible.
subject: Sociology

best_comment: The final research project for this class is more like a continuous project that is conducted throughout the semester.  It's a really valuable opportunity, so I definitely think starting to brainstorm research topics earlier and being mentally prepared to dive in and work ahead is a good call.

It is such a privilege to be able to learn from Prof. Marsden; please take this opportunity if you can. This class presents an in–depth look at social networks, with a sort of thoroughness that that is hard to find in other quantitative courses.

course_title: Proseminar on Inequality and Social Policy III 001
best_comment: I believe that this course works best if students know one another and are able to build trust and respectful understanding. This helps the discussions feel more constructive across disciplines.

TAKE THIS CLASS! Richard ji is enthusiastic, funny, and a great instructor. He makes sure that everyone is comfortable with the material and you will learn so much in just a semester. I found myself looking forward to Hindi class every day because I knew I'd be able to relax, laugh, and learn about my culture.
worse_comment: Please take this class! You won’t regret it!
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: If you are at all interested in engaging with South Asian literature, culture, and intellectual output, please consider taking Hindi–Urdu 102! Richard ji is an incredible instructor. He cares deeply about all the students in the course, makes himself available to support students outside of class, fosters a collaborative classroom environment, and encourages students at all stages of learning.
subject: Hindi-Urdu

best_comment: This class is a wonderful introduction to Sanskrit, but is certainly not an 'easy' class. By the end, you will learn a great deal of elementary Sanskrit, and feel comfortable with the script (Devanagari) and be able to read and understand basic prose. Nell is a fabulous instructor who cares deeply about her students. However, be prepared to work hard. The language is difficult, and Nell definitely expects a lot of her students in regards to putting in the work to memorize verbal conjugations, nominal declensions, and vocabulary. Because everything is additive and builds on previous things, I highly recommend not skimping over the basics like sandhi or the meaning of each declension class. But, all in all, I recommend if you are interested in Sanskrit and are willing to work hard. If you want an easy A in a language class, skip.
subject: Sanskrit

best_comment: Amazing course! Take it, you'll love it especially as the readings get more interesting and challenging throughout the year. Nell does an amazing job of making the course flexible and making sure everyone is on the same page.
worse_comment: If there is a Sanskrit class offered by Nell Hawley. TAKE IT! There are no exceptions to this rule (unlike in Sanskrit)
subject: Sanskrit

best_comment: Don't be intimidated if analysis is a lot at first. Make sure you have commentaries so it's easier to dig deeper into Pāninian grammar (what I enjoyed about the analysis process), or just establish a word order so that you can start applying the skills you've learned in intermediate. Start verses early because it can be a time crunch to do 3 verses between Monday and Wednesday, but definitely manageable.
subject: Sanskrit

course_title: South Asian Language Tutorials, Introductory Level 004
best_comment: If you are wanting to learn a new language, THIS IS THE COURSE TO TAKE!!!! Prof. Evans is an amazing teacher who truly takes the time to make sure you understand the basics of the language but also in a fun and enjoyable way! The workload is not heavy, and he is always open to helping out to help you better understand the language. It is constructed very differently than other language courses and is not as stressful.
subject: South Asian Studies
course_title_2023: South Asian Language Tutorials, Introductory Level

best_comment: Stick with it. For beginners, it starts out tough but ends up fun.
subject: Tibetan

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: This class is an excellent introduction to statistics! Kelly is an AMAZING professor, and it is so apparent that she deeply cares about her students. Although I am not a statistics concentrator, her enthusiasm really made me enjoy this class, and I will be taking her other course just because she was a lovely teacher. Psets are very long, and you do have to put in the time & effort if you want to do well in the exams since they are quite similar to the pset questions. If you attend office hours and make an effort to truly understand the concepts, I feel like the course content is not hard at all and the workload is totally manageable. The oral exam, however, can be a bit of a challenge (especially since it is not something that a typical student would be familiar with), so do try to practice some of the questions out loud. The section component of this class is also great since it is designed as a time to ask your pset questions to the TF rather than him going over the course content. One suggestion I would have is to go to every lecture and take notes to digest the material since there is quite a bit of content in every lecture, and it is very easy to fall behind. In any case, definitely take this course if you are looking to fulfill the stat requirement!
worse_comment: The grading is horrible. They ask certain questions and you answer them, but there are certain things they expect you to include in the answer that was never made clear to you. The rubric for grading is very confusing and unclear. You will leave the class knowing the concepts however.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science

course_title: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science 001
best_comment: This class is an excellent introduction to statistics! Kelly is an AMAZING professor, and it is so apparent that she deeply cares about her students. Although I am not a statistics concentrator, her enthusiasm really made me enjoy this class, and I will be taking her other course just because she was a lovely teacher. The rubric for grading is very confusing and unclear. You will leave the class knowing the concepts however.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Statistics and Data Science

course_title: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics 001
best_comment: Overall, this class has gotten pretty bad reviews in the past, but I've overall had a really wonderful experience in this class. I think you get really great intuition for probability without the stress of Stat 110. If you take the time to review the lecture notes, attend office hours, and do the practice exams in preparation for the midterms, you will be perfectly fine in this class. I don't think it's a class you can necessarily breeze by in, but by no means did I ever feel overwhelmed by the amount of work. Kevin Rader is a wonderful Professor who is always willing to help explain things further if you're confused. He actively hosted study sessions for 2–3 hours per week where you could get help on the PSETs or just understanding the material presented in the class. I think that Kevin Rader has really transformed this class and improved it's reputation given that this is his fourth semester teaching it. Be ready to put some work into this class and it by no means is easy, but you also won't be ripping your hair out as long as you stay on top of your stuff.
worse_comment: It is important that you understand fundamentally what is going on because equations alone won't get you far. You have to do a lot of explanation in order to understand what is going on.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Introduction to Quantitative Methods for Economics

course_title: Data Science 1: Introduction to Data Science 001
best_comment: This advice goes particularly to students who are not CS/AM/STEM and have not had previous experience with coding. I came into this class as an Economics concentrator, without ever having taken CS50 (admittedly because I was scared of computers), and only a brief encounter with using python and pandas for a network analysis. I had a lot of experience with economic research in R, and the PhD student I worked for recommended CS109 as one of the most useful classes he had done in his doctoral degree (also hadn't learnt python before). I came in scared that I wouldn't have the background to succeed, but sticking with this class was THE BEST DECISION I made. If you don't have much experience with coding, use HW0 as an opportunity to learn. It's very comprehensive, if you find a friend who can also help you understand the concepts and you use the Data Science Bedrock materials Pavlos provides, you'll learn Python really quickly. By the end of the class, I felt extremely proficient in my coding abilities, could complete all the homeworks quickly and without any problems, and honestly am super grateful that I had the opportunity to practice so much coding in college. The material I learnt was also extremely helpful for other classes, such as Ec 1126, and it helped me develop hard skills which I later plan to use for research/jobs.I left this class now in Am/Ec and considering a secondary in CS because there are simply too many other courses I want to take. This was a great introduction to data science and I highly recommend anyone who wants more experience with handling data to take this course. If you're not super comfortable with coding, just make sure you are willing to put in the hours (particularly in the beginning) and you'll do fine.
worse_comment: Don't take this class. This class takes lots of time, not because the material is difficult but because of busywork.  Professors aren't interested in teaching, class is 100+ students, Ed crashes all the time, online quizes don't work, assignment grading has no actual feedback... many problems with this course. It's much better to watch external online videos and learn by doing. The amount of work/learning ratio is really really low for this course.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: This class teaches some incredibly interesting topics but can get quite intensely hard (as you may have seen from the 364237498239 sidechat posts.) It's not the same as AP Stat (in fact way, way, way far away from it) in that it teaches probability, so keep that in mind if you're looking to learn statistics for data science. It's hard. Did I say it's hard? It's really hard. But rewarding. Joe is a fantastic lecturer, and I think it honestly should be a gold standard in terms of how classes should be organized. 9–12 AM office hours and sections every day, Joe (or another person in the class) explains every single post on Ed at lightning speed, the 3 hour midterm/final reviews that TFs hold; it's really fantastic! Three things:1. For the love of God don't do what I did; please read the textbook early. Do the problems in them. The problems are hard when you begin, but you'll thank yourself when midterms and finals roll around and you can actually solve the problems in the practice exams. Think the textbook is insurmountable when you're trying to read it to get those PSETS in? It's ~expo(nentially) worse when you try to cram 7 chapters in 2 days. 2. Speaking of practice exams, for midterms and finals, do. all. the practice. exams. Please. They'll be your saving grace. Somehow Joe writes a new midterm and final every year, so he releases all the old midterms from the previous year all the way back to the dinosaur ages. They're so helpful, and there are patterns that repeat themselves. Do them (and not with the answer key in front of you so you gaslight yourself into feeling like you know the answer and that you could get the answer on an exam. Nothing more frustrating than knowing you saw the literal exact problem structure and looked at the answer key, but actually don't know how to solve it. It's devastating.) 3. Go to the 200 office hours that are available! And go to section. I know it's hard because it's not assigned, but the TFs are absolutely fantastic. And they'll make figuring out the PSET way faster.This class can be a monster at times, but it's worth it. Somehow by the end, it transforms half of the class into stat concentrators, so take that as you will. Good luck soldier may Joe bless you with intuition and a lot of time to study for this class.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE. AVOID AT ALL COSTS UNTIL THEY CHANGE IT.TL;DR: The material is interesting, but the execution of the class is so bad you could literally read the textbook and not do anything else and gain about the same amount of information on probability as you would otherwise. Joe's lovely though.The Good:Blitzstein's a good lecturer, he's funny, likes to joke with the class, and very human. Very generous extension, drop, and grading policy, and he does have his heart in the right place. The material is also interesting and has many connections (too bad literally none of them are explored lmao).The Bad:This course wants to be an intro course while teaching material that is not intro–level, and definitely not at an intro–level pace. Do not listen to the requirements, if you don't have multivariable calculus or some notion of linear algebra you will not be able to fully understand and appreciate the material, especially in the latter half of the semester, where it's all calculus and Markov chains are entirely linear algebra. It also sits at a crossroads between rigorous and unrigorous maths; proofs are required in PSETS and exams but it is never explained how one should get to such proofs, some results are entirely opaque and not even the TFs understand them, and story proofs have a special place in hell. The textbook is terrible and proof–laden, which is incredibly counterproductive and does not serve students. Practice problems are useless since you don't have the solutions to them. All the material pre–midterm does not require actual logic but rather rote memorization of the examples in lecture and the textbook, which artificially deflates grades and makes the course a lot harder than it needs to be. The midterm is not useful in any way for a thorough understanding of the material and relies solely on being lucky about what topics are drawn. The class is also completely different pre– and post–midterm in terms of intensity and PSET difficulty, messing up students' plans and greatly increasing the amount of time needed. For evidence of this, look to 80% of the TFs, whom all say they did terribly on the midterm and then great on the final. Also, a standard deviation of over 20 points is insane.Lectures are useless. Blitzstein is a good lecturer and can get his points across, but there's no point in going if everything he says is on the textbook anyway, literally word–for–word the same. PSETS have little to do with what is actually being taught that week and are always a weird mix, especially post–midterm, of stuff you did the week prior and stuff you're covering the week of the PSET. They also vary wildly in terms of time commitment, with in most recent memory, PSETs 9  and 10 being day and night, respectively.The course is structured such that there is no natural connection between topics even though there can definitely be one, which makes the material uselessly frustrating to wrap one's head around.Section is not useful in the slightest, and there is so little publicity for it anyway that one can go the entire course without going and it would not make a difference. Office Hours also suffer from the same issues, with TFs not being much help and the bulk of the benefit of OHs being finding a PSET group, because even though this class is 800 people you might as well be the only one taking it due to the lack of communication between students.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Introduction to Bayesian Inference and Applications 001
best_comment: A perfect course. The lecture notes are well–designed, a perfect combination of theoretical models and applications in real world scenarios. Professor Kou is a great professor. He can illustrate the materials very clearly and concisely. The homework is also well–designed by Professor Kou. They not only enhance your understanding of the materials covered in class, but also help you to think of using these Bayesian models learnt to address real world issues.  Professor Kou also gives practical and helpful suggestions on your learning, even beyond the scope of this class, if you go to his office hours.  The two TFs, Yicong and Jiaze are very helpful and nice.
worse_comment: Starts easy but the end is very hard. Assignments are brutal and exam covers content beyond what you have a chance to practice in the homework. Bizarre class where you learn a lot but the logistics are soul crushing. Class itself is hard to stay awake in; lectures are not recorded so if you get confused you’re just lost for the rest of lecture.

best_comment: May look scary, but 139 was actually very interesting and rewarding. A great intro to applied stats, a completely different perspective on the subject from 110/111. Expect to become a better coder!
worse_comment: please don’t take this class unless you absolutely have to for concentration reqs; if you have to take it, wait until senior fall — there is no need to take it earlier and it will probably tank your gpa unless you’re one of those quant bros. coming into this class, i was hoping that the horror stories aren’t true and this class wouldn’t be that bad if i put enough time into it. boy was i wrong. despite spending more than 20 hours in this every week, i still was not able to fully grasp the content. unlike 110 and 111, 139 does not have a textbook; so if u need a textbook to learn, you are basically screwed in this class as the class notes are horribly disorganised and are missing a lot a lot of things. psets are also nightmares in this class unless u have tf friends. each pset ends up being around ~25 pages but have a lot of strange R coding and interpretation questions that take a very long time to do, make you very sad, and don’t help you grasp the content.

best_comment: For those looking for a class that's easy or implementation–heavy but theory–light, this is not the one for you. It's heavy on math and statistics—but honestly does a pretty good job building up the core RL fundamentals from scratch. There really isn't a ton of good RL material on the Internet; rather than learning things like MDP's and policy gradients from half–baked Medium articles, this class will teach you the fundamental concepts, rigorously demonstrate how they work, and motivate things from a first–principles perspective. You will emerge from this class capable of reading almost any RL paper. With that being said, it's a bit of a mess. The teaching staff was disorganized, and the lecture slides often had notational errors (although this was usually Sham, not Lucas). In other CS classes with a singular focus (e.g. 121), you get this nice tapestry of ideas throughout the semester that build on one another and serve as core to the course. The same is true in the *material* of 184, but not the execution—as a student, you have to put in a lot of mileage discovering the intricate connections of things that really could just be said in lecture. The homeworks were generally fine, but I was never clear how they would be graded + the programming components could be much better.
worse_comment: Difficult course. Don't take if not prepared to work with the mathematics

subject: Statistics

best_comment: This is a solid class, but the title bites off more than is actually chewed; to be honest, a better name for this course would have been something like "Linear Algebra Applications in Machine Learning" "Algorithms for Dimension Reduction" (which, fun fact, is pretty much what the class used to be called long ago). The course's focus was algorithms like PCA, SVD, NMF, ISOMAP, and then some stuff on clustering, with LOTS of linear algebra and a bit of theoretical background (but no proofs), and in some places felt like it was running pretty slow; we spent like the first 3 weeks talking about PCA, which kind of dragged on. If you have aligned your expectations with that reality, the course is good. Alex lectures well (but writes everything in all caps for some reason, which is a little hard to read; anyway...) and is a pretty accessible guy. The material is pretty fundamental, presented well, and *will* strengthen your intuition for linear algebra, like it or not. Look out for the term paper; there's not a ton of guidance given and it's a nontrivial effort. Ultimately I enjoyed the class, but I will say that if you choose to take it, get ready to get good at linear algebra.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: If you liked Stat 110 (especially thinking about different distributions and how they relate to one another), you'll probably also like Stat 210. It's a really interesting continuation of the topics that Stat 110 covers but in greater depth and rigor. Reasoning by representation (e.g, proving results by connecting different distributions) is really powerful and interesting, and the measure theoretic foundation that Stat 210 provides makes probability (at least in my opinion) more intuitive but also more rigorous. Problem sets are fair and interesting, and exams are reasonable (the midterm was fair, and the final felt generous – I know it's been a bit harder in previous years though).Overall, the course feels more like an upper–level undergraduate class compared to a graduate class – both in content and in enrollment. From what I know, for better or for worse, the course differs a bit from other schools' graduate probability classes: it's less focused on measure theory (e.g., spends less time on rigorous constructions of parts of probability) and more focused on providing intuitive results and explanations. It also at times awkwardly balances between doing analysis (e.g., when proving the CLT) and not doing analysis (e.g., handwaving parts of measure theory and MGFs). I'd definitely still recommend taking some form of analysis before this class – the class is definitely doable without it, but Math 25/55/112 or equivalent makes the course much more understandable (especially when it comes to topics like CLTs and LLNs). Also, taking Math 114 at the same time as this course is underrated – it makes the measure theory parts of this course so much more understandable, and depending on who teaches Math 114, it'll make the end of that class a whole lot easier too.Last bit because I would've liked to have a review like this when I was looking at the QGuide: I self–studied Stat 110 over the summer by watching the Youtube lectures, doing the psets, and reading the textbook – in the end, I felt really well–prepared for Stat 210, and I think that it was a good move to take Stat 210. I came from a Math 25 background, and even though Stat 210 can be/sound a little intimidating, it's definitely doable, and if you already know some probability and like analysis, it's a jump worth considering. On the flip side, if your Stat 110 knowledge isn't fairly solid or you're not too confident in basic probability, Stat 210 will be a bit challenging. After a few lectures on measure theory, the class dives into reasoning by representation; if you're shaky on probability distributions, this (large) section and foundation of the course won't be very fun.
worse_comment: This class is extremely difficult if you haven't had a proof–based math and measure theory background. Be prepared to do lengthy proofs that require a Math–55 level of rigor, even though it isn't a required course. Everyone else in the class will have already heard half of the concepts in other Math courses while you struggle to understand the most basic concepts. At Office Hours, be prepared for students to discuss extremely technical points on a book problem that isn't even on the homework while you fail to get the TF's attention to ask a single question on any of the homework problems which you don't even know where to start on.
subject: Statistics

best_comment: Arguably Prof. Janson went a bit easier this semester—the midterm and final exams were only two questions, not three. But this course is still HARD.  Maybe deceptively so: you could be in a situation where you attend lecture, catch up on the notes, and feel like you have a good command of the material. But then you see a homework problem and just have no idea how to even start it. And when you do figure it out, it's like two pages of bashing. Biweekly problem sets help you manage the workload, but this also creates a dual threat: you get less chances to review the material through solving problems. Anyway, I cannot do the difficulty justice so I'll instead just point to past reviews.Lucas is a terrific lecturer in this course and delivers the material with fluency, seeking to build deeper statistical intuition through the material. This same ethos is reflected in the excellent course notes. Consequently I actually thought the material was more engaging and interesting than Stat 210 and even Stat 111; I definitely left this course having not just learned lots, but also with a better statistical intuition. But, still. Should you take on this course, do NOT underestimate the difficulty.
worse_comment: Extremely hard. Harder than it should be.
subject: Statistics

course_title: Computational Tools for Statistical Learning: Approximation, Optimization, and Monte Carlo 001
best_comment: The professor is amazing – super responsive, gives great lectures, and really cares about your learning. Goes above and beyond! Monte carlo is also very cool.
worse_comment: DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS. This is the only time I've ever given a 1 on the Q guide, and I've reviewed many classes at Harvard. Every part of this class is terrible.Lectures are incomprehensible and impossible to follow because of how badly they are taught. I'd be more forgiving if the professor was new, but he's not. Lecture notes are typo ridden.Assignments are typo ridden.Requirements are vague and never clear.Office hours are necessary but things are still painful even with them. I don't mind hard classes. It's that everything takes 3x longer than necessary in this class because you have to teach the material to yourself for each assignment. Use Bayesian Data Analysis and don't take this course.Avoid Prof Liu. I've never had a class this bad at Harvard and sincerely hope the reader takes my advice and does not subject themselves to such a terrible experience.
subject: Statistics
course_title_2023: Computational Tools for Statistical Learning: Approximation, Optimization, and Monte Carlo

best_comment: The course material is useful, but the pedagogy of this class was really bad.In lectures, Dr. Glickman will often explain extremely basic concepts, like what a derivative is (a real example), how a Taylor approximation works, why the expected score derivatives are zero, etc. He wastes time for several minutes, and then suddenly he moves on and speedruns the explanation for some nontrivial algebraic manipulations, and you're completely lost. Sometimes it feels like he explains really basic knowledge because it's easier to explain than the more complicated stuff, but this is unhelpful because what you truly need help understanding is what kind of random variable the quasi likelihood model is actually supposed to represent and why you can’t write it down as a probability distribution (is it because the PDF doesn't integrate to 1 and just needs a normalizing constant? We still don't know!).The exams are only one hour long, which is truly not enough time to do any problem solving. You also can't bring a theorem sheet. As a result, they ignore all but roughly two lectures’ worth of material, and only test how fast you can take a derivative, do tricks with matrices, or recall the specific wording of definitions. There is less than 10 points of variance between the min and max project grades, and project grades are capped at 95, since higher scores are reserved for “publication worthy” papers, even though the project is supposed to be a literature review and nowhere do the guidelines mention expecting novel results. Thus, the class grade is basically completely determined by the two *one–hour* exams.Furthermore, the TFs were unhelpful. The review sessions were not intelligible because they were drawing on a Zoom whiteboard with a laptop touchpad. They were extremely stingy with pset grading, and took off points for typos and "poor choice of wording," even if the ideas are clear. It is also quite insulting that one TF expressed the belief the students taking the class this year were just a "dumb" group of students, hence why they thought Stat 244 was better as a 20–student class because the material "didn't get any harder" from last year and seemed to not understand why everyone can't “just do better on the midterm." Mind you, the course material is not rocket science. If the students in the course, who are generally graduate students in statistics–related fields and competent undergraduates who succeeded in stat 210/211, can’t figure out the basics of generalized linear models, it might not be because they are “dumb.”I am not usually so annoyed by teaching styles, and this is the first time in several semesters at Harvard that I have expressed such a vehement level of distaste in a Q guide review. Stat 244 epitomizes all the bad things about taking classes: learning techniques that aren't particularly novel (and might not lead to interesting research directions), but in a convoluted way, and banging your head against the wall to complete pset problems that are all just quite random linear algebra tricks, and being tested on how fast you can reason about the four fundamental spaces of a matrix like a juvenile high schooler. This class was such a bad experience that it has made me jaded about continuing to take more classes that could turn out to be like this one and has motivated me to take time off from school.
worse_comment: Thought this would be more interesting, albeit more difficult, than STAT139. This was not true. A lot of results and work done in the homework is very tedious and doesn't add to understanding. Closed note exams are annoying when it's mostly proof–based. Grading seemed arbitrary and largely pedantic, with non–responsiveness to regrade requests.

best_comment: Take the course! Prof. Imai is incredibly brilliant, supportive, and intelligent. The course covers many important topics that have a range of applications across industries. The class is also very useful for those interested in pursuing careers in policy.

best_comment: I loved this class!! It’s a perfect gateway class for SCRB and very nicely guides you into the HDRB world. Bill is a wonderful lecturer albeit a little bit slow but it’s for nicely executed dramatic effect. The content in this class is so amazing and engaging, and it truly does give you a comprehensive overview of the next SCRB classes to come. I’m so glad I chose to concentrate in HDRB based off this class as the staff is so wonderful and the information really teaches you how to think like a scientist. I also loved the biological and experimental systems we learned and it’s incredibly satisfying and rewarding to be able to read a scientific journal and actually understand it. There are only three psets, nicely spaced out during the semester, two short writing assignments, and two very reasonable midterms. Make sure to clearly understand the genetic toolkits they teach you these help a ton in the exam questions!
worse_comment: The exams are difficult, it is hard to tell what's important from lectures sometimes. The material is very interesting at first, it sets very high expectations for the rest of the course, but then it becomes more boring. Also, some of the experiments done on the animals that we learn about are so cruel, I think this class need a bioethics component or at least some warnings, I cringed many times during lectures. But I am glad I took the course anyways, it is crazy what stem cells already allow us to do and more is to come.
best_gem_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Probably one of the best biology classes taught at Harvard. Bill is a true gem, he's really entertaining to watch during lecture and also super effective – one of those lecturers that cares more about how much you absorb rather than how much content they cover. The assignments are also really well–targeted without any fluff – there's only 3 psets the entire semester plus 2 writing assignments (and no lab!!), but I still walked away thinking I learned a lot. This course will give you so much insights into how to design experiments, and I feel so much more confident about doing research after this class.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: Take this class! It's honestly been one of my favorite courses I've taken at Harvard (I'm a senior).  Dr Whited is so enthusiastic and is a wonderful person –– she conveys her excitement for regeneration so well, and all the discussions were fascinating. I learned so much about regeneration. It's really interesting to think about the role of the immune system and nerve cells, as well as signaling proteins in inducing regeneration. I also liked that the course encompassed a fair amount of biodiversity (planarians, axolotls, newts, lizards, stick insects, frogs, mice, zebrafish...), and discussed different strategies of regeneration that these organisms have, as well as similarities across distantly related species. I found the discussions to be really thought–provoking and I've been recommending this class to all my friends.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Especially if you want to learn more about regeneration pathways and potential modulations! Class is basically a cool journal club where your SCRB 10 and 50 skills can be applied!Wouldn't recommend taking if you're not of a stem background – most of the quizzes deal with experimental methods and systems (like Cre/lox) and you will be lost if you can't create a rapid amount of experiments in a limited time period. There was a pure CS kid in our class and every quiz was like one of those dreams where you're naked in front of a firing squad for him, so would be wary.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: This is a fantastic class!!!! The experiments are super interesting and cool, and you will learn a lot, and gain a lot of new lab skills. This class will help you better think like a scientist, and all the teaching staff are fantastic and super supportive! Definitely take this class if you are considering it!
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

best_comment: This class rocks! If you're genuinely interested in learning about the immune system, this is definitely the class for you. Sometimes STEM (especially biology classes) get super jargon–y and you have to spend hours memorizing pathways and molecule names, but this class truly emphasizes understanding and grappling with the bigger picture so that you have a more foundational understanding of the immune system and its many functions. Pacing of the course is great, PSETs are super fair, and the final project is really fun. Teaching staff is super passionate about the material, and they make themselves available always. Can't say enough good things.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol

course_title: Understanding Aging: Degeneration, Regeneration, and the Scientific Search for the Fountain of Youth 01
best_comment: This is definitely a REALLY great course. Amie gives very interesting lectures and really knows her stuff. The course has heavy focuses on not just the biology aspect of aging, but also the social/political consequences of it (without the course getting political) as well as drug development. I would recommend having taken a biology class or two (SCRB 10 was super helpful) just so you can follow easily in lecture. I'd say whereas SCRB 10 had a focus on being creative and thinking big, this course encourages you to think very practically. This aspect is reflected in the psets and final project where the teaching team isn't afraid to push back if they think experiments you propose aren't realistic or feasible, so keep that in mind when doing assignments. However, it is very evident that Amie genuinely cares about what you learn and wants you to take certain things away from the course. The course overall is extremely interesting, but appropriately challenging. The psets and midterms are challenging but doable if you put in a little bit of time to study and get them done. The final project can also be a lot of writing, but they gave us feedback based on our outlines so we knew how to refine our proposals, so I'm hoping they turn out well based on that. I agree with previous years' Q guides that it's not an easy A, but definitely possible. Still waiting for grades to come out, so we'll see how those turn out.
best_gem_comment: If you want to learn about how to read a scientific paper and also about leading research in aging biology, take this course! There is really not too much work – the psets are pretty short and the exams are (relatively) low stress. However just because there isn’t that much work doesn’t mean that its a gem – the PSETs are graded pretty hard. The course casts a pretty wide net and you will go through information very fast, but there is always time to focus in on something specific that you are interested in for the final project or on certain PSET questions.  The content can also be pretty hard to understand sometimes, but I feel like I’ve gotten a really good overview of the entire aging biology field.
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2023: Understanding Aging: Degeneration, Regeneration, and the Scientific Search for the Fountain of Youth

course_title: The Translational Science of Stem Cells: Present and Future 001
best_comment: THIS IS MY FAVORITE COURSE I'VE TAKEN AT HARVARD!!!! If you have any interest in doing translational research or going into biotech, this class is one in a million. No other STEM course have I taken at Harvard that actually made me excited about the material. Lee is such a wonderful teacher as well and clearly is so knowledgable and passionate about the material, but is also so kind and approachable. He literally brought cookies to each class, like are you kidding???  Additionally, this class is not stressful at all. Its the epitome of a good education – you get to learn A LOT but without feeling like you want to die! 10/10 recommend!!!
subject: Stem Cell & Regenerative Biol
course_title_2023: The Translational Science of Stem Cells: Present and Future

best_comment: Take it! Learn a ton, exposure to smart people, enjoyable!

best_comment: Take a advantage of the judgment free zone and as result it allows for you to improve your presentation and public speaking abilities.
worse_comment: Be VERY careful about what information you include on the improv survey beforehand. It's pitched as a 'get to know you' questionnaire but it's actually used to guide the one–on–one portion of the improv section. Be prepared to be vulnerable in an extremely uncomfortable and not really helpful way.
subject: Systems Biology

course_title: StudioLab on Creativity and Entrepreneurship LEC
best_comment: Its a great class content–wise, but you'll switch between doing no work for a few weeks straight and then editing and filming for 3 days straight right before thanksgiving, Changed the way I think about creating startups, and has a great mix of awesome guest lectures and super interesting lectures from Veil.
subject: Creativity and Entrepreneurshi

best_comment: enjoy this immersive experience!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Beginning Acting Through Scene Study and Monologue Work 001
best_comment: This is an awesome class, but you must have an enthusiasm for acting––whether that is an openness to learning or a life–long passion. This is not the type of course you can take half–heartedly, and because of this, it is very rewarding. A lot of memorization; hard work, but hard work that is much much different from psets and papers. Be prepared to learn more about yourself through the characters you portray.
worse_comment: It's a decently low commitment class as you really only need to work every other week, however, finding the right monologues are difficult. By the end I believe you will ultimately find your voice.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Beginning Acting Through Scene Study and Monologue Work

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS. This class was always the best part of my week. Erika and Jonathan are so lovely to work with!!! THEY ARE THE BEST. I learned a lot about how to be an effective speaker, and feel more comfortable with my public speaking skills. Prob one of the most fun classes at Harvard!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: What's so Funny?: Introduction to Improvisational Comedy 001
best_comment: Remo is absolutely remarkable! If you have the opportunity to take a class with him (this one especially) then do it! You will NOT regret it. Not only did I have so much fun during class and section, I also learned many life skills: from immensely improving my memorization (which is critical when doing improv) to embracing the unknown to building my overall confidence with interacting with others. You will leave this class fostering friendships with all of your peers while evolving into a more confident, playful version of yourself. I have so so much love for improv, for Remo, and for my classmates <3 This is simply one of the best classes I’ve taken at this institution and one I will remember throughout my entire lifetime.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: What's so Funny?: Introduction to Improvisational Comedy

best_comment: This class is a must–take for anyone interested in how to direct people for both the stage and screen. The class is excellently structured and project–focused, forcing you to produce a lot of high quality work. Marcus is an excellent and very supportive teacher who creates just an awesome environment for people to really grow as directors.

This class was filled with positive energy and was very relaxed. It would be a great class to express yourself without too much stress or homework. However, if you are wanting to take a class to truly push yourself as an artist, I would not recommend this course and suggest participating in more extracurriculars where you can further learn your art through practise since this class primarily revolves around talking about your art form (unless that’s what you prefer, then this class is perfect for you!!).

However, if you are wanting to take a class to truly push yourself as an artist, I would not recommend this course and suggest participating in more extracurriculars where you can further learn your art through practise since this class primarily revolves around talking about your art form (unless that’s what you prefer, then this class is perfect for you!!).

However, if you are wanting to take a class to truly push yourself as an artist, I would not recommend this course and suggest participating in more extracurriculars where you can further learn your art through practise since this class primarily revolves around talking about your art form (unless that’s what you prefer, then this class is perfect for you!!).

Gaga dance class was an amazing experience that I would highly recommend to anyone. Despite being a dance class, I found that I learned more in this class than in some of my CS classes. This is likely due to the immersive and hands–on nature of the class, which made it feel like I was really learning in a meaningful way.One of the best things about this class is its convenience and proximity to the quad. It was easy to fit into my schedule and attend regularly, which allowed me to make the most of the class. The workload was also manageable, with only a couple of short assignments to complete in addition to the dancing.Overall, I would say that Gaga dance class is a must–take if you are in the quad area. It is a fun and enjoyable way to learn, and I feel like I came away from the class with a lot of valuable knowledge and skills. So, it is highly recommended to all the students.
worse_comment: If you take this course, leave your ego at the door.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Latinx Movement: Embodied Intersections of Latin Dance, Music, and Communal Practice 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS COURSE!! This is an amazing course! I never took a TDM course before and this was the perfect introduction. Even in the very first week I knew that this class would be a place of relaxation because it just felt very zen, being able to communicate through our bodies. The class was usually structured with some sort of warm up, history about the dance form that was being introduced and communal dance practice.  The structure was awesome and many students were able to get out of their comfort zones given the varying amounts of experience. The final consisted of an individual choreography created by LROD as well as a partner choreography created by us! The final wasn't stressful at all and had just been something we'd done several times in general class. LROD is an amazing instructor and she taught this class of 44 like a veteran (even though it was her first time!) Take this course and learn amazing dance forms of salsa, mambo, cumbia and bachata.
worse_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!! I took this course because I am Mexican but grew up not knowing how to dance. At first, I was nervous to dance in front of others,  but  we really built a community. I learned so much, especially about the roots of all of the dances we did.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Latine Movement: Embodied Intersections of Latin Dance, Music, and Communal Practice

course_title: Directorial Concepts and Set Design of the 20th and 21st Centuries 1
best_comment: Take this class if you're looking for a fun, informative, stress–free addition to your week! You'll have the opportunity to receive really great feedback on design concepts and will feel free to experiment and explore your own aesthetic sensibility! Prof. Smeliansky is a great teacher and person and creates a really fun and positive environment for learning and conversation!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Directorial Concepts and Set Design of the 20th and 21st Centuries

best_comment: this course is a super interesting introduction to lighting from a design perspective. there's some technical instruction, but this is very much a design course. some of the material, especially at the beginning of the course, might be boring if you have experience with lighting already. Jeff is really interesting, the workload isn't crazy, and the small class size is nice.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Playwriting: Ritual Practice and Curious Worlds 001
best_comment: super fun class! love the professor. really grew so much as a writer. it's tdm, so the content is very experimental, but this has really helped me find with finding a unique style, which I couldn't do back when I only cared about commercial writing.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Playwriting: Ritual Practice and Curious Worlds

best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS!!!! The professor is amazing. The content is amazing. The other students are amazing. The way you'll force yourself to grow and change and explore are amazing. You'll have so much fun in this class. It changed my life and potentially my career direction. It was my favorite course this semester!
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

course_title: Before and Beyond Angels: The AIDS epidemic in live arts, culture, and protest 1
best_comment: WOW, take this class. Professor Levine's  course was one of the most enjoyable experiences that I had in my four years at Harvard. You will have the unique opportunity to learn about the fight to end the AIDS epidemic from someone who was instrumental in the early days of AIDS advocacy movements. Every day in this class was exciting and completely changed the way that I think about the world. Thank you Debra and Danielle for an amazing semester.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media
course_title_2023: Before and Beyond Angels: The AIDS epidemic in live arts, culture, and protest

course_title: Street Dance Activism: Co-choreographic Praxis as Activism 001
best_comment: Take this class! You won't regret it! Dr. Bell's pedagogy and genuine care for her students makes everyone so excited to attend class . If you're looking for an opportunity to learn something that you feel is truly useful as you go on in life and is not just more information you have memorized from a textbook, you would benefit from this class!
worse_comment: Unless you're someone who really thrives in a class with lots of freedom and lack of structure. I don't suggest taking this class. The lack of structure and communication drove me up a wall and had me completely lost and confused for the majority of the class. Also, you don't really do any dancing so don't expect that.

best_comment: The main work of this class is exploring "freedom dreams" ––> an idea you have about how the world could be more just that is not tethered to narrow limits of what is probable/feasible.  This work is done by bouncing ideas off of the teaching team and others in the class. There are weekly readings that are set at the beginning of the class that included the writings of Robin D.G. Kelley, Bell Hooks, and others. Like most classes (but especially some over others) the amount of value you get out of this class is dependent on how much you put in.  This class is less about taking in lots of information and is instead about having time to process and think about the world we want.
worse_comment: This is not a TDM class. Do not expect to learn about theater, dance, and/or media. This is a class about community–based activism. That's an awesome topic, just not what I was looking for in my studies of theater. I might have liked the class anyway, except it was so disorganized that it was difficult to follow. There was no real syllabus with dates and assignments.  I didn't get the flow of the readings because they all seemed disconnected from each other. We did different activities that seemed to barely relate to each other. The professor did not come to every class meeting. The final projects were tangentially related to the class. I'm not sure I really learned anything.

best_comment: This is a really good introductory course if you are interested in socially engaged art as a practice. There is a really valuable focus on practice–based approaches to socially engaged art that help to compliment the more theoretical portions of the course. The final project is also a really valuable chance to develop a new idea or to continue work on an ongoing piece.
subject: Theater, Dance & Media

best_comment: This class was my favorite! The readings are so interesting, and the discussions are so thought–provoking and make the concepts much easier to understand. You will grow so much in this class in terms of understanding feminist/gender theory, and you will definitely enjoy it!
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Gender and Sexuality in Korean Pop Culture 001
best_comment: The class is amazing! Professor Choi, not only seems very passionate about this topic, but she also is just a kind and amazing person overall.  She provides feedback on every assignment and piece of work you turn in by either the office hours you attend or the next week's class. She always has lots of options for office hours and responds to emails very promptly. If you like WGS or Korean culture, I highly recommend this class. It is not very difficult and is very fun. I loved the subject and the professor as well.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Gender and Sexuality in Korean Pop Culture

course_title: Dangerous Words: Feminist Debates on Speech, Harm, and Representation 001
best_comment: TAKE THIS CLASS! Professor Wells is the best and you will learn so much. When I signed up for this class, I didn't think I would be learning so much about philosophy/ legal frameworks– but I am so glad I did. If you're interested in feminist legal studies this class is for you! Amazing! Group discussion is great and you learn so much from your peers.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Dangerous Words: Feminist Debates on Speech, Harm, and Representation

best_comment: If this class is with Dr. Conners, you absolutely need to take it. He's a once–in–a–lifetime kind of instructor in terms of the care he takes with the material and his ability to maneuver through discussions. The course material itself is truly diverse in its list of theorists, and it offered some truly radical arguments about what queer theory looks like and what it can do. I learned how to really think through gender in a high–level, theoretical way without ever losing sight of the importance of lived experience and the need for change. The assignments very subtly builds to a more involved final project (I chose to do a 10–15 page paper, but you have total creative freedom on what the project could look like) – I never felt like I was being hand–held, but I also never though an assignment was out of my reach, even though I started and ended on two different planes of capacity. Tommy offers incredible feedback and truly cares about our successes. I can definitely see how this class could suck if it was in different hands, so if you're lucky enough to have Tommy, take advantage of it.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

best_comment: This class is amazing and so is Dr. Noll. Take this class if you are at all interested in how gender comes to be, how gender can be performed, how gender can be embodied, and anything relating to development, consciousness, the brain, and the body. Conversations can get meta, but that is part of the fun, and you will learn so much and think differently as a result of this class! It is a great environment. Take it!
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality

course_title: Love's Labors Found: Uncovering Histories of Emotional Labor 001
best_comment: This class is fantastic! Don't take it if you can't commit to doing the work/readings––it's definitely a heavier load because it's a high level seminar. Professor Light is brilliant, so great at community building, and an over all great teacher. She supports everyones growth and is clearly so glad to be facilitating these conversations.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Love's Labors Found: Uncovering Histories of Emotional Labor

course_title: Transgender Rights and the Law: Assumptions and Critiques 001
best_comment: This class was incredible!!! I was in a community of trans people in an academic setting for the first time ever and it was the most rewarding experience. Kendra is a very knowledgeable and supportive professor, and they are very approachable. I had a great time in this class and learned so much.
subject: Women, Gender & Sexuality
course_title_2023: Transgender Rights and the Law: Assumptions and Critiques

subject: Economics
course_title_2023: Early-Stage Research and Discussions on Urban Economics
